HEADLINE: Venezuelan Leader Pushes for New Charter, but Is It Reformist Tool or a Power Grab?

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 24

 BODY:
The fate of South America's longest-running, if turbulent, democracy hangs in the balance in the vote on Sunday to select delegates to write a new constitution -- the 27th in Venezuela's history, although the first since 1961.
But that may be the only point on which President Hugo Chavez and his opponents agree. 
 Mr. Chavez maintains that only a new charter will enable him to carry out the "peaceful social revolution" he promised in his successful presidential campaign last year.
His critics contend that the election of the 131 members of the National Constituent Assembly is their last chance to prevent Venezuela, the largest foreign supplier of oil to the United States in recent years, from slipping into what they see as a coming one-man dictatorship.
"On paper, this is a laudable initiative, an effort to get representatives of the people together to discuss where we have failed and to rethink who we are," said Jorge Olavarria, a lawyer and historian who was an early political adviser to Mr. Chavez but has now broken with the President and is running for an assembly seat on an anti-Chavez slate. "But in reality, it is a plan for Chavez to carry out a coup under legal cover."
Among the changes that Mr. Chavez, a 45-year-old former army colonel who organized an unsuccessful coup attempt in 1992, wants enshrined in a new constitution is the right to succeed himself in office. When sworn in early in February, he contemptuously described the current 1961 Constitution as "moribund," and on repeated occasions he has acted as if the charter had already been revoked and his own powers expanded.
This month, for instance, Mr. Chavez promoted 34 military officers who had been part of his 1992 uprising, defying a warning by the Senate that his action was unconstitutional.
He has also made Gen. Lucas Rincon his chief of staff, a move thatopposition leaders said also violates a law prohibiting active duty soldiers from holding such posts.
And he tried to put military officers in charge of the police, provoking threats of resignations there.
"The decision is mine," Mr. Chavez said in brushing aside the disapproval of the Senate, whose powers of advise and consent are even more extensive than those of its American counterpart.
"I am commander in chief of the armed forces."
In addition, Mr. Chavez has bypassed Government ministries and put some 70,000 soldiers to work on huge public works projects, building schools and hospitals, providing free medical services and selling food to the poor below market cost.
Beginning in September, the Government also intends to send soldiers into the schools to teach military doctrine to students.
"Chavez's ultimate goal is to remain in power, converting the traditional political class into a scapegoat and making the armed forces his political party," said Anibal Romero, author of "Security, Defense and Democracy in Venezuela," and other books. "Some of the things he is doing, such as his flirtation with Fidel Castro, bother them, but they like the fact that he is incorporating them into his Government and giving them civilian posts."
The election, which will take Venezuelans to the polls for the fourth time in less than a year, is nominally nonpartisan. But the campaign has turned into a bare-knuckles display of political brinkmanship, with Mr. Chavez, who enjoys an 80 percent approval rating in the latest polls, inevitably at the center of the fray.
When the National Electoral Council, for instance, ruled that Mr. Chavez could not actively campaign for candidates from his own party, he was defiant.
"If they want to take me to jail, let them come for me," he said. "Here I am."
But when the same body last week barred his weekly radio and television shows until after the vote, his response was to comply with the letter of the verdict, though not the spirit.
He sent aides to substitute for him at the radio program last Sunday and then called in as a guest. The President then circumvented the ban on his television show by using his powers as head of state to convoke a national network for a speech that all stations were obliged to carry.
"They can bind me with 1,000 chains, but Hugo Chavez will keep on talking," he said during the telephone call to the radio program. Fined the equivalent of $7,700 by the tribunal because of the violations, Mr. Chavez has set up stands on the street to collect donations from supporters to pay the penalty.
"We must help Chavez root out the corruption that is eating away at this country," Pedro Rafael Hernandez Ochoa, a supporter of the President, said Thursday night at a ceremony at which money was delivered to Mr. Chavez at the Presidential Palace to pay the fine. "The rotten political elite is blocking his way, and only with a new Magna Carta can he make the changes we need to make Venezuela a true democracy."
Forbidden by law from being a candidate himself, Mr. Chavez has urged his wife, Marisabel, a radio broadcaster with no previous political experience, to run as his standard-bearer. In addition, five members of his Cabinet resigned to run for assembly seats, joining former President Carlos Andres Perez, against whom the 1992 coup was directed, and lawyers, economists, athletes, journalists and even an astrologer among the 1,059 candidates.
 The President is also facing an investigation into whether he has misused state funds to promote his candidates. He has described that effort as part of a politically motivated conspiracy to weaken his fight "against the tyranny of corruption and the elites that destroyed this country."
Eduardo Roche, the nation's Comptroller General, retorted: "The President can be certain that insults and falsehoods do not frighten me. He must understand that this office will never be subservient."
Despite the passions aroused by the issues, and the country's history of military strongmen and coups before the 1961 Constitution, the campaign his been generally peaceful.
On Wednesday, though, four people in white hoods interrupted a university forum featuring Alberto Franceschi, an outspoken opposition leader who is expected to be the principal anti-Chavez spokesman in the assembly, and detonated a series of bombs. No one was injured in the incident. But Mr. Franceschi described the episode as "a humiliating display of Chavez-style democracy," intended to "silence the voice of the opposition."
There are persistent reports that Mr. Chavez's ruling coalition, the Patriotic Pole, has agreed that the top vote-getter will be made president of the assembly, with powers to control the agenda and pace of work.
In a television interview this week, Mrs. Chavez, who polls indicate may win that distinction, said she was unaware of such an arrangement, but added, "I feel prepared and would accept the challenge."
Whatever the result, further conflict is expected. Despite rulings by the Supreme Court to the contrary, Mr. Chavez has said the assembly will have the power to dissolve Congress and the courts and assume their powers until a new charter is approved, indicating on several occasions that he wants it to do precisely that.
"The Constituent Assembly is going to be the moment of truth for Chavez," said Dr. Romero, who is a professor of political science at Simon Bolivar University here. "It is going to force him to define a path, and I believe that path is going to be one of military populism and anti-imperialism."

HEADLINE: To Spur German Economy, Schroder Offers Veer to Right

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: BERLIN, July 24

 BODY:
After nine months of confused inertia in economic policy, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has at last set out where his New Middle in politics lies -- and it is a long way to the right of anything previously embraced by the German leader's Social Democratic Party.
Abandoning the hesitations that have left Europe's economic engine stalled with unemployment at more than 10 percent, Mr. Schroder's Government this week set out a radical agenda of American-inspired changes aimed at making Germany more nimble, less regulated, more entrepreneurial and less dependent on the state. 
 A glossy Economics Ministry report on the sweeping program of cutbacks in state spending and plans for tax changes and deregulation quoted the chairman of the Bertelsmann media company, Dr. Mark Wossner, as saying, "A piece of America -- without losing the social aspect of our market economy -- that is the road to greater German prosperity."
Embracing such a message amounts to a big political gamble by Mr. Schroder, whose political style has previously been one of sit-on-the-fence prudence in economic matters and whose party still finds the bedrock of its support among workers, labor unions, teachers and other state employees who have little enthusiasm for the wonders of Wall Street.
"As with Kosovo in military questions, the Social Democrats are now trying to go way beyond what Chancellor Kohl and the Christian Democrats ever dared in economic matters," Karsten Voigt, a Social Democrat, said. "But there are considerable dangers, because many feel the party's traditions have been betrayed."
Those dangers include possible defeat in elections in 5 of the 16 states in the next few months, including a vote in the capital, Berlin. It remains far from clear that the Social Democrats, with no Thatcherite legacy to build on, can follow Tony Blair's Labor Party in veering steeply rightward without heavy cost.
But with Europe's long-term prospects and its new currency, the euro, dependent on Germany's economic performance and high unemployment sapping the country's self-esteem, Mr. Schroder evidently felt that further hesitation was unacceptable. Although his reputation was salvaged as the "war chancellor" in the Kosovo conflict, the Social Democratic leader has seen his popularity sag since the fighting ended.
His proposed medicine looks dire -- slashing state spending by $16 billion next year, freezing pensions for two years, ending many subsidies and cutting the state's share of national income, from 48.8 percent today to 40 over the next several years.
In addition, Mr. Schroder has made clear that he wants to balance the budget, lower taxes and abandon the collective sector-by-sector wage bargaining that has been a feature of the social-market economy in favor of wage negotiations based on productivity gains in individual companies.
The Government produced a welter of grim statistics to back the need for change. The share of long-term unemployed, those out of work for more than a year, has risen, from 9.6 percent in 1975 to more than 36 percent today. The state's share of the economy has jumped, from 39 percent in 1970 to almost 49 today.
Although unemployment in the United States was far higher than in Germany in 1983, it now stands at less than half the German level. And the share of wages represented by payments for various social insurance programs has soared, from 26.5 percent in 1970 to 42.3 percent today.
On that basis, Economic Minister Werner Muller roundly dismissed Germany's hugely successful postwar economic model as one "now stumbling along at the cost of future generations."
Mr. Wossner said the chief problem lay in a "leveling of wages" and an "oversupply of Social Security" that had resulted in a lack of "performance-related incentive for those willing to work."
Bertelsmann has acquired Random House over the last year, and other big German companies like banks and automakers have also been investing heavily overseas, partly to offset their dependence on a sluggish German economy, which has the highest labor costs in the world.
It is clear that it is the global outlook of such corporations that Mr. Schroder, who was on the board of Volkswagen before he became Chancellor last year, is trying to bring to the German economy as a whole. His sympathies have long stood further to the right than those of many of his fellow party members, but he had previously hesitated to discuss them.
In finally doing so, he risks reinforcing a widespread sense in Germany that tax and other economic policy has tended to favor the wealthy while penalizing workers on the pretext that they have to adjust to the realities of global competition.
"The New Middle is full of slogans like responsibility, self-reliance and new entrepreneurship, but the reality is that most Germans are employees and workers, and once again they are being asked to make sacrifices," said Susanne Stumpenhusen, a Social Democrat who is head of the union of public-sector workers in Berlin.
"For example," Ms. Stumpenhusen said, "we are now told that labor unions must exercise wage restraint, because tax cuts will more than compensate for any salary losses. But we have yet to see any of those tax benefits. Only when the tax money is in our pockets can we discuss this sort of thing."
Like many union members, she expressed sympathy for the alternative proposals put forward by Oskar Lafontaine, who was ousted this year as Finance Minister. Those centered on raising wages to stimulate demand and jump-start the economy.
"The economic program is one-sided, a pure expression of neo-liberal economics," Michael Knoche of the IG Bau construction union said. "Instead of adopting the view of big companies, Mr. Schroder should have focused on some of Mr. Lafontaine's ideas."
But the fact is that Mr. Lafontaine is gone, and Mr. Schroder knows that he almost certainly cannot win the elections in 2002 with unemployment at its current level and Europe's biggest economy stalled.
The essence of his political gamble this week appears to be that short-term setbacks are acceptable if a real reform can be pushed through that would restore Germany's confidence in its ability to find employment for its people.
"Schroder has thrown down a gauntlet, declaring that yesterday's ideology has no place, even if most of his party does not support him," Lutz Erbring, a political scientist, said. "In essence, he is gambling that a majority of Germans have the common sense to see that he is right."

HEADLINE: Two-Way Presidential Coattails

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
After his galling defeat by the Governor of Arkansas in 1992, President George Bush became something of an outcast in his own party. At Republican functions, speakers rattled on longingly about Ronald Reagan. But never about Mr. Bush. It was as if Republicans had collective amnesia about the man who led their party and the nation from 1989 to 1992.
Not anymore. The President who was belittled for breaking his no-new-taxes pledge and ridiculed as a passive, in-box President who dealt only with matters in front of him, is now basking in the glow of a surprisingly early, and positive, reassessment of his stewardship. 
 It is common for Americans to like their Presidents better after they leave office. But the resurgence of respect for Mr. Bush -- a view demonstrated in polls and expressed in interviews with dozens of Republicans at all levels, and even held by some Democrats -- has occurred surprisingly quickly.
History books aside, the shift carries more immediate political implications. Worried that Mr. Bush's enhanced stature is helping his son, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, stampede to the Republican Presidential nomination, the Governor's foes are trying to tamp down the reassessment of the Bush Presidency.
Just last week, President Clinton offered a not-so-nostalgic recollection of the Bush years in a speech in Baltimore. And two of Governor Bush's rivals for the nomination, Steve Forbes, the multimillionaire publisher, and Lamar Alexander, a former Education Secretary, have ridiculed the elder Mr. Bush's slogan about a "kinder and gentler" country -- a not-so-subtle effort to condemn the Governor's similarly feel-good slogan of "compassionate conservatism."
Sixty percent of Americans have a favorable view of the former President and only 17 percent have an unfavorable view, a CBS News Poll conducted last month found. It is not the adulation Mr. Bush enjoyed after the Persian Gulf war, when his job approval rating catapulted as high as 90 percent. But it is far better than in a CBS News/New York Times poll the month before he was ousted by Mr. Clinton. Then, Mr. Bush was rated favorably by 35 percent and unfavorably by 45 percent.
"People have in retrospect a rosy nostalgic view and warm feelings toward him," said Gary Orren, a professor of public policy at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.
"The difficulties that Bill Clinton has had have only amplified the contrasts: in retrospect he looks even more virtuous. That George W. is the moon getting a lot of bright light off his father is something you might not have predicted in November of 1992, when the economy was bad and there was all the hopefulness about Clinton."
Indeed, many people, particularly Republicans, said that after the Clinton scandals they have a new appreciation for Mr. Bush's personal rectitude. Many also cited a greater appreciation for his effort to end the cold war.
Sounding a familiar refrain among active Republicans, Michael McDaniel, chairman of the Indiana Republican Party, said, "Believe me, there's a big buyer's remorse out there."
Mr. Bush, who is 75, and his son, 53, appear to be drawing residual benefit from each other. Governor Bush is so enormously popular in his party that many Republicans look fondly upon the former President for being part of his son's winning aura, even as they praise the son as a far looser and more natural politician.
"We are in a country that excessively loves winners and we tend to be hard on Presidents who were defeated in office after one term," said Michael R. Beschloss, a Presidential historian. "But when you have a son who seems the likely favorite to be a Republican nominee and possibly the next President, it causes people to look for good things about his father."
He said a similar dynamic was last at play with the Roosevelts; people had a much more positive view of Theodore Roosevelt after he left office because of the popularity of his cousin, President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Yet the dynamic works both ways: the younger Mr. Bush benefits from his father's name and reputation: he draws instant credibility as the offspring of someone who served in the Oval Office and left Washington with his integrity intact. (The same factors affect another Bush son, Jeb, the Governor of Florida.)
"The romanticism of his being the son of a former President just makes it that much more sexy," said Georgette Mosbacher, a co-chairwoman of Senator John McCain's Presidential campaign whose former husband, Robert, was Mr. Bush's Commerce Secretary.
Robert M. Teeter, a pollster in Michigan who ran the 1992 Bush campaign, said: "People just automatically say, 'If this guy is George and Barbara Bush's son, we don't have any question about those personal qualities that we were fooled on by Clinton.' That's where his family heritage really works for him."
Except for two high-profile parachute jumps, the last in June to celebrate his 75th birthday, the elder Mr. Bush has done nothing to aggressively reshape his image. Unlike most Presidents, he has no plans to write his memoirs, though he did write a book on foreign policy with Brent Scowcroft, "A World Transformed" (Knopf, 1998). If anything, Mr. Bush's decision not to speak out about the transgressions of his successor has probably enhanced his reputation as an elder statesman who is above politics.
Characteristically, Mr. Bush went out of his way not to gloat when asked to comment for this article. "I am unfamiliar with the polling numbers you talked about," Mr. Bush said in a typewritten note faxed from his home in Kennebunkport, Me. "But if what you say is true -- well, that is very nice. Since leaving the White House, I have tried hard to stay out of the limelight. I also have not tried to shape history. I will leave it up to the historians and academics to figure all that out. What I hope they will say is that we got some things right, made some mistakes, but served with honor."
Ronald Kaufman, who was Mr. Bush's political director in the White House and is still his political adviser, said there had been a dramatic rise in requests for the former President to appear at party functions.
"In '93, we'd get maybe two or three requests a month, max, like, 'Can he do the Lincoln Day speech for the Harris County Republican Party in Texas?' " Mr. Kaufman said. "I'd get calls, 'Do you think the President would mind asking his son if he'd be the speaker?' But this year, I probably get from 25 to 30 requests a week for him to be the headliner at events like the Republican National Committee's annual gala."
Mr. Bush is not as adored as Mr. Reagan in his party. There are still lingering hard feelings from the 1992 campaign; a month before that election Mr. Bush was faring so poorly that only two dozen of more than 400 Republican Congressional candidates accepted Mr. Bush's offer to appear in campaign videos with him.
In fact, his improved popularity may come as much from moderates as from hard-core conservatives who never quite trusted Mr. Bush as a genuine conservative -- and still do not. "I think he's a more beloved figure in the country than in the party," Mr. Teeter said. "It's the marginal, more independent Republicans who look back and say, 'Gee, compared to Clinton, he's wonderful.' "
A poll conducted in March for Fox television found that if the 1992 election were held now -- certainly a fanciful notion -- Mr. Bush would draw 58 percent of the vote; Mr. Clinton, 37 percent. But it is impossible to decipher the accuracy of a survey that asks people to re-evaluate how they voted. For all anyone knows, respondents were confusing Mr. Bush with his son, who has dominated the political news for months.
In his speech last week, Mr. Clinton did not mention his predecessor by name, but clearly sought to dash any fond memories of the Bush era. "We may have to remind our fellow citizens in times to come just what it was like back then," Mr. Clinton said. "How high the unemployment was, how stagnant the wages were, how steeply growing the inequality was, how fast the social conditions were worsening."
The efforts to link the younger Bush with his father are inevitable because of their similarities. They both have sought to take any harsh edge off their Republican principles. They both toiled in the Texas oil business. But while the elder Bush had long expertise in foreign policy and Federal matters, the Governor's has been limited to state government.
But the biggest difference, cited by many Republicans, is that Governor Bush's hands-on, wade-into-the-crowd campaigning style more resembles Mr. Clinton's than that of President Bush.
"George W. has that Clintonesque, Reaganesque ability of relating to people that was George senior's major problem," said Mike Kiedrowski, executive director of the Republican Party in Montana. "He's much more like Ronald Reagan than his father. But in retrospect, President Bush has gained over the years. I may not agree with every policy, certainly not the '90 tax increase. But he was a good leader."
Billy Van Devender, a Republican national committeeman from Mississippi, said of the younger Bush, "He's got all the attributes of his dad, but his son can do it a lot better."

HEADLINE: Asian Group Lends Support To Beijing Over Taiwan

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, July 24

 BODY:
Southeast Asian foreign ministers weighed into the China-Taiwan dispute today, giving support to Beijing's "one China" policy in a communique that also warned that rising tensions could harm economic growth.
Tensions between China and Taiwan will be the backdrop for a meeting between Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and the Chinese Foreign Minister, Tang Jiaxuan, on Sunday. It will be the highest level diplomatic meeting between China and the United States since the NATO bombing of Beijing's embassy in Belgrade in May. 
 The two will hold talks on the sidelines of the annual meeting of foreign ministers from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which runs until Wednesday.
The foreign ministers at the meeting said they hope for a peaceful resolution to the conflict between China and Taiwan, which was renewed when President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan said on July 9 that it was ending the "one China" policy, which had kept the peace in the Taiwan Strait for decades.
Negotiations with China would take place on a state-to-state basis, Mr. Lee said.
China continues to consider Taiwan a renegade province. The notion of "one China" stems from the civil war that ended in 1949, when Taipei and Beijing both claimed to be the one legitimate government of all of China.
"We expressed our concern over the tension that arose in the Taiwan Strait after July, 9, 1999, which could seriously affect regional peace and stability and prospects for economic recovery," the communique said.
"We hoped for a quick and peaceful return to normalcy. We reaffirmed our commitment to our 'One China Policy.' "
The organization includes Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Brunei and Myanmar.
The communique also included a reference to a code of conduct for the Spratly Islands, a contested cluster of potentially oil- and gas-rich islands that are claimed by China, the Philippines, Brunei, Taiwan, Malaysia and Vietnam.

HEADLINE: Black Groups Switch Sites For Meetings In Flag Protest

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C., July 24

 BODY:
The National Urban League has become the second group this week to cancel a convention in Charleston to protest state lawmakers' refusal to remove the Confederate battle flag from the Capitol dome in Columbia.
Milton Little, the League's executive vice president and chief operating officer, said the group would select another site for a regional convention next spring. 
 On Tuesday, four days before it was to convene, the Southern Christian Leadership Conference canceled its convention in Charleston in protest over the flag.
The African Methodist Episcopal Churches also has said it will relocate its statewide youth conference scheduled for next year in Columbia.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People voted earlier this month, at the urging of its South Carolina chapter, to boycott the state for flying the banner.
The Urban League conference would have attracted members from 11 Southern states, said Maxine Martin, executive director of the Charleston Urban League.
Mr. Little said the withdrawal was a way to punish the state economically.
South Carolina's display of the Confederate battle flag raises concerns about its willingness to provide equal access for economic opportunity, Mr. Little said.
Gov. Jim Hodges, a Democrat, has said he supports removing the flag but will not push the issue. Former Gov. David Beasley, a Republican, encountered heavy opposition when he proposed removing the flag.
The effects of an N.A.A.C.P. boycott of South Carolina's convention industry could produce mixed results, The Charleston Post and Courier reported last week.
Some officials are worried that the number of moderately lucrative black family reunions could drop off, but others predict that the state's convention business will not be harmed much, the newspaper said.
That is because very few large conventions are held in South Carolina, primarily because space for meeting rooms and hotels is limited.

HEADLINE: National Parks, Strained by Record Crowds, Face a Crisis

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo., July 22

 BODY:
In growing numbers that now exceed 3.1 million a year, visitors travel here to America's oldest national park to marvel at wildlife, towering mountains, pristine rivers and geological curiosities like geysers, hot springs and volcanic mudpots.
Yet many things tourists may not see on a typical trip through Yellowstone's 2.2 million acres spread across parts of Idaho, Montana and Wyoming could have a greater impact on the park's future than the growl of a grizzly or spew of Old Faithful. 
 For all its beauty, Yellowstone is broken. Hordes of summer tourists and the increasing numbers now visiting in the spring, fall and winter are overwhelming the park's ability to accommodate them properly.
In recent years, the park's popularity has created such enormous demands on water lines, roads and personnel that park management has been forced to spend most of Yellowstone's annual operating budget, about $30 million, on immediate problems rather than investing in long-term solutions that would eliminate the troublesome areas.
Yellowstone is not the only national park suffering. With the nation's 378 national park areas expected to attract almost 300 million visitors this year, after a record 286 million in 1998, many parks are deferring urgently needed capital improvements.
For instance, damaged sewage pipes at Yellowstone have let so much ground water from spring thaws into the system that crews have had to siphon off millions of gallons of treated water into meadows each of the last four years.
And with budget restraints forcing personnel cutbacks in every department, even the number of park rangers with law-enforcement authority has dropped, contributing to a steady increase in crime throughout Yellowstone.
"It's so frustrating," Michael V. Finley, Yellowstone's superintendent, said. "As the park continues to deteriorate, the service level continues to decline. You see how many Americans enjoy this park. They deserve better."
Over the last decade the annual budget of the National Park Service, an agency of the Interior Department, has nearly doubled, to $1.9 billion for the fiscal year 1999 from $1.13 billion in 1990, an increase that narrowly outpaced inflation.
But in an assessment made last year, the park service estimated that it would cost $3.54 billion to repair maintenance problems at national parks, monuments and wilderness areas that have been put off -- for decades, in some cases -- because of a lack of money.
The cost of needed repairs at Yellowstone was put at $46 million, the most of any park area in the system. But the park service report shows that budget limits have forced virtually all national parks to set aside big maintenance projects, delays that many park officials say compromise visitor enjoyment and occasionally threaten their health and safety.
Senator Craig Thomas, a Wyoming Republican who is chairman of the Subcommittee on National Parks, and Bob Stanton, director of the park service, negotiated a deal this week to spend $12 million over the next three years for Yellowstone repairs.
Other parks may have to wait longer. The Grand Canyon National Park depends on a water treatment system that has not been upgraded in 30 years, a $20 million problem, park officials say. Parts of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park along the Potomac River are crumbling, another $10 million expense. The Everglades National Park in South Florida needs a $15 million water treatment plant.
Even with a heightened awareness of need among Federal lawmakers and Clinton Administration officials, money to repair those problems may be hard to find at a time when Congress is wrestling over the true size of a projected budget surplus and how much of it will pay for tax cuts. If billions were to become available for new spending, the park service would still have to slug it out with every other Federal agency, and few predict that parks would emerge a big winner.
It is a disturbing prospect to conservationists, parks officials and those lawmakers who support increased spending to help the parks address their backlog of maintenance problems.
"It's kind of like a decayed tooth," said Dave Simon, the Southwest regional director for the National Parks and Conservation Association, a citizens' group that is working with Yellowstone to solve some of the long-term needs. "If you don't take care of it, one day you'll wake up with a mouthful of cavities."
The parks' supporters like Representative Ralph S. Regula, an Ohio Republican who is chairman of Appropriations Subcommittee on the Interior, concede that budgetary increases as well as revenue from new programs that allow parks to keep a greater share of entrance fees and concession sales have been offset by inflation, rising costs and daily operational demands that now accommodate 8.9 percent more people than those who visited national parks a decade ago.
With few dollars available for maintenance programs, the parks suffered "benign neglect," Mr. Regula said, adding: "It's not very sexy to fix a sewer system or maintain a trail. You don't get headlines for that. It would be nice to get them more money, but we're constrained."
Denis P. Galvin, the deputy director of the National Park Service, noted that only twice this century, in the 1930's and in 1966, has the Federal Government authorized money for systemwide capital improvements, and he said he was not expecting another windfall soon.
"Generally," Mr. Galvin said, "domestic programs come at the back of the line when they're formulating the Federal budget, and I just don't think parks are a priority."
Perhaps no park in America reflects the array of hidden problems more than Yellowstone, which opened in 1872, years before Idaho, Montana and Wyoming became states.
Park officials here say that the longer problems go unattended, the more expensive and threatening they become.
The budget restraints have meant reducing the number of rangers who carry guns and have the authority to make arrests.
Rick Obernesser, Yellowstone's chief ranger, said the roster had dwindled to 112 from 144 over the last 10 years, which often means leaving the park without any of these rangers from 2 A.M. to 6 A.M.
Next year, Mr. Obernesser said, the park will have only 93 of these rangers, about 1 for every 23,000 acres, compared with 1 for every 15,000 acres when his staff was at peak strength.
That has not only led to slower response times to emergencies, like auto accidents and heart attacks, he said, but also to an increase in crime. Since the peak staffing year of 1989, he said, the park has experienced significant increases in the killing of wildlife, thefts, weapons charges against visitors and violations by snowmobile drivers.
Yellowstone's 446 miles of roads are also a constant concern. Some of the most widely traveled routes have not been improved or widened in almost 65 years, and many are littered with potholes so deep that cars have broken axles.
Not all roadways that snake along mountain ledges at 10,000 feet have guard rails.
Alan Sumeriski, acting assistant chief of maintenance at Yellowstone, said some of the park's broken water lines are 60 years old and had been strained beyond reason by the growing use of of bathing facilities and toilets.
Senior parks officials like Mr. Galvin and Mr. Finley say the maintenance backlog has grown, in part, because of their own inability to convince Congress that the need is critical. And in an era when lawmakers are pressing Federal agencies to operate more efficiently, some are not convinced that senior parks officials know how to manage their budgets and set their priorities.
Mr. Finley, 51, who has worked more than half his life for the park service, conceded that management had been lax in some places. But he said the magnitude of problems has convinced him that the time for assigning blame is over.
"These parks are the goose that keeps on laying even larger golden eggs," Mr. Finley said. "All you have to do is take care of it."

HEADLINE: Serb Opposition Leader Criticizes NATO Forces in Kosovo

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: NIS, Serbia, July 24

 BODY:
A leading Serbian opposition leader, Vuk Draskovic, today made an emotional attack on NATO forces, saying they had allowed the ethnic purging of Serbs from Kosovo and the creation of an Albanian state in the province.
Speaking at a rally of some 25,000 supporters here, he condemned the killing of 14 Serbian farmers in the Kosovo village of Gracko. He said the incident would promote anti-Western feelings in Serbia and hurt the political opposition to President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia. 
 Breaking into English, Mr. Draskovic appealed to the American people "to stop, please, with the collective punishment of the Serbian people and to stop supporting the project of a Greater Albania in the Balkans." He said a Kosovo that was deprived of its ethnic mix under NATO control would undermine the fundamentals of the American commitment to a "multi-ethnic, multi-racial" state that protects the rights of all citizens.
"I'm indicting KFOR and the United Nations mission in Kosovo for the massacre that has happened," he said after the rally, using the initials for the Kosovo peacekeeping force and echoing a similar statement made by Mr. Milosevic. "Gangs and bandits committed crimes against Albanians in the name of the Serbian people. And now, when Albanians commit crimes against Serbs, no one is against them."
But in his speech, Mr. Draskovic blamed Mr. Milosevic for the tragedy of Kosovo, which has a strong emotional and religious pull on Serbs, and for everything else that has gone wrong in Yugoslavia for the last 10 years, as his supporters shouted, "Slobo, resign!"
"Guilty or not," Mr. Draskovic shouted, "the interests of the nation require you to give up your armchair and resign!"
But this will be Mr. Draskovic's last mass rally for some time, senior aides said today, because they believe that the moment is not yet ripe for ousting Mr. Milosevic. Such a conclusion could fuel speculation among Mr. Draskovic's rivals in the Serbian opposition that all he really wants is to replace Mr. Milosevic, rather than really change Serbia.
The aides said they believed that the opposition was wasting energy by holding an endless series of summertime rallies that were not attracting enough people to put any real pressure on Mr. Milosevic.
Mr. Milosevic must go, Mr. Draskovic believes, but he must be induced to go in a way that avoids civil conflict and significant bloodshed.
His aides say he will hold no more meetings for at least several weeks, although the other main opposition grouping, the Alliance for Change, has scheduled further rallies and hopes to lead a grand march on Belgrade in September.
"Every one says Milosevic must go," a senior Draskovic aide said. "But how? He doesn't even contemplate going. You can ask him to go for 1,000 days, but asking him isn't serious."
Mr. Draskovic will resume mass meetings as an important part of the strategy to get Mr. Milosevic to resign, "but we want to pick the right moment, when we can create momentum and there is something important to say," the aide said.
Mr. Draskovic is concentrating instead on trying to choose a transitional government of experts agreed on by most or all opposition parties, and then trying to push Mr. Milosevic to empower that government and finally to step aside after new elections.
That too has prompted other opposition leaders to suspect that Mr. Draskovic wants only to replace Mr. Milosevic with himself.
The Alliance for Change demands Mr. Milosevic's resignation first, before any transitional government. Under pressure from American and European diplomats, however, Mr. Draskovic and alliance leaders are working on a joint platform as a way to bridge their differences, if not to solve them all. That platform will include the idea of Mr. Milosevic's ouster and of new elections.
Mr. Draskovic and the Democratic Party leader Zoran Djindjic, who were allies in the 1996-97 marches against Mr. Milosevic, are now bitter rivals, which has undermined both of their reputations and the credibility of the opposition generally.
Washington and the Serbian opposition are also hoping that Mr. Milosevic's Government will begin to crumble from within, particularly if there are new indictments of those close to Mr. Milosevic from the international tribunal on war crimes in The Hague. Mr. Milosevic and four of his closest aides were indicted in late May on charges of war crimes for their role as commanders of Serbian forces that killed Kosovo Albanians.
Indictments may come soon of Mirjana Markovic, Mr. Milosevic's wife and the leader of the party that partners his in government, and of Vojislav Seselj, the ultranationalist leader of the Radical Party and a Serbian deputy Prime Minister, American officials say.
The officials and the opposition are hopeful that the former army chief of staff, Momcilo Perisic, who came out this week in sharp opposition to Mr. Milosevic and the Government, will attract more army and police support to the idea of the President's ouster. But Mr. Perisic is likely to form his own party, given his lack of respect for Mr. Draskovic, Mr. Djindjic or another former general, Vuk Obradovic, who heads the Social Democracy Party.
Washington and its European partners will also resume aid to independent media and opposition parties here, buying the argument that there will be no ouster of Mr. Milosevic otherwise.
The Americans are pushing a revered economist, Dragoslav Avramovic, who helped end Yugoslav hyperinflation in January 1994, as a uniting figure for the opposition and even as prime minister of a transitional Serbian government. Mr. Draskovic said tonight that the transitional government of experts should be nonpartisan and nonpolitical, and that its members should vow not to seek elected office.
But Mr. Draskovic believes that it is not yet the right time to name such a government, his aides said. And he believes that the opposition is dissipating anger at Mr. Milosevic by rallies now that have no idea except Mr. Milosevic's ouster and that offer no serious alternative program for citizens to unite behind.
The main tasks of the transitional federal and Serbian Governments would be to restore diplomatic and economic ties with the West, to prepare for free and fair elections monitored by outsiders and "to stop the genocide of the Serbian people," Mr. Draskovic said at the rally.
Mr. Draskovic, a nationalist, believes that the West is harming the opposition cause by allowing the majority Albanians to sweep most of the Serbian minority from Kosovo through intimidation and killings.
"There is now no border with Albania, but they make only a Serbian-Kosovo border," he said of NATO. "Albanian criminal gangs go over to burn Serbian churches and the roots of our religion, raping Serbs and kidnapping them and burning their houses. If KFOR came to protect innocent Albanians, who will now help the Serbs?"
After his speech, Mr. Draskovic said, "Our friends in the U.S. and European Union, through their support to Albanian terrorists, are supporting Milosevic."
There are growing feelings in Serbia that NATO and the West are not serious about protecting the rights of all the citizens of Kosovo, including the Serbs. NATO and the United Nations have been slow to start policing the province in earnest, the Serbs feel, and Government officials have started to suggest that the Yugoslav police and even army troops should return to Kosovo if such killings continue.

HEADLINE: Up, But Not Running, on the West Side

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Covered with rust and weeds, it stands as a grim memorial to New York City's faded industrial might, an elevated freight train platform running 1.6 miles down Manhattan's West Side, from 34th Street to Greenwich Village.
For nearly two decades, through a succession of mayors, City Hall joined with private developers in trying to get Conrail, the platform's owner, to tear it down to clear the way for development. 
 Now, a new owner has proposed that the city or a private organization transform the platform, unused since 1982, into an elevated park, bike path or promenade with shops and outdoor cafes.
The new owner, the CSX Corporation, insists that the 65-year-old platform must be retained, possibly for future rail service as development of the West Side continues.
"We are trying to avoid tearing it down, and would consider turning it over to a public entity or entrepreneurs," said Michael Brimmer, regional vice president for government relations at CSX, which has enlisted the Regional Plan Association, a nongovernment advisory group, to look at alternatives.
A report by the planning group, which was circulated quietly last week among community boards and city officials, concluded that the platform -- 14 feet above the ground at its lowest level and 50 feet wide at its narrowest -- could support a variety of public amenities, including a bike trail, light rail service, restaurants and art galleries.
At City Hall, advisers to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani dismissed such proposals as idle fantasy.
"That platform has no right to be there except for transportation, and that use is long gone," Joseph Rose, the City Planning Commissioner, said in an interview on Friday. Because of the city's protracted efforts to have it demolished, he said, "this has become the Vietnam of old railroad trestles."
Private developers hold similar views.
"It's all about money, and they are just trying to stall," said Jerome Gottesman, the owner of an entire block on the west side of 10th Avenue, between 17th and 18th Streets. He plans to build a new Federal Express distribution center on the site, which now is bisected by the elevated platform.
"By dragging its feet, CSX is just maintaining the blight on the West Side of Manhattan," he said.
For years, the platform has been the subject of lawsuits and petitions to Federal regulators, all seeking to have it demolished. And CSX acknowledges that it would be liable for at least $7 million in such demolition and cleanup costs.
Whatever its fate, the platform sits at the center of a wave of new development pressures, making it either a cornerstone or a barrier in what real estate experts say could be a sweeping renaissance of the far West Side of Manhattan.
Few sections of the city have attracted such active new development interest as the blocks along the elevated structure, where recent additions like the Chelsea Piers sports complex and newly opened galleries along 10th Avenue have come amid even more ambitious proposals for a sports stadium, expanded convention center and hotels on the blocks west of the Farley Post Office Building.
Such commercial interests would have seemed remote when the platform, known as the High Line, was completed in 1934 by the New York Central Line and praised as an engineering marvel of its day. Built on huge steel girders, the platform extends south from 34th Street through the middle of more than 20 blocks and ends at Gansevoort Street in Greenwich Village.
The platform was built to support four rail lines, and was part of a burst of industrial construction up and down the West Side. While the rail platform itself was unusually large, its connection to warehouses and industrial buildings made it even more remarkable. Even today, sidings from the platform run into second-story bays in several neighboring buildings.
For its day, it was an engineering feat of a heft and intricacy rarely found in the nation's large cities. But as Manhattan's industrial economy began to be replaced by finance, advertising, publishing and other enterprise in the 1960's, the need for such heavy freight moving up and down the West Side diminished.
After the last trains rumbled down the High Line in 1982, what was left was an aged urban curiosity. Like other railroad companies that were scaling back service and abandoning tracks, Conrail resisted pressure by government regulators to sacrifice either its rights of way in Manhattan or its tracks, saying that they could prove useful in the future.
That contention is now at the core of CSX's efforts to keep the High Line intact. "If we are going to have several new high-rise buildings along this part of the West Side, wouldn't it make sense to have a rail line in place to connect them with some form of public transit?" said Mr. Brimmer of CSX.
He said the proposal for shops and recreational activity on the platform was particularly appealing because of the spurs already connecting it to buildings, since restaurants, galleries and retail activity on the second floors of those buildings could easily be connected to outdoor seating or display areas.
CSX may gain support for its plan from the Federal Government, which has sought to encourage the preservation of railroad rights of way through what has become known as the "Rails to Trails" program. The Federal guidelines for that program allow railroad companies to sell or donate their tracks to local governments or civic groups, which in turn clear away old tracks to make way for recreational corridors. But the guidelines also enable the rail companies to reclaim their rights of way far into the future if they elect to restore rail service.
Since the Federal guidelines took effect in 1982, 3,620 miles of track have been set aside across the nation for hiking trails, bike paths and other public amenities, said Karen Stewart, a spokesman for the Rails-to-Trails Conservancy, a nonprofit group based in Washington that advises railroads and municipalities.
But the CSX proposal for Manhattan differs from any other, she said, because it would involve a stretch of elevated track, posing added expenses and safety requirements for any group that wanted to take up the railroad's offer. "It would be stretching the limits," she said.
One architect, however, praised the CSX proposal.
"It would be fantastic," said Peter Eisenman, whose proposal for a huge development on the West Side rail yards, a tract bounded by 34th Street and 30th Street, was selected as the top entry in an international competition this month.
"We have to begin thinking about a city with mixed uses at different levels," he said. "Having walkways or roads running into buildings above the street would be a stunning architectural achievement."
Perhaps the biggest hurdles facing CSX's proposal have more to do with money than architecture. The railroad company, which could be relieved of $200,000 to $300,000 a year in city real estate taxes if it turned over the High Line to another company or a nonprofit group, declined to say how much it would expect to receive in rental payments or as a purchase price.
"It would depend on what type of organization approaches us and what use they have in mind," said Debra Frank, an urban planner who has been retained by CSX to study its options for the High Line. Although some investment would be required to landscape or pave over the elevated platform, and additions like stairways and elevators to the street would probably be required, "we don't see this as a very major amount or a deterrent," she said.
But Mr. Rose, who said he and his planning staff have inspected the High Line and considered its fate repeatedly for more than a decade, said the costs of repair and maintenance would discourage outside groups from taking any responsibility for the elevated structure.
It was cited for more than 60 safety violations this year, he said, including an incident in which concrete fell through the windshield of a parked car.
"It would be one thing if CSX was saying they would provide the investment necessary to fix this old thing up as a public park," he said. "That we would consider, but that is not what they are saying."
"What this is all about is delay," he said. "The bottom line is that the High Line will have to come down."

HEADLINE: Mourners Pay Respects to Third Victim of Kennedy Crash

BYLINE: By JULIAN E. BARNES

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., July 24

 BODY:
More than 600 mourners gathered here this evening to pay respects to Lauren Bessette, the third victim of the plane crash that also killed John F. Kennedy Jr. and Carolyn Bessette Kennedy just over a week ago.
Lauren Bessette, 34, was remembered as "rich, vibrant and multifaceted" in a eulogy delivered by her uncle, Jack Messina. Mourners also recalled her as a successful investment banker and a lover of opera during a ceremony that lasted just over an hour at Christ Church, an Episcopal church. 
 Ms. Bessette's ashes were dropped into the ocean on Thursday along with those of her sister and Mr. Kennedy, who were mourned Friday during a memorial service on Manhattan's Upper East Side.
In the days since the crash, Ms. Bessette's life was curiously both thrust into the open and draped in shadow. Among the three crash victims, hers was a private life that has been mostly overlooked as Americans lingered over images of Mr. Kennedy and his wife.
But today, Greenwich turned its attention to Lauren Bessette, in the place where she was raised and educated. Ms. Bessette and her twin sister, Lisa Ann, attended Central Junior High School and Greenwich High School. After graduating from high school in 1982, Lauren Bessette attended Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N.Y., where she majored in economics. In 1991, after graduating from the Wharton School of Business, Ms. Bessette joined Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the investment bank, where she worked as a financial adviser.
In 1994, Ms. Bessette began a job in the company's Hong Kong office. She rose to vice president and then to principal when she returned to Manhattan in 1998.
As guests began arriving around 5:45 P.M. until the service began at 7 P.M., photographers called the names of members of the Kennedy family and snapped pictures. In attendance were Ms. Bessette's sister, Lisa Ann, her father, William Bessette, her mother, Ann Freeman, and her stepfather, Richard Freeman. Many members of the Kennedy family also attended, including Edward M. Kennedy and Caroline Kennedy.
In a eulogy for Ms. Bessette, Mr. Messina offered the congregants richly detailed memories about her, including the day she played miniature golf in her backyard, dressed in pajamas and high heels.
"If the events of these past eight days have taught us anything it is to honor the moment," he said. "Cherish those around you. Try to find a balance between work and family. Contribute something to your community, and above all share the love you feel for each other each and every day."
The Rev. Hugh Tudor-Foley, an assistant to the rector at Christ Church, said that Robert F. Kennedy Jr. read a quote from Shakespeare during the service and two of Ms. Bessette's friends offered remembrances. He said that Carole Radziwill, the daughter of Lee Radziwill, the sister of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, delivered a reading in honor of Carolyn Bessette Kennedy. "It was tearful and it was joyful and it accomplished what the family wanted, which was to celebrate the lives of their two children," Mr. Tudor-Foley said.
Outside the church, a few Greenwich residents laid flowers on the grass.
"I remember her as an eclectic and fun person," said David Dall, 35, a classmate of Ms. Bessette's at Greenwich High. "She was friends with everyone."
Theo A. Constantine, 38, a member of Greenwich High's class of 1979, said he came to pay his respects to someone the world did not know very well.
"As a community we need to show our support. The Kennedys have more than enough support and Carolyn was recognized through them," said Mr. Constantine. "The focus hasn't been equal and this is a nice way to remember Lauren as an individual."

HEADLINE: July 18-24;
A Good Deficit

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

 BODY:
The more American consumers spend, the more the trade deficit rises -- last month to a record $21 billion, according to figures just released. And eventually that's bad news. But for now, it's good.
The deficit is soaring because the economy is running flat out. Countries are shipping Americans as much as they will buy. And because the goods are relatively low cost, they help keep down inflation, while taking few jobs away from Americans. 
 But sooner or later the economy will slow. And then today's inflation-fighting trade deficit will turn into tomorrow's threat to American jobs. Someday.
 DAVID E. SANGER

HEADLINE: Tax Cutters Aren't Conservatives

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Martin Feldstein (Op-Ed, July 21) notes that the share in income tax contributed by upper incomes has risen in recent years, and he welcomes the House plan for its across-the-board rate cut of 10 percent (front page, July 23) as a way to halt that shift. However, he does not mention that over the same period upper incomes have enjoyed a sharp increase in their share of pretax income. 
 Given the philosophy of a progressive income tax, in which most of us still believe, does it not follow that their tax share should have risen as well? The Senate bill, which focuses on reducing the first bracket rate, recognizes this, although both versions provide for an excessive revenue loss and should not be adopted.
 
RICHARD A. MUSGRAVE
Hartland Four Corners, Vt.
PUB-DATE: July 23, 1999
 
The writer is professor emeritus of political economy at Harvard University.

HEADLINE: Tax Cutters Aren't Conservatives

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Martin Feldstein (Op-Ed, July 21) asserts that "high taxes reduce the incentive to establish new businesses, to expand existing ones and to take the risks of introducing new products and new ways of producing. This reduces economic growth and the creation of better jobs." 
 What aspect of our economy could possibly cause anyone to conclude that nobody is willing to establish a new business or introduce a new product? To the contrary, business today is dynamic, not to mention chaotic, with major shifts in the manner of doing business, products becoming obsolete almost immediately, and so on. Can Mr. Feldstein present at least a modicum of evidence to support his assertions?
 
FRANK ROBINSON
Mountain View, Calif., July 21, 1999

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
A Worldly Getaway 2 Hours From Manhattan

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE

 BODY:
AHA! Another weekend warrior up from the big city," Paul Cavaccini, the manager of Rent a Wreck in New Paltz, N.Y., said with a chuckle when he saw me walk in the door. I certainly looked the part of a New York City runaway -- my dark linen pants ensemble hinted of brunches in SoHo, while the North Face backpack I hoisted smelled of sweat and insect repellent.
Mixed signals, certainly. But I was experiencing simultaneous cravings for urban sophistication and rural idyll. I wanted to lose myself in sylvan woods and babbling brooks, but only if they were within shouting range of a good wine store, an interesting restaurant and, perhaps, a purveyor of prosciutto di Parma. 
 I've never been much of a weekender. When faced with the choice of spending several thousand dollars on a summer rental on, say, Fire Island versus spending the same or less on a month's sojourn living extremely well in Mexico, the Caribbean, or Asia, I've always opted for the faraway trip.
Still, there are those Fridays in June when the sky is so blue, the air so fresh and warm, the smell of blooming wisteria drifting in the air from Prospect Park so lush, that it seems almost a misdemeanor to spend Saturday and Sunday in Brooklyn. Could I stage a swift, brief getaway that wouldn't upset my notions of travel economy?
On a weekend like this in early June, I decided to try. I took a subway to the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan and hopped on an Adirondack Trailways bus headed to New Paltz, about 85 miles north, in Ulster County.
Southern Ulster, where New Paltz is, isn't as hip and well-trodden as Woodstock (in northern Ulster), nor as fashionable as celebrity-studded Columbia County. So I figured that accommodations would be a bit cheaper. I'd been there before, to visit my friend Annie, and we had spent a day wandering through almost-empty, gorgeous wooded trails in Minnewaska State Park, where the Shawangunk Mountain range drops, in a dramatic series of bare rock cliffs, down to the Hudson Valley -- an amazing vista that I wanted to see again.
There's a good Web site for the Hudson Valley region (www.hvnet.com), and a local magazine with lots of bed-and-breakfast listings called Ulster Magazine. Between these two sources, I was able to arrange my travel plans in less than an hour.
I decided to stretch my getaway, and stay four nights instead of two, from Friday to Tuesday. I booked a single room without bath for the first two nights at the Kripplebush Bed-and-Breakfast, not too far from Annie's cabin in the town of Stone Ridge, for $50 a night. Then, I'd splurge on a two-night stay ($80 a night) at Ujjala's B & B, near New Paltz.
Abby Johnnes, the owner of Kripplebush, gave me the number of Rent a Wreck in New Paltz, a short walk from the Trailways depot. Paul set me up with an economy car for $29 a day, including all insurance, and gave me the inside dope on local sources of Italian ham.
Abby, a sweet petite grandmother who once ran a bookstore in Greenwich Village, bought her house in the country after her children went off to college. Her house sits on a country road across the street from the Methodist church, a 12-mile drive northwest of New Paltz. My room was one of six that she rents out in the large wood-frame house that dates to the mid-1800's.
The room was tiny, but had a window with a view of her inviting back garden, where pink peonies and stalks of foxglove were blooming. The decor ran to Oriental prints, Abby's own paintings and shelf after shelf of interesting books, artifacts of a downtown literary life, circa 1960.
It was already dinnertime. I'd figured there would be little diversion available, but soon Annie called. "You're right near me," she said. "We're going to the film festival tonight. Pick you up in a half hour."
The Hudson Valley Film Festival was in its last week in Rhinebeck, about a half-hour drive from Stone Ridge across the Hudson River. We hurried over, just in time to catch a screening of a documentary on the photographer Walker Evans ($5). Afterward, I was pleased to find that the enthusiastic festival organizers had arranged a reception for the participants -- free wine and excellent and abundant canapes of smoked salmon, vegetables, and cheese.
I munched away at "dinner," amused that I'd run off from New York City only to bump into it upstate, as strains of movie conversation floated through the room: "You know I told Marty that he needed to talk to Bobby about this." Annie explained that the Stone Ridge-High Falls area of Ulster was a weekend hideaway for the independent film industry. Harvey Keitel and Willem Dafoe, among others, had houses along the same road as Kripplebush -- hadn't I noticed Dafoe's house, made of rubber?
I hadn't. I bit into another canape and savored the weekend warrior experience.
Breakfast was ready when I stumbled down at 8:30 the next morning: crepes with fruit and cream, bagels and superb coffee.
Braced and well-fed, I set out for Minnewaska -- with a detour, first, for provisions. In High Falls, a picturesque village three miles from Kripplebush, I bought a big bag of date bars ($3.99) and a bag of organic almonds ($3.99) at the local food co-op. At a deli closer to the park, Stone Ridge Specialty Foods, I picked up some homemade crab cakes ($3.75 each), for the rest of my trail lunch.
Crab cakes, a crisp blue sky, no bugs in sight and a nearly deserted trail stretching ahead -- hiking doesn't get much better than this, I thought to myself. My feet hit a nice walking rhythm along the carriage road. Until the mid-80's, this area was the grounds and preserve of a grand hotel (owned by the brother of the owner of the nearby Mohonk Mountain House). After the hotel burned down, the property became part of the state park system.
At one end of the park, Lake Minnewaska draws crowds, but the vast network of foot trails isn't much used. With the free map that the guard had handed me as I pulled into the parking lot (the fee is $5), I charted a course that I figured would lead me about four miles to the far end of the park, to a high bluff with a panoramic view of the valley and of Lake Awosting. The map was not very detailed, so I stuck to the carriage road. Then I bumped into a park ranger who had some good news: today, the park was inaugurating a hiking path that wasn't on the map yet but that led in the direction I was headed. The ranger pointed out the trail blazes, and I was off.
I followed a riverbed for a while, then took a turn and headed over high bare rocks. Suddenly, I was on a bluff covered with gnarled, ancient looking pitch pines. I was alone, and in the midst of a natural setting as remote and wild as any I've experienced. That this pristine place is but a short drive from Manhattan seemed almost a miracle. The wind up here howled -- some of the pines were bent almost horizontal. I continued, stopping to take pictures and have lunch.
Scrambling up another little ridge, I came down the other side and gasped. Below the mountain that dropped several hundred feet, Hudson Valley farmland spread out like a tablecloth checkered in shades of green. Lake Awosting shimmered at the other side. It was a lot of view, considering how little climbing I had to do. (I'd say my hike was moderately easy, with a bit of rock scrambling.)
Still, I'd come about four miles, and my return route to the parking lot, which skirted the ridge and passed the park's other lake, Minnewaska, was about another four and a half miles. By the time I got my sweaty self back to Kripplebush, I was ready for a nice dinner.
The Clove Cafe in High Falls is designed to please a city slicker out for a meal in the country -- dim lights, comfy wooden booths, not overly formal. The menu looked ambitious (the new owners , I found out, are graduates of the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, across the Hudson), and was filled with wild things like venison and rabbit.
I had rabbit stew in a hearty Mediterranean-style sauce, polenta and steamed arugula. On the chef's recommendation, I tried a glass of a South African red wine called Pinotage, delicious, richly oaky and fruity, perfect for the end of a full day of tramping. With dessert and tip, dinner came to $48 -- pricey, but worth it, and my repast the night before had been free, after all.
Ujjala's Bed-and-Breakfast is about a 15-mile drive from Kripplebush, on the other side of the Shawangunk ridge, just south of New Paltz. I set out early, stopping for a bit to poke among old books and kitchen appliances at the Sunday morning flea market in High Falls.
At Ujjala Schwartz's lilac-colored Victorian house on a quiet small-town road, my room was larger than the one at Kripplebush, with antique bed and desk, lacy comforter and a puffy featherbed over the mattress. Wind chimes tinkled outside the kitchen, which opened to a little deck, sauna and pocket-sized garden. In the back was a meditation lodge, and two sweat lodges, where Indian purification rituals are sometimes held.
My friend Mark arrived from Westchester, to join me for a day of wine tasting. This part of the Hudson Valley was settled by the French Huguenots in the 1600's, and the Gallic farmers planted some of the first vineyards in the Americas. Viniculture in the region has waxed and waned through the centuries, but has recently hit its stride again: there are now enough vineyards in the area to support two wine trails, organized by local tourist organizations. We set out to visit the six vineyards on the Shawangunk Wine Trail.
The winding county roads ran through picturesque farmlands where cows lazed beside big red barns and young deer occasionally darted across our path. We tasted about four wines each at three vineyards; Mark, the connoisseur, was underwhelmed. Just when we'd decided that the scenery, rather than Hudson Valley wines, was the main attraction of the wine trail, we came upon Baldwin Vineyards in far southern Ulster. There, we sampled some unusual and subtly sweet dessert wines, intense with essences of local strawberries and raspberries. Even Mark was impressed, and we bought five bottles between us ($7 to $10).
I awoke early my last day because I wanted to go sightseeing in New Paltz before hiking again. To my dismay, I found that on Mondays, the town's old stone Huguenot houses are closed. But I enjoyed a walk in the cool of the morning down Huguenot Street, peering into the windows of the old settlers' homes, now museums, some of which date back to the 1700's. Since there was no one about, I could imagine I was walking in Colonial New York.
My time travel continued as I drove, about 20 minutes later, through the parking lot gates of Mohonk Mountain House. This Victorian resort, its main lodge a riot of over-the-top gingerbread, Tudor and the generally eclectic, sits on a huge tract of land with quaintly manicured grounds -- once one of the grand hotels of America.
It remains in the hands of the original owners, the Smiley family, and it retains its idiosyncratic and authentic Victorian atmosphere. Entrance to the main property is restricted to hotel guests, whose meals are included with their lodging. Nonguests who wish to hike the property -- a stretch adjacent to Minnewaska with similar topography -- must pass a checkpoint, wear a badge and pay a fee ($12 on weekends, $9 on weekdays).
Minnewaska State Park is a much better choice for serious hiking. But Mohonk is the place to absorb and understand Victorian esthetics -- not the faux lace-and-curtains Victoriana of home decor, but the 19th-century sensibility. Each of Mohonk's paths winds in a fashion calculated to provide the most pleasing view of the natural setting. Nature is tamed and made softer and more comfortable by wooden benches placed at regular intervals, charming gazebos, clever ponds and other evidences of the hand of man.
I rested on one of those benches and took stock: in four days I'd gone to a screening party, hiked in splendid woods, tasted wine, poked in a flea market, eaten an excellent dinner and even managed to tuck in a sauna. I had had as much variety of experience, and as much fun in Ulster County as in many faraway exotic places, without buying an airline ticket. This novice weekend warrior felt victorious -- and began to plot her next campaign.
 
The bottom line: culture, nature and relaxation
I spent $96.50 a day for food, lodging and activities during my four days in Ulster County.
 
Getting There
Round-trip bus fare from midtown Manhattan to New Paltz, N.Y., cost $31.35 on Adirondack Trailways, which runs about a dozen trips a day, lasting just under two hours. Information: (800) 858-8555.
I rented a 1992 Mercury from Rent a Wreck in New Paltz, 87 North Chestnut Street, (914) 255-5666, for $29 a day. Mileage is free up to 125 miles a day and you must stay within a 100-mile radius of the office.
 
Where to Stay
Kripplebush Bed-and-Breakfast, 160 Kripplebush Road, Stone Ridge, N.Y., (914) 687-0723, is also Abby Johnnes's home. She has six guest rooms in a stagecoach house that dates from the 1840's. My single with bath across the hall was $50; doubles are $65 to $95. No credit cards.
Ujjala's Bed-and-Breakfast, 2 Forest Glen Road, New Paltz, (914) 255-6360, www.ujjalasbnb.com., has four rooms, with lace duvets, antique furniture and lots of pillows. I chose it for its New Age accouterments: there's a sauna and a meditation chamber. Ujjala Schwartz offers advice on rock-climbing and kayaking and canoeing in the area. My room, with bath across the hall, was $80 a night; doubles are $90, $105 with private bath. No credit cards.
 
Where to Eat
The Clove Cafe, 1003 Route 213, High Falls, N.Y., (914) 687-7911, has a sophisticated menu of local game and other delicacies. Dinner with wine, tax and tip came to $48. Lunch served on Friday, brunch on Saturday and Sunday. Closed Monday and Tuesday.
Along Route 209, Stone Ridge Specialty Foods, High Falls, (914) 687-2000, sells takeout foods with an Italian touch, and is putting in tables. I picked up two meaty crab cakes for lunch for $7.50. Closed Monday.
The High Falls Food Co-op, 1398 Route 213, High Falls, (914) 687-7262, has a good selection of organic munchies.
A few miles north of the entrance to Minnewaska State Park, The Log Cabin Restaurant, 5941 Route 44-45, Kerhonkson, N.Y., (914) 626-9838, caters to Ukrainian retirees in the area. The proprietor, Olga Sawchuck, served me scrumptious pirogis stuffed with potatoes and cheese, and topped with brown-fried onions in butter. I washed this down with a draft beer; the tab came to $9. Open for lunch and dinner daily, except Tuesday.
 
What to Do
The annual Hudson Valley Film Festival, (914) 473-0318, presents aprogram of features, documentaries and shorts during the first week of June in Rhinebeck; many screenings are followed by talks and receptions.
Minnewaska State Park Preserve, (914) 255-0752, charges a parking fee of $5, $6 in summer. There are hiking trails, but no overnight camping. Swimming is available at two lakes. The park opens at 9 A.M daily and closes as late as 9 P.M., depending on season.
The wineries on the Shawangunk Wine Trail have varied hours, but most welcome visitors on Saturday and Sunday afternoons in the summer. A list of the participating wineries, and a map of the trail is available at www.hvnet.com. The trail is reasonably well marked by signs with grapes, but taking a map along is a good idea.
The stone houses along Huguenot Street in New Paltz form a National Historic Landmark District. The Huguenot Historical Society, (914) 255-1889, www.hhs-newpaltz.org., runs tours, 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. every day but Monday from May to October. Tours, which cost $3, $6 and $10, depending on length, start at the visitors center, 18 Broadhead Avenue.
The grounds of Mohonk Mountain House, New Paltz, N.Y., (914) 255-1000, www.mohonk.com, but not the house itself, are open to the public. Entry is $12 on weekends, $9 during the week; $8 and $7 under age 12. Day visitors can use the nine-hole golf course ($12 to $20) and six tennis courts ($12 an hour) if space is available. DAISANN McLANE
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: August 1, 1999, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Frugal Traveler column last Sunday, about a weekend in Ulster County, N.Y., described hiking in the Minnewaska State Park Preserve. On July 16, after the article was prepared for publication, the state closed about 80 percent of the park because of fire danger. As of Monday, several miles of carriageways remained open, as did one of the two beaches, Minnewaska. The park said the closings would remain in effect until rain alleviated the danger. For information, call (914) 255-0752.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Can Profits Keep Surging All Year? A 'Yes' Vote

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
CORPORATE AMERICA is rolling in dough. So too, it must be added, are those who have bought and held shares during the last few years. This is not an incidental relationship.
The reporting season for second-quarter profits is about half over, and the results are much better than most had reason to expect even six months ago. 
 Through the end of last week, better than half of the companies that make up the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index have reported an average profit gain of more than 15 percent from the same period in 1998, according to First Call. And there is a good chance that profits will rise at a double-digit rate for all of this year, compared with a 4 percent increase in 1998.
The trouble is, many people worry that the game will soon be up. They think the market, which has been struggling with stratospheric price-to-earnings ratios, may fall sharply when S.& P. 500 earnings gains revert to historical norms, around 7 percent.
But Thomas M. McManus, equity portfolio strategist at Banc of America Securities, thinks this earnings run could last a long, long time, and he took some time last week to explain why. Here are some excerpts:
 
Q. You are of the view that this period of strong earnings growth can continue for the indefinite future. Why?
 
A. I sense a significant underlying shift in the ability of American companies to grow earnings.
For many, the roots are in consolidation, which has been important in terms of combining two attractive businesses, maintaining the same amount of revenues but with a much smaller cost base. That doesn't happen instantly, but over a couple of years.
Even without consolidation, companies have continued to restructure, coming up with a different mix of businesses that are growing faster, are less cyclical and in areas that are attractively positioned. The best example here is General Electric, which has been restructuring its businesses for 20 years.
 
Q. So what does this lead you to conclude?
 
A. That there is a higher secular growth rate for S.& P. earnings than most are willing to concede. And the cyclical rebound off of the decline in earnings last year has occurred sooner and been more robust than anyone had forecast.
 
Q. What is your current earnings forecast?
 
A. At the start of 1999 we were more optimistic than most, and thought S.& P. profits would rise by about 10 percent from 1998 levels and a further 14 percent in 2000. At the beginning of May, I revised those numbers up, to a gain of 12 percent this year and 16 percent in 2000. And I think we are going to raise estimates for this year and 2000 again.
 
Q. What do you say to those who say the S.& P. is overvalued at these levels?
 
A. I think anyone who is saying the market is overvalued this year, be it the Fed or stock market strategists, is not taking into account that the underlying business mix has improved at least as much as General Electric has improved because of a very rapid turnover of components in the index. It now has less cyclicality and greater sustainability than it did in the past and deserves to trade at a higher P/E multiple relative to any interest rate you might choose or any competing market benchmark around the world.
Also, people should be focusing on free cash flows, not earnings. Net income is only the first approximation of profitability. The real value to investors is the amount of cash a company can take out and still be left with a business that is just as good as it was before. Companies like Microsoft and Intel are like that, and that is one reason they trade at such high multiples to net income.

Q. There are plenty of folks who are worried about the effect that Year 2000 computer problems will have on the economy and earnings. Do you share those concerns?
 
A. It is my view that profits are actually being negatively impacted right now.
Last week, for example, W. W. Granger admitted their costs went up by $7 million and their revenues were cut by $10 million in the last 10 days of June because they adopted a new computer system. It is my hunch that is their Y2K compliance system.
 
Q. Which companies or groups of companies are likely to enjoy the most rapid earnings growth over the next year or so?
 
A. We could see continued improvement in a whole host of companies.
Right now, the market is looking for trends of earnings repair, or a bounce off the dip we saw last year.
Individual companies we like include Ethan Allen, the furniture manufacturer and retailer, which experienced a significant hit last year. We also like W. W. Granger, which is investing heavily in its Internet presence. We are also very attracted to the semiconductor capital equipment sector, and really like Novellus in that area. And we like technology generally.
