HEADLINE: The World: Ominous Signals in Iran;
In Islamic Mideast, Scant Place for Jews

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS

 BODY:
TO those who monitor events in Iran, the arrest of 13 Iranian Jews on spying charges this year is a menacing sign that bigger trouble may lie ahead -- trouble that, unchecked, could cause one of the last two Jewish communities of any size in the Islamic Middle East to follow most of the others into virtual oblivion.
Until the arrests, Jews in Iran had survived the 20-year dominion of Iran's ruling ayatollahs better than many feared in 1979, when the Islamic republic was declared. In fact, the 30,000 Jews in Iran, while down from the 80,000 who lived there before the revolution, constitute the largest Jewish community to have survived in the Muslim Middle East and North Africa. The only other one of similar size is in Turkey, another non-Arab country, where about 20,000 Jews remain. 
 The Iranian Jews' significance becomes clearer when their endurance is measured against what happened elsewhere after the birth of Israel. From Morocco through Algeria, Tunisia, Libya, Egypt, Yemen, Lebanon, Syria, Iraq and Turkey, Jewish communities that totalled perhaps a million people in 1948 dwindled between the 1950's and 80's to the point that barely 60,000 -- including the 50,000 in Iran and Turkey -- remain.
But now, Iran's Jews must worry that tactics used against Jewish minorities elsewhere could erode their security, making migration more attractive. For the time being, the American and European diplomats who have been leading a discreet campaign to persuade Iran to drop the spying charges remain hopeful. They point to the opprobrium that would be sure to fall on Iran if the cases come to trial, or -- improbable, but still possible, in the view of experts on Iran -- if the Jews were convicted and sentenced to long prison terms or death.
The case has unfolded slowly. When the first of the 13 was arrested in January, the State Department kept the matter quiet, hoping diplomacy could resolve the issue. But that had not happened by early June, when Iran announced the arrests over the state radio.
The spying charges bear every earmark of a trumped-up case. Those arrested -- including a rabbi, three Hebrew teachers, a kosher butcher and even, by some reports, a 16-year-old boy -- were originally picked up for alleged infringements of Iranian laws that conflict with Jewish practices. The rabbi was charged with teaching Hebrew, the language of Jewish prayer; others were accused of closing their shops on Saturday, the Jewish Sabbath.
Their actions were condemned as evidence of disloyalty to Iran, and thus as proof that those arrested were in the service of "world arrogance" and "the Zionist entity," meaning the United States and Israel. By escalating infractions of religious laws into treason, the conservatives who control Iran's police and courts evidently hoped to stir antagonism toward the West and place fresh obstacles before Iran's reformist President, Mohammed Khatami.
BY no coincidence, the charges originated in the southern city of Fars, a stronghold of Islamic conservatives loyal to Ayatollah Ali Khamanei, Iran's supreme leader. Although the violent clashes earlier this month between students supporting President Khatami and security forces loyal to the Muslim clerics have now abated, the underlying dispute between those favoring a broadening of freedoms and the clerics' insistence on tight control remains. With it, at least theoretically, remains the risk that other Jews might become political pawns.
It is a situation redolent of the hazards Jews have faced throughout history, made more poignant in Iran by the fact that Jews there seemed, until the spying case, to have a more secure place than elsewhere in the Muslim Middle East. The Islamic constitution recognizes Jews as a religious minority, allows them a representative in Parliament and accepts Jewish laws on burial and divorce. In Teheran, 27 synagogues function, Jewish schools flourish and the Jewish hospital is among the city's most respected.
Now all this could be at risk, and with it a crucial vestige of the Jewish settlement that has left a deep imprint on virtually every country in the Middle East. According to estimates in the "Atlas of the Jewish World," a survey by Dr. Nicholas de Lange of Cambridge University, as many as four million Jews lived in parts of the Roman Empire beyond Judea, the Jewish homeland, at the dawn of the first millennium; most of these lived in the Arab lands that now surround Israel. On the eve of the third millennium, these countries together could not muster a Jewish population as numerous as those that were once to be found in many of the major cities of the region.
Iraq, where there were about 150,000 Jews in 1948, has about 70 now. In Syria, there are about 300, in Lebanon about 80, in Jordan, Egypt and Yemen fewer still. In Saudi Arabia there are no Jews, at least by official count. In Morocco, which had about 300,000 Jews in 1948, about 6,000 remain. In Algeria, which saw 115,000 Jews emigrate hastily to France at independence in 1962, the count is down to a few hundred. In Tunisia, which counted 105,000 Jews in 1950, there are no more than 2,500. In Libya, where a 1931 census counted 24,500 Jews, one recent count put the number of Jews remaining at 5. In Turkey, a community of 90,000 in 1948 has shrunk to less than a quarter of that now.
While flight from the Muslim lands has been precipitous in the last 50 years, a slower decline dates from the Middle Ages, when the rise of Christian Europe attracted large westward migrations among Jewish populations in the Middle East. Other factors, including local pogroms, prompted Jews to leave over the centuries. But in the modern era, the watershed was the creation of Israel. Living in a Jewish state was an attraction in itself; a surge of hostility among Arabs toward Jews, or at least toward Zionism, was another factor.
Still, many of those who left did so reluctantly, and many chose not to leave until much later. This attests to something widely accepted among Jews who have lived as minorities in Muslim nations -- that the Islamic world has been less fertile ground for anti-Semitism than the Christian lands of Europe. Why this has been so has been endlessly debated, but Islamic scholars cite stories from the life of the Muslim prophet, Mohammed, to show that respect for Jews was close to his heart.
Nothing in Jewish experience in the Middle East came remotely close to the Holocaust. But even long before Hitler's killing machine, Jews in Muslim countries were comparing their experiences favorably with those of Jews in Europe. In his survey, Dr. de Lange quotes a Jew writing from Constantinople to Jews in the Rhineland in 1454. "Is it not better for you to live under Muslims than under Christians?" he wrote. "Here, every man may live at peace under his own vine and fig tree."
SINCE 1948, of course, there has been no lack of discrimination toward Jews in Arab countries. Eighteen months after the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, Iraq convicted 14 people, nine of them Jews, on dubious spying charges and hanged them from lampposts in a Baghdad square. In many Arab countries, Jews could not emigrate, or could only on forfeit of all they owned. Jewish religious practices were restricted. In many countries, Jews were excluded from government employment, at least at the top.
Some Jewish historians have argued that Israel, or at least Zionists, must accept a share of the blame. These scholars cite the Zionists' plan to encourage Jews everywhere to migrate to Israel, and link that plan to covert Israeli intelligence operations in the years after 1948. One often-cited case involves a bungled Israeli intelligence schemet in 1954 in which bombs were placed at key centers in Cairo, including the American library, with a view to disrupting relations between Western countries and President Gamal Abdel Nasser. These historians say another aim -- and certainly one effect -- was to encourage Egypt's 50,000 Jews to flee to Israel.
Avi Shlaim, a professor of international relations at Oxford University who has written on relations between Israel and the Arab states, says that actions like these accelerated the flight of Jews from communities where many might otherwise have remained. But Dr. Shlaim, whose own family left Iraq for Israel in 1950, believes that now that the Jewish communities in the region have all but vanished, not even a lasting peace between Israel and the Arab states will lead to their regeneration.
The reason, he says, is not that the Arab states or Iran are innately anti-Semitic, but that they lack democratic institutions and economic opportunities. "I can't imagine anyone in their right mind going back to Iraq, or Syria, for that matter," he says. King Hassan of Morocco, who died last week, "held out this opportunity to Moroccan Jews all along, and even they haven't exercised it," Dr. Shalim added. "The most I can imagine now is that Jews born in these countries may eventually want to return as tourists, but nothing more."

HEADLINE: An Idea Whose Time Has Gone

BYLINE: By Mark Lilla; Mark Lilla is the editor of "New French Thought: Political Philosophy."

 BODY:

THE PASSING OF AN ILLUSION
The Idea of Communism in the Twentieth Century.
By Francois Furet.
Translated by Deborah Furet.
596 pp. Chicago:
The University of Chicago Press. $35. 
 TWO years ago this month France lost Francois Furet, one of its most important historians, at the age of 70. Although in the last decade of his life Furet was chairman of the prestigious Committee on Social Thought at the University of Chicago, he was virtually unknown in this country outside academic circles. But in France he was recognized as one of the most influential thinkers of the post-1968 period, a man whose writings probably did more to shape the intellectual mood of the Mitterrand era than anyone else's. It was during this period that French intellectuals completed their change of allegiances from the schools of Marxism and structuralism that dominated the postwar years to a resigned democratic liberalism. It was Furet, following in the footsteps of his mentor Raymond Aron, who presided over that remarkable transformation.
That an academic historian whose specialty was obscure details of the French Revolution could have had such wide impact might strike foreign observers as improbable. But the Revolution (always capitalized) has never been a remote, scholastic subject in the political and intellectual life of France. As Furet himself did so much to show, the Revolution had a unique imaginaire, or symbolic significance, through which the French viewed all subsequent political developments at home and abroad. Beginning in the early 19th century, French (and, following them, German) thinkers saw the Revolution as the turning point of world history, the culmination of all earlier struggles for human freedom and the messianic promise of a final emancipation to come.
Whether or to what degree Furet shared this view of the Revolution's significance was never entirely clear. At times he followed his beloved Tocqueville in treating the Revolution as a rip in the fabric of time, through which emerged a unique historical epoch -- the democratic age -- with unique problems and prospects. At other times he commented more skeptically on this fetishizing of the Revolution, which bred countless illusions about the genuine condition of modern man and the nature of liberal democracy. It is this second Furet who wrote his last and most personal book, "The Passing of an Illusion," which is not about the French Revolution at all but about its presumably last offspring: the idea of Communism.
In a sense, as some of his critics correctly pointed out, Furet was always writing about Communism, even in his books on the Revolution. He had been a card-carrying and quite militant member of the party until the failed Hungarian uprising of 1956, which opened his eyes to the illusion that had colored his entire life until then. Figuring out how it had been possible for him and so many others to be so easily duped became his life's work, which is what gives the present book (translated by his widow) its autobiographical force. It has been justifiably compared to Eric Hobsbawm's "Age of Extremes," another extremely personal work of history, which tells the story of the rise and fall of the Communist idea in this century from a far more sympathetic perspective. Taken together, these books give the contemporary reader a feel for the passions that have driven politics and scholarship throughout our bloody century.
Furet sets the stage for the rise of the Communist idea by returning to the French Revolution and describing the tension between the bourgeois world it created in economics and politics and the antibourgeois passions it bred in the human heart. The bourgeois 19th century was stillborn: in Europe it was ruled over by a hopelessly weak class racked by self-doubt and intellectually incapable of understanding its own significance. The disaster of World War I robbed it of whatever confidence it had and encouraged even some of its own members to see in the Russian Revolution of 1917 a kind of salvation.
FURET'S chapters on the early European reactions to the Russian Revolution are maddeningly Gallocentric but revealing nonetheless. He shows how foreign observers were much more attracted to the violent and authoritarian revolution of October than to the milder and potentially more democratic one of February. In the puritanical ruthlessness of Lenin many Europeans saw the spitting image of Robespierre, and they liked what they saw. Foremost among these were intellectuals, who were attracted to the claims of Russian Communism to have united science and morals, and who remained attached to it even when the science failed and the morals were perverted. With Europe's house in political and economic shambles in the wake of the Great War, such hopes in a new path might have been understandable. But as credible reports of purges, famines and massacres began to leak out of the Soviet Union in the 1920's and 30's, only something stronger than rational hope could have sustained the Western partisans of Communism. George Bernard Shaw's remark that "Stalin is a good Fabian, and that's the best that can be said of anyone" was hardly exceptional, and illustrates how the will to believe overcame even the most skeptical minds.
But in what sense can Communism be called an "illusion"? After all, it was real enough to millions of workers who couldn't have distinguished Shaw from St. Nick. Furet has no interest in proving that supporters of Communism in the 20's and 30's were simply ignorant, or that their actions had unintended consequences; that is true of all historical actors. What made Communism different, for workers and thinkers alike, is that it demanded and received a psychological investment rendering it virtually impermeable to rational or empirical refutation. Keeping in mind the bon mot reported by the Spanish writer Jorge Semprun that dialectics is "the science of always landing on your feet," we may say that Communism was a dialectical illusion.
In Furet's view, what tightened this illusion's grip on the minds of so many for so long was the birth of a second illusion, an evil twin with which it waged mortal combat: fascism. Here Furet's argument has been highly contentious but also, in my view, quite fruitful. While he is careful to distinguish the indigenous roots of the German and Italian versions of fascism, he also usefully reminds us that its founder was the former socialist Benito Mussolini, who among other things was an assiduous student of Lenin. The parallels between fascism and Communism as ideologies are significant. "Both Bolshevism and fascism drew their basic education from war," Furet writes. "They transferred to politics the lessons of the trenches: familiarity with violence, the simplicity of extreme passions, the submission of the individual to the collectivity, and finally the bitterness of futile or betrayed sacrifices."
In recent years a similar line of argument, with altogether different moral and political implications, has been put forward by the German historian Ernst Nolte and his revisionist followers. They have tried to exploit the undeniable similarities between Communism and fascism to reinterpret Nazism as little more than a reaction to the genuine threat of Bolshevism, and thereby to reduce its moral culpability, not least for the Holocaust. This is not at all Furet's position, as he made abundantly clear in a long correspondence with Nolte following the publication of "The Passing of an Illusion" in France. (These letters have now appeared in a French edition and deserve rapid translation into English.)
Furet rejected any attempt to reinterpret the exterminating fury of German anti-Semitism as an unfortunate byproduct of anti-Communism, maintaining against Nolte that it had no parallels in modern history, not in Communism or in fascism elsewhere. The aim of Furet's book was to demonstrate how the illusions, not the reality, of Communism and fascism fed off each other in our century, to the point that they eventually came to see themselves distortedly as mirror images of their adversaries.
Furet's treatment of the 30's is the high point of the book. As the economic disaster of the Great Depression was slowly overcome, Communist intellectuals and movements turned from economics to the struggle against fascism. And when the Spanish Civil War broke out, this battle of the ideologies suddenly took on military reality, conveniently providing Communist sympathizers with an excuse for belittling as war propaganda reports of atrocities in Russia and behind partisan lines in Spain. Stalin deftly exploited this moment. He even saw the value in the development of a non-Communist but sympathetic antifascist "third column," a new kind of left "independent of Communism yet inseparable from it," as Furet puts it. These fellow travelers, as they came to be called, flocked to Moscow to kiss Stalin's ring, all the while professing themselves to be good Fabians, good French Republicans or good American democrats committed only to the struggle against fascism.
That threat was real enough. But its psychological effect on the left was to act as a filtering device that automatically read out all nonfascist threats to human decency, Soviet Communism foremost among them. The Moscow trials could be ignored in the name of solidarity with Catalonia; the Hitler-Stalin pact could be atoned for by the noble defense of Stalingrad. And so it went throughout World War II and the dark decade that followed, as Eastern Europe fell under the shadow of Soviet tyranny and the gulag sprawled like a macabre Levittown over the Siberian tundra. By the 1950's, fascism had disappeared but substitutes for it were ready at hand for the fellow travelers: American imperialism, the arms race, McCarthyism.
Again, it must be emphasized that Furet has no interest in minimizing these disturbing developments, which he devoted a good part of his journalistic career to combating. But the alternative they formed in the mind of the Communist sympathizer -- apres Communisme, le deluge -- was a false one. In every Western country there were responsible people on the left and in the liberal center who saw no contradiction between opposing Communism and also opposing imperialism, McCarthy or the arms race. Yet it was precisely these figures who were treated with the most contempt by those for whom life without the Communist illusion could not be imagined.
Unsurprisingly, if a little disappointingly, the drama of Furet's book ends in 1956, and developments over the next four decades are only lightly sketched in. They were not uneventful years, ideologically speaking. Most of the third world was rapidly decolonized, there was a drawn-out war in Southeast Asia, and a new generation of political radicals was born that appealed to many symbols in the Communist repertory but eventually undermined them. This generation had its own illusions, which it was eventually forced to abandon after the revelations of Solzhenitsyn, the butcheries of Cambodia, the rise of Islamic fundamentalism and the routinization of tyranny in countless former colonies. Yet, in its own way, this was the generation to seal Communism's fate.
And what remains? In Furet's view, less than nothing: "All that remains of the regimes born" of the October Revolution "is what they sought to destroy." But he was too much the historian, and too subtle a psychologist of the modern mind, to think that the passions first kindled in 1789 were extinguished without a trace in 1989. The Communist illusion ended because Communism ended, not the reverse. The passions of the democratic age, cooled perhaps by the political traumas of our century, are still lurking in our breasts. It seems to be our destiny as modern men, Furet wistfully concludes, to live in an age that "creates the need for a world beyond the bourgeoisie and beyond Capital, a world in which a genuine human community can flourish." A need that no society can ever satisfy.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

LENGTH: 981 words

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce Report;
For local merchants interested in on-line sales, faith may be the biggest element of the business plan.

BYLINE: By Bob Tedeschi

 BODY:
ONLIKE most people drawn to the siren song of Internet commerce, Phil Worley started a Web site last spring with a modest goal: bring in some additional sales for the small-town hardware business. No 50-page business plan. No venture capital. No initial public offering.
After three months of advertising Weber grills on the site, operated by The Hartford Courant (www.courant.com), at prices lower than many competitors, his experience has not met even his humble expectations. In other words, he has not sold a thing on line. 
 "I haven't seen much payback," said Mr. Worley, owner of Worley Ace Hardware in Canton, Conn., a town of about 8,000 that lies 14 miles west of Hartford. "But I feel like I need to be there, since so many in my industry are. I'm keeping the faith."
For many people dipping their toes into E-commerce, the process requires an element of faith -- whether for consumers concerned about security, investors uncertain of their return or retailers with no idea how consumers' on-line behavior will evolve. But for local merchants who want to participate in the world's hottest industry, faith is perhaps the biggest component.
It is not only that owners of small businesses often lack the time, expertise and marketing budgets to compete with bigger companies. It is not yet clear that people will look to local merchants when they surf the Net for bargains. Meanwhile, on-line city guides, which seek to aggregate local businesses for ads and transactions, are a fragmented bunch, with only experimental ideas on how to approach local markets.
"It's not a pretty picture for local merchants right now," said Lisa Allen, an E-commerce analyst with Forrester Research, an Internet consulting firm. "First of all, a lot of what's sold on line are commodities, and you don't need to buy a book or CD from a local yokel store," she said. "But also, the national players have the deep pockets to create sites with the best user experience and market them. And the mom and pops don't have that."
Ms. Allen said local merchants would attract $680 million in Internet sales this year, or 9 percent of the total $7.8 billion projected by Forrester. By 2003, Forrester expects local merchants to increase those sales to $6 billion, but that number will account for just 6 percent of the projected $108 billion in Web sales.
In promoting the potential of local E-commerce, some executives point to the fact that people spend nearly 80 percent of their money within a 20-mile radius of their homes. But "interests, not geography, will be important on line," Ms. Allen said.
"If you're a wine aficionado, you won't necessarily go to the local site," she added.
There are, however, certain categories that show greater local potential on line -- including tickets, which Forrester anticipates will reap 43 percent of local Web sales, or $2.6 billion, by 2003. Such numbers bode well for Ticketmaster Online-Citysearch, which runs a network of city guides catering primarily to entertainment-minded consumers.
Perhaps mindful of the limits of local E-commerce, many merchants use the Web for marketing rather than for completing transactions with customers. Here, businesses like employment agencies, realtors and car dealerships are among the biggest spenders, analysts and executives said.
"More and more things in the real estate industry will be done on line, so I'd expect our ad budget to grow on line in the next couple of years," said Stat Geer, regional manager for the Chicago Title Insurance Company, which advertises on the Chicago Digital City site, operated by America Online in conjunction with The Chicago Tribune.
Indeed, at least one study shows that local advertising on line is gaining momentum. According to a report last month by Kelsey Group and Constat Inc., the Web has surpassed direct mail as an ad medium for local businesses and is nearly equal to local spending on newspaper advertising. The report said that 17.2 percent of businesses involved in local commerce use the Web for advertising and promotion, versus 15.5 percent for direct mail, 18.7 percent for newspapers and 37.2 percent for Yellow Pages.
On-line city guides like Digital City and Citysearch, as well as guides owned by newspapers (including The New York Times, which publishes the New York Today site), have until recently attracted advertisers using the same formula as any local media: provide local news and entertainment information, and sell ads surrounding that content. But with the E-commerce bandwagon picking up speed, more local merchants are demanding not only advertising opportunities, but sophisticated Web sites that enable them to sell goods within the city guide.
"The bar is a lot higher now," said Charles Conn, chief executive of Ticketmaster Online-Citysearch. "When we used to sell sites in our city guides to merchants, they wanted four or five pages with pictures, maybe a menu if they were a restaurant. Now they want streaming audio, the recipe of the day, and merchants want the ability to transact."
Mr. Conn, who said merchants pay between $100 and $700 a month for a site within a Citysearch guide, noted that consumers, too, will increasingly expect local merchants to offer more transaction capabilities. "I think because people have been trained by tools like Amazon and Ebay for buying on line, they'll look not only for fresh information from sites like ours, but transaction tools to help them get things done."
That, of course, is the great hope of merchants like Mr. Worley, of Worley Ace Hardware, who pays $200 a month for his site. "As with so many people who are trying E-commerce, this is a large experiment for me," he said. "But I haven't really given this a lot of attention, since I have so much going on running the business. I suppose to do it right you have to do it big. And I haven't done that yet."

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
An Entrepreneurial Exception Rides The Internet in Japan

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 25

 BODY:
Masayoshi Son seems an unlikely deal maker in the bubbly and free-spirited world of the Internet.
Short, boyish-looking and soft-spoken, Mr. Son -- while in Japan -- wears the Japanese business uniform of a white shirt and an immaculately pressed black suit. In public, he sometimes stands stiffly and smiles only slightly. He bows often to emphasize his humility. 
 Moreover, he lives in Tokyo, the risk-averse capital of the world, where the Internet is still a foreign concept to many.
But if there is such a thing as an Internet financial and media empire, Mr. Son's company, Softbank, may be it. Mr. Son, 41, and Softbank are already among the most powerful financial forces in cyberspace, controlling key stakes in 100 Internet information providers in the United States and 20 such companies in Japan. The stakes in publicly held companies, worth $15 billion to $20 billion, are sprinkled widely. Softbank now owns 28 percent of Yahoo, and it has important stakes in Geocities, E-Loans, E*Trade, USWeb, Message Media, and TheStreet.com.
And Softbank is intensifying its focus on the Internet with new deals all the time. Last Tuesday, for example, it agreed to pay $20 million for a 40 percent stake in Webhire, an on-line recruiting company. And Softbank may sell much of its 70 percent stake in Ziff-Davis, the publisher of such magazines as PC Week.
"If you want a global player in the Internet, they are the player," said Jarett F. Wait, chief operating officer in Asia for Lehman Brothers, which recently released a 195-page report on the company. "There's nobody else that comes close."
But while Mr. Son is Japan's leading entrepreneur, the oddity, and perhaps the reason, is that he is not ethnically Japanese.
A Chinese-Korean, he grew up poor in southern Japan, closed off from normal avenues in Japan's corporate world because of discrimination against the Korean minority. Denied a chance to succeed at a leading company, he started Softbank and has become one of Japan's richest men.
Softbank's aim is to become a global Internet "zaibatsu," a Japanese-style empire with investments in many linked companies. Softbank has begun Internet ventures through Yahoo in Germany, France and Britain; it has investment alliances with Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation in Europe, and a joint venture in South Korea.
"For the next 10 years, we do nothing but Internet," Mr. Son said, speaking in English during an interview in his spacious office. "Because that's where the whole society is going to have a big revolution."
Now, after building the foundations of his Internet kingdom in the United States, Mr. Son is turning back to Japan -- one of the least entrepreneurial societies. Last month, he and Frank G. Zarb, chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, announced a plan to form a new trading exchange, a Japanese version of Nasdaq, that could become a center for electronic brokerage activity, electronic research and entrepreneurial ventures in Japan.
Mr. Son will feed that entrepreneurial spirit with venture-capital funds that aim to pour $85 million into building Japanese start-ups and grooming hundreds of Softbank wannabes. On June 29 Mr. Son held a reception for 1,400 budding entrepreneurs. He spent the morning of July 5 with Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi and other Government officials to offer some ideas for reviving Japan's economy. The entry of Mr. Son, an entrepreneur from the Korean minority, into the Prime Minister's residence underscores the changing times in Japan.
Yet he faces some enormous challenges. So far he has been a kind of venture capitalist, backing Internet enterprises early and riding on their success. But he does not manage or plan them. And the soaring value of Internet stocks has perhaps exaggerated his ability to pick individual winners.
Mr. Son's appetite for expansion has often outstripped his financial ability. Even now, he often taps the bond markets, and is carrying about three times as much debt as equity.
If there is a shake-out in the Internet, or if Internet stocks prove to be a bubble that pops, then Softbank may falter. Moreover, as Mr. Son ventures into relatively new territory -- like the stock exchange -- he is taking risks in areas in which he has no proved expertise.
Still, no one seems eager to bet against him. And almost no one is better than he is at adjusting to a new situation; he sometimes comes across as a chameleon.
He can backslap and talk in colloquial English with American investment bankers and then discuss the details of new computer chips with the techies. He can also turn somber and bow and speak in polite Japanese to melt into a Japanese business crowd.
This knack for mixing comes from his personal background, which has haunted and helped him since his days growing up in a small town on the southern Japanese island of Kyushu. Mr. Son's grandparents came to Japan from Korea, where his family had lived for 21 generations after migrating from China.
His father and other Koreans illegally built their houses on land owned by Japan National Railways, which led to a long-running conflict with the authorities. It was on that land that Mr. Son's father raised pigs and chickens and illicitly made sake. The home brew was apparently lucrative, for he became the first person in town to buy a car.
When Mr. Son's family moved out of its Korean neighborhood so he could attend a better school, to try to melt into society the family took a Japanese last name, Yasumoto.
"I was a good student, but in those days I had a darkness in my mind all the time," Mr. Son wrote in an essay in 1992. "It was because of my nationality. When I was with friends, I was very happy. When I came back home alone, I had the feeling that I was hiding something from my friends."
He took on his real Korean-Chinese name, Son, when he went to the United States at 16 to attend high school and then on to the University of California at Berkeley. It was his American experience, he says, that laid the groundwork for his career.
"If I had stayed all the time in Japan," Mr. Son said, "I probably would have become much more conservative, just as other Japanese."
One important element in the effort to change attitudes of young people will be to expand opportunities for them to finance their companies and to reward them with stock options -- and that is where the new stock exchange comes in. In February, Mr. Son met John L. Hilley, an aide to Mr. Zarb for the first time through a mutual friend.
Over dinner at a French restaurant at the Royal Park Hotel, close to Softbank's offices, Mr. Hilley began pouring out his frustrations over trying to break into the Japanese market. He had been in meetings his whole trip and had received very little encouragement.
"I said, 'Maybe we can help, maybe you went to the wrong place,' " Mr. Son recalled. He told Mr. Hilley, "You need someone who has the entrepreneurial spirit to make this happen."
Mr. Son and Mr. Zarb then began talking about setting up a new exchange, an idea made possible by recent changes in the securities regulations under Japan's financial liberalization. The idea also dovetailed with Mr. Son's ambition to help shape electronic brokerage and the Internet in Japan.
Even if this proposal fails and Mr. Son suffers a blow to his reputation, he still has his bet on the Internet. He says that as Internet technology evolves, the potential for returns from the information that travels on the network will be far greater than anything realized so far.
"That's my fortune-telling, " he said. "I'm betting on that."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2594 words

HEADLINE: JOE HILL IN HIGH TECH: A special report.;
Unions Need Not Apply

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
As the labor movement sets its sights on the booming high-technology world, employees like Matt Shea, a 24-year-old software developer, seem ripe for the picking. He often clocks 70-hour weeks, his managers sometimes push him to work past midnight, and he never receives overtime pay.
But ask Mr. Shea whether he wants a union at his workplace, a thriving Internet start-up called Go2Net, and his response is a puzzled expression that says "Does Not Compute." 
 "As far as me personally, and for everyone else here, unions have never come up," said Mr. Shea, who said he loved his job, notwithstanding the sweatshop hours. "Everything I want is offered to me here."
The American labor movement has belatedly recognized that if it is to reverse the decades-long slide in the percentage of workers belonging to unions, it must make some headway in high technology, the economy's fastest-growing sector. To increase their numbers and their influence in politics and at the bargaining table, unions cannot afford to be shut out of the glamorous, powerful high-technology industry, which accounts for an ever-larger share of the work force.
Persuading technology workers to join unions will not be easy, though, because of all that is lavished upon people like Mr. Shea. His job gives him valuable stock options, flexible hours, an excellent medical plan, a sense of family and, perhaps most important, the thrill of building something.
Labor leaders acknowledge that they face an uphill battle -- only a small fraction of the nation's two million computer and software developers, programmers and engineers belongs to labor unions.
But organizers are far from packing their bags in Seattle or Silicon Valley, convinced that many high-technology employees will ultimately warm to labor's message that workers need a collective voice to stand up to management.
In a public relations coup this spring, union organizers trumpeted one of their first successes in high technology when 16 temporary workers at Microsoft became the first group of software workers in a single workplace to call for union representation. Their action reflects a little-understood aspect of high-technology America: while most high-technology workers are contented haves, there are also many discontented have-nots.
Most have-nots come from the sea of long-term temps who work at Microsoft and other high-technology companies, and they often complain of being second-class citizens who receive bare-bones benefits and have no job security or stock options. Microsoft employs 20,500 regular workers domestically and 6,000 temps, who often call themselves permatemps because they work anywhere from six months to three years at the company, testing software, writing manuals, designing Web pages and developing CD-ROM's.
Industry experts estimate that at many companies -- including Compaq Computer, Hewlett-Packard and Intel -- more than 10 percent of the workers are temps.
"The conditions are not the same as where unions have had a lot of success," said Jonathan Rosenblum, organizing director for the King County Labor Council in Seattle, "but that doesn't mean there aren't a lot of substantive issues that concern high-tech workers and make them feel they want to have a voice in their job."
Just as high technology has had vast ripple effects on the way Americans live, it is forcing changes in the American labor movement. Labor's traditional focus has been getting a majority of employees at a work site -- usually full-time workers tied for years to a single employer -- to vote for a union then negotiating a contract for them.
But unions are finding that this model may be as obsolete in high-technology America as a 286 Intel chip because workers jump among companies like honeybees from flower to flower.
Some labor organizers acknowledge that they may never get a majority of workers at start-ups or at giants like Intel to vote in a union. So they are trying to devise new ways to represent high-technology workers.
An innovative example came in February when, seeking to improve benefits for high-technology temps, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s office in Silicon Valley set up an employment agency offering far better benefits than other agencies.
"The way we go to work has changed," said Amy Dean, director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Silicon Valley office. "So we, the labor movement, have to create a response that recognizes that the world has changed, while still embracing the values, like equity and giving workers a voice, that labor has always stood for."
 
The Haves
Big Salaries And Benefits
For Mr. Shea, the 24-year-old software engineer, unions are not so much undesirable as irrelevant.
At Go2Net, he has no out-of-pocket costs for his health or dental plan. He is happy with his flexible hours and two weeks of vacation a year. And he loves working at a start-up where he has a strong sense of making a contribution.
"My goal has always been to develop software that lots of people use," he said. "Here you can see 10,000 people using your software every day."
Nor do his 70-hour weeks make him resent management.
"As far as what gets me up in the morning or what makes me stay up so late, that's a pride issue," said Mr. Shea, who received a bachelor's degree in computer science from the University of California at San Diego. "Last night I was up till 4 A.M. testing a new home page."
The salary of a software Wunderkind like Mr. Shea usually ranges from $50,000 to $100,000 a year, often with stock options that double or triple that amount.
High-technology executives say that one overarching factor works against labor's success: the shortage of skilled software workers. Because demand far outstrips supply, companies often feel they must offer lavish generous salaries and stock options to recruit and retain workers.
"This industry is so damn competitive in seeking the best talent that if you don't give your employees what they want, you'll lose them in a second," said Ethan Caldwell, general counsel of Go2Net, which is known for its Metacrawler search engine and a financial discussion Web site.
At many start-ups, the workplace culture is so worker-friendly that it leaves union organizers out in the cold. High-technology start-ups emphasize hiring entrepreneurial self-starters, the type of employee least likely to turn to unions for help.
High-technology companies also strive to create a sense of family and fun. At many companies, there are free sodas, basketball courts and latte bars. One company took all its workers on a free ski trip when it met a crucial sales goal.
And last -- but certainly not least -- are stock options, a compensation strategy that strengthens loyalty to management and inspires workers to want to build the company.
"For a lot of workers, there's a little bit of a hero's journey, that I can be part of building this thing into a $10 billion company," said Evan Kaplan, chief executive of Aventail, a start-up in Seattle with 100 workers that provides security software for computer systems.
"You try to build a work environment that's fun and challenging and you try to deal with benefits in a way that brings them up to a level that you know is good, which is one of the reasons you don't see a tendency toward unionization," he added.
Another reason unions are not catching fire with high-technology workers is that so many are in their 20's and 30's and grew up when labor's visibility and clout were on the wane. Union anthems like "Solidarity Forever" and "Joe Hill" are as unfamiliar to them as 14th-century madrigals.
"I never think about unions because they were never part of my life," Mr. Shea said.
Many high-technology workers say that if they disliked their job, it would make more sense to hop to another employer than to undertake a unionization drive that could cause a six-month war with management.
"The market is so hot now that if you have the training and job experience, you can walk down the street to the next start-up or to Microsoft and get a job," said Debra Joyce, the 29-year-old manager of information systems at Aventail. "So if you're unhappy, you don't necessarily need union protection."
Despite such a cold shoulder, labor leaders say that the industry's workers will warm to unions when the high-technology boom crests -- when high-technology stocks fall, stock options tumble in value and unemployment rises in the industry, making it harder for unhappy workers to simply jump to other companies.
 
The Have-Nots
For the Temps, Quest for Equity
As five Microsoft temps met with two union organizers at Azteca, a restaurant two minutes from the Microsoft campus, the conversation ranged from mild to militant. Over beer and tortilla chips, they talked of staging a sit-in at a temp agency and of organizing a T-shirt day when dozens of supporters would wear pro-union shirts to Microsoft's main cafeteria.
Mark Turner, a 39-year-old accountant turned software temp who has been at Microsoft since August, explained before the meeting that a mountain of grievances had pushed him and the 15 other workers to back unionization. Unlike regular workers, the temps receive no Microsoft stock options, no pay on sick days and an inferior health plan. Many said they were misclassified into jobs that paid less than they deserved.
"We like what we do, we like our Microsoft managers and we like each other," said Mr. Turner, who complained that he has to pay $3,300 of the nearly $60,000 he earns each year toward health insurance premiums. "If we didn't, we wouldn't be fighting to improve a job we really like. But I believe that without a union we have no shot. They'll just blow us off."
The 16 workers, part of an 18-person team creating a new financial software product, want to be represented by the Washington Alliance of Technology Workers, known as Washtech, a fledgling union with four organizers and a $175,000 annual budget paid for by the Communications Workers of America.
Microsoft is renowned for churning out 30-year-old multimillionaires, but it is also churning out lots of disgruntled temps, and that is fueling the unionization push.
"It's frustrating because you're working side by side with other people who are getting so much more for doing substantially the same thing," said David Larsen, a $15-an-hour temp who has worked as a Microsoft software tester for 18 months. "The company softball field says you can't use it. They give regular employees stock options and discounts on Microsoft products and all we get is an E-mail from our temp agency saying there's a drawing for a free snow board."
Microsoft executives say it makes sense to use thousands of temporary workers because the company has so many projects -- like new software development -- that last six months. While Microsoft's critics insist that the company uses temps to skimp on benefits and severance payments, company executives say using temps is fairer to the workers -- they do not come in thinking they have permanent jobs, only to be laid off once their project ends.
Microsoft is also quick to note that many workers prefer temping to permanent employment because it gives them greater freedom to travel or work on the side and because they can earn lots of overtime pay -- unlike regular Microsoft workers, who are considered salaried professionals.
"I'm happy with being a contractor," said Emmet Skaar, a 32-year-old software tester. "I'm happy being in charge of my own destiny, and I'm very pleased with the compensation package. If these people aren't happy as contractors, they should go get themselves hired as permanent employees."
Discontent among temps has resulted in one lawsuit in which a Federal appeals court has found for the plaintiffs. The court ruled that thousands of workers hired by Microsoft through employment agencies were regular employees rather than temps and should qualify for certain Microsoft benefits, including its discount stock purchase plan.
The two sides are now thrashing out how many tens of millions of dollars Microsoft owes these so-called temps. And Microsoft has adopted a new rule requiring all temps to a 31-day break in their work at least once a year to insure that they can no longer be viewed as regular workers.
"Microsoft is engaged in a pretense about people working for Microsoft not being its employees," said Stephen K. Strong, one of the plaintiffs' lawyers. "If Microsoft provided a reasonable level of benefits to all employees, if Microsoft grew up and acted like the major employer it is and not a small business, no one would be thinking about a union."
 
The Unions
Looking for Ways To Gain Members
Despite the impassioned words from Microsoft's pro-union temps, they face a decided challenge. For one thing, Microsoft insists that their real employer is not Microsoft but their employment agencies.
"Organizing is an issue between an employee and the employer, and in this case the employers are the contingent staffing companies," said Dan Leach, a Microsoft spokesman.
Union organizers fear that if the 16 temps petition for a unionization election, there will be years of litigation to determine who is the employer and whether the appropriate bargaining unit is their 18-worker software group, the 6,000 temps at Microsoft or a 3,000-worker employment agency.
"It's virtually impossible to organize workers in this co-employer setting," said Michael Blain, Washtech's co-founder. "Existing labor law is totally inadequate to address issues of the new economy."
Seeing the difficulties in getting most workers at a high-technology company to vote to unionize, labor leaders are looking to nontraditional ways to build a union. Kirk Adams, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s organizing director, said unions could attract high-technology workers by providing two important benefits: affordable training and mobility of benefits.
In an industry where it is vital to know the latest software-writing languages to advance to higher-paying positions, many temp workers complain about paying for-profit schools $600 for a 10-hour course. (Temps often cannot take the free in-house courses that companies offer.) So Washtech provides such courses for $75 to people who join the new union by agreeing to pay one hour's wages each month; 175 have joined so far and more than 1,000 others have asked to be on the union's electronic mailing list.
Some union leaders talk of creating a high-technology hiring hall, similar to ones in construction, in which companies would contribute to a joint pension and health plan so workers who hop between companies would not lose their pension credits or health insurance.
Larry Cohen, the organizing director for Washtech's parent, the Communications Workers of America, said labor might settle early on for the rudimentary role of creating a collective voice for high-technology workers. Mr. Cohen said such a union, instead of negotiating contracts, would exchange information among members and sometimes speak for them.
"Rather than feel they're just a little boat bobbing in the water," he said, "people could feel they're part of a larger organization that shares their values."
But all these strategies could prove futile because so many high-technology workers view unions as unnecessary.
"I love my job," said Paul Primrose, a customer service worker at Amazon.com. "Some occupations do need unions, but not here. It's because things change so rapidly that you need to change quickly, and unions could get in the way."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Point That Finger

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
We have stumbled into the era of no-fault government. Blamelessness is next to godliness; nobody in authority is held responsible for blunders, no matter how costly.
Take last week's case of the cell biologist at a Berkeley, Calif., lab who was found to have faked his research findings -- supposedly linking electric power to cancer -- to win his lab $3.3 million from three Federal agencies.
A whistle-blower alerted the Office of Research Integrity, which found him "falsifying and fabricating data." The swinging scientist, Robert Liburdy, avoids prosecution by not contesting these findings, though he admits nothing.
Is the lab being forced to return the money to taxpayers? No. Its lawyer tells William Broad of The Times that the unused portion is "being used for other science."
What of those at the Departments of Defense and Energy and the N.I.H. who ladled out the money and now make no effort to recover it? No letter of reprimand for nonfeasance is being placed in anybody's personnel file.
That's typical of no-fault government. I'm not talking about prosecution for criminal wrongdoing -- only the absence of penalty for failure to do one's job.
Another case: The Times's Tim Weiner reported that House Appropriations discovered the Air Force illegally diverting untold millions to a secret "black program." Congress has secure procedures for financing secret operations, but here a Pentagon clique apparently resisted. With unwitting irony, the Pentagon spokesman brushed it off as "an oversight."
Did successive A.F. Chiefs of Staff know of this misuse of funds? Did Senate Armed Services ask the Acting Secretary, Whitten Peters, about this during confirmation? If those in command were in the dark, shouldn't they be publicly reprimanded, if only as an example to other easily duped administrators?
But that would be "finger-pointing," now a bureaucratic no-no. Only institutions may be chastised in this blame-free society -- not those individuals wrapped in anonymity who make the costly mistakes.
Remember that cruise missile President Clinton launched to take out a suspected terrorist target in Khartoum in Sudan? The pharmaceutical plant, Al Shifa, was destroyed with great precision.
But it turns out somebody goofed. The plant really was making medicines and we are now quietly paying the Sudanese compensation. We can presume no evil intent -- not even a Presidential attempt to change the subject -- only a disastrous misjudgment.
How should you assign blame when identification of those responsible might endanger their lives? In that case, Richard Clarke, who is Samuel Berger's counterterrorism chief at the National Security Council, should come forward to say:
"An outside task force has examined mistakes made both in collection and evaluation of evidence. Its top-secret report has been made to the intelligence committees of the House and Senate, which can make their own judgments. We have also spelled out the procedures newly designed to avoid any repeat of this failure."
That would make certain that those responsible know exactly what they did wrong, and know that a repeat of the mistake will result in transfer to a less dangerous line of work. Such corrective is necessary training; its avoidance promotes incompetence.
The same approach should apply to the sequence of breakdowns in collection of intelligence and command decision-making that led to the mistaken bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade.
As of now, some sort of explanation has been provided to Beijing as part of our groveling process. But Chinese intelligence, which lost three of its best operatives (under journalistic cover) in the bombing, guiltily suspects we wanted to close down its secret operation that may have been aiding the Serbs. That fitted neatly into Beijing's need to whip up nationalist fervor against the West to divert its people's minds from deflation and the spiritual pull of Falun Gong.
For the sake of improvement of our own military intelligence -- and not to prolong the kowtowing -- the N.S.C. should lay the facts before Congressional overseers. Bumbling is forgivable only if it leads to specific acknowledgment of error, even if in secret.
Enough of this evasion of accountability as "the blame game" and airy dismissal of responsibility as "who-shot-John." Finding fault now averts greater fault later.

HEADLINE: Progress on Presidential Pay

 BODY:
The next American President, whoever that turns out to be, will be getting a raise. Thanks to a bipartisan vote by the House earlier this month, Bill Clinton's successor will be making twice what Mr. Clinton does -- $400,000 a year, which is also twice what the country has paid its Presidents for the past three decades.
Although a substantial increase, it is fully justified. Even the new Presidential salary does not begin to approach the huge amounts earned these days by many corporate executives. Nor does it approach the nearly $900,000 the President would be earning if the current $200,000 salary fixed in 1969 had been adjusted for inflation. The House showed respect for the singular role of the Presidency by increasing the spread between the chief executive's pay and the salaries of other top Federal officials. Cabinet officers now make $151,800. These salaries could well be increased in the future. 
 The House also overcame its normal political jitters about raising its own pay. In a 276-to-147 vote, it blocked an effort by some junior Republicans to reject the cost-of-living increase that current law automatically provides unless Congress explicitly votes to deny it. With the increase, the pay of most lawmakers will rise to $141,300. Congressional leaders will earn somewhat more.
But the House pay package, which is part of a Treasury Department spending bill that now goes to conference with the Senate, has one glaring omission. It does not include a cost-of-living increase for Federal judges, whose salaries historically have been linked to those of lawmakers. House and Senate conferees should take steps to remedy this, mindful of a recent Federal District Court decision that found that Congress exceeded its authority and shortchanged Federal judges by denying them several past cost-of-living increases.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Vietnam Agree in Principle on Trade Pact

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, July 25

 BODY:
After three years of wrangling, the United States and Vietnam announced today that they had reached agreement in principle on a trade accord.
The tentative deal, which still requires approval by the United States Congress and Vietnam's National Assembly, is considered the last major step in normalizing relations after the Vietnam War, which ended more than 24 years ago. 
 It also could pave the way for Vietnam, one of the world's poorest nations, to join the World Trade Organization.
"We in the U.S. believe this agreement will assist in the transformation and modernization of Vietnam," said the Deputy United States Trade Representative, Richard Fischer.
Work began in 1996 on the trade pact, which would give normal trading status -- formally known as most favored nation status -- to Vietnam. Only a few countries, including Cuba and North Korea, do not have such status with the United States.
That would give Vietnamese exporters entry to the huge American domestic market and grant improved access to the Vietnamese market for American companies.
Vietnam began opening its markets in the mid-1980's under a restructuring process but has been hit hard by the fallout from the Asian financial crisis.
The pace of reform has slowed to a crawl in the last two years, and the Government has been under growing pressure to move more quickly, particularly in restructuring the debt-ridden banking system and improving competitiveness of losing state-owned enterprises.
With declines in foreign investment and exports and a rise in unemployment, the Government is eager for the hundreds of millions of dollars the agreement is expected to infuse into the economy.
Talks had stalled over Vietnam's tariffs and unwillingness to open its markets to American investment and services, along with fears that its fledgling businesses would be at a disadvantage in competing with American companies.
Vietnamese legislative changes are likely to be necessary, along with major reforms in Customs and the financial sector.
Most experts agree that Vietnamese industries are not yet ready to compete with major international companies but say competition would be one of the best ways to help them get up to world standards.
The ninth round of talks between American and Vietnamese trade officials began on Tuesday. After the last round of talks ended in March, officials said they largely had the framework of a deal but still were far apart on a handful of contentious issues.
Experts have said that if an agreement is not signed this year, the American Presidential elections next year will draw attention away from the talks.
The agreement, which is about 100 pages long, will need to undergo official translation before being signed, probably in September, and presented to both countries' legislatures. Without snags, it could go into effect early next year.

HEADLINE: In Scenes Of Tumult, Moroccans Bury King

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER and DOUGLAS JEHL

DATELINE: RABAT, Morocco, July 25

 BODY:
Marching under a merciless sun through streets thronged by hundreds of thousands of mourners, President Clinton and President Jacques Chirac of France led an assemblage of dozens of kings and princes, presidents and prime ministers for the burial of King Hassan II of Morocco today.
A gun carriage bore the King's coffin, which was draped with a thick black blanket embroidered with verses from the Koran, and members of the royal court chanted Muslim liturgy and the Moroccan national anthem. 
 As the funeral procession moved slowly through Rabat, Morocco's capital, the multitudes chanted "God is great," wailed and waved flags and scarves.
At times the surging crowds appeared to press in on Mr. Clinton, Mr. Chirac and other dignitaries following the King's coffin, giving rise to Secret Service concerns about the President's safety.
Joe Lockhart, the White House press secretary, said Mr. Clinton was well protected by the Secret Service and was determined to take part in the procession "as a mark of respect" to the late King and his successor and as a statement of support to the Moroccan people.
Former President George Bush, who also made the three-mile walk, said that he was "not at all concerned" about his own safety and that he believed that Mr. Clinton "did exactly the right thing."
The King's coffin was preceded by a gilt carriage carrying the new Moroccan ruler, King Hassan's 36-year-old son, King Mohammed VI. The carriage was drawn by four white horses and was accompanied by military honor guards in colorful uniforms.
It was the second time in less than six months that world leaders had gathered to mourn the passing of an epoch-making Arab monarch. The death of King Hussein of Jordan in February after a 47-year reign produced similar scenes of public mourning and impromptu meetings of heads of state.
Virtually all Moroccan businesses were closed today in observance of the King's death, which came Friday after four years of deteriorating health. But the work of diplomacy continued as leaders conducted unscheduled conversations between their funeral duties.
The scenes outside the capital were almost as extraordinary as those in Rabat. To pay their last respects, thousands of people made their way by foot along a highway that had been closed to all but official traffic. Some had begun their journey as far away as Casablanca, 60 miles to the south.
"He was like a father," said Youssef Mohammed, 25, who said he would walk all the way to Rabat if necessary to say farewell to the late King.
As they awaited the beginning of the funeral procession from the royal palace to the burial ground, Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, were seen in an animated discussion with Mr. Clinton in a room in the palace.
An anticipated meeting between Mr. Clinton and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria did not happen, however. Mr. Assad remained in Damascus. Mr. Clinton did not meet with the Syrian officials who attended the funeral. "He certainly would have if he had seen them, but we didn't see them," said Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser.
Mr. Clinton had brief discussions with a series of other leaders, but Administration officials said that they were not particularly substantive, given the nature of the event and the large number of people involved. Aides said that Mr. Clinton encouraged Mr. Barak and Mr. Arafat to continue their efforts at resolving Israeli-Palestinian disputes, but did not offer specific formulas for achieving progress.
Russia was represented by Yegor Stryoyev, the President of the Russian Senate. President Boris N. Yeltsin attended the funeral of King Hussein in Amman in February, but he was obviously frail at the time.
Dennis Ross, the Administration's special coordinator for Middle East negotiations, said the most noteworthy aspect of today's gathering was that it brought the Israeli Prime Minister in contact with Arab leaders in an atmosphere lacking in the tension that has long marked Israel's relations with its neighbors.
"Barak mingled easily with all leaders there; you didn't see barriers," Mr. Ross said. "That is in no small part a tribute to King Hassan and what he represented."
Before leaving Rabat, Mr. Clinton held short private meetings with Mr. Arafat; Abderrahmane Youssoufi, the Prime Minister of Morocco; and Abdelaziz Bouteflika, the new President of Algeria.
The rapidly assembled American delegation included the First Lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, and the Clintons' daughter, Chelsea. Mr. Bush and two former Secretaries of State, Warren Christopher and James A. Baker 3d, also flew here aboard Air Force I to attend the rites.
They were met at Rabat's military airport by Prince Moulay Rachid, the 29-year-old brother of the new King.
Mrs. Clinton was accorded a rare honor for a woman of an audience with the new King. She also paid a condolence call on the King's widow and other women of the family.
The President and Mrs. Clinton met with the new King for about five minutes after paying respects to the body of the late King, which lay in state in the ornate throne room of the Royal Palace.
In Muslim societies, women are strictly segregated from men at religious observances, particularly funerals.
Mrs. Clinton had been a guest of the King during a visit here in April. She said today that she was happy to return to Morocco, "but sorry that it is for such a sad occasion."
Mr. Clinton cut short a weekend of recreation and fund-raising in Aspen, Colo., to attend the funeral. The President's weekend began with a memorial service for John F. Kennedy Jr. in New York on Friday.
In remarks to staff members of the American Embassy here after the funeral, the President said that the late King had been known as the "great survivor," having outlasted most of the enemies who had fatal designs on him.
But Mr. Clinton said that description did not do the King justice because he did not merely survive, but used his reign to improve the lives of his subjects and build ties with other Arab nations and with Israel.
"He was never embittered by the dangers he faced and over time he grew in wisdom, stature and standing in the world, and as he grew, so did Morocco," the President said.
Mr. Clinton said he had confidence in the new King and had told him this afternoon that he expected that the partnership between Morocco and the United States "will only grow stronger."
King Hassan served as a bridge between Israel and Egypt in the secret diplomacy leading up to President Anwar el-Sadat's path-breaking visit to Jerusalem in 1977 and the Camp David accord of 1978.
King Hassan was the Arab world's longest-serving monarch, having ruled for 38 years that were marked by half a dozen coup attempts, social upheaval and economic progress for many of Morocco's 29 million citizens.
Mr. Clinton said that the deaths this year of King Hassan and King Hussein represented the passing of an old order and expressed optimism that their successors would continue their legacy of moderation and recognition of Israel.
"I think the important thing is that Morocco has been a model of reconciliation within the country and a model of partnership and friendship for peace in the Middle East," he said. "And I think that direction will continue."
King Hassan was buried alongside the onyx tomb of his father, King Mohammed V, who died in 1961, in a massive mausoleum designed by Vo To An, a Vietnamese architect, and built beginning in 1962.
The burial chamber is surrounded by a white marble pavilion covered with a roof of typical Moroccan green tiles. The ceiling of the chamber is formed of intricately carved mahogany covered with gold leaf fashioned by hundreds of craftsmen from throughout Morocco.
The entombment of King Hassan was attended by a small group of male family members, courtiers and Muslim foreigners, including Mr. Arafat. The sound was piped outside to tens of thousands gathered in the pavilion, and Moroccan television cameras recorded scene inside for the millions of Moroccans watching in their homes.

HEADLINE: U.S. AND CHINA SAY THEY ARE MENDING POST-BOMBING RIFT

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, July 25

 BODY:
At their first high-level encounter since the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, the United States and China today depicted their tattered relationship as improved, despite important differences, and announced that President Clinton would meet the Chinese leader Jiang Zemin in September.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright met here over what she described as a "very friendly lunch" with the Chinese Foreign Minister, Tang Jiaxuan, for two hours and afterward told a news conference that there was "an easing of tensions." 
 "We were able to restore a level of communication we had before" the bombing, she said.
For his part, Mr. Tang announced Mr. Clinton's meeting with President Jiang in New Zealand at September's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. Some doubt had been cast on whether these long-planned talks would actually proceed given Chinese fury over NATO's mistaken bombing of the embassy in Belgrade in May during the war against Yugoslavia over Kosovo.
The hottest issue on today's agenda was Taiwan. Ms. Albright pointedly took issue with Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, who two weeks ago renounced the "one China" policy, which says the Chinese mainland and Taiwan are two parts of the same country.
The United States has since urged Mr. Lee to soften his language, but Ms. Albright did not seem to think he has done so sufficiently. "I think the explanations offered thus far don't quite do it," she told the news conference, referring to Mr. Lee's most recent comments.
Mr. Lee said at the end of last week that he agreed to the idea of eventual reunification of China and Taiwan, but he defended his new position that contact between the two should be on a "state-to-state" basis.
Ms. Albright and Mr. Tang were attending the annual meeting of foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, a group of 10 countries that invites other nations -- for instance, the United States, China, Japan and Russia -- to its major gatherings.
The fragile condition of the Washington-Beijing relationship is one topic dominating this year's meeting, along with prospects of North Korea testing a long-range ballistic missile this summer.
For the Clinton Administration, Ms. Albright's meeting with Mr. Tang was a barometer of whether Washington's efforts to rebuild the relationship with Beijing were working. There was already a sign last week that things were looking up when Mr. Jiang, who had refused a phone call from Mr. Clinton immediately after the embassy bombing, spoke to the President by telephone.

 Mr. Tang is not a powerful member of the Beijing Government, but Washington officials said the tone of his presentation to Ms. Albright and to the press afterward appeared thoroughly calibrated. A Clinton Administration official who was present at today's meeting said that Mr. Tang appeared to adhere closely to his "talking points," a reference to the carefully prepared script that officials take to important meetings.
Mr. Tang said at his news conference that Taiwan was "key" to the improvement of the Beijing-Washington relationship.
Indeed, the declaration by the Taiwanese leader, Mr. Lee, that he was no longer abiding by the "one China" policy gave the Clinton Administration a wedge to use with Beijing. In his news conference last week, Mr. Clinton articulated the "one China" policy that China favors. The President also delayed the scheduled visit of Pentagon officials to Taiwan, a move designed to impress the Chinese.
Ms. Albright apparently tried a similar technique in person with Mr. Tang. She said she repeated Washington's position on Taiwan -- that Washington stands by the "one China" policy, encourages direct dialogue between the mainland and Taiwan and desires a peaceful resolution.
Mr. Lee's reversal has caused consternation because Beijing has always insisted that it would use force if Taiwan declared independence. Ms. Albright said that Mr. Tang reiterated that stance today.
The policy allowing Beijing and Taipei to maintain that each is a legitimate ruler of the other has been the cornerstone of American policy for more than two decades.
At his news conference, conducted almost exclusively in Chinese, Mr. Tang broke into English for a moment when he said that Ms. Albright should understand that Mr. Lee was a "troublemaker" for relations between China and the United States. He added that he warned Ms. Albright that the United States should be "very careful not to say anything to fan the flames" of independence.
On another subject, Ms. Albright said she expressed concern to Mr. Tang about the rights to free assembly and expression in light of the Chinese Government's crackdown against followers of the Buddhist Law movement, Falun Gong.
Ms. Albright apparently did not make a lot of headway on China's demand for compensation for the bombing of the embassy in Belgrade. Three Chinese were killed in the attack, which was caused, according to the Director of Central Intelligence, George Tenet, by faulty map reading and other mistakes at his agency.
Mr. Tenet's admission last week appeared designed in part to mollify Chinese demands that the Clinton Administration assign blame and punish those responsible for the bombing.
Mr. Tang said he "noted and attached importance" to Ms. Albright's explanations of the bombing, but added that China was not yet satisfied.
The Secretary said that the State Department's legal counsel, David Andrews, would return to Beijing within the next week to explore a solution. Mr. Andrews was part of a team that went to Beijing earlier this month to try to explain how the bombing happened and to settle the Chinese demands for compensation. The explanations were rebuffed, and the Chinese have signaled that the bombing is one subject to be settled before Beijing will consider reopening talks on accession to the World Trade Organization.
China's admission to the 134-member group that governs the way global commerce is conducted is a major concern of both Beijing and the Clinton Administration. The Administration would like China to join as a way of opening China's huge markets but decided last spring, during a visit by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, that concessions to open up China's economy to foreign investors were not sufficient. Talks on China's membership have been stalled ever since.
Mr. Tang said he was "surprised" that Ms. Albright did not raise the World Trade Organization today, and said it was up to Washington "to create the necessary atmosphere for resumption of negotiations."
On fears that North Korea may be about to test another ballistic missile, Ms. Albright said she had discussed the problem with Mr. Tang. A senior Clinton Administration official who was present said the minister suggested that China and the United States shared a common interest in keeping the North Koreans from going ahead with the test.
Washington regards Beijing as central to its efforts to persuade North Korea not to conduct the test, but today China's Foreign Minister was not forthcoming on how Beijing may be exercising its influence, officials said.
Ms. Albright also met today with India's Foreign Minister, Jaswant Singh, who expressed appreciation for the role the Administration played in trying to resolve the fighting in Kashmir, an Administration official said. They also discussed, he said, the likelihood of a visit to South Asia by President Clinton -- probably early next year.
