HEADLINE: Clinton Says No To Any Tax Cut Of $500 Billion

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration said for the first time today that it would not accept a compromise $500 billion tax-cut plan proposed by a group of Senate Democrats, virtually assuring that the debate over how to spend the projected budget surplus will not be settled quickly or easily.
"The President will veto a $500 billion tax cut because it doesn't leave room for what's necessary," said Lawrence H. Summers, the Treasury Secretary. 
 Echoing that statement, Gene Sperling, the White House economic adviser, said, "The President will veto a tax cut of $800 billion or $500 billion because it threatens our ability to secure Medicare and Social Security and pay down our national debt."
Before today the White House had said it favored limiting any tax cut to about $300 billion but had never said it would reject the Senate Democrats' compromise. The Senate Democratic leadership has also said it favors a tax cut plan of about $300 billion.
About a half-dozen Senate Democrats who have often been at odds with the Administration proposed the plan earlier this month to cut taxes by $500 billion over 10 years, as a way to bridge the gap between the $792 billion cut approved by the House of Representatives and the $250 billion to $300 billion proposal offered by the White House.
But for the compromise to have had any chance of being accepted, either the White House or the Republican leadership in Congress had to endorse it. The Senate Republicans have already rejected the plan, and today's statements from the White House mean the proposal is most likely dead.
Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana continued to promote the $500 billion plan today, arguing that it would "give us enough money to address Medicare, prescription drugs, and also give us enough money for discretionary spending."
But Senator Breaux, a member of the Finance Committee, added that without a compromise "we are headed for a major train wreck, which I think would be terrible for the American people. Here we have a trillion-dollar surplus, and the two political parties in Washington can't figure out what to do with it."
Mr. Breaux and Mr. Summers spoke on the CBS program "Face the Nation." Mr. Sperling appeared on the Fox Sunday news program.
The Government's current estimates project a surplus of $2.9 trillion over the next 10 years, and that has set off the loud and contentious debate over how the money should be spent. Both party proposals are mirrors of their basic philosophies, and both are addressing the issue with the 2000 elections clearly in mind.
Speaking of the House tax cut bill on CNN today, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, said, "There's so much compassion in this package that I have to tell you, my heart warms."
Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, who is chairman of the Budget Committee, said, "Frankly, if we don't do something like this, I think the American people can justifiably ask: Who is going to spend the surplus?"
Republicans are trying to make the argument that, without a tax cut, the budget surplus will be squandered by Democratic spending programs. "And the important thing is," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, "if you create all these new programs, you'll never get the money back."
Democrats contend that the budget projections are just that -- uncertain looks at the future of the economy. Therefore, large tax cuts are risky. But Senator Gramm proposed a solution. "If you give it back to the American people," he said, referring to the surplus, "if you ever really needed it you could get it back by raising taxes."
With the White House promise to veto the $500 billion tax cut proposal proffered by some in Mr. Clinton's own party, and no other compromise on the table, both sides turned to harsh rhetoric.
In his radio address on Saturday, the President called the Republican tax-cut plan "reckless," adding that "it would require dramatic cuts in vital areas, such as education, the environment, biomedical research, defense and crime fighting."
Senator Gramm appeared with Mr. Sperling on the Fox show this morning and said the Administration's arguments were "like everything else you all do. It's totally dishonest. You guys are shameless, shameless."
Senator Breaux suggested that both sides postpone the debate until the fall and then take it up in the context of related issues.
Under that plan, he said: "You don't have a veto, you don't have an agreement. You just take the time off in August to take a breath of fresh air and listen to the people back home, come back in September and let us do a real Medicare reform bill with prescription drugs."
After that, Senator Breaux added, Congress could tackle the tax-cut question. That would force the Republicans to defend their tax-cut plans at the same time they try to reach agreement on the next Federal budget, a process that requires painful choices about which Federal programs to support and which to cut.
Responding to the Senator's proposal, Senator Domenici said, "What I would say right here is I would have no trouble working with this Senator," adding that his suggestion "is probably very constructive."

HEADLINE: Voters Push Power Toward Venezuela Leader

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 25

 BODY:
In a vote that President Hugo Chavez called "the most important of the past 100 years" for Venezuela, his followers have won an overwhelming majority of seats in a national assembly that will write the new constitution he says he needs to carry out a sweeping "social revolution."
With more than four-fifths of the vote counted tonight, candidates from Mr. Chavez's populist Patriotic Pole coalition had won three-quarters of the seats for which official results were available. In a victory speech from the balcony of the presidential palace tonight, a jubilant Mr. Chavez predicted that the final count would end up giving his alliance more than 120 of the 131 seats that were at stake. 
 "The victory of the patriots has been pulverizing," he said, his wife, Marisabel, who was one of the most successful of the candidates, at his side.
"It's a home run with the bases loaded," he added.
The results promise immediately to usher in a period of conflict and uncertainty for Venezuela, which has become the largest source of imported oil for the United States in recent years.
Since being sworn into office in February, Mr. Chavez, a former army colonel who led a failed coup attempt in 1992, has repeatedly maintained that the constituent assembly will have the power to dissolve Congress and courts and should do so, a position he mentioned again tonight in his speech.
The Supreme Court has already ruled that Mr. Chavez's argument is legally faulty. But in a speech delivered Saturday night to commemorate the 216th anniversary of the birth of Simon Bolivar, the founding father of this South American nation of 23 million, Mr. Chavez reiterated his position, saying that the assembly will have absolute authority during the six months of its existence.
"This has to be very clear, because this is a process with no turning back," he said emphatically. "Neither the President nor Congress nor the Supreme Court, which are the maximum representatives of the constituted powers, can contrive to place themselves above, or put into a subordinate position, a sovereign elected assembly."
Today, though, the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, Cecilia Sosa Gomez, once again rejected the President's interpretation. While stressing to the reporters who crowded around her as she waited to cast her vote that "we do not want to get into a debate of a political nature," she said, "The court has already given answers to all pending questions."
The assembly's responsibility, she said, is to draw up a new constitution, not to supplant existing institutions or to govern the country. Until the new charter has been written and approved by voters, she added, "the Supreme Court will carry out its duties in accordance with the Constitution of 1961."
Mr. Chavez said he intends to place his own job as President "at the disposition of this most sovereign assembly" and will resign if that is what the 131-member assembly wants. The offer is purely symbolic, since the assembly will be dominated by his own followers, but it will increase the pressure on the other two branches of Government not to challenge the deliberations of the assembly, scheduled to begin work early next month.
As a presidential candidate last year, Mr. Chavez made a new constitution the focal point of his campaign, saying he needed it to end corruption and assure social justice for the poor. Other changes he has said he wants would give him the right to succeed himself in office and would vastly expand his power at the expense of the legislature and judiciary.
The constituent assembly vote, the fourth election in less than a year here, has dominated news coverage for weeks, with many of the more than 1,000 candidates distributing posters, T-shirts and baseball caps with their images and organizing forums to discuss the issues.
Despite the intense coverage and generally favorable weather, though, it is estimated that fewer than half of the 11 million eligible voters cast ballots today.
Although the political climate here is increasingly polarized, today's vote took place without incident.
"I cast all of my votes for the Chavez slate, which is the only one that I trust to fight for the change we need so badly in this country," Darwin Gomez Uribe, an unemployed mechanic, said as he emerged from a polling place here. "I want the President to have a free hand to throw out the old system and replace it with one that will create jobs and end this dictatorship of corrupt political parties."
In his final speech before voting began, Mr. Chavez sought to frame the choice facing Venezuelans in the starkest terms possible. "You are either with God or the devil," he said. "There are only two positions here in Venezuela: those of us who want profound transformation and those who refuse to lose their privileges."
Some voters, however, said they found the President's pugnacious tone troublesome. Mr. Chavez's opponents say that he wants to replace an imperfect democracy with a one-man dictatorship, and they contend that the assembly is the country's last chance to avoid authoritarian rule.
"I agree that the country needs to be transformed, but I do not like the way the President is trying to do it," said Gloria Mercado Chacon, a bookkeeper, as she waited in line to cast her ballot for a mixture of pro- and anti-Chavez candidates this morning. "Our new system must be built on the basis of concord and cooperation, not confrontation and conflict."

HEADLINE: Reform Party Takes Decisive Turn From Perot to Ventura

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., July 25

 BODY:
In a raucous rejection of Ross Perot, delegates to the Reform Party's national convention voted overwhelmingly today to install a chairman backed by the party's new star, Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota.
The vote is a significant setback for Mr. Perot, who won 19 percent of the vote in the 1992 Presidential election, more than any other independent Presidential candidate since 1912. His two campaigns, the second one in 1996, were memorable for his use of charts and graphs, and for some of the lines he delivered in debates -- saying he was "all ears," promising to "get under the hood" of the national economy and declaring that the national debt was like a "crazy aunt in the basement." 
 The fresh leadership can be expected to try to make the Reform Party much more attractive to potential third-party candidates next year. The outcome of today's race was closely watched because the Reform Party can claim one of the great pinatas in politics: its nominee is eligible for $12.6 million in Federal money, based on Mr. Perot's showing in his 1996 bid for President.
Several of the more conservative Republican candidates for President have weighed the possibility of switching to an independent bid, and Senator Robert C. Smith of New Hampshire left the Republican Party this month and is now running as an independent.
Lowell P. Weiker Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the former independent Governor of Connecticut, who has said he is considering seeking the Reform Party nomination for President.
Draft movements are under way for Donald J. Trump, the flamboyant developer, and Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate.
The three-day convention featured a showdown between Mr. Perot's loyalists and backers of Mr. Ventura, the party's only major electoral success story. The 400 delegates elected John J. Gargan, 68, known as Jack, who had promised to move the party's headquarters from Dallas, Mr. Perot's base, to his own home state, Florida.
In a pointed reference to Mr. Perot's staff, Mr. Gargan, whose supporters wore "Gargan's Geezers" T-shirts, criticized "control freaks" in the party. In a speech before the vote, he called Mr. Ventura's victory "not only the greatest thing that's happened to this party but the greatest thing that's happened to the third-party movement."
"He has blown away forever that old Republican and Democratic lie that says your vote doesn't count for a third-party candidate," Mr. Gargan said. To capitalize on Mr. Ventura's momentum, especially among young voters, he said he planned a national advertising campaign for the party.
Mr. Gargan took 61 percent of the vote in a runoff against Patricia R. Benjamin of Cherry Hill, N.J., who had been endorsed by the party's founding chairman, Russell G. Verney, who is also Mr. Perot's spokesman. Thomas J. McLaughlin of Bartonsville, Pa., lost in the first round.
Mr. Verney said today that Mr. Perot would have no comment on the results of the party election.
Mr. Gargan, a retired financial consultant from Cedar Key, Fla., is best known for having bought full-page newspaper advertisements throughout the country in 1991 calling for term limits for members of Congress. In a reference to his signature on the advertisements, he was nominated today as "Jack 'Mad as Hell' Gargan." In his speech, he came across as down-to-earth and noted playfully, "I do have an eye for the ladies."
The Reform Party grew out of petition drives for the Presidential bids of Mr. Perot, 69, who drew 19 percent of the vote in 1992 and 8 percent in 1996. Today, members said they were grateful to Mr. Perot but it was time for new blood.
"A man must know his time," said Greg Brown, the Oklahoma state chairman. "He exits the stage to applause."
Supporters of Mr. Perot wore "Ross Was Right" buttons, and some put "Remember Ross?" posters in the windows of their campers, parked in the front lot of the Hyatt Regency hotel here, where the convention was held. Mr. Ventura's fans sported T-shirts from his campaign for governor, with his promise to "Retaliate in '98."
Partly because of the bounding economy and the centrist stands of the leading candidates in both major parties, Vice President Al Gore for the Democrats and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas for the Republicans, pollsters have found mixed signals about the potential for a third-party candidate this year. But Michael Harrison, the publisher of Talkers magazine, the trade journal of talk radio, said that people were hungry for some excitement, and that as a result the Reform Party candidate would at least be guaranteed tremendous attention.
"The opportunity for a third party is better than ever," Mr. Harrison said. "This race is the old versus the old, the inside versus the inside. There's a terrible feeling of letdown, because there's nothing to talk about."
Governor Ventura, 48, has said he will not seek the Presidency this year, but many party members hope he will run in 2004. Mr. Ventura's two top political aides buzzed around the convention, one gumming an unlighted cigar and the other wearing a black "Jesse Ventura, Man of Action" polo shirt. Their mission was to help the party attract a Presidential candidate who would draw at least 5 percent of the vote, preserving its Federal financing and its ballot slots.
As a sign of the tension that fueled Mr. Gargan's candidacy, the convention was hamstrung by infighting and administrative matters. Bickering E-mail with headings like "Re: Mavis' Reply to Kevin" was run off by the hundreds and circulated as campaign fliers.
All Saturday was spent wrangling over what factions from which states would be seated as delegates, and what the parliamentary rules would be. The convention did not take up its platform -- the issues to motivate its members and perhaps lure new ones -- until 10:43 on Saturday night.
The distractions did not discourage one of the Reform Party's more serious strategists, Michael Zumbluskas, 39, of Manhattan's Upper East Side, who ran unsuccessfully for vice chairman as "Big Z." He said he hoped to take advantage of term limits to help win two City Council seats for the party.
"There are a lot of crackpots in the party -- I should say zealots," Mr. Zumbluskas said. "But I'm not playing on the Internet, or worrying about the rules. I'm out recruiting people for the party."
Off the convention floor, the chief activity was a series of draft movements encouraging famous names to seek the party's Presidential nomination. Perhaps the largest movement was for Mr. Trump, a Republican who has supported Democrats, and who said in an interview that he had no interest in running. A "Trump Tribune" was circulated, and supporters put out position papers for him, based on quotations they found on the Internet. Ira J. Cohen, 65, passed along a rumor that Mr. Trump was willing to commit $40 million "to save the Reform Party."
Reached on an airplane, Mr. Trump sounded taken aback but was coy. "I don't know anything about what's happening," he said. "But I'm nevertheless greatly honored by all the hoopla for Trump."
Patricia Cummings of Gaithersburg, Md., has never talked to Gen. Colin L. Powell, a Republican who has said he will never run for national office. But she held a news conference to announce a movement to draft him, and named herself national chairman. She vowed to collect the signatures of 500 people who would each give $50.
Another draft was under way for Mr. Nader.
One of the more serious efforts was launched on behalf of Pat Buchanan, the conservative Republican Presidential candidate, with a champagne reception thrown by William von Raab of Virginia, who was United States Customs Commissioner from 1980 to 1989.
Mr. von Raab's group blanketed the convention with circulars denigrating Mr. Weiker. Mr. von Raab's group attacked Mr. Weicker as a liberal tax-raiser who is "wrong for reform."

HEADLINE: Clinton Says No To Any Tax Cut Of $500 Billion

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration said for the first time today that it would not accept a compromise $500 billion tax-cut plan proposed by a group of Senate Democrats, virtually assuring that the debate over how to spend the projected budget surplus will not be settled quickly or easily.
"The President will veto a $500 billion tax cut because it doesn't leave room for what's necessary," said Lawrence H. Summers, the Treasury Secretary. 
 Echoing that statement, Gene Sperling, the White House economic adviser, said, "The President will veto a tax cut of $800 billion or $500 billion because it threatens our ability to secure Medicare and Social Security and pay down our national debt."
Before today the White House had said it favored limiting any tax cut to about $300 billion but had never said it would reject the Senate Democrats' compromise. The Senate Democratic leadership has also said it favors a tax cut plan of about $300 billion.
About a half-dozen Senate Democrats who have often been at odds with the Administration proposed the plan earlier this month to cut taxes by $500 billion over 10 years, as a way to bridge the gap between the $792 billion cut approved by the House of Representatives and the $250 billion to $300 billion proposal offered by the White House.
But for the compromise to have had any chance of being accepted, either the White House or the Republican leadership in Congress had to endorse it. The Senate Republicans have already rejected the plan, and today's statements from the White House mean the proposal is most likely dead.
Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana continued to promote the $500 billion plan today, arguing that it would "give us enough money to address Medicare, prescription drugs, and also give us enough money for discretionary spending."
But Senator Breaux, a member of the Finance Committee, added that without a compromise "we are headed for a major train wreck, which I think would be terrible for the American people. Here we have a trillion-dollar surplus, and the two political parties in Washington can't figure out what to do with it."
Mr. Breaux and Mr. Summers spoke on the CBS program "Face the Nation." Mr. Sperling appeared on the Fox Sunday news program.
The Government's current estimates project a surplus of $2.9 trillion over the next 10 years, and that has set off the loud and contentious debate over how the money should be spent. Both party proposals are mirrors of their basic philosophies, and both are addressing the issue with the 2000 elections clearly in mind.
Speaking of the House tax cut bill on CNN today, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, said, "There's so much compassion in this package that I have to tell you, my heart warms."
Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, who is chairman of the Budget Committee, said, "Frankly, if we don't do something like this, I think the American people can justifiably ask: Who is going to spend the surplus?"
Republicans are trying to make the argument that, without a tax cut, the budget surplus will be squandered by Democratic spending programs. "And the important thing is," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, "if you create all these new programs, you'll never get the money back."
Democrats contend that the budget projections are just that -- uncertain looks at the future of the economy. Therefore, large tax cuts are risky. But Senator Gramm proposed a solution. "If you give it back to the American people," he said, referring to the surplus, "if you ever really needed it you could get it back by raising taxes."
With the White House promise to veto the $500 billion tax cut proposal proffered by some in Mr. Clinton's own party, and no other compromise on the table, both sides turned to harsh rhetoric.
In his radio address on Saturday, the President called the Republican tax-cut plan "reckless," adding that "it would require dramatic cuts in vital areas, such as education, the environment, biomedical research, defense and crime fighting."
Senator Gramm appeared with Mr. Sperling on the Fox show this morning and said the Administration's arguments were "like everything else you all do. It's totally dishonest. You guys are shameless, shameless."
Senator Breaux suggested that both sides postpone the debate until the fall and then take it up in the context of related issues.
Under that plan, he said: "You don't have a veto, you don't have an agreement. You just take the time off in August to take a breath of fresh air and listen to the people back home, come back in September and let us do a real Medicare reform bill with prescription drugs."
After that, Senator Breaux added, Congress could tackle the tax-cut question. That would force the Republicans to defend their tax-cut plans at the same time they try to reach agreement on the next Federal budget, a process that requires painful choices about which Federal programs to support and which to cut.
Responding to the Senator's proposal, Senator Domenici said, "What I would say right here is I would have no trouble working with this Senator," adding that his suggestion "is probably very constructive."

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
An Entrepreneurial Exception Rides The Internet in Japan

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 25

 BODY:
Masayoshi Son seems an unlikely deal maker in the bubbly and free-spirited world of the Internet.
Short, boyish-looking and soft-spoken, Mr. Son -- while in Japan -- wears the Japanese business uniform of a white shirt and an immaculately pressed black suit. In public, he sometimes stands stiffly and smiles only slightly. He bows often to emphasize his humility. 
 Moreover, he lives in Tokyo, the risk-averse capital of the world, where the Internet is still a foreign concept to many.
But if there is such a thing as an Internet financial and media empire, Mr. Son's company, Softbank, may be it. Mr. Son, 41, and Softbank are already among the most powerful financial forces in cyberspace, controlling key stakes in 100 Internet information providers in the United States and 20 such companies in Japan. The stakes in publicly held companies, worth $15 billion to $20 billion, are sprinkled widely. Softbank now owns 28 percent of Yahoo, and it has important stakes in Geocities, E-Loans, E*Trade, USWeb, Message Media, and TheStreet.com.
And Softbank is intensifying its focus on the Internet with new deals all the time. Last Tuesday, for example, it agreed to pay $20 million for a 40 percent stake in Webhire, an on-line recruiting company. And Softbank may sell much of its 70 percent stake in Ziff-Davis, the publisher of such magazines as PC Week.
"If you want a global player in the Internet, they are the player," said Jarett F. Wait, chief operating officer in Asia for Lehman Brothers, which recently released a 195-page report on the company. "There's nobody else that comes close."
But while Mr. Son is Japan's leading entrepreneur, the oddity, and perhaps the reason, is that he is not ethnically Japanese.
A Chinese-Korean, he grew up poor in southern Japan, closed off from normal avenues in Japan's corporate world because of discrimination against the Korean minority. Denied a chance to succeed at a leading company, he started Softbank and has become one of Japan's richest men.
Softbank's aim is to become a global Internet "zaibatsu," a Japanese-style empire with investments in many linked companies. Softbank has begun Internet ventures through Yahoo in Germany, France and Britain; it has investment alliances with Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation in Europe, and a joint venture in South Korea.
"For the next 10 years, we do nothing but Internet," Mr. Son said, speaking in English during an interview in his spacious office. "Because that's where the whole society is going to have a big revolution."
Now, after building the foundations of his Internet kingdom in the United States, Mr. Son is turning back to Japan -- one of the least entrepreneurial societies. Last month, he and Frank G. Zarb, chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, announced a plan to form a new trading exchange, a Japanese version of Nasdaq, that could become a center for electronic brokerage activity, electronic research and entrepreneurial ventures in Japan.
Mr. Son will feed that entrepreneurial spirit with venture-capital funds that aim to pour $85 million into building Japanese start-ups and grooming hundreds of Softbank wannabes. On June 29 Mr. Son held a reception for 1,400 budding entrepreneurs. He spent the morning of July 5 with Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi and other Government officials to offer some ideas for reviving Japan's economy. The entry of Mr. Son, an entrepreneur from the Korean minority, into the Prime Minister's residence underscores the changing times in Japan.
Yet he faces some enormous challenges. So far he has been a kind of venture capitalist, backing Internet enterprises early and riding on their success. But he does not manage or plan them. And the soaring value of Internet stocks has perhaps exaggerated his ability to pick individual winners.
Mr. Son's appetite for expansion has often outstripped his financial ability. Even now, he often taps the bond markets, and is carrying about three times as much debt as equity.
If there is a shake-out in the Internet, or if Internet stocks prove to be a bubble that pops, then Softbank may falter. Moreover, as Mr. Son ventures into relatively new territory -- like the stock exchange -- he is taking risks in areas in which he has no proved expertise.
Still, no one seems eager to bet against him. And almost no one is better than he is at adjusting to a new situation; he sometimes comes across as a chameleon.
He can backslap and talk in colloquial English with American investment bankers and then discuss the details of new computer chips with the techies. He can also turn somber and bow and speak in polite Japanese to melt into a Japanese business crowd.
This knack for mixing comes from his personal background, which has haunted and helped him since his days growing up in a small town on the southern Japanese island of Kyushu. Mr. Son's grandparents came to Japan from Korea, where his family had lived for 21 generations after migrating from China.
His father and other Koreans illegally built their houses on land owned by Japan National Railways, which led to a long-running conflict with the authorities. It was on that land that Mr. Son's father raised pigs and chickens and illicitly made sake. The home brew was apparently lucrative, for he became the first person in town to buy a car.
When Mr. Son's family moved out of its Korean neighborhood so he could attend a better school, to try to melt into society the family took a Japanese last name, Yasumoto.
"I was a good student, but in those days I had a darkness in my mind all the time," Mr. Son wrote in an essay in 1992. "It was because of my nationality. When I was with friends, I was very happy. When I came back home alone, I had the feeling that I was hiding something from my friends."
He took on his real Korean-Chinese name, Son, when he went to the United States at 16 to attend high school and then on to the University of California at Berkeley. It was his American experience, he says, that laid the groundwork for his career.
"If I had stayed all the time in Japan," Mr. Son said, "I probably would have become much more conservative, just as other Japanese."
One important element in the effort to change attitudes of young people will be to expand opportunities for them to finance their companies and to reward them with stock options -- and that is where the new stock exchange comes in. In February, Mr. Son met John L. Hilley, an aide to Mr. Zarb for the first time through a mutual friend.
Over dinner at a French restaurant at the Royal Park Hotel, close to Softbank's offices, Mr. Hilley began pouring out his frustrations over trying to break into the Japanese market. He had been in meetings his whole trip and had received very little encouragement.
"I said, 'Maybe we can help, maybe you went to the wrong place,' " Mr. Son recalled. He told Mr. Hilley, "You need someone who has the entrepreneurial spirit to make this happen."
Mr. Son and Mr. Zarb then began talking about setting up a new exchange, an idea made possible by recent changes in the securities regulations under Japan's financial liberalization. The idea also dovetailed with Mr. Son's ambition to help shape electronic brokerage and the Internet in Japan.
Even if this proposal fails and Mr. Son suffers a blow to his reputation, he still has his bet on the Internet. He says that as Internet technology evolves, the potential for returns from the information that travels on the network will be far greater than anything realized so far.
"That's my fortune-telling, " he said. "I'm betting on that."

HEADLINE: Donna Allen, 78, a Feminist and an Organizer

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Donna Allen, an early standard-bearer of feminism who kept an eye on the news and communications industry from her Washington home, died on July 19 of a heart attack. She was 78.
Her family said she died at a hospital but declined to identify it. 
 Dr. Allen came to social and political activism as a young woman, organizing farm workers on the West Coast and writing pamphlets for the American Federation of Labor in Washington. In the early 1950's, she became involved with the League of Women Voters, which was scrutinizing the Truman Administration's loyalty program for Government employees.
At the time, there was widespread fear of Communist infiltration and subversion. Dr. Allen strongly objected to loyalty oaths and their general acceptance by the press.
From this, Dr. Allen developed a lifelong interest in communications and the role of women in the field.
On the political side, she was a founder of Women Strike for Peace, which opposed nuclear weapons and the Vietnam War, and she served as Washington representative for the National Committee to Abolish the House Un-American Activities Committee.
Dr. Allen herself ran afoul of the Un-American Activities Committee in 1965, when it questioned a visa granted to a Japanese law school dean and leading pacifist for an American lecture tour in 1963. She and two others refused to testify at a closed hearing, claiming a constitutional right to an open hearing.
The committee cited the three for contempt of Congress. A United States district judge found them guilty and gave them suspended sentences of four months in prison and $100 fines. Those were overturned on appeal.
In 1972, Dr. Allen founded the Women's Institute for Freedom of the Press and started a newsletter, Media Report to Women: What Women Are Doing and Thinking About the Communications Media. She edited Media Report, now a quarterly, until selling it in 1987 to another publisher, but continued as president of the institute at her home to the end, organizing conferences and writing in an effort to get a woman's point of view across in communications here and abroad.
Donna Allen was born in Petoskey, Mich., and graduated in history, with a minor in economics, from Duke University in 1943. She received a master's degree in economics at the University of Chicago in 1953 and a Ph.D. in history at Howard University in 1971, with a dissertation on national health insurance.
Dr. Allen taught grievance procedures and labor economics and history at the School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell University in the early 1950's. She assisted Senator Paul H. Douglas, an economist, with an update of his standard text, "Theory of Wages," and wrote briefs for Presidential emergency boards named to resolve railroad labor disputes.
She was the author of "Fringe Benefits" (1964) and co-author of "Communications at the Crossroads: The Gender Gap Connection" (1988). She was active in the National Women's Political Caucus, the National Organization for Women and the National Women's Party.
Dr. Allen is survived by three daughters, Dana Densmore of Santa Fe, N.M., Indra Allen of San Francisco and Dr. Martha Allen of Washington; a son, Mark, of Memphis; a brother, Donald Rehkopf of Chicago; and three grandchildren. Her marriage to Russel Allen, a resident of Nashville, ended in divorce.
Dr. Allen sat in the audience when the Committee on Un-American Activities delved into the Ku Klux Klan in 1965, representing the group that wanted the House committee abolished. As the investigators sorted out such mysterious denizens as klaliffs, klokards and kludds, Dr. Allen sported a button proclaiming: "I am not now nor have I ever been a member of H.U.A.C."
The committee stopped asking questions about Community Party membership in 1969, when it went out of business. Dr. Allen's group henceforth turned itself into the Committee Against Repressive Legislation, of which she became vice chairman in 1975.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
A Passion for the Budget Drives a Michigan Republican

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN Representative Fred Upton talks about the cause that beckoned him here -- that nudges him out of bed in the morning, pings around his cerebral cortex all day and whispers to him at night -- something happens.
His eyes blaze. His speech accelerates. His voice climbs several notes. 
 This, apparently, is what a passion for Federal balance sheets will do to a man.
"My heartbeat has always been the budget -- and the deficit," Mr. Upton, a Michigan Republican, said last week in his Capitol Hill office, where a plaque atop the bookcase reads, "It's the national debt, stupid."
"That's what drives me," he said, his manner and appearance unusually boyish at 46. (As recently as two years ago, he was asked for identification when buying beer.) "That's why I came. That's why I chose to run. It's really everything."
That conviction explains why Mr. Upton, among a group of moderate Republicans, rained on the tax-cutting parade in Congress, forcing Republican leaders to make cuts contingent on controlling interest payments on the national debt.
But what explains Mr. Upton's conviction? The answer lies partly in history, which holds an interesting paradox.
The last tax cut as sweeping as the bill that House Republicans passed on Thursday was put into effect by President Ronald Reagan in 1981, and Mr. Upton was right there, in the middle of it, as a senior aide to David Stockman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget at the time.
But while President Reagan took a machete to taxes, he did not raise even gardening shears to spending. And Mr. Stockman dutifully provided candy-coated predictions about that economic program, which predictably fattened deficits. Mr. Stockman later conceded that he had seen it coming and warned others in the Administration, but their hunger to be popular overwhelmed the willpower to be smart.
Mr. Upton shared Mr. Stockman's experience and lessons, much as he shared every step of Mr. Stockman's political career. Attending a speech by Mr. Stockman in 1976, when Mr. Stockman was a candidate for the Congressional seat from southwestern Michigan that Mr. Upton now holds, was what set Mr. Upton on a political path.
Mr. Upton had just graduated from the University of Michigan with a degree in journalism and was in limbo. Mr. Stockman needed help, so Mr. Upton signed up with the campaign.
After Mr. Stockman's election, Mr. Upton followed him to Washington to be his staff project director. After Mr. Stockman was plucked for the O.M.B. job in 1980, Mr. Upton followed him there too. And after Mr. Stockman resigned in 1985 and went to work on Wall Street, Mr. Upton set his sights on his boss's old Congressional seat, winning election to it the following year.
The two men are still close. Mr. Stockman's mother, Carol, is Mr. Upton's campaign chairwoman, and Mr. Stockman and Mr. Upton caught up with each other at her house in St. Joseph, Mich., just three weeks ago.
"We talked about this tax bill," Mr. Upton said. "Literally, the first thing out of his mouth was, 'You guys have to pay down that debt.' "
Mr. Upton said that he agreed, believing that the country's sustained prosperity hinged on such fiscal restraint.
Mr. Upton grew up in St. Joseph with a quasi-famous surname, because his grandfather helped found Whirlpool, the appliance manufacturer, in the neighboring city of Benton Harbor. His father was a vice president there, and Fred and his four siblings never wanted for much.
But Mr. Upton said they were taught to be socially and financially responsible. He used earnings from part-time jobs to pay his college tuition.
He has a strong work ethic, evident in his mastery of policy details. Explaining his recent votes on gun control -- he sided with Democrats for tighter restrictions that he deemed reasonable -- he can instantly recite the minutiae of various provisions under consideration.
If a lawmaker is going to buck his party, Mr. Upton said, "You have to be able to explain why."
But that is no guarantee against heartburn. After joining Democrats in support of a 1994 crime bill that included not only gun control but also such putatively liberal programs as midnight basketball leagues, Mr. Upton was booed at a Republican convention back home.
Representative John Lewis, a Georgia Democrat, praised him as a politician with an open mind and heart.
"He's eager and ready to do what he can to build bridges and bring people together across racial and party lines," said Mr. Lewis, who is black.
MR. UPTON also has a playful side. He proposed to his wife, Amey, by hiring a plane to fly over a Baltimore Orioles game with the banner, "Amey, this is the inning to say yes." The couple have two children, ages 11 and 7.
Mr. Upton once seemed destined for a role in House leadership but proved too independent -- more liberal than his party on some social issues, more conservative on some fiscal ones. The latter are his abiding focus and, he said, the most important aspect of governing, even if previous Administrations and Congresses lost sight of that.
"Thank goodness, we're beginning to put Humpty Dumpty back together again," Mr. Upton said.

HEADLINE: VITAL SIGNS: STANDARDS;
A New 'to-Do' List for Fertility Clinics

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
Federal health officials last week issued model standards for the 300 fertility clinics in the nation, giving states a tool if they choose to start accrediting such clinics.
State action is voluntary, but some state legislators have been considering establishing some regulatory framework, especially after incidents like the embryo mix-up at a New York laboratory in which one woman gave birth to twins, one of whom was another couple's genetic child. 
 Even in the best of laboratories and with the best medical practices, success is not guaranteed with reproductive techniques like in vitro fertilization.
But the guidelines, issued by Dr. Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, are intended to make sure that embryology laboratories and clinics meet standards on laboratory procedures and equipment, record keeping and personnel qualifications.
"The fertility industry is a $2 billion part of our economy, and it has been almost completely unregulated," said Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat, who wrote a 1992 law that required the Government to set up these standards.
Insurance does not always cover infertility treatment, so couples may spend tens of thousands of dollars on difficult and stressful procedures, with low rates of success.
The Society for Assisted Reproductive Technology, which represents 90 percent of American clinics, backs the model standards.

HEADLINE: Team of Scientists to Prepare a Rolodex of Life on Earth

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 24

 BODY:
A group of countries has decided to prepare "the equivalent of a world telephone book of life on earth," a project that promises to revolutionize the study of biology and influence international environmental policy.
"It may seem surprising," said Dr. James Edwards, an assistant director at the National Science Foundation in Washington and one of the scientists involved in the project, but there is no single place that has recorded the scientific names of all species that have been named. 
 The project, he added, will include the creation of a catalogue of all named organisms, in effect a catalogue of life. "It will be a fantastic resource for everybody," Dr. Edwards said.
But the main thrust is the creation of a worldwide electronic information network called the Global Biodiversity Information Facility. Scientists hope it will become the single database that pools all the recorded but widely scattered data about the earth's animals, plants and microorganisms. The database is to be made accessible via the Internet.
Work on the facility is to start this year. It is being launched under the aegis of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based research group that encompasses the 29 most industrialized nations. Science ministers from the organization approved the plan in June and specialists, with an initial budget of $3 million, this month began setting up a secretariat and work program.
"This will mean that biodiversity information will finally move from the cuneiform tablet to the computer screen," said Dr. Tom Lovejoy, chief biodiversity adviser to the World Bank and one of the planners of the project.
"People doing molecular biology or gene sequencing started in an era where they automatically used electronic systems," he said. "Natural history began hundreds of years ago and has stayed behind."
The designers of the network say it should be a boon not only to biology students and researchers but also to poor nations that are rich in species but have small or no species collections of their own.
While most of the world's plant and animal species occur in developing countries, almost all significant natural history collections are in rich northern Europe and North America. "The information is scattered in dozens of centers, in museums, universities, in journals, drawers and card files," Dr. Lovejoy said. "The idea is to put all this together and make it available to everybody."
The global network is to include both the domestic biodiversity of each participating country and the data about its stored materials that have been collected around the world. Designers say the database will have to be flexible enough to adapt as science gains a greater understanding of organisms and redefines categories.
A number of countries, including Australia, Britain, Canada and the United States, already have on-line programs offering biological information on their main domestic species, but even in these countries the biodiversity inventories are not complete. Moreover, many of the world's historical collections, like those in Britain, France, Germany and Russia, often dating back to the 18th century, have not been entered into computer records.
For example, at the British Natural History Museum, which owns one of the world's largest collections, only a few of its millions of specimens have so far been put into computer catalogues. Museum officials say the task is daunting and that it costs about $5 per specimen to enter it into the new, digitized databank.
The network will not compile or organize its own species inventories but will pull together the databases being created at national and local levels in many countries. "A lot of countries are very interested in getting all their collections up in digitized form and accessible to everyone," Dr. Edwards said. "Quite a few want to use this initiative to get the ball rolling."
But weaving together existing records will be complex. "The databases that exist are very diverse and not based on common methods," said Michael Oborne, an O.E.C.D. economist who is involved in designing the project.
"We have to work out an agreed road map so that all the systems become compatible," Mr. Oborne said. "It will be like creating a world telephone book with the same codes. You want collections that match seamlessly."
There are other complications. In the past, different countries and cultures have developed different methods of classifying or naming species and definitions vary widely. In addition, many species have duplicate names.
"Part of what we'll have to do is to come up not only with the named species but also all their synonyms," Dr. Edwards said. "Now that we try to computerize things, we'll have to weed out the ambiguity that exists. This will be of value not only to scientists but also to policy makers. If people prepare a new law, say to protect a species, there can be no ambiguity."
The databases that will jointly make up the global center will remain the property of the institutions that own and provide the data and link them to the Internet. "This seemed more appropriate and more practical than starting a single central database for biological information from scratch," Mr. Oborne said.
The center will have its own secretariat and a small staff. Several countries are bidding for the seat and have offered accommodations, but the final decision is still pending. The $3 million budget is expected to grow in the next few years and will be provided by the member countries.
During the preparatory meetings in June, several countries said they did not want the new center to compete with other international programs compiling biological information, including the Clearing-House Mechanism for recording species, created as part of the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity in 1992.
Some critics say the mechanism, tailored to the least advanced countries, was intended to be little more than an archive and has been slow in starting. "An understanding has been reached that this new facility will get moving and concentrate on digitizing all the information," Mr. Oborne said. "The idea is not to duplicate or compete but to help the Clearing-House Mechanism."
The fundamental point, he continued, is to help provide a measuring stick for basic questions on the world's species. Among the questions: Are new species evolving? Are many being lost? What exists today?
The center will have an open-ended membership. After the richer countries provide the data and pay for the infrastructure, poorer countries will be able to join, but will be allowed to pay lower fees. This will provide people who have access to computers with a large on-line reference that will include images and details of their domestic specimens, now housed in museums, libraries and zoos of the rich nations.
Economic planners and industry, including pharmaceutical companies that do biological prospecting, also may find the data useful, the project backers believe.
But the most challenging part will be the next stage, the "vertical links," said Dr. Stefan Michalowski, one of the planners, "when the project will try to link the species databases with others dealing with soil, climate, human populations and the like."
"Say you want to know the effect of a pesticide on some species," he continued. "Then you should be able to see what climates the species live in, what else is part of that ecosystem and how all that will be affected by the chemicals."
The vertical links "will be the most worthwhile, but horrendously difficult," he said.
Estimates are that it will take several years for the first phase of the project to go on line. The broader project is expected to grow and evolve indefinitely.
But even in its embryonic phase, the project will make an enormous difference, said Dr. Edwards. "Right now, if I wanted to know all the specimens of a particular bird," he said, "I would have to write to all the museums that may have a specimen, then go to the museums myself and look at labels and cards. Our initial focus is to get the data from the tags and the drawers into the computer and, where possible, include images."

HEADLINE: Inches Underground, Secrets of Northern Slave Life

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

DATELINE: SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y., July 22

 BODY:
Alice Fiske, grande dame of Sylvester Manor on this coastal island, emerged from the stately Georgian house, steadying herself with a walking stick, to inspect the defacement of her handsome front lawn. She couldn't have been more pleased about the big hole there, the mark of archeologists at work.
"You know, we have so much history here," Mrs. Fiske said, nodding toward the dig, then the house and the water beyond, where ships of commerce once tied up and a society of cultural diversity took some of its first steps in the New World. 
 Archeologists are not only digging into the past of her late husband's family, going back to the middle of the 17th century, but are also discovering material remains of an aspect of American colonial history little known and rarely investigated: the existence of Northern plantations worked by African slaves.
"People generally assume all the plantations with slaves were in the South," said Dr. Stephen Mrozowski, an archeologist at the University of Massachusetts at Boston and co-leader of the excavation. "No one has really looked at the archeology of a Northern plantation in a systematic way."
As the second summer of excavations drew to a close, Dr. Mrozowski said the new findings, combined with a study of old wills, deeds and other documents, were beginning to reveal patterns of life and work on the Sylvester plantation, which at one time encompassed virtually all of Shelter Island.
Starting around 1650, this was a major enterprise with a long economic reach. Unlike Southern plantations, which concentrated on large cash crops like tobacco and cotton, this was one of several "provisioning plantations" founded at the time in the North. Its main function was to supply food and timber for the Sylvester family's sugar plantation on Barbados in the West Indies. Ships regularly sailed to Barbados bearing cured meat, grain, barrel staves and lumber and returned with molasses for making rum.
"We're seeing the beginning of the modern world," Dr. Mrozowski observed. "These people were already thinking of commerce on a global scale, labor from Africa, a plantation in one place supporting another far away and the products being traded on two continents. And you see all these cultures coming together, English, Dutch, Native American and African."
At both plantations, much of the labor fell to African slaves. According to inventories in the 1680's, more than 20 slaves worked at Sylvester Manor, more than 200 on Barbados. The slaves are listed on lines just above the inventory for livestock.
Only a generation or so after the settlement of Jamestown in Virginia, in 1607, and the arrival of the Pilgrims at Plymouth, Mass., in 1620, plantation culture had spread to a few places on the Northeast coast, where Africans were brought in as slave workers. By the early 1800's, every state above Maryland had abolished slavery. Excavations on Shelter Island, the archeologist said, could reveal whether there were differences in the lives of Africans on Northern plantations compared with those in the South, perhaps reflecting differences between a provisioning plantation and those based on large crops requiring intensive field work.
Dr. Mark P. Leone, an anthropologist at the University of Maryland at College Park, said the excavations should turn up "interesting and important results" about the role of Africans in early American culture, particularly in the North.
Until about two decades ago, African-Americans were a neglected element in archeology. Excavations at plantations usually focused on the architecture of the big houses of the white masters and were confined to the South. As an example of the changing emphasis, Dr. Leone has been investigating the slave quarters of historic houses in Annapolis, Md., to learn how the slaves maintained their African identity.
The excavations at Sylvester Manor are directed by Dr. Mrozowski and Dr. Marley Brown, director of archeology at Colonial Williamsburg in Virginia. The two had worked together on a dig at Jamestown, the first permanent English settlement in what is now the United States. A third partner is the Shelter Island Historical Society.
Stepping down into the excavation on the front lawn, Dr. Mrozowski said, "The beauty of archeology here is, we only have to go down inches to get to the 17th century."
Here the archeologists were looking for traces of the original plantation house, built in 1651; the present manor house dates to 1735. They found some Dutch-made yellow bricks and red roof tiles that belonged to the old house.
"We know the present house was always painted yellow, probably because the original one was built of yellow brick," Mrs. Fiske said.
So far, the foundations of the original house have eluded archeologists, perhaps because it stood on the site of the present house. But they think they may be able to learn even more about plantation life from the artifacts coming out of the lawn and other dig sites. Where he stood, Dr. Mrozowski said, he and his graduate students uncovered a deposit of 17th-century trash. This must have been outside the kitchen, most likely a free-standing structure in those days and a place occupied by the slaves.
Indeed, excavation also exposed the wood stains from decayed posts, coral-based mortar and other traces of a building. Dr. Mrozowski said he was not sure, but the arrangement of the post holes and trenches reminded him of construction patterns of some slave houses made of clay or mud mixed with branches or straw -- wattle and daub -- on South Carolina plantations. These the slaves had built themselves along the lines of dwellings where they or their ancestors had come from in West Africa.
Among animal bones, remains of plantation meals, archeologists here found broken pottery they considered even more distinctive evidence of an African presence. The pieces, gray to brown and unglazed, were from earthenware cooking pots in a style known to archeologists as colono ware. For a long time, such artifacts were thought to be Indian pottery. Now, archeologists have noted similarities to pottery in Nigeria and Ghana and agree that Africans, not Indians, were its primary if not exclusive makers in the New World.
Some Indian artifacts, primarily wampum shells, have been uncovered on a peninsula near the manor house, but it is not yet clear what role Indians had in plantation life. The shells could be from a pre-plantation encampment. But Indians lived on the island after the Europeans' arrival. The island's first census, in 1771, counted "140 persons white, 27 slaves, 5 free negros, 23 Indians."
Nathaniel Sylvester, founder of the plantation, emigrated from England , probably by way of Holland, and, with some partners, acquired the land from the Montauk Indians. (Mrs. Fiske' husband, Andrew Fiske, was a descendant of the Sylvesters.)
From the evidence in the trash deposit -- or midden, in archeological parlance -- the Sylvesters were a cosmopolitan family and their plantation prospered from the start. "It's the most upscale midden I've ever excavated," Dr. Mrozowski said.
Two student archeologists, Ann Hancock and Lee Priddy, arranged a sampling of their artifact haul on a table inside the manor house. There were English, French and Irish coins; fine German ceramics along with humbler colono ware; silver buckles and a stick pin, and pieces of Dutch clay pipes and a copper pipe tamper.
Behind the manor house, on a lawn sloping to Gardiner's Creek, the archeologists have uncovered traces of 17th-century outbuildings that appear to run down to the water. They suspect that these were places where workers made the barrel staves and stored the goods to be transported on the next ship to Barbados. Further excavations are planned here.
Of all the artifacts, the one most prized by Mrs. Fiske is a rusted latch key, four inches long. Because it was found in the 17th-century midden, archeologists told her it was most likely the key to the original manor house, and one more key to the past of a Northern slave plantation.

HEADLINE: Helping Churches Help

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In advocating Government use of faith-based institutions to help people, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas (front page, July 23), Vice President Al Gore and others ignore James Madison's heeding that Government "employment of religion as an engine of civil policy" would be "an unhallowed perversion of the means of salvation." 
 Religious institutions can help now through private donations, and Mr. Bush's proposal to allow taxpayers who do not itemize their tax returns to claim deductions for their charitable donations would be equitable. However, expanded use of faith-based groups would make it hard to police proselytizing, discrimination and preferences for some faiths or secular charities. "It is proper," Madison warned, "to take alarm at the first experiment on our liberties."
 
EDD DOERR
Silver Spring, Md. July 23, 1999
 
The writer is the executive director of Americans for Religious Liberty.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Buy Time, Not Guns

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
I've said it before and I will say it again: Taiwan is a remarkable country. And so much about Taiwan has changed for the better in the past decade. Its politics has changed to a vibrant democracy; its economy is the high-tech envy of Asia. Its media have evolved into the freest in Asia. Yes, so much has changed for Taiwan. There's just one thing that hasn't changed: its geography.
Taiwan is still a tiny island of 23 million people living 90 miles off the coast of a China with 1.3 billion people. A senior Taiwanese official recently described the Taiwan-China relationship, saying: "It's like I have an 800-pound gorilla in my living room, and the worst thing is, he thinks he's my brother." It may be awkward, but that's the reality, and both we and Taiwan must never lose sight of that. 
 Let me be clear: If China attacks Taiwan without provocation, the U.S. must defend Taiwan. We cannot turn our backs on a country that has built its whole political system and economy in our own image. But this is not a fight that Taiwan or the U.S. should court. Yet that is what Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, was doing when he said in an interview with German radio that henceforth relations between Taiwan and China should be seen as a "special state-to-state relationship" rather than an "internal" one -- seemingly nullifying the fiction that there is one China that will one day be reunified.
Eliminating that fiction and ambiguity about whether Taiwan will ever be reunited with China was reckless, because it is precisely that fiction and ambiguity that have enabled Taiwan to triumph over its geography. By pretending that one day it might reunite with China, Taiwan has kept China at bay, insured continued U.S. military support and bought itself time to build up an economy so dynamic -- the 12th-largest in the world -- that it now has critical leverage over China. Taiwanese own 40,000 businesses around the Mainland, making Taiwan the most important foreign investor in China today.
It was also reckless because President Lee's effort to eliminate the ambiguity in Taiwan-China relations was not part of any apparent, considered strategic reassessment, let alone coordination with the U.S. It was simply tossed off in an interview by Mr. Lee, primarily to pick up some pro-independence votes in the upcoming Taiwanese presidential elections.
Lastly, it was reckless because the only long-term solution for Taiwan -- the only thing that will insure that its flourishing democracy and free market are never threatened by China -- is not if it describes China differently, but only if China actually becomes different, only if China evolves into a more democratic, pluralistic country that will not seek unity with Taiwan by force and that Taiwan itself would find a more attractive partner.
Seeking more time, through more ambiguity, for this evolution should be the centerpiece of Taiwan's strategy. This is no time for provoking clarity. It was little noticed that last week Standard & Poor's Ratings Service downgraded China's Government debt and the bonds of nine shaky state-backed Chinese banks. It was the first time that China's official debt has been downgraded since the Tiananmen massacre. S.&P. cited a slowing Chinese economy and rising unemployment as the main reasons for the downgrade. If China's economy continues to decline, and there is more urban unrest, Beijing could be tempted to deflect internal tensions by attacking Taiwan.
It's interesting that if you go to Silicon Valley today and ask high-tech execs there which country they fear most, many will tell you Taiwan -- because it combines entrepreneurial talent with innovative prowess. Taiwan has been recognized by Silicon Valley; it doesn't need to spend billions to be recognized by Suriname. Being recognized by Silicon Valley may not come with embassies and flags, but it conveys real power -- a power that makes Taiwan unignorable even if it remains diplomatically unrecognizable.
What will make Taiwan diplomatically recognizable is a change in China. Not only is that change in process, but Taiwan has a huge role to play in nurturing it. The only thing Taiwan needs is time, and the key to buying time is not clarity about its relations with China, but ambiguity. Ambiguity is what bought time for Taiwan to make itself unignorable, and more ambiguity is what will buy it the time to make itself fully recognizable. Forcing clarity now is reckless and stupid for Taiwan. It will buy Taiwan nothing but trouble. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Ship Cove Journal;
A Son of the Land Stands Up for Birds of the Sea

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: SHIP COVE, Newfoundland

 BODY:
The thought of escaping this sweet and miserable land has long tempted Stan Tobin. Once or twice over the years he has even slipped off to Ireland -- where his brogue makes him sound home-grown -- with no intention of coming back.
But the hardy ground in Ship Cove -- population six when his whole family is here -- simply will not let him go. Tobins have lived here since the start of the last century and now the land's gotten to him too, he says, and made him sort of crazy. 
 So he keeps his restless soul here, and he has his hands in many things. He raises calves and sells them, and he and his wife, Dolores, run a creamery where they make good, hard butter.
But his real passion these days is the squat building on the edge of one of his fields where he and other volunteers wash and clean other wayward souls -- sea birds that have been contaminated by oil. It is one of the only animal rehabilitation centers in Atlantic Canada, and when birds start to come ashore, Mr. Tobin and other volunteers clean them and nurse them back to health.
These volunteers know their limitations, especially when it comes to what the Canadian Coast Guard calls mystery spills that occur more than 100 miles offshore when a commercial ship deliberately empties out its oily bilge water, in violation of regulations requiring that it be treated and disposed of onshore.
Most often, no one knows when the mystery spills happen, or who is responsible. Most of the carcasses of the oiled birds wash out to sea or sink. A small number -- government researchers estimate it at one-tenth or fewer of the total number of sea birds contaminated by oil -- wash to shore and they are usually the first clues that there has been a spill.
As many as 100,000 puffins, murres and other sea birds will die in the icy waters off Newfoundland this year after landing in oil from "mystery spills." That will equal about 40 percent of the 250,000 birds that died in the Exxon Valdez spill off Alaska a decade ago, but the kill will attract little attention here because as many birds have died just about every year for the last few decades.
Mr. Tobin says that as little as half a teaspoon of oil can kill a bird. Feathers greedily absorb the oil and then cannot keep out the cold ocean water. Even a tiny spot can be fatal, like a small tear in a diver's wet suit. The birds get cold, develop hypothermia and eventually become too weak to find food or fly away.
Federal and provincial authorities have known for years that some maritime crews try to skirt regulations and cut costs by emptying their bilges offshore, where no one sees them.
Occasionally, a polluter is caught in the act, as happened last year when a ship bound for England was fined $25,000 (U.S.) after being spotted dragging a sheen of oil five miles long.
The Canadian Coast Guard now runs aerial surveillance flights looking for spills. But they must cover an enormous area, and many spills can never be traced. Even when the polluters are found and prosecuted, officials say, the fines imposed are too low to provide any real deterrence.
"The problem is the courts," said Brian Tobin, Premier of the province of Newfoundland and Labrador and a former federal fisheries minister but no direct relation to Stan Tobin. "The fines that are imposed are laughable."
The Canada Shipping Act, which regulates commercial shipping, is now under review and amendments have been offered to increase fines and make them mandatory in some cases.
As one of the founders of the Newfoundland and Labrador Environmental Association, Stan Tobin has done all he could to help wildlife -- everything from keeping oiled sea birds in his bathtub while they recover to serving on several commissions that have carefully documented the effect of "mystery spills."
Now 50, Mr. Tobin, a former fisherman and, he confesses, former bird poacher as well, said authorities that are supposed to be protecting the province's environment have shown they are willing to gloss over environmental issues to keep from antagonizing businesses that provide badly needed jobs. Unemployment in Newfoundland hovers around 17 percent, more than twice the national average.
Terry Harvey, director of the Canadian Coast Guard's Prevention of Oiled Wildlife Project, also believes that the province caters to commercial interests without fully assessing the effect of such decisions on natural resources.
"The province has been crying out for industrial development for some time, and that probably has driven us to make radical and uninformed decisions," Mr. Harvey said.
Mr. Tobin, Newfoundland's Premier, said the province has proved it will reject projects that harm the environment, like a proposal to build more than a dozen small dams to produce electricity, even though they mean jobs.
"We are concerned about the environment," he said, "perhaps like no one else on the planet."
For centuries, the province's economy was linked to the bounty of the North Atlantic, in particular the Grand Banks fishing grounds that were once so rich that a fisherman need only lower a basket over the side of his boat to get his daily catch.
But earlier this decade the cod seemed to disappear and the Canadian Government closed the commercial cod fishery, throwing thousands of Newfoundland fishermen out of work.
Projects, like the Hibernia offshore oil platform, bring thousands of new jobs. A joint venture of several oil companies, including Mobil and Petro-Canada, Hibernia received financial support from the Canadian Government.
Hibernia officials reported 21 small spills last year that dumped a total of about 600 gallons of oil into the ocean, not much against more than 130,000 barrels of oil the platform pumps up every day.
Hibernia received no fines for any incident. Mr. Harvey of the Coast Guard says he believes that there were many other unreported spills.
"In its environmental impact statement, Hibernia said the possibility of spills occurring was nearly nil," he said. "Yet we have oil in the water almost every week. "
Thomas F. Zapatka, environmental and safety manager for Hibernia, said the company strictly follows all environmental guidelines. "We've never seen any wildlife damaged or impacted," near the platform, he said.
Experts say sea birds are loath to come to land, and only something as awful as being coated with oil will bring them to shore. The point isn't wasted on Stan Tobin, who, truth be told, is loath to leave this land.
"I can't put my finger on it, exactly," he said, watching waves break on the gravelly beach of Ship Cove that he knows so well. "You develop this great attachment for the land. A guy could almost die for it."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Housing Data, New Offerings Cool Demand For Treasuries

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Bond prices fell for a fourth session as record home resales and more than $22.5 billion of expected debt offerings by borrowers including Allied Waste Industries reduced demand for Treasuries.
Bonds also fell amid concern that testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and reports on growth and employment costs later this week would increase the chance of another interest rate increase later this year. 
 "Money managers are going to assume the worst -- that the strength of the economy will cause the Fed to raise rates again" and that is hurting the market, said Bryce Doty, who manages $750 million of bonds at Sit Investment Associates in Minneapolis.
The price of the 30-year bond slipped 3/32, to 89 10/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.03 percent from 6.02 percent on Friday.
In a further sign of economic might that hurt Treasuries, the National Association of Realtors reported a 10.6 percent rise in home resales in June to a record annual rate. Traders and investors said they were not looking to buy bonds before Mr. Greenspan concludes his testimony before Congress tomorrow and reports are released on second-quarter growth and employment costs on Thursday. Last week, Treasuries fell after Mr. Greenspan, in the first half of his semiannual report to Congress, said the Fed was prepared to act "promptly and forcefully" if it saw signs of faster inflation.
The central bank, whose policy committee next meets on Aug. 24, raised its target for overnight lending between banks by a quarter-point, to 5 percent, on June 30.

HEADLINE: Net Up 12% At American Express

BYLINE: ByBloomberg News 

 BODY:
The American Express Company said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 12 percent as consumers spent more with its signature green charge cards and invested more with its financial planners.
American Express, the world's biggest charge-card issuer and travel agency, said net income rose to $646 million, or $1.41 a diluted share, from $578 million, or $1.24 a share, in the period a year earlier. That beat analysts' expectations of $1.40 a share. 
 An economy in its ninth year of expansion and a stock market in its fifth year of gains increased fees from charge and credit cards, financial planning, mutual funds and the travel agency, which together make up the bulk of revenue and profit at American Express.
Revenue rose 12 percent, to $4.82 billion from $4.29 billion. That beat the company's goal of 8 percent growth. Return on equity rose to 25.3 percent from 23.5 percent, exceeding the company's target of 18 percent to 20 percent.
Earnings at Travel Related Services International -- the company's biggest unit, which offers charge cards, credit cards and vacation plans -- rose 14 percent, to a record $411 million. Customer accounts and spending per account rose.
The company has focused on issuing more cards through international banks and obtaining a bigger share of spending in United States groceries, pharmacies and gasoline stations. The effort has been bolstered by television advertisements featuring the comedian and actor Jerry Seinfeld buying food, pharmacy products and gas with the American Express card.
Earnings at the money-management subsidiary, American Express Financial Advisors Inc., increased 14 percent, to $242 million, a record. The unit offers financial planning, mutual funds and other investments.
Profit at American Express Bank, which includes the company's traveler's check business, fell 19 percent, to $38 million from $47 million.
Shares of American Express rose 93.75 cents yesterday, to $136.50.

HEADLINE: Sales of Existing Homes Set All-Time Record Rate in June

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes soared to a record rate in June as buyers rushed to take advantage of low mortgage rates, the National Association of Realtors said today.
Existing home sales rose 10.6 percent in June, to an annualized rate of 5.53 million units, up from a rate of 5 million units in May. It was the highest rate on record. 
 "When buyers saw interest rates moving up this spring, they jumped off the fence and into the market to take advantage of excellent affordability conditions before mortgage rates moved higher," said Sharon Millett, the president of the association.
The group said the June rate put the housing market on track for another record year, with expected sales of about 5 million units, up from 4.97 million units in 1998.
"This huge number is a manifestation of a very healthy U.S. economy and bodes well for all of the industries that are tied to the housing industries," said James Smith, the chief economist for the association.
Bill Cheney, chief economist at John Hancock Financial Services, said the housing market should slow to a rate of less than five million homes by the end of the year on expectations that interest rates will move higher.
"This is not a sign that the economy is overheating and should not make us back off from predictions that the housing market will slow down as the year continues," Mr. Cheney said.
Although he was surprised by the strong gain in June, Mr. Cheney said that the figures are volatile given the long process of buying a home and that the June data suggested that any potential slowdown of the economy would be gradual.
The current economic expansion has been driven largely by consumer spending, which has been spurred by new homeowners buying such big-ticket items as sofas and appliances.
The association's report showed signs that the housing market was increasingly becoming a sellers' market. At the end of June, there was an inventory of 1.97 million homes available for sale, representing 4.7 months of supply at the current sales pace, the lowest inventory level since December 1994, when the inventory stood at 4.1 months.
The group also reported that the median sale price rose to a record $137,000 in June.
The average 30-year fixed mortgage rate rose to 7.55 percent in June from 7.15 percent in May, according to Freddie Mac.
