HEADLINE: Discord Undermines Efforts to Repair and Build Public Schools

SERIES: PHYSICALLY UNFIT: Second of two articles.

BYLINE: This article was reported by John Sullivan, Jacques Steinberg and Christopher Drew and was written by Mr. Steinberg. 

 BODY:
A fire that was touched off by a welder working in a Brooklyn vocational school briefly trapped 150 students last year. The construction work was not supposed to begin until school was done for the day, but school administrators and construction officials could not agree on when classes were actually over.
A new elementary school opened in Washington Heights in 1995 with problems ranging from loose floor tiles to a broken elevator. It took nearly three years to fix all of them while officials at the New York City Board of Education and the School Construction Authority argued about whose job it was to make the repairs. 
 A computer system that the board and the authority have been designing since 1990 is yet another sign of their dysfunction. The agencies still cannot perform basic tasks like tracking and sharing information on a construction program that has spent $9 billion over the last 10 years.
A decade after the State Legislature created the construction authority and joined it in a shotgun marriage with the city's school board, the breakdown in their relationship has been a major obstacle to reaching the goal that was set for them: mending and expanding the nation's largest school system by century's end.
Legislators were hoping to rescue a school system whose building division was taking 10 years, and often a few bribes, to build a single school, but in their haste to solve the problem they effectively hard-wired the new arrangement for failure.
They made the board the client and the new authority its builder, but they never specified where one agency's job ends and the other's begins. They wanted to insulate the process from corruption, but left it completely vulnerable to politicians competing for much-needed construction money. And they divided power over the new system between the governor, the city's schools chancellor and the mayor, but never held any of them accountable.
Now, as city and state officials are beginning to pour $7 billion more into school construction and repairs over the next five years, they have done little to fix the broken partnership they created. The board is slow to plan, the authority is lax in policing contractors, and the disagreements between the two agencies are fundamental.
"The city and state have a primary responsibility to provide children and teachers with safe and comfortable surroundings, and that's sort of a minimum expectation," said Raymond Domanico, education adviser to the Metro New York Industrial Areas Foundation, a parent organizing group. "I don't think the kids are getting that right now. I think the board and the authority bear a great deal of the blame."
The decade's work has hardly been a waste. Space for about 115,000 classroom seats was created, enough for every public school student in San Francisco and Seattle combined. Yet more than half of the seats are in trailers or leased spaces like churches, or are carved out of existing classrooms, adding to the makeshift nature of many schools.
School construction officials went on a buying spree of those temporary trailers, which now fill the playgrounds and parking lots of many schools, out of frustration with the inefficiencies and chronic underfinancing of their own system.
Permanent seats in new buildings were expensive. They cost about $300 a square foot in recent years, according to authority figures, far higher than school construction in other cities, even when adjusted for the steep price of labor and materials in New York.
An almost unfathomable amount of work remains. An analysis of the city's most recent school-by-school engineering survey by The New York Times shows that at least 40 percent of the 1,100 schools are plagued by porous roofs, disintegrating facades or windows that do not open or shut. The survey also identifies problems with millions of dollars' worth of work that the construction authority completed only within the last five years.
Little wonder that the system is a regular target of politicians' scorn. Gov. George E. Pataki accused the board and the authority of "robbing students" of a "proper learning environment" when he started an investigation of school construction in January.
But if there is plenty of blame, none of the officials dishing it out are immune. The construction apparatus is overseen by one appointee each of the governor, the mayor and the schools chancellor.
It was a leadership model that perhaps only Albany could conceive: any top official can take credit for the system's successes, but no one is directly responsible for its failures. That includes the State Legislature and the city government, which, combined, have left the authority with about $2 billion a year less than the amount some experts say is needed.
In the last two years, the authority's chairman, Howard Wilson, and the president, Milo E. Riverso, have made significant strides in speeding projects and tightening supervision of them. But critics see more fundamental problems.
"Not putting in place an overall system of accountability, and leaving it as a divided house, doomed the system to failure from the very beginning," said Anne Rouse, the senior vice president for education at the New York City Partnership, an association of corporate executives. "No one single leader, no matter how charismatic, persuasive or managerially successful, can compensate for the structure of this system, which is flawed."
 
Troubled History
Flaws Were Built Into the System
When Public School 8 in Washington Heights opened in the fall of 1995, at a cost of $24 million, the elevator was leaking hydraulic fluid and could not be used, leaving handicapped students to be sent elsewhere. Floor tiles were popping out all over the cafeteria. And a fitful heating and air-conditioning system was roasting some rooms while chilling others.
The problems persisted for almost three years as the board and the authority argued about who should fix them. The board, in letters to the authority, said the flaws were the result of poor construction and therefore the responsibility of the authority. The authority said the deficiencies could be cured through maintenance, a responsibility that rested with the board. The authority did not fully correct the problems until last year, according to board officials.
"It was like a custody battle between two people in a bad divorce," said Susan Montez, a former community school board member in Washington Heights. "But no one wanted the kid."
The School Construction Authority was born in the closing hours of a chaotic 1988 state legislative session. Twenty Board of Education employees had been arrested on construction-related charges in the previous two years, and legislators wanted to make a bold statement. On Dec. 15, they hastily passed a bill creating the authority.
The legislators gave the authority one big advantage, exempting it from several costly public construction laws, but they failed to draw a line between the powers of the board and those of the new authority. For example, the Legislature, in two different laws, gave both agencies a role in designing schools, but never decided which one had the final say.
Bowing to union pressure, the Legislature also granted employees of the board's Division of School Buildings, the office being disbanded, the right to transfer to the new authority.
Two hundred thirty-six did.
Many of those left at the board chafed at the new status of their former colleagues, with whom they still had to work within the new partnership. They are still bristling.
In an internal memorandum last year, a new authority employee wrote of being told by a senior manager, "The Board of Education doesn't want us to succeed because it will prove that they are failures because they couldn't succeed when they ran this department."
From the outset, the board and the authority were overwhelmed by the job of rebuilding a deteriorating system with more than 1,100 school buildings, half built before 1940.
The revolving-door leadership that plagued the public schools quickly engulfed the construction authority, too: in the last 10 years, the school system has had five chancellors; the authority has had five chairmen and six presidents.
With new and better school buildings needed in every quarter, the construction process became infected by the very politics that had eaten at the schools for generations.
"There was a hope that somehow the S.C.A. would change the nature of the whole allocation and construction process, to make it more efficient and more equitable," said Norm Fruchter, a former district school board member in Brooklyn and an education researcher at New York University. "Instead of changing the terms of the game, they fell victim to another variant of the same game."
Perhaps nothing captures the dissonance between the two agencies better than their failure over 10 years to share information on construction projects.
Authority officials complain that when the board changes its construction plans, as it frequently does, the updated information is not available on computer. The board, in turn, says that the authority cannot keep track of projects because it has no fewer than four computer systems that often contain conflicting information.
"This has been the Bermuda triangle," said Lewis H. Spence, Chancellor Rudy Crew's designee at the authority.
To solve the problem, the two agencies have spent enough money to build an elementary school -- more than $22 million, at least half on consultants -- to no avail.
During a recent interview, Mr. Riverso tried to dispel the image of the computer system as troubled by calling up information on the renovation of an elementary school on Staten Island. The computer indicated that the project had been completed in August 1997. In fact, the work is not finished yet.
"That's an error," Mr. Riverso said, clearing the screen.
 
Fire in Brooklyn
Poor Communication Puts Lives at Risk
The screams of "Fire!" began echoing through William H. Maxwell High School in East New York, Brooklyn, about 4 P.M., just after a worker welding a first-floor pipe accidentally ignited a storage closet full of fluorescent bulbs.
As smoke filled the building on May 12, 1998, about 150 students and teachers in an after-school program began feeling their way down a stairwell from the fifth floor. When the lead teacher reached the first-floor exit, she found the door jammed with a construction rod.
Frightened, the group climbed back up three stories to avoid the fire, and crossed the width of the school to get out. "We had to walk toward the smoke," recalled Tina Johnson, a special education teacher.
One teacher and one student were taken to a hospital for treatment of smoke inhalation. An investigator for the authority's inspector general wrote in a report after the fire that, given the circumstances, the outcome could have been "far more disastrous."
The confluence of problems that led up to the fire typify the way schools are often renovated in New York. Long delays in work were followed by a mad dash to finish. Lax safety precautions were aggravated by poor communication between those running the school and those overseeing the construction.
"If I was a parent of a child in that school," said Mr. Riverso, the authority president, "I'd be outraged."
When Mr. Riverso became an authority vice president in February 1997, the $29 million renovation of the high school, which included a new library and cafeteria, was more than a year late. He replaced the general contractor on the job with HRH Construction, which had been supervising the dismissed contractor, according to the inspector general's report. He also shaved six months off the latest timetable and ordered that the project be completed for the 1998 school year.
At the time, Maxwell, an 85-year-old school, was just one of dozens of projects that the authority was pressing to complete. Mr. Wilson, the authority chairman, was intent on avoiding what had become an annual ritual of the first day of school: students arriving to the clamor of last-minute construction work.
"You want it done fast," Mr. Wilson said at his first meeting as an authority trustee on Dec. 5, 1996. "You want it done right. You want it done on time."
"Next September is going to be perfect," he added, according to the authority minutes. "If it is not perfect, people will be held accountable."
In the weeks leading up to the fire, HRH itself fell behind schedule and was in danger of being removed by Mr. Wilson and Mr. Riverso. To catch up, it tripled its work force to 150, according to the minutes of authority meetings.
But safety did not command the same attention as speed.
After the fire, authority investigators determined that the welder whose torch set off the blaze was not certified and that the general contractor had not provided a fire watch by someone specifically trained to spot fires, in violation of the fire code, according to the report. No fire alarm was transmitted to the Fire Department because the custodian engineer had temporarily disconnected it to avoid false alarms caused by the construction, the report said. (A custodial worker put the fire out.)
No dangerous work was supposed to have been performed until the "night," or "after school," shift, according to the inspector general's report. But there was confusion about when exactly that was.
"No one seemed to have the specific responsibility for determining who was in the building and whether or not they were adequately protected during construction," the authority investigator wrote.
The final bell at Maxwell rings at 2:57 P.M., but after that, hundreds of students stay for remedial classes and extracurricular activities. Six months before the fire, the Maxwell custodian engineer wrote to the authority's project manager at Maxwell, "Maxwell High School is occupied from 6 A.M. to 4:15 P.M. on Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays."
The fire was on a Tuesday, and investigators determined that the welder fired up his torch about 4 P.M.
The investigators, according to the report, could find no evidence that the authority had informed the contractor of the school schedule. A statement by an HRH spokesman did not comment directly on the authority's findings, but the company told investigators that there was no way workers could have known whether there were students in the building, according to the report.
To Barbara Elk, the school principal, the dispute over the school hours is intended to obscure the real issue.
"They were welding while kids were in the building, but they were working without safety precautions," she said. "This is just an attempt to get out of responsibility."
Neither HRH nor the authority project manager was disciplined at the time. A year later, HRH received an unsatisfactory rating on the job and, according to authority documents, was suspended from authority work, a ruling it has asked officials to review. But Mr. Riverso said he and the board took one corrective step: appointing a committee to fashion a definition of after-school hours for contractors systemwide.
The committee met for more than a year without coming up with a definition, Mr. Riverso said.
 
The Politics
Competing Interests Create Turmoil
The relationship between the board and the authority is often at its worst when it comes to deciding how construction money is to be spent.
By law, the board issues a construction plan every five years that is supposed to be the authority's blueprint for what to build and repair.
But for all practical purposes, the plans are obsolete the day they are printed.
"The S.C.A. is into the fourth year of the current five-year plan," authority officials wrote in an internal report last year, "yet for almost the entire duration of the plan since its adoption in November 1994, this document has been in such a state of constant flux that it was impossible to build any kind of execution strategy."
The board's intentions sometimes shift as suddenly as a breeze.
One night in August 1997, authority officials had arranged for traffic to be halted on the George Washington Bridge so two prefabricated school additions, carried on trailers, could be transported to the Bronx in time for the opening of school. As the trailers were preparing to make their way across the bridge, Mr. Riverso said, a board official called him to order that the buildings be rerouted to two schools in Queens.
Patricia Zedalis, the board's top construction official since 1996, said the board switched gears after the authority determined that the century-old school, P.S. 31 in the Bronx, was so unstable that its students had to be evacuated. "It just so happened the transportables were on their way on the truck," said Ms. Zedalis, the chief executive for school facilities..
(Two years later, the fate of the Bronx school, a landmark, remains a sore point, as the board and the authority feud over whether to renovate it or tear it down.) The board's plans are ever-changing largely because, in addition to the authority, everyone from the Mayor to City Council members, and from neighborhood groups to principals, has a voice in the process.
"We've got to make sure a school is in the right place and with the right program, so all of the stakeholders of that educational community buy into the ultimate solution," Ms. Zedalis said. "Sometimes reaching consensus takes time."
With limited financing, competition to get a project listed in the five-year plan is fierce. Independent estimates have put the cost of providing adequate space for all students as high as $28 billion, yet there was just $4.9 billion in the plan that concluded on June 30.
Since the construction budget ultimately has to be approved by the Mayor and the City Council, horse-trading is rampant.
Last spring, the seven members of the Board of Education, who are politically appointed, squabbled two months past their deadline before approving the $7 billion construction plan for the next five years. Ultimately, a majority directed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani added thousands of seats to Queens and Staten Island at the expense of seats planned for the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan.
If history is any guide, that plan, too, will change.
A recent report on the five-year plan that just expired included hundreds of projects on 43 single-spaced pages -- many for critical wall, window and roof work -- that had been promised, only to be deferred. They were replaced by 35 pages of other projects, most picked by the Mayor and the Council. The board granted them that privilege in exchange for the addition of more than $1 billion to the construction budget.
The changes make for dashed hopes at schools like John Bowne High School in Flushing, Queens. In the fall of 1997, the board informed Bowne administrators that its laboratories would be renovated, welcome news since three of its labs are 35 years old and the fourth is a home economics classroom. All 3,500 students at Bowne are required to take two lab classes to graduate.
But in March 1998, after the new labs were already designed, the board suspended the project indefinitely, deciding instead to repair the exteriors of other schools.
The reason the project died matters little at a school where the advanced placement environmental sciences class is held in an old kitchen. There, 22 students share two sinks and cannot light Bunsen burners on the counter tops for fear of setting the wooden cabinets on fire. Instead, they hold the burners in their hands.
The halting process of making and then changing plans wastes time and money, authority officials said, and creates pressure to hurry up and finish long-delayed projects.
It happened again this year when the board scrambled until May, less than two months before the end of the fiscal year, to approve designs for projects representing nearly half of the authority's annual budget. That meant that bids for $500 million in designs were dumped all at once onto an already competitive construction market.
"The process seems to encourage delay and non-decisions," said Mr. Wilson, the authority chairman. "Maybe the system is paralyzed."
 
Makeshift Fixes
Going to School In a Trailer Park
The people who run the authority and board are quick to point out that whatever the shortcomings of the last decade, they have produced classroom space for 115,000 students, 76,000 within the last five years.
Schools are now erected in as little as 3 years, much quicker than the average of 10 years it took in the 1970's and 80's. And Mr. Wilson estimates that the authority will complete 70 percent of its major repair projects on schedule this year, compared with 5 percent in 1996.
"I think that this agency is in a very good place now," Mr. Wilson said. "Not perfect, but very good."
Yet dissecting the numbers sheds a different light on what the city got for the $9 billion it spent. Fewer than half of the new classroom seats, about 53,500, are in new, permanent buildings. More than a third, about 42,000, sit in leased commercial spaces, in makeshift classrooms partitioned from existing classes and locker rooms, or in factories and other buildings that the board now owns. The remainder, about 20,000, are in trailers and other portable buildings.
Trailers were hastily delivered to school playgrounds and parking lots during 1996 and 1997, when an acute shortage of classroom space became an election issue. But given the trailers' flimsy construction, the board anticipates replacing them all with permanent classrooms by 2007.
Ruth W. Messinger, who railed against the use of temporary classrooms as the Democratic candidate for mayor in 1997, said they represented the unrealized promise of the authority. "Trailers have one advantage," she said. "They are better than closets or hallways."
Nowhere are trailers more prominent than at George Washington High School in Washington Heights, its walls crammed with 2,500 students. Two years ago, the authority blanketed the tennis and basketball courts with 15 aluminum-sided trailers, each with two classrooms, as a substitute for an addition delayed by lack of money since 1994.
This past year, all 500 ninth graders took their classes in the complex of trailers, known as "the north campus," which looks like a mobile home park, with wooden staircases leading up to rooms with windows no larger than those of microwave ovens. Though the classrooms have bathrooms, the nearest water fountains and the school cafeteria are several hundred yards away.
Trailers are not only a faster way of creating classrooms, but they cost just $6,900 a seat, about one-tenth of the $68,000, on average, that New York spends for each permanent high school seat.
Examined another way, the price of a new classroom in New York City, according to Mr. Riverso, is about $300 a square foot. But using an index compiled by R.S. Means, a consulting firm, which adjusts for the high costs of building in New York, other systems still come out far lower: $240, or at least 20 percent cheaper, in Yonkers; $202 in Chicago, and $171 in Philadelphia.
Mr. Riverso attributed the higher costs to more stringent building requirements in New York, as well as to special conditions of building in the city, as in the recent construction of a school over a subway tunnel.
Whatever that money has bought, the needs of the system are seemingly endless. A recent survey by the board found that almost one-third of the city's schools had their windows or roofs replaced, their exterior masonry shored up or some combination over the last five years. But that survey also found that one out of four city schools had seriously deteriorated roofs or exterior walls, and two out of five had deteriorated windows.
In a more disturbing finding, the survey highlighted significant problems in a number of schools that were either built or repaired by the authority within the last five years. Those deficiencies, often in the very roofs or set of windows that were to have been fixed, point to any number of shortcomings in the system, from sluggish contractors to a maintenance budget so paltry that it allows for little maintenance.
This leaves teachers and students waiting -- people like Karina Constantino, the principal of P.S. 22 on Staten Island.
The authority spent $2 million putting a new roof on the school and sealing its brickwork from 1995 through 1997. But almost two years later, the roof leaks in seven places, she said, pointing out the wide, wet blotches on the ceilings of a number of classrooms.
Ms. Constantino is hardly surprised, since she said it was often up to her to bound up to the roof to scrape her fingernails against freshly set mortar to determine its consistency or to check whether the chimney was in danger of falling -- tasks, she says, the authority should have been doing.
The board and the authority disagree over who is to blame for the lingering leaks.
Ms. Constantino, her eyes on the ceilings above her students' heads, closes her ears to their squabbling, while awaiting the next round of repairs she has been promised.
 
Physically Unfit
 
MONDAY -- By depending on inept contractors, and paying scant attention to their work, New York City school construction officials have fallen short in their quest for a physically fit school system by century's end. Attempts at reform have been hard-won, and sometimes short-lived.
 
TODAY -- To mend and expand the city school system, the School Construction Authority and the Board of Education must work closely together. But their discord has made a daunting task even harder, and a succession of top political officials have too often declined to intervene.

HEADLINE: Ship Cove Journal;
A Son of the Land Stands Up for Birds of the Sea

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: SHIP COVE, Newfoundland

 BODY:
The thought of escaping this sweet and miserable land has long tempted Stan Tobin. Once or twice over the years he has even slipped off to Ireland -- where his brogue makes him sound home-grown -- with no intention of coming back.
But the hardy ground in Ship Cove -- population six when his whole family is here -- simply will not let him go. Tobins have lived here since the start of the last century and now the land's gotten to him too, he says, and made him sort of crazy. 
 So he keeps his restless soul here, and he has his hands in many things. He raises calves and sells them, and he and his wife, Dolores, run a creamery where they make good, hard butter.
But his real passion these days is the squat building on the edge of one of his fields where he and other volunteers wash and clean other wayward souls -- sea birds that have been contaminated by oil. It is one of the only animal rehabilitation centers in Atlantic Canada, and when birds start to come ashore, Mr. Tobin and other volunteers clean them and nurse them back to health.
These volunteers know their limitations, especially when it comes to what the Canadian Coast Guard calls mystery spills that occur more than 100 miles offshore when a commercial ship deliberately empties out its oily bilge water, in violation of regulations requiring that it be treated and disposed of onshore.
Most often, no one knows when the mystery spills happen, or who is responsible. Most of the carcasses of the oiled birds wash out to sea or sink. A small number -- government researchers estimate it at one-tenth or fewer of the total number of sea birds contaminated by oil -- wash to shore and they are usually the first clues that there has been a spill.
As many as 100,000 puffins, murres and other sea birds will die in the icy waters off Newfoundland this year after landing in oil from "mystery spills." That will equal about 40 percent of the 250,000 birds that died in the Exxon Valdez spill off Alaska a decade ago, but the kill will attract little attention here because as many birds have died just about every year for the last few decades.
Mr. Tobin says that as little as half a teaspoon of oil can kill a bird. Feathers greedily absorb the oil and then cannot keep out the cold ocean water. Even a tiny spot can be fatal, like a small tear in a diver's wet suit. The birds get cold, develop hypothermia and eventually become too weak to find food or fly away.
Federal and provincial authorities have known for years that some maritime crews try to skirt regulations and cut costs by emptying their bilges offshore, where no one sees them.
Occasionally, a polluter is caught in the act, as happened last year when a ship bound for England was fined $25,000 (U.S.) after being spotted dragging a sheen of oil five miles long.
The Canadian Coast Guard now runs aerial surveillance flights looking for spills. But they must cover an enormous area, and many spills can never be traced. Even when the polluters are found and prosecuted, officials say, the fines imposed are too low to provide any real deterrence.
"The problem is the courts," said Brian Tobin, Premier of the province of Newfoundland and Labrador and a former federal fisheries minister but no direct relation to Stan Tobin. "The fines that are imposed are laughable."
The Canada Shipping Act, which regulates commercial shipping, is now under review and amendments have been offered to increase fines and make them mandatory in some cases.
As one of the founders of the Newfoundland and Labrador Environmental Association, Stan Tobin has done all he could to help wildlife -- everything from keeping oiled sea birds in his bathtub while they recover to serving on several commissions that have carefully documented the effect of "mystery spills."
Now 50, Mr. Tobin, a former fisherman and, he confesses, former bird poacher as well, said authorities that are supposed to be protecting the province's environment have shown they are willing to gloss over environmental issues to keep from antagonizing businesses that provide badly needed jobs. Unemployment in Newfoundland hovers around 17 percent, more than twice the national average.
Terry Harvey, director of the Canadian Coast Guard's Prevention of Oiled Wildlife Project, also believes that the province caters to commercial interests without fully assessing the effect of such decisions on natural resources.
"The province has been crying out for industrial development for some time, and that probably has driven us to make radical and uninformed decisions," Mr. Harvey said.
Mr. Tobin, Newfoundland's Premier, said the province has proved it will reject projects that harm the environment, like a proposal to build more than a dozen small dams to produce electricity, even though they mean jobs.
"We are concerned about the environment," he said, "perhaps like no one else on the planet."
For centuries, the province's economy was linked to the bounty of the North Atlantic, in particular the Grand Banks fishing grounds that were once so rich that a fisherman need only lower a basket over the side of his boat to get his daily catch.
But earlier this decade the cod seemed to disappear and the Canadian Government closed the commercial cod fishery, throwing thousands of Newfoundland fishermen out of work.
Projects, like the Hibernia offshore oil platform, bring thousands of new jobs. A joint venture of several oil companies, including Mobil and Petro-Canada, Hibernia received financial support from the Canadian Government.
Hibernia officials reported 21 small spills last year that dumped a total of about 600 gallons of oil into the ocean, not much against more than 130,000 barrels of oil the platform pumps up every day.
Hibernia received no fines for any incident. Mr. Harvey of the Coast Guard says he believes that there were many other unreported spills.
"In its environmental impact statement, Hibernia said the possibility of spills occurring was nearly nil," he said. "Yet we have oil in the water almost every week. "
Thomas F. Zapatka, environmental and safety manager for Hibernia, said the company strictly follows all environmental guidelines. "We've never seen any wildlife damaged or impacted," near the platform, he said.
Experts say sea birds are loath to come to land, and only something as awful as being coated with oil will bring them to shore. The point isn't wasted on Stan Tobin, who, truth be told, is loath to leave this land.
"I can't put my finger on it, exactly," he said, watching waves break on the gravelly beach of Ship Cove that he knows so well. "You develop this great attachment for the land. A guy could almost die for it."

 CORRECTION:
A map yesterday with an article about Ship Cove, Newfoundland, where volunteers clean sea birds contaminated by oil, showed the location incorrectly. The scene of the article is in southeast Newfoundland; another Ship Cove, shown on the map, is at the northern tip of the island of Newfoundland.

HEADLINE: WINE TALK;
Lessons From an Up-and-Down Past

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
"FROM the moment when you start to think of wine as an investment and not as something to be drunk, that's the end," Elie de Rothschild said almost 30 years ago, when he was managing partner of Chateau Lafite-Rothschild in Bordeaux. His words, applied to today's frenzied market, are still wise, if anyone will heed them.
Back then, the Bordeaux wine market had gone mad. After a string of mediocre vintages, the world was ready for a good Bordeaux, and 1970 supplied that demand. Americans, for the first time, had become important players in the Bordeaux market. Thanks to the publicity engendered by the excellent 1959 and the legendary 1961 vintages, Bordeaux sales to the United States had been increasing 10 percent a year through the 1960's. In 1969, they increased 50 percent from the prior year. The value of good older vintages shot up as well. 
 As Mr. de Rothschild said, Bordeaux wine had changed from a drink to an investment. But his timing was a bit off; it wasn't until 1973 that the Bordeaux market collapsed, and it took almost a decade before the market fully recovered.
Since those days, a new generation of wine drinkers -- and wine investors -- has appeared on the scene, just as eager to pay any price for high-end Bordeaux wines and to hold them as investments rather than to consume. The Bordeaux trade has gone through fundamental changes since the early 1970's but there are few signs that it is any less susceptible to the boom-and-bust cycles of the past.
New investors in Bordeaux with little sense of the past and big spenders who think the party will go on indefinitely would do well to read "The Winemasters of Bordeaux," Nicholas Faith's absorbing book about the Bordeaux wine trade. First published in 1978, it has been thoroughly updated and just released by Prion ($29.95). Given the current state of the Bordeaux market, with wines like Chateau Petrus selling for $500 a bottle and more, Mr. Faith could not have chosen a more opportune time to reissue his book.
Mr. Faith, a former business editor of The Sunday Times of London and a contributor to The Financial Times, first explains Bordeaux's beginnings as a medieval trading center. But he concentrates on the wine trade's long, painful transformation from a fusty, inward-looking community based on family ties, to a business that has opened itself to the modern world, though somewhat grudgingly.
Mostly, he writes about the rise and fall of the Chartronnais, the small group of powerful merchants, mostly of foreign origin, who controlled the Bordeaux market for two centuries. Originally banned from the center of Bordeaux by the local wine merchants, the foreigners, who came from Germany, Scandinavia, Britain and Ireland, settled just outside the city along the Quai des Chartrons. Beginning with the export markets to their countries of origin, the Chartronnais came to dominate the entire Bordeaux wine trade.
The influence of the Chartronnais families -- the Cruses, the Eschenauers, the Bartons and the Johnstons -- began to wane after World War II. To Mr. Faith, it was Baron Philippe de Rothschild, who took over his family's property, Mouton-Rothschild, just after World War I, who began to change things. Traditionally, the Chartronnais bought wine from the chateaus, bottled it, aged it, sold it and shipped it. Philippe de Rothschild chose to do it all himself.
Eventually many other chateau owners did the same, taking control of their own wine. In 1973, the most powerful of all the Chartronnais families, the Cruses, were convicted of buying cheap wine and selling it as higher-quality Bordeaux. The trial, which became known as Winegate, made it clear that many of the merchant families had routinely done the same.
Though the 1971 and 1972 vintages were of indifferent quality, investors snapped them up. With prices still high and a glut of wine from the enormous 1973 crop, demand began to drop rapidly. The world oil crisis and, to some extent, suspicions raised by the Winegate affair turned off would-be buyers. Investors who bought the 1971 and 1972 wines before they had been bottled watched helplessly as the prices of those wines plummeted.
The golden days quickly ended, as they almost inevitably will again. How long will the current boom last? In this country, at least, as long as the economy, which fuels it, continues to grow.
Will Bordeaux survive the next crisis? Almost certainly, as it has each crisis in the past. The Chartronnais are gone, and so for the most part are the international liquor companies that invested in the chateaus for a time. A new breed, including insurance companies and wealthy private individuals, has moved in.
And some of the old families who had been under the thumb of the Chartronnais have come to the fore. They are typified by Jean-Michel Cazes, who owns Chateau Lynch-Bages in Pauillac and Les Ormes-de-Pez in St.-Estephe. He also manages half a dozen properties, including Chateau Pichon-Baron in Pauillac for AXA, an insurance company with wine investments in France, Portugal and Hungary. Like many of the new Bordeaux wine merchants, he was educated in the United States and is at home selling wine anywhere in world.
The prestige of owning a Bordeaux chateau has always been high and, if anything, has grown over the last 15 years, when so many vintages have been good to superb. But as Mr. Faith shows and as any serious wine buyer should know, the Bordeaux wine trade is like no other business anywhere.
To sum it up, Mr. Faith, paraphrasing Winston Churchill's description of democracy, calls it "the worst system ever invented, except all the others that anyone has ever thought of."
 
Tastings
A Red Seeking a New Image
Lang & Reed Cabernet Franc 1997, Napa Valley, Calif. About $18.
CABERNET FRANC is the vinous equivalent of the decent guy in the movies who never gets the girl. It's always there, but never seems to rise to star status. One exception comes to mind: Chateau Cheval Blanc, one of the most famous properties in St.-Emilion. The magnificent wine of Cheval Blanc is invariably a blend of two-thirds bouchet, which is what cabernet franc is called in that part of the world, and merlot.
Cabernet franc is also the grape in Bourgueil, Chinon and Saumur-Champigny in the Loire Valley. Washington State has produced some fine cabernet francs, and so has Long Island.
California has produced its share of good ones, but the wine has yet to emerge as an important varietal. Lang & Reed, a new winery in the Napa Valley, is among those hoping to create a new image for the grape. Its version is worth trying. It has the intensity of a good cabernet sauvignon, plenty of fruit and an intriguing bouquet, but the structure is leaner and less complex. And it isn't marred by too much oak.
Unlike so many merlots, which can be mistaken for cabernet sauvignon, this wine has its own attractive personality.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
A Hum, Then a Shout: The Shock of the New at Tanglewood

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

DATELINE: LENOX, Mass., July 27

 BODY:
Since Seiji Ozawa instigated a shake-up two years ago at the Tanglewood Music Center, the summer training institute for young musicians in the bucolic Berkshire Mountains, there have been notable changes. This is to be expected. After all, Mr. Ozawa, the conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which sponsors and runs the institute, intended to put his stamp on the program.
No move this summer has been more provocative than the appointment of the Chinese-born composer Tan Dun as the director of the weeklong Festival of Contemporary Music, which has just concluded. For at least 20 years this festival has attracted international attention. Composers and musicians have felt passionately about it and been quick to extol, ponder and criticize the choices of repertory. Some highly distinguished and diverse composers have presided over new music activities at Tanglewood in the past, including Gunther Schuller, Oliver Knussen, John Harbison and Reinbert de Leeuw. 
 Mr. Tan, who was trained at the Central Conservatory in Beijing and at Columbia University and now lives in New York, certainly represents a departure. Going on 42, affable and full of irrepressible energy, he was present everywhere during the festival week and conducted the students in some solid performances of difficult new works. He also purposely tried to internationalize the offerings, presenting works by composers from 18 countries. If a large number of them were Asian-born and fairly young, that arguably represents an overdue correction of a focus that has favored composers from the West.
That said, as a composer role model Mr. Tan fell short. Earlier in his career his music was intricate and stimulating. But as he has gained popularity and won major commissions (including from the Metropolitan Opera), his music has become increasingly muddled and gimmicky, like his 1993 "Orchestral Theater II: Re," which was performed by the Boston Symphony on Sunday afternoon at the Music Shed as a contribution to the festival on a program that also offered Mr. Ozawa conducting works by Gabrieli, Mahler and Tchaikovsky. This 25-minute work for divided orchestra with two conductors (Mr. Tan and Federico Cortese) and bass (Stephen Richardson) is a trademark Tan grand statement. "It's about life, nature, growing," the composer enthused beforehand, "where nature, the audience and the orchestra are one." In two passages the audience is asked to participate: first by humming a prolonged mid-range D (the "Re" of the title) to reinforce the pedal tine drone that runs through much of the piece; later by chanting "Hong-Mi-La-Ga-Yi-Go," first slowly, then frantically.
Mr. Tan and Mr. Cortese took time to rehearse the audience beforehand, and the normally sedate listeners entered into the spirit with surprising eagerness. There wasn't much else to do, for Mr. Tan's score is pretty thin: orchestra drones, sustained clashing intervals of a minor second that take their time to resolve, some occasional orchestral busyness that evokes Chinese music. The soloist, Mr. Richardson, was required only to mutter low-pitched chants like a gravelly voiced Tibetan monk, though here and there he started shouting exhortations: "Light unending! Mountains! Silence!" The fellowship musicians in the audience could be observed in perplexed conversation afterward, trying to make sense of work that, even taken as theater, was cliched and silly.
That night the students presented a concert at Seiji Ozawa Hall called "Vocal Calligraphy," which featured works in which the mimicking by the voice of florid, elegant calligraphic handwriting is more important than purely melodic writing or the lucid setting of words. And the skill and craft of several works, most by composers born in the 1950's and 60's, were gratefully received after Mr. Tan's theatrics.
"As in a Dream" by the Chinese composer Chen Yi was impressive for its mix of leisurely yet elaborate vocal lines for soprano (Caprice Corona) and skittish fluttering writing for piano trio. Three Chinese Love Songs by Bright Sheng were also alluring, in which a soprano (Martha Angeline Guth) and violist (Christine Grossman) engage in intense interplay while a pianist (Christopher Luthi) measures the music with clipped rhythms and pungent chords. There were also interesting works by Unsuk Chin, Robert Zuidam and Karin Rehnqvist. But the master at calligraphic vocal writing was Earl Kim, who died last year and whose "Now and Then" for soprano (Marie Anne Kowan) and viola/flute/harp trio was performed; this is music of inner-directed beauty and stunning economy of gesture.
The level of playing was generally high, and sometimes extraordinary, especially Scott Andrews, a recent Tanglewood Music Center Fellow and, since 1995, the second clarinet of the Boston Symphony. Mr. Andrews played a solo piece, "Wings" (1981), on a prelude concert of works by Joan Tower. The music shifts from long spans of sustained tones that evoke the motionlessness of a falcon in flight to incandescent passages that dip and dive as the falcon picks its prey.
The final concert on Monday night by the Tanglewood Music Center Orchestra began shakily. Michael Gordon's kinetic but rather formulaic "Romeo," which like many of this American composer's works tries to merge Stravinsky, Minimalism and brash bold rock, received an uncertain performance under Mr. Tan.
The British composer George Benjamin's "Sometime Voices," in its United States premiere, was much anticipated and did not disappoint. Though just 12 minutes long, this work for large orchestra, chorus and baritone soloist seems a mystical masterpiece. The vocalist (Drew Poling) intones a passage from Shakespeare's "Tempest" in almost eerily halting vocal lines as the chorus comments in sputtering, soft abstract syllables or quiet choralelike benedictions. A keen ear as well as an indebtedness to the ecstatic harmony of Messiaen and the textural precision of Toru Takemitsu characterize Mr. Benjamin's work. The composer drew a compelling performance from the fellowship players.
Mr. Benjamin's work set up our expectations for the wondrous Takemitsu piece that concluded the evening, "Twill by Twilight," conducted by Stefan Asbury. But the program's most unusual item was "A Thousand Sweeps" by Wing Fai Law, a concerto for pipa (a lutelike traditional Chinese instrument) and orchestra, with Wu Man as soloist and Mr. Tan conducting. Like an Indian sitar, the pipa can bend pitches, wail softly and slide. But its sound is not large, so long stretches of the vivid work were call-and-response exchanges between the soloist and orchestra. The music is not what most Western concertgoers are used to and not what the festival has been known for in the past. Mr. Tan has changed that. And whatever you think of this piece or his leadership, this is what he was brought in for, and he did it.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
China and U.S. Meet on Trade and Chilled Relations Thaw a Bit

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 27

 BODY:
China and the United States held trade talks here today and agreed to higher-level discussions later this year, a new sign of slowly thawing relations. But they remained frozen on the most prominent issue -- China's proposed entry into the World Trade Organization.
Deputy Commerce Secretary David L. Aaron met with Foreign Trade Minister Shi Guangsheng and two other senior Chinese officials to discuss a number of commercial issues. Yet the Chinese only talked about trade organization membership indirectly, Mr. Aaron said, and they showed no willingness to establish a timetable for new negotiations. 
 "I think we're still waiting," he added. "The decision remains to be theirs."
Chinese officials have said they were still determined to enter the trade organization, the 134-nation group that makes the rules of global commerce, by the end of the year. Entry would require approval of the United States and other influential members of the trade body.
Yet China and the United States have been unable to recover the ground lost in April when President Clinton rejected a proposed deal, with significant concessions, offered by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji during a visit to Washington.
Criticized for missing an opportunity, Mr. Clinton then expressed a willingness to close a deal quickly. But before it could be secured, United States aircraft operating under NATO auspices accidentally bombed the Chinese Embassy in Yugoslavia on May 7, seriously angering Beijing. Talks on trade organization membership, human rights and security issues were suspended.
Beijing and Washington still cannot agree on how China should be compensated for the deaths of three Chinese journalists killed in the attack. Chinese officials have been unwilling to reopen trade organization negotiations until the matter of compensation is resolved.
Mr. Aaron said he found it encouraging that Chinese officials invited him to visit at all. In addition, he said, the Chinese told him repeatedly that their country wanted to strengthen its relationship with Washington. They also refrained from lecturing him about American faults, as Chinese officials often do when relations are at their worst.
Mr. Aaron said that he and Mr. Shi had agreed to lead a meeting of a joint commercial forum here later this year with Secretary of Commerce William M. Daley. A date was not set. The forum, called the Joint Committee on Commerce and Trade, will include working groups on information technology, aviation, environmental technology and in other areas, Mr. Aaron said.
He also said he thought it was still possible that an agreement could be reached on trade organization membership this year. Other officials have said that reaching a deal in 1999 will only be possible if it is endorsed by President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin when they meet in New Zealand in September at an Asia-Pacific economic conference.

HEADLINE: Benedict Wolf, 94, Negotiator On the Federal Labor Board

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Benedict Wolf, a New York lawyer and veteran mediator who served on the original Federal labor board, died on Friday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 94.
Mr. Wolf was summoned to Washington from his private New York practice in 1933 to become executive officer of a newly formed National Labor Board. Under the chairmanship of Senator Robert F. Wagner, it brought together representatives of business and labor unions to settle disputes, and Mr. Wolf acted as Mr. Wagner's legal assistant. 
 Mr. Wolf, a Democrat, was a principal architect of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal legislation. His interest in protecting working people from unfair labor practices during the Depression led to the formation in 1935 of a more structured National Labor Relations Board with branches around the country.
One of Mr. Wolf's final tasks with the earlier board took him back to New York, where 200,000 elevator operators and building-service employees were preparing to strike in February 1935. Foreseeing health hazards and a crippled economy, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia marshaled the Police and Fire Departments to keep the city moving, but negotiators, including Mr. Wolf, narrowly averted the walkout in a long night of contract bargaining.
Mr. Wolf became the executive secretary and chief trial examiner of the new labor board. He oversaw the board's administrative and field staffs and kept close contact with its 22 regional boards.
The system was functioning in the uncharted territory of a new law, the Labor Relations Act, and Mr. Wolf traveled coast to coast to see that the board was working as intended. He organized and oversaw a staff of trial examiners who fanned out across the country to conduct hearings when violations of the act were alleged. He regularly reported to the members of the board about its operations and the affairs of the regional branches.
He returned to private practice in 1937 but kept up his role as an independent labor mediator and arbitrator for several more years and later served on the New York State Mediation Board.
Benedict Wolf, a native of Wood ridge, N. Y., was a 1925 graduate of City College, where he played football and contributed to its literary magazine. While at Columbia Law School, he also pursued a master of arts program and received degrees in law and English literature in 1928.
In 1945 he was a founder of what is now the Manhattan firm of Wolf Popper, to which he remained of counsel.
Mr. Wolf's wife, Miriam Jacobi Wolf, died in 1995 after 67 years of marriage. He is survived by his daughter, Dr. Deborah W. Tanzer, and three grandsons.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil, in a Rift With Argentina, Suspends Commercial Talks

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 27

 BODY:
Brazil has halted all commercial negotiations with Argentina after the two countries, South America's largest economies, clashed in a series of trade disputes.
A decision by the Argentines on Monday to review imports for evidence of unfair trading practices and possibly to impose restrictions in some areas led to Brazil's decision. 
 The Brazilians also called for a meeting next week with Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay, the members of the Mercosur regional trade zone, to discuss the bloc's future. Mercosur has economically benefited all its members by stimulating cross-border trade through lower tariffs.
"This type of protection by Argentina is not legally foreseen within Mercosur, which was created under the principles of free trade," Jose Alfredo Graca Lima, an under secretary in Brazil's Foreign Ministry, said to reporters in the capital, Brasilia.
The tension between the bloc's two largest members represents the most serious crisis to confront Mercosur since it was formed in 1991. Mercosur ranks as the world's third-largest trading bloc, though well behind the North American Free Trade Agreement and the European Union.
Although Mercosur expanded trade among its four members to $18.2 billion last year from $3.6 billion in 1991, a severe regional economic slowdown has strained relations between Brazil and Argentina. The flash point of recent tension can be traced to Brazil's currency devaluation in January, which destabilized the flow of regional trade.
After the devaluation, Argentina's exports to Brazil, its largest trading partner, tumbled more than 30 percent in the first quarter of the year. And although Brazilian goods were made cheaper with the decline of the real against the Argentine peso, which is locked into the exchange rate of the United States dollar, exports to Argentina also declined, falling 22 percent in the same period.
The slump in economic activity in both countries explains the fairly severe decline in trade. And Argentina, which is more dependent on the larger, more varied Brazilian economy than vice versa, appears to be under greater strain.
For instance, there have been an estimated 10 bond defaults by Argentine borrowers in international markets so far this year, compared with half that number by Brazilian borrowers. Argentina's gross domestic product is forecast to shrink 3 percent this year, compared with a 1 percent expected decline in Brazil..
Argentina's first serious dispute with Brazil came in the form of an anti-dumping charge against the Brazilian steel industry late last year, and was followed by restrictions on Brazilian textiles. Similar actions involving Brazilian shoes and sugar are under consideration.
"Since Europe and the U.S. are also our significant trading partners, the problems with Argentina don't always merit great attention," said Michel Alaby, vice president of the Mercosur Integration Association of Brazilian Companies. "But in Argentina, where trade with Brazil is so important, this is a very big deal."
While economic concerns are overriding, Brazil's pressure on Argentina is also political.
The Brazilians, who are seeking to exert greater influence in Latin America, were irked by Argentine overtures to forge closer ties to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Speculation that Argentina might adopt the dollar as its currency has also worried Brazil's Government.
Nonetheless, relations between the two countries are better than they were 20 years ago, when Argentina and Brazil were stockpiling weapons and considered each other potential enemies.

HEADLINE: In Congo War's Wake, a Massacre of the Wildlife

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: BUKAVU, Congo, July 27

 BODY:
Kahuzi-Biega National Park is where Dian Fossey first saw wild gorillas. It is the first park to allow tourists to get near them, for a price that enriched local people. Bill Gates visited there in 1993, and he tipped his guide $400.
Now the park, in the jungles of eastern Congo, is providing a glimpse of how the war in central Africa, fought for five years now, is destroying the region's distinctly beautiful wildlife. 
 In neat rows near the park entrance, workers have created an above-ground graveyard for the victims' remains: the skulls of more than 40 elephants, 3 grown gorillas and a baby. Nearby lay the tiny severed hands of two small gorillas.
"In Rwanda they are talking about a human genocide," Basengezi Katintima, Governor of South Kivu Province in eastern Congo, said, looking over his shoulder at the skulls. "Here we are talking about an animal genocide."
Park officials estimate that perhaps 100 of the 250 eastern lowland gorillas in the park's highlands have been killed since 1996, along with three-quarters of the 400 forest elephants alive before the war. Poaching has picked up markedly since April: arrested poachers have admitted to killing 20 gorillas and 17 elephants since then. Trade in ivory thrives.
Even as the many combatants in Congo discuss peace, the war is also clearly disrupting a complex dynamic -- among animals, local people and rich foreign tourists -- that some conservationists believe is the best hope for saving the dwindling wildlife of Africa.
Before the war, more than 3,000 tourists, most of them Americans like Mr. Gates, visited the park each year. They helped keep poachers away, in part because so many people were in the forest. As important, their money helped build schools, roads and water projects that made people in the poor and densely populated area around the park feel they had a stake in its survival.
Now, with no tourists during five years of war, the local economy has hit bottom. Mankoto Ma Oyisenzoo, a primatologist and the park's director, said that elephant meat is popular because it is half the price of beef ($1 for two pounds). Hostility to the park -- once the home of pygmies who hunted and collected wood and plants for medicine -- is rising.
"These people have nothing," said Norbert Mushenzi, director of the Congolese Institute for the Conservation of Nature.
On a recent day at the park, the authorities displayed half a dozen arrested poachers, including Bulabi Lubaga, a 62-year-old pygmy dressed in an irredeemably tattered jacket and pants. The authorities say he is a longtime poacher. He said he was in the park collecting honey and trapping monkeys to survive.
"I was hungry," he said.
But Mr. Lubaga is only a bit player in a poaching problem that wildlife officials say has risen substantially since the turbulence in Congo began in the early 1990's. Poaching has always existed, officials say, but after 1994 the poachers began to do their work with automatic weapons, which made killing far more efficient.
The weapons were bought cheaply from Hutu former Rwandan Army soldiers who fled Rwanda that year after the killings of at least half a million Tutsi and moderate Hutu.
Since then Kahuzi-Biega National Park has been a base for Hutu rebels and Congolese guerrillas called the Mayi Mayi through two uprisings. The first one began in October 1996 and ended in the overthrow of Mobutu Sese Seko, the longtime dictator of Congo, then known as Zaire. The second began last August, and continues today in its drive to oust Mobutu's successor, Laurent Kabila.
Mr. Oyisenzoo, the park director, said poaching had become highly organized in the absence of any authority in the park. Elephants are slaughtered for meat, he said, and the ivory is shipped to Rwanda and then on to Dubai. Gorillas, he said, are also killed for meat -- which he said costs about the same as elephant -- and their heads are shipped abroad as trophies. Live baby gorillas are also sold abroad, he said.
What makes Mr. Oyisenzoo's numbers all the more worrying is that he is only able to see a small part of the park, the highlands that rise about 7,500 feet to the park's east 15 miles from Bukavu. The vast lowlands, which make up some 90 percent of the park, are still occupied by the Hutu rebels and the Mayi Mayi.
And he said he fears that many of the 2,200 eastern lowland gorillas there -- among a total population of perhaps 5,000 in Congo before the war -- may have been slaughtered for meat.
"The Mayi Mayi don't eat vegetables," he said. "Only meat."
The park's eastern highlands are distinct for two reasons.
First, some experts say the gorillas there, while called lowland gorillas, are actually closer genetically to the nearly extinct mountain gorilla. There are only 650 mountain gorillas left, in parks in Rwanda and Uganda and farther north in Congo. Eight tourists were killed in March by Hutu rebels, while tracking mountain gorillas in Uganda, and tourism has yet to rebound.
Second, many of the gorillas killed recently -- 12 of the 20 in the last three months -- had been conditioned to human contact and were, in fact, the gorillas that tourists came to see. Before the war, five families of gorillas had undergone what is called "habituation," a process that takes two years or more. While some conservationists object, tourists could actually touch the park's gorillas.
"You could swim among them," said John Kahekwa, 35, a gorilla tracker who has worked in the park since 1983.
Since then, four out of the five habituated silverbacks, the male gorillas who lead the families, have been killed.
And so now gorillas are much harder to find, which may make the revival of the park, apart from the war, that much more difficult. On a recent day, Mr. Kahekwa and other trackers followed a group of gorillas once led by a silverback named Nindja.
In October 1997 Nindja was shot to death by poachers while crossing a road. The head female of the group, Mugoli -- the name means Queen in the local Mashi language -- took over but has since been afraid of human beings.
"She doesn't want to see people because they fired on them," Mr. Kahekwa said.
He led a group of visitors though the forest, stopping at one point over the ashes of a campfire left by poachers and by a tree where elephants had once scratched their heads.
"I walk in here every day and I haven't seen any elephants for the past three months," he said.
Of the 24 gorillas in Nindja's original group, only 6 remain -- among them a young male, the only gorilla Mr. Kahekwa found after three hours of looking. He is not used to human beings, and with a loud growl, he charged at Mr. Kahekwa twice. Mr. Kahekwa dropped down but stood his ground. The gorilla backed off.
"He charged just to intimidate," he said. "But I talked to him. I said, 'Calm down.' "
The local authorities are praying for the war to end and for the tourists to return. Although a peace accord was drafted in Zambia this month, the three rebel groups have yet to sign and the fighting goes on, a bad sign for people and wildlife alike.
"If we cannot respect man," Mr. Oyisenzoo asked, "how can we respect the animals in the forest?"

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Gain As Attractive Yields Lure Investors

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Bond prices rose for the first time in a week as yields above 6 percent lured buyers.
"Any time yields are above 6 percent, they're pretty attractive," said Mitchell Stapley, who invests $3 billion of bonds for the Kent Funds in Grand Rapids, Mich. 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 9/32, to 89 19/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.01 percent from 6.03 percent.
Bonds also drew support after the Conference Board said its index of consumer confidence fell to 135.6 in July from 139 in June, a sign higher interest rates may be slowing the economy. Expectations were for a smaller decline, to 137.8.
Still, gains were limited by concerns that about $30 billion of corporate and Treasury debt scheduled for sale and the prospect of higher interest rates would hurt prices later. Two reports tomorrow may point to economic strength and inflation and prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates for a second time when its policy committee meets on Aug. 24.
"The corporate calendar is quite heavy," said Christopher Sullivan, who manages the $475 million bond portfolio for United Nations Federal Credit Union. "It may be a bit of a struggle" getting all the bonds sold.
Sales by Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and other companies planned for the days ahead offer investors a higher-yielding alternative to Treasuries. Wal-Mart, the world's biggest retailer, plans to raise $5 billion, while Sun Microsystems Inc. and Home Depot Inc. are each expected to sell at least $1 billion of bonds.
Allied Waste North America Inc. sold $2 billion of bonds yesterday, while United Pan-Europe Communications issued $1.54 billion and 300 million euros of debt.
Companies are rushing to borrow to avoid any glitches from the Year 2000 computer problem and ahead of a possible increase in interest rates.
Besides the corporate debt sales, the Treasury will issue $15 billion of two-year notes today, which may draw demand from outstanding bonds. These sales also hurt Treasuries because investment banks tend to sell government debt before underwriting big bonds.
They do this to protect against a drop in prices as investors absorb the new securities. They buy their Treasuries back when the sales are complete.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Shares Surge as Investors Chase Bargains After Selloff

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks had their biggest gains of the month as investors speculated that the drop of the last week made shares a good buy as long as interest rates do not rise much further.
Intel led a surge in computer-related shares after an analyst said the company, the world's largest semiconductor maker, was benefiting from strong demand for cheap computers. 
 The Nasdaq composite index rose 60.14 points, or 2.3 percent, to 2,679.33, after losing 8.6 percent since July 16. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 15.08 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,362.84. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 115.88, or 1.1 percent, to 10,979.04.
After declines like those of the past week, "I step in there and buy," said Uri Landesman, chief investment officer at Aaron Fleck & Associates, which manages $400 million. "It presents a tremendous opportunity for those who keep their heads."
Sellers overreacted to concern that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates, Mr. Landesman said. Now that that selling has dried up, investors who expect that rates will not head much higher are buying, he said.
Any Fed rate increase is likely to be limited to a quarter-point, or a half-point at most, Mr. Landesman said. "I don't think that would be nearly enough to choke off the earnings momentum we're seeing," he said.
About 723.9 million shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange, below the three-month daily average of 756 million. Eight stocks rose for every seven that fell on the Big Board.
Intel, the most-active stock, gained 4 11/16, to 67 9/16, after Drew Peck, an analyst at SG Cowen, raised the shares to buy from neutral and added 8 cents to his profit forecast for the year. He now expects the chip maker to earn $2.33 a share. Intel had lost 7.5 percent in the previous eight sessions.
Other makers of computer chips also rose. Micron Technology, the biggest United States maker of computer memory chips, gained 5 7/8, to 57 7/8, and Texas Instruments rallied 7 7/8, to 143 1/8. Semiconductor makers have benefited in recent weeks as chip prices have risen in tandem with demand for PC's.
American Express rose 5 7/8, to 142 3/8, after Kenneth Posner, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, started coverage of the stock with a strong-buy recommendation on optimism the company would keep increasing profit, partly through Internet initiatives. Mr. Posner said the shares could reach $175 in the next 12 months.
Over all, profit from operations for the 342 companies in the S.& P. 500 that have reported earnings was 15.3 percent higher than in the second quarter of 1998, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings. Once all the companies in the index have reported, profit growth should be about 15 percent, the company said.
Waters, a maker of scientific instruments, rose 3 5/8, to 56 3/4, after reporting second-quarter earnings that beat analysts' estimates.
Hartford Life, a leading seller of variable-annuity retirement savings plans, rose 3/8, to 50 9/16, after posting a greater-than-expected 21 percent increase in profit.
Ebay fell 4 13/16, to 99 9/16, on concern profit will suffer as the on-line auction company spends more to add workers and computer systems.
Chubb fell 1 15/16, to 62 15/16. The property and casualty insurer said second-quarter earnings increased 5.9 percent, lagging behind analysts' forecasts.
Excite@Home rose 4 3/4, to 50 15/16. A decision by San Francisco officials gives Excite@Home the exclusive right to offer Internet access over the city's cable television system, shutting out rivals such as America Online. San Francisco will revisit the issue later.
AT&T, Excite@Home's largest shareholder, rose 1/8, to 55. America Online, which slid 7.2 percent on Monday, dropped 1 15/16, to 98 3/16.
Some investors remain concerned that interest rates are headed higher. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said last week that the central bank would move quickly if the signs of inflation cropped up, leading investors to conclude the central bank will raise rates as soon as its Aug. 24 meeting.
Mr. Greenspan will testify on the economy today before the Senate Banking Committee. While the speech will be a repeat of the one he gave last week to the committee's House counterpart, investors will listen to the question-and-answer session for clues on the direction of interest rates.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Corporate travel managers win an important victory from Delta Air Lines on Internet fares.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
DELTA AIR LINES' decision last week to make its discount Internet fares available to corporate customers appears to have been an important victory for travel managers, who are always looking to hold down business fares.
Much of the pressure behind Delta's decision was applied by the National Business Travel Association, which had argued that those fares should be made available to corporations and that such bookings should count toward the volume quotas that determine the size of discounts that corporations negotiate with the airlines. (Internet fares, which are typically lower than negotiated fares, seldom appear in computerized reservations systems.) 
 In addition, Northwest Airlines said it would soon test negotiated rates and Internet fares for three corporations through its Web site.
Almost two months ago, Mark Johnson, the president of the travel association, wrote to the major airlines to ask them to load Internet fares into the computerized reservations systems so that companies would have access to them. Delta's decision was announced at the travel association's annual convention last week, even though it will probably not go into effect until December.
When Delta's plan does go into effect, it is expected to bypass the computerized reservations systems in favor of its Sky Links site and electronic tickets. The airline said traditional ticketing costs $500,000 a year and is four times more expensive than booking through its on-line site. Delta also hopes to implement a system of direct payment that will eliminate credit card fees.
But even while some details remain to be worked out, Norman Sherlock, executive director of the National Business Travel Association, said Delta's decision was a "very significant initiative."
He added, "We've been talking to other carriers, and we believe they'll follow suit."
 
Electronic Books
Beginning next Monday, British Airways passengers in first-class or business-class lounges at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago will be able to pick up an electronic book filled with the equivalent of 400 pages of daily newspapers, current magazines, financial information and perhaps even current novels or nonfiction books. Daily newspapers and financial information will be downloaded twice a day. The E-books, as they are called, weigh 22 ounces and, at 7 by 6 inches, fit comfortably into a reader's hand.
The trial period will last a month, while the airline gauges consumer reaction with the goal of putting the books in lounges at 22 United States airports to which it flies. It also plans to make E-books available on British Airways flights worldwide.
Eventually passengers will be able to check out the E-books before their departure flights and return them upon reaching their destination, or when they complete their journey. If all goes well, passengers will be able to phone and request a specific book to be downloaded into the E-book which they can pick up at the airport.
 
Millennium Tests
Japan Airlines, All Nippon Airways and Japan Air System each say they have completed their Year 2000 computer tests and are now fully compliant. Nevertheless the Japan Travel Bureau, the nation's biggest travel agency, said it would not sell package tours whose flights are scheduled to be in the air midnight Greenwich mean time on Dec. 31.
The reason, the agency said, is concern that other countries will not be fully compliant, and it "puts the safety of its customers first." The agency said it might reconsider, however, if the International Civil Aviation Organization declared the world to be 100 percent safe from the Year 2000 computer problem.
 
Playing Through
It may be hard for some to believe, especially when they think of the Upper Peninsula in winter, but Michigan is now one of the top golfing states. A 1998 report, recently released by the National Golf Foundation, placed Michigan eighth nationally, behind Florida, South Carolina, California, Texas, North Carolina, Arizona and Nevada.
Among those who travel primarily to play golf, it trailed only Florida, South Carolina, Texas and North Carolina. Michigan officials say it has more public golf courses than any other state, nearly 800, and that golfers contribute almost $1 billion annually to the state's economy.

HEADLINE: Kelvin Lancaster, 74, Dies; Revised Economic Theory

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Kelvin J. Lancaster, whose theoretical writings reshaped the economics profession's ideas about trade, industrial structure and regulation, died on Friday at his home in New York City. He was 74.
The cause was cancer, his son, Clifton, said. 
 Mr. Lancaster made two powerful contributions to economic theory, and they were felt far beyond the world of theoreticians. He and R. G. Lipsey wrote an article for Review of Economic Studies (1956-57) that outlined "The General Theory of Second Best." Before Mr. Lancaster, economists generally agreed that society's best option for consumers would be unregulated, perfect competitive markets -- which would drive prices to their bare minimum. That is why economists used to reflexively call for lifting tariffs or other barriers to free trade.
But Mr. Lancaster asked a simple, if intellectually shattering, question: Is free trade for all goods still best in the face of market flaws somewhere in the economy? For example, what if strong unions drove up wages and prices in the domestic auto industry, causing production to fall below its ideal level?
Mr. Lancaster's work showed that under these circumstances, a tariff on foreign cars could raise consumer demand for domestic cars, offsetting the depressive impact of unions on domestic production. Mr. Lancaster's point is that economists ought not jump to conclusions: when the best option -- perfect competition everywhere -- is impossible, society's second-best option might run counter to the economists' clarion calls for free trade and unfettered competition.
Mr. Lancaster's elegantly analyzed proposition was that economists forever after needed to carefully determine what policies worked best in a world where some markets work well, but others work poorly. A colleague, Prof. Jagdish Bhagwati of Columbia University, said after Mr. Lancaster's death "that economists constantly pay homage to Mr. Lancaster's insight, often prefacing a policy pronouncement with the reminder, 'In the world of the second best. . .' "
Mr. Lancaster's second major contribution was to revise the economic tool for analyzing consumer demand. Before him, economists studied the demand for a whole product -- how much consumers were willing to pay for bananas compared with apples. But Mr. Lancaster developed the theory for analyzing more basic preferences -- for something's underlying characteristics. For cars, that might require analyzing consumer demand for horsepower versus weight and fuel economy. That might seem an obvious way to analyze demand, but Mr. Lancaster's theory paved the way for economists to tackle a surprising array of new problems.
For example, classical theory held that countries would ordinarily trade with countries that looked like their opposites: The high-tech United States would export computers to the Third World in exchange for commodities like copper. But in fact the bulk of United States trade takes place with similarly industrialized places like Canada, Japan and Western Europe. Mr. Lancaster provided the ingredients for a potent explanation. Europe and the United States shipped cars back and forth because they specialized in cars with different characteristics.
Only by breaking down the analysis of consumer demand into constituent characteristics, economists came to realize, could they understand something as basic as trade flows. Prof. James Heckman of the University of Chicago said "Mr. Lancaster's theories have had a wide variety of applications, for example, giving companies a tool to analyze how consumers will react to the introduction of new goods -- goods that do not yet exist but that offer consumers bundles of characteristics whose demand can be studied on the basis of past purchasing patterns."
Mr. Lancaster was born in Sydney, Australia, and volunteered for the Royal Australian Air Force during World War II. He earned undergraduate degrees in English literature, geology and mathematics at Sydney University, and received his Ph.D. in economics from the University of London in 1958.
Mr. Lancaster was the John Bates Clark Professor of Economics at Columbia University and served twice as the department's chairman. He was elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and elected as a Distinguished Fellow of the American Economic Association.
He is survived by his wife, Deborah Grunfeld Lancaster; two sons, Clifton, of Avon, Conn. and Gilead, of Redding, Conn., and five grandchildren.
"He was widely regarded as a potential recipient of the Nobel Prize," said Professor Bhagwati. "He joins the list of extraordinary economists whom death deprived of this singular honor."
