HEADLINE: Insurer Establishes Foundation to Settle Lawsuits

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Advancing its campaign to consolidate Blue Cross and Blue Shield companies in the Northeast, Anthem Inc. agreed yesterday to finance a $41 million public health foundation for poor and uninsured people in Connecticut.
The agreement settled lawsuits filed by state officials and a coalition of consumer, labor and religious groups after Anthem merged in 1997 with Connecticut Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the state's largest health insurance company. 
 Anthem, based in Indianapolis, is also acquiring the Blue Cross plans in Maine, where it agreed two weeks ago to create a public foundation valued at about $100 million, and New Hampshire, where the foundation would be about $80 million, a company spokesman said. Both deals must be approved by state regulators.
The Blue Cross-financed foundations, which have ranged from $28 million in Ohio to several billion dollars in California, respond to laws requiring compensation for tax breaks and subsidies given to Blue Cross plans over the years. In the biggest example, the conversion of California Blue Cross by Wellpoint Health Plans, two foundations received cash and stock valued at $3 billion.
A merger between Anthem and New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield two years ago collapsed after the state attorney general insisted that Blue Cross assets in New Jersey be dedicated to a foundation and Anthem refused. Anthem has lately been flexible on the foundation issue, adjusting to varying state laws and policies.
Although each state is singular, the Anthem-financed foundations are context for a much larger conversion planned by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield in New York. Empire, which says it is about to report operating profits for the third consecutive quarter, has been meeting officials of the state attorney general's office and insurance and health departments to iron out plans to convert to a for-profit company.
Empire plans to issue stock, all of which would be turned over to a public foundation. The conversion requires the approval of a state supreme court. With the settlement in Connecticut, "Anthem has decided to take its medicine and pay the bill," said Nancy Wyman, the State Comptroller, who joined Richard Blumenthal, the Attorney General, in the suit.
Anthem said in a statement that extended litigation would not have served its policyholders or taxpayers in Connecticut and could have affected the company's reputation and good will.
Anthem, which is a mutual insurance company owned by its policyholders as was Connecticut Blue Cross. Anthem has about four million members in Blue Cross plans in Indiana, Kentucky and southern Ohio, and one million more in Connecticut. Maine Blue Cross has 380,000 members. New Hampshire Blue Cross has 320,000.
Massachusetts Blue Cross, the biggest in New England, rebuffed overtures from Anthem and is trying to block a takeover of Blue Cross of Rhode Island by Anthem.
Each of the New England Blue Cross plans is the biggest health insurer in its state but they are all financially weak and face competition from bigger regional companies, including Aetna U.S. Healthcare, Cigna's Healthsource unit, and the nonprofit Harvard Pilgrim and Tufts health plans. Kaiser Permanente, the nonprofit California-based health plan, recently decided to cut its losses in New England and left the region.
"We see a tremendous opportunity to take advantage of efficiencies and economies of scale that consolidations can create," said Jim Parker, a spokesman for Anthem.
In a still unresolved bidding war for Blue Cross of Colorado/Nevada, which has 500,000 members, Anthem raised its commitment to establish a $140 million foundation to match a competing offer by Wellpoint.
Todd Richter, a health care analyst at Banc of America Securities, said Anthem would have "a very tough time financing all the deals."
But Arun Kumar, an analyst at Standard & Poor's, said Anthem had a strong balance sheet and a big surplus and could arrange loans if necessary.
Anthem reported $178 million in operating income on $5.9 billion in revenue last year. It had $79 million of operating income in 1997 and $141 million in 1996. With reserves of $1.7 billion, Anthem has more than twice the reserve level set by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, even after setting up foundations in all the states it hopes to enter, Mr. Parker said.
Wellpoint and Anthem are among the nation's largest Blue Cross plans, along with Highmark Inc. in Western Pennsylvania, Michigan Blue Cross, the merged Illinois and Texas Blues plans, and Empire.
A spokeswoman for Empire said yesterday that its reserves were $454.6 million on June 30. Operating income was $13.9 million for the second quarter of this year, $14.5 million in the first quarter, and $14.9 million in the last three months of 1998.

HEADLINE: Former Chief Of GE Capital Plans to Start Buyout Fund

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
Gary C. Wendt, who built GE Capital Services into a financial powerhouse before leaving last year in a management shake-up, is planning a buyout and private-equity investment fund that he would run with other former GE Capital executives.
Mr. Wendt expects to focus on Japan and Europe, two areas that have attracted attention from big United States investors because of the large amount of nonperforming Japanese debt, estimated at as much as $1 trillion, and the quickening pace of reorganizations and takeover activity in Europe. 
 In a statement issued late yesterday, Mr. Wendt confirmed a Bloomberg News report about his plans, saying he had not determined how much money he would try to raise. He added that if he was able to garner enough to begin a fund, he and his partners "will not focus only on highly leveraged investments but will stress operating management, not simply financial acumen."
Mr. Wendt, 57, declined to comment further on his plans, as did Paul Street, a former senior executive at GE Capital and Lazard Freres, who is expected to be part of the group. But a person close to the situation said the group would seek to raise more than $1 billion.
At GE Capital, Mr. Wendt built a reputation as a dynamic executive who made the company into the biggest and most profitable unit of General Electric. In his dozen years at the helm, profits at the unit rose to nearly $4 billion from $300 million.
But it was a messy divorce from his high school sweetheart, Lorna J. Wendt, that ultimately gave him a higher national profile. In their divorce proceedings, Mrs. Wendt rejected a settlement offer of $10 million and sought half of Mr. Wendt's net worth, which her lawyer estimated could be more than $100 million. In December 1997, a judge in Connecticut awarded Mrs. Wendt $20 million -- half the Wendts' hard assets -- but a smaller part of Mr. Wendt's stock options and future pension benefits. To many, her legal fight came to serve as an exercise in determining the true economic value of a corporate spouse.
And despite Mr. Wendt's success at running GE Capital, he was said to have had a strained relationship with John F. Welch Jr., G.E.'s chief executive. During the divorce proceedings, for example, Mr. Wendt acknowledged that he and Mr. Welch were not close. And in December, when Mr. Wendt departed, Mr. Welch said that Mr. Wendt had not been considered a candidate to succeed him.
GE Capital has been very active in Japan, most recently buying $11 billion in commercial loans from the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan. But a person close to Mr. Wendt's group said it would stay away from the sort of investments that might also draw G.E.'s interest.
In Europe, Mr. Wendt's group would join a long list of American investment funds that have sought to cash in on the growing number of takeovers, spinoffs and other reorganizations brought on, in part, by the monetary union. Buyout firms that have set up offices in Europe or begun funds recently include Apollo Advisors; the Carlyle Group; Clayton, Dubilier & Rice; Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst; Kohlberg Kravis Roberts; the Texas Pacific Group, and Warburg Pincus.
Dan Blanks, a partner in Hicks, Muse, a Dallas buyout firm that is putting together a $1.5 billion European fund, said that according to IFR Securities, total mergers and acquisition activity in Europe has risen fourfold since 1984, to almost $600 billion last year.
"Europe is really undergoing a fundamental change," Mr. Blanks said. "The watchword has become, 'Get big, become competitive, or lose out.' "

HEADLINE: Consumers' Confidence in Economy Slips

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
Consumer confidence in the economy slipped this month from its highest level in more than 30 years even as Americans said they planned to increase their spending on big items, the Conference Board's figures showed today.
The research group, based in New York, said its index of consumer confidence fell to 135.6 this month from 139 in June, the first drop in nine months. 
 A separate index measuring consumers' impressions of current economic conditions, however, rose to a record, and indexes reporting consumer plans to buy houses, appliances and autos all rose.
"Consumers are expressing some vague feeling of unease, but fundamentally for them things are good," said Nick Perna, chief economist at Fleet Financial Group in Hartford.
Concern about the state of the economy six months from now pushed down the overall index. Consumers surveyed expect overall business conditions to weaken, with fewer jobs available and pay increases limited.
That may reflect "headlines about higher gas prices and interest rates," said Cary Leahey, an economist with Primark Decision Economics in New York. "People have jobs and are getting real wage increases, and they say to themselves, 'how can things get any better?' "
Certainly, Americans seem sanguine about their own prospects. The Conference Board's measure of consumer plans to buy houses rose to 4 percent this month from 3.9 percent in June. The percentage of those who plan to buy major appliances rose to 30.7 percent from 28.4 percent, and the percentage of those who plan to buy cars rose to 10 percent from 8.3 percent.
The key to consumers' current optimism lies in the survey's employment measures. For instance, the percentage of those surveyed who see jobs as plentiful rose to a record this month. A study of the index by the New York Federal Reserve Bank last year found that people spend based on their own situation, not the state of the overall economy.
"Consumers seem to spend more when they feel good about future job prospects than they do when they think business conditions are favorable," said Sydney Ludvigson, a New York Fed economist and co-author of the study.
In the first half of this year, companies created 1.2 million jobs, and the nation's unemployment rate has averaged 4.3 percent, close to a 29-year low.
At the same time, personal incomes have risen the last five months, and the Dow Jones industrial average set closing highs above the 11,000-point level for most of the first three weeks of July.

HEADLINE: For Serb Draftee in Kosovo, A Close-Up of Deadly Purges

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: LESKOVAC, Serbia, July 25

 BODY:
Vlada sleeps late and often doesn't bother to shave. He says he has stopped talking in his sleep, but he often finds himself shuddering uncontrollably, staring down at his trembling body as if it belonged to someone else.
His business as an artisan here in southern Serbia is in tatters, but he is forgiving people their debts because he knows they have no money. "I'm satisfied with small things now," he said, licking the paper on a cheap Drina cigarette so it would burn longer. "I want to make a lot of friends and not argue over anything petty. But if there's a car accident and there are dead -- I'm utterly indifferent." 
 Vlada, 31, was a unit commander of the Yugoslav Army in Kosovo. He hated it, but he is proud that he passed through, and he thinks he kept his soul.
But there was ethnic purging, and some of his men helped carry it out. They held the ground while the police and paramilitary troops moved through villages, killing and expelling Albanians. They looted freely and burned houses and stood by while others did the dirtiest work.
"There was a war down there, and the main thing was to stay alive," Vlada said. "Mostly, when I arrived, the cleansing was done, and it was done by police and paramilitaries, and it was awful and stupid. We soldiers are softer, we are not murderers, and it's an ugly thing to say, but those guys did a job for us."
He and his men spent 60 days without clean water or electricity, sleeping on the floor of abandoned Albanian houses in the hills, moving between Gnjilane and Kacanik. They prepared pond water for drinking by removing the tadpoles and dumping in purifying tablets.
Vlada watched his friends crack up or die or turn into avid looters or killers. They dug in against the NATO bombing, and they lived with the constant fear felt by uniformed soldiers in a hostile countryside facing a peasant army. They dreaded not only the Kosovo Liberation Army, but also booby traps and ambushes and almost any Albanian civilian.
"It was dangerous to turn your back, even on an old lady," he said. "You always had your gun in your hands or within reach."
He told the story of an Albanian in civilian clothes walking toward a Serbian soldier, who approached him. Two uniformed Albanian fighters shot from an ambush.
"It was a tactic," Vlada said. "And the guy who didn't shoot was a fool, and his family is without him. But if he shot first, then he's a murderer."
He rubbed his face and licked another Drina.
"When I was mobilized, I went to church and prayed for two things," he said. "First, not to kill anyone. And second, to come back alive." Even the first prayer was answered, he said. At least he thinks so.
But then he tells the story of three men in his unit who killed three Albanian fighters at close range. "Each one thinks he didn't kill someone," Vlada said. "But those guys had so many bullets in them, each one must have hit them all."
He commanded 14 or so soldiers on patrol, and "we became very good," he said with some pride. "We protected each other and we were faithful to each other."
There was a lot of looting, he said. "In the beginning, it was silently licensed by the officers, under the theory, 'Take what you need or want and use it when you're here.' Then people got crazy and took a lot of things. The first thing stolen from a house was the television. Our unit sometimes had seven sets, but of course there was no electricity," he said, shaking his head.
And there was no way to bring the loot back, except for the officers, who had access to trucks. So there was a lot of destruction, too, especially of expensive things like televisions, refrigerators and tractors.
About the expulsion and murder of Albanian citizens, his stories match those of others: The army held the ground; special police and paramilitary units, sometimes with long hair, beards and bandanas, cleared the villages, often killing those who resisted leaving; the civilians were channeled toward buses or the border; bodies were often cleared out by other police units. Then the army checked the villages again.
But there was some army involvement in driving ethnic Albanians from their homes. For these special actions, "to expel or 'cleanse' or whatever you say," another officer would come to collect two men, who would be gone for 48 hours or so.
"Everything was awful in Kosovo," he said. "It was full of horrible things. Not on the level of massacres, not that I saw happening at least, but there was nothing good. I think of myself as a form of pacifist, and even going there was horrible enough."
Vlada described how the paramilitaries and police units emptied Zegra, south of Gnjilane: "About 260 of them cleaned Zegra in 12 hours, 6,000 to 7,000 people. They took about a minute a house. There was shooting. The volunteers got to the center of town and started to shoot the first people to come to them. The whole village heard this and people started to run away on their own, and there were police to guide them toward Macedonia."
Then they went into the houses, looking for people, and sometimes Albanian fighters remained and there were firefights. "Soldiers couldn't do that," Vlada insisted. "It would have taken us three days to do all the houses. Soldiers couldn't just go into a house and start shooting all the people in the house right away."
He stopped, sighed, continued. "It was ugly but it happened, and everyone you saw felt like an enemy. It's the worst kind of war. A granny could have a grenade. The first blood demands second blood, revenge, and so it goes. The K.L.A. had their positions and their bunkers themselves, and as we were drafted, so were they, and their orders were to stay and cause trouble, and many of them were sacrificed."
To be sure, he said, some people liked the killing. "You find out a lot about people in 24 hours in a war," he said. He described clearing a house in a village where there were elderly Albanians still inside. One man went in while Vlada and another soldier kept guard. Another group of Serbs arrived, pulling out knives and wanting to kill the Albanians.
"These are my Albanians, and if you want to kill Albanians, you go catch them in some other house," Vlada told them. "But I was scared. It was stupid. We were yelling and nearly shooting each other, and we were all targets, and if someone was hiding in the stable, he could have killed us all."
They burned many houses, "especially the big, rich ones," Vlada said. "If we got in a house where we found K.L.A. insignia, or uniforms or pictures of men in K.L.A. uniforms with arms, you cannot stay calm. They are not the only ones guilty for this war, but they are among them. And a lot were in big houses, with Jacuzzis, and Albanian flags, when 70 percent of those in Albania don't have electricity, and you can't be calm. There's rage in you and you ask yourself, what more does he want than this? There is no sign inside of this country, but only of another country, and it burns."
He became mystical about the houses, he said. "Sometimes, they won't burn, even with oil," he said. "It's like the house protects itself. Then I thought, This is the house of honest people. And I ordered: Leave this house alone. You can see it won't burn."
Asked if the Serbs thought the Albanians would never be back to demand an accounting, Vlada sighed.
"People thought there would be some deal with NATO or a partition of Kosovo or something," he said. "They were stupid. You can't clean out two million people or kill 100,000 people, but some thought you could. There were a lot of army and police, and you had the weapons, and the Albanians were too few and poor. And without NATO, they could have done nothing."
Life at war was exhilarating and terrifying, full of adrenaline and sensation, and life afterwards is pallid and full of worries, especially in a war-broken, sanctions-battered economy where money, gasoline, sugar and even cooking oil are scarce.
Vlada has taken part in the daily demonstrations of army reservists in Leskovac for their back pay and for the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic. His experience is typical of many of the reservists interviewed, but he was a commander and more insightful than most. There is fury here, but unfocused, a tinder box waiting for a leader and a spark. The daily demonstrations are dwindling, last only about 15 minutes, and often no one even speaks.
"It's apathy," Vlada said. "There are lots of problems to deal with, daily things like money and bread, and like an animal, you deal with those things only."
No one here really wants to hear about the war. There are already a lot of divorces among his friends, he said. "People can't talk about it. Your life is awful and you're trying to survive that. People ask, 'How are you?' The answer now is: 'Same as you,' and everyone's face falls."
Already, he said, "people feel like the war was two years ago: they are trying to cope with current problems, trying to get money, trying to prepare for the winter" -- canning and storing food, when they can afford it, or cutting wood.
As for questions of war crimes, "it's the same as in Belgrade," Vlada said, "no one wants to deal with it."
But it does not much matter now, he says. "Kosovo and its problems are too far away. It's a luxury to think of Kosovo when I have such problems here. People are so poor that when they go to the shops, they just write i.o.u.'s. It makes you feel guilty, you feel somehow lost, you lose all the self-confidence that you had when you were there, in Kosovo."
The first days after the reservists came home, the police were absent. Now, with the protests, they cruise around town, not just in their little Zastava cars but in big blue four-wheel-drive vehicles with white bars on the windows. Many of them are from surrounding towns, Vlada says. "It's good thinking. It's hard to beat or arrest your neighbors."
Sometimes now, he says, he dreams that he is being arrested, but he is not sure for what. "Not for Kosovo, but because of the protests, or because I owe money for electricity, or whatever," he says. "But it's a horrible feeling of insecurity, and for all the reservists it's the same."
They talk to each other; they go fishing. "This is like the golden age of fishing," he said. "It's the cheapest form of entertainment and escape from reality," he said. "Really, a perfect escape."

HEADLINE: House Renews China's Trading Benefits

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
The House today renewed trading privileges with China for another year, separating United States commercial interests from a long list of grievances that Washington has with Beijing.
The vote was 260 to 170 to reject a measure that would have ended the trade benefits. 
 The outcome was widely expected, even though relations with China have nosedived after allegations that China stole American nuclear secrets, the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, a soaring trade deficit with Beijing, and China's crackdown on a spiritual movement, Falun Gong.
An unusual alliance of liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans tried to capitalize on the strained relations to buttress their contention that granting trade privileges to China would reward a Government that abuses the rights of its own people, persecutes its citizens for their religious beliefs and menaces neighboring Taiwan.
But the critics never gained much traction, buffeted by an intensive lobbying campaign of business groups like the United States Chamber of Commerce and corporations with interests in China like General Motors, Boeing and Kodak.
As a result, opponents picked up just four more votes than they did last year to end what is now called "normal trade relations" with China.
The House vote last year was 264 to 166.
Supporters of extending trade privileges, including the House Republican leadership and moderate Democrats, argued that engaging China through trade rather than isolating it would give Washington more influence to improving human rights and religious tolerance there.
"We can have a constructive, purposeful engagement with China or we can have a new cold war with a new evil empire," said Representative Tim Roemer, Democrat of Indiana.
Corporate America applauded the vote and expressed confidence that it would rekindle momentum for a deal to gain entry for China into the World Trade Organization this year. Such a bargain would require Congress to drop the annual debate and grant China a permanent version of what was once called "most favored nation status."
"China's accession to the World Trade Organization is the next key step, and one we hope Congress will take promptly, once a final market-opening trade agreement is reached," Dana G. Mead, chairman of Tenneco and of the Business Roundtable, an association of chief executives, said in a statement.
In April, President Clinton and Prime Minister Zhu Rongji of China fell short of striking a major trade deal to present to Congress when Mr. Clinton pulled back at the last minute.
The bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade on May 7 cut off negotiations altogether.
House opponents to making the trade benefits permanent have pledged a fierce battle. Administration officials are pinning their diminishing hopes for a deal on a meeting between Mr. Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China in September in New Zealand at an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
"I remain determined to pursue an agreement for China to join the W.T.O. on viable commercial terms," Mr. Clinton said in a statement.
Annual votes on trade with China are required under a 1974 law that was intended to pressure Communist Governments to relax emigration policies. The votes were routine until the killings of pro-democracy protesters at Tiananmen Square in 1989. Congress has never revoked the trade privileges.
The Senate has not yet considered the matter this year.
In a test vote this month, senators indicated that they would extend benefits, mostly lower taxes on Chinese goods shipped to the United States, for an additional year.
Even with the outcome preordained, a spirited debate seized the House floor today.
One of the most emotional speeches came from Representative David Wu, a freshman Democrat from Oregon who is the first Taiwanese-American elected to the House.
"The business of America must be more than just business, and engagement must be through more than just the cash register," Mr. Wu said in opposing renewed trade relations. "Real engagement sees the Chinese people as real people, people like us, people with aspirations, with hopes, people who aspire to walk the path of freedom."
But Representative Philip M. Crane, Republican of Illinois, said cutting off benefits would be counterproductive.
"A nation of 1.2 billion people is more likely to imitate our powerful example," Mr. Crane said, "than it is to bend as a result of our threats."

HEADLINE: Cox Is in Deal With Gannett For Cable-TV Subscribers

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
Continuing to expand its cable-television holdings, Cox Communications said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 522,000 cable subscribers from the Gannett Company.
Cox paid a high price to expand its cable operations. It is spending $2.7 billion in cash to acquire systems in Kansas, Oklahoma and North Carolina for a record $5,100 a subscriber. 
 However, the company said that its effective price was actually lower since the acquisition was a purchase of assets that generate a $350 million tax credit.
Nevertheless, the price was sufficiently higher than earlier transactions to push up the stock of other cable companies. Cox lost 81.125 cents a share, closing at $38, but Time Warner stock rose $1.1875, to close at $73.6875 a share. Comcast stock jumped $1.50, to close at $36.1875, and the Cablevision System Corporation rose 93.75 cents, to $72.0625.
While Cox did agree to pay a premium compared with other cable deals, the company is considered possibly the best operator in the industry, and analysts were optimistic that Cox could make the deal pay off. David Goldsmith, who follows cable for Buckingham Research Group, a New York-based firm, said that he believed the deal made a lot of sense, since Cox is "bulking up on subscribers and doing it in a clustered way."
"Cox already has a huge cluster in the Tidewater area of Virginia, so acquiring the Carolina system makes a lot of sense," Mr. Goldsmith added. "They are buying a scarce resource, and when you factor in the rollout of new services and what they will do to cash flow, that is not an egregious price." The new rollouts could be in the areas of digital television, Internet services and telephony.
Another part of the purchase -- Gannett's Multimedia Cablevision unit based in Wichita, Kan. -- fits into a regional cluster that Cox is building in the central United States. After its current acquisition is completed, Cox said it would have more than 2.4 million customers in a region spanning Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana, Arkansas, Kansas and Nebraska.
Because Cox is paying a relatively high multiple of cash flow, the company was eager to explain the price by pointing out the tax benefits of a cash transaction. Cox's treasurer, Dallas Clement, said that the majority of cable deals are done for stock, and the acquiring company depreciates the value of the assets that are on the selling company's books. A cash purchase allows the buyer to write up the value of the assets closer to the purchase price and therefore higher. The buyer can expense a larger percentage of the purchase price and reduce taxable income.
Cox is the fifth-largest cable operator in the country and has been creating regional clusters through acquisitions. After its current and pending deals close it will have six million subscribers and will remain the fifth-largest cable operator.
Many of Gannett's systems are already upgraded and considered a good mesh with Cox's systems. However, Gannett, which bought the cable systems five years ago from the Multimedia Corporation for $2.3 billion, has never been a major player in the industry, which has consolidated dramatically. This has enabled the larger companies to benefit from economies of scale.
Cox Communications was initially part of Cox Enterprises, the privately held media giant that owns The Atlanta Constitution and 18 other daily newspapers, as well as TV and radio station and an auto auction business. In 1993, James Kennedy, the grandson of Cox's founder and chairman of Cox Enterprises, decided that Cox either had to grow in cable or sell out. The company then took its own cable operations public and used that stock to acquire Times Mirror's cable operations.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Little-Known Stocks Gain On Usually Reliable Ones
For most of the 1990's, individual investors have gotten rich in the stock market by sticking to a couple of relatively simple strategies: buying big-name companies whose products they know or use and piling into stocks that have already been big winners.
But these strategies appear to be losing steam. Some of the stocks that have been the hottest -- companies as diverse as America Online, Pfizer, Yahoo, Gillette and Dell Computer -- are down considerably from their highs of earlier this year. Many of these stocks have been outrun by companies few investors have ever heard of. Market Place. Page A1. 

Cox Buying Gannett Cable Unit
Cox Communications is spending $2.7 billion in cash to acquire a Gannett cable unit with 522,000 subscribers in Kansas, Oklahoma and North Carolina. C2.
 
Microsoft Rebuffs America Online
Continuing the battle over whether users of its software should be able to link into America Online's popular instant message system, Microsoft rebuffed America Online's invitation to discuss a possible deal. C2.
 
China and U.S. Hold Trade Talks
China and the United States held trade talks in Beijing and agreed to higher-level discussions later this year, a new sign of slowly thawing relations. But they remained frozen on the most prominent issue -- China's proposed entry into the World Trade Organization. Deputy Commerce Secretary David L. Aaron, above, met with Chinese officials to discuss commercial issues. Yet the Chinese only talked about trade organization membership indirectly, Mr. Aaron said, and they showed no willingness to establish a timetable for new negotiations. C4.
 
The House backed trading privileges for China for another year, separating United States commercial interests from a long list of grievances Washington has with Beijing. A4.
 
Nursing-Home Chain to Take Charge
Beverly Enterprises said it would take a second-quarter charge of $175 million to $225 million, which could equal earnings for the last eight years, in anticipation of settling a Medicare fraud investigation. C5.
 
Stocks Surge on Bargain Buying
Stocks made their biggest gains of the month as investors sought bargains. The Nasdaq rose 60.14 points, or 2.3 percent, to 2,679.33. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 15.08 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,362.84. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 115.88 points, or 1.1 percent, to 10,979.04. C13.
 
No Delay Granted in Cendant Suit
A Federal judge refused a request by prosecutors investigating Cendant to delay a class-action lawsuit against the company while they examine an accounting scandal. The United States Attorney's office in Newark had asked for the delay, arguing that continuing the civil action would interfere with its criminal inquiry into financial fraud at CUC International, which merged with HFS and formed Cendant. The fraud forced Cendant to restate earnings for three years. C11.
 
F.D.A. Approves Inhaled Flu Drug
The Food and Drug Administration approved a new inhaled drug to treat influenza -- Relenza by Glaxo Wellcome -- overriding a panel of independent scientific advisers. A14.
 
Consumer Confidence Fell in July
Consumer confidence in the economy slipped in July from its highest level in more than 30 years even as Americans said they planned to increase their spending on big items. C8.

HEADLINE: New Home Costs Found Highest in New York

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
A study commissioned by New York City has found that the cost of residential construction in the five boroughs is the highest in the country, with pervasive corruption, outdated regulations and excessive labor and material costs continuing to make it prohibitively expensive to build new homes.
The study found that it costs an average of $183,000 to build one apartment in a typical six-story building in New York City. That is 22 percent higher than Dallas, 10 percent more than Chicago and 4 percent higher than in Los Angeles, where added costs to reduce earthquake damage narrow the gap. 
 As a result, residential construction in New York City has failed to keep pace with demand, the report says, pointing out that although building permits for 52,000 new dwelling units were issued between 1980 and 1996, the city's population grew by 120,000 households during that period.
"That shortfall contributes to low vacancy rates, skyrocketing rents and incredible rent-to-income burdens," said one of the report's authors, Michael Schill, the director of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law. "We found that rents in New York are the highest in the nation, and that one out of four renter households pays more than half its income for rent."
Labor is by far the largest contributor to the higher costs. For example, the report said, the base hourly wage and fringe-benefit rate for bricklayers in the city is $46.64, 35 percent more than Chicago, 42 percent more than Los Angeles and 155 percent more than Dallas.
While the cost of living has long kept wages high in New York, labor costs are also inflated, the report says, because of featherbedding and inefficient work rules, such as the requirement that plumbers install toilet paper holders, or that electricians install mailboxes.
The report was commissioned by the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development and the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce.
Among the report's major recommendations are a "broad redrafting" of the city's 38-year-old zoning code, which it calls "arcane and byzantine"; replacement of the building code with a model code written by a national engineering association to reflect current construction technology, and elimination of environmental reviews for new buildings of 90 apartments or less. Currently, all buildings with 3 or more apartments require an environmental review.
The report also finds that "contrary to allegations of some members of the real estate industry, rent regulation is unlikely" to contribute to higher building costs, except when a developer seeks to demolish an old building. In that situation, the report calls for the rewriting of the rent law to allow for the removal of holdout tenants, with fair compensation, if the new building will have 20 percent more floor space than the demolished one.
In conducting the study, the authors retained architects to draw up specifications for a town house, a six-story apartment house and a 15-story luxury building. Then they compared construction-cost estimates for New York with those in Chicago, Dallas and Los Angeles.
Professor Schill called the cost gaps "extremely conservative, because they factor out the far higher costs of land and soft costs," like professional fees, "in New York City."
Along with wage rates and inefficient union rules, the report cites corruption as a significant contributor to high labor costs in New York.
"Extortion, bid-rigging, bribery and other illegal practices are pervasive in the construction industry," it says. "These illegal practices often take place because organized crime has infiltrated labor unions and construction companies."
While Federal officials have been going after corruption in some of the city's largest building unions, the report says that more needs to be done. It recommends that the city create a commission to investigate and license all construction managers to weed out those connected to organized crime, something Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has proposed.
The report also recommends that builders and labor unions "negotiate a lower wage rate for construction outside the central core of Manhattan," and that wages "reflect the complexity of construction, and vary depending upon whether the development is low-, mid- or high-rise."
Edward J. Malloy, president of the city's Building and Construction Trades Council, questioned the cost estimates in the study.
"We are doing good-sized projects in the Bronx and have negotiated agreements on these projects that brought the price down to a number that the construction manager and the developer found competitive," he said. "I do not believe that there's that big a disparity in the wage package between New York, Chicago and Los Angeles."
Asked about the report's conclusions regarding featherbedding and corruption, Mr. Malloy said: "If you told me that 10 years ago, I would probably agree with you. But in today's market, all the agreements have been changed to reflect the competitive market, and most of the so-called featherbedding clauses have been eliminated."
The report says that a major reason that material costs in New York are excessive is that the city's building code is "stringent" and "cumbersome." The report cites as one example that plastic pipe can be used only in one- and two-family buildings in New York, while other cities allow it in larger buildings.
And the report says the city's zoning regulations "can only be described as arcane and byzantine."
"Only experts can wade through the multiple levels of regulation that may affect a single piece of property," it says. "This discourages new developers from entering the market and expanding the capacity of the city to produce housing."
Prof. Jerry Salama, who wrote the report with Prof. Martha Stark and Professor Schill, said that to meet housing needs the city must convert more manufacturing areas to residential use, something that zoning rules inhibit. The report also recommends against the requirement of environmental reviews for developments of up to 90 apartments, and up to 150 apartments of affordable housing.
"What we recommend," Professor Salama said, "is that the mayor and the City Council create a task force to undertake a broad redraft of the Zoning Resolution with the driving vision being to make it easier and more cost-effective to build housing."
The Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, Richard T. Roberts, called the study "a very good document."
Mr. Roberts added, "It really reaches the mark in terms of outlining specific steps that can be taken."
"We want to consult with the Mayor, the City Council and policymakers in Albany," he said, "and see how many of these recommendations we can put into effect in the next couple of years."

HEADLINE: North Korea Urged Again Not to Test New Missile

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, July 27

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and her counterparts from South Korea and Japan appealed today to the isolated Communist Government of North Korea to accept engagement with the world rather than risk "serious negative consequences" with a long-range missile test.
The warning, in a statement issued here, is part of a full-blown diplomatic effort to keep North Korea from going ahead with the test. 
 It was the latest in a series of admonitions from American officials including Defense Secretary William S. Cohen, who is visiting Japan and South Korea this week.
The prospect of another such test by North Korea, after a surprise test last August, has dominated the annual meeting of the Association of South East Asian Nations here.
It has added to the sense that security concerns have replaced economic matters as the top focus of the region. As the countries that were battered by financial crisis two years ago begin to recover, attention has turned to new tensions between China and Taiwan and to the threat of North Korea's missile and its ability to build nuclear weapons.
The United States fears that another test could set off a chain of potentially destabilizing actions around the Korean peninsula.
American intelligence data have pointed to steady preparations by North Korea to launch a Taepodong 2 missile, which has an estimated range of up to 3,750 miles, making it theoretically able to reach Alaska or Hawaii. The new rocket is described by officials as an advanced version of the Taepodong 1, which North Korea fired over Japan and into the Pacific Ocean in August.
The Japanese Foreign Minister, Masahiko Komura, said at a news conference here today that if North Korea went ahead with its test, the Japanese Government would probably withdraw the $1 billion it recently allocated for the Korean Energy Development Organization.
"Should there be another test launch by North Korea, in view of the Japanese people's sentiment, it will be extremely difficult for Japan to continue its cooperation" with the development organization, he said.
The development consortium, also backed by the United States, has agreed to build two light water nuclear reactors in North Korea in return for the Government's ending its nuclear program. The United States gives North Korea 500,000 tons of fuel oil a year as part of an effort to create an alternative to nuclear energy.
A breakup of the consortium could induce North Korea to resume construction of nuclear reactors that produce plutonium usable in nuclear weapons, officials said.
The Clinton Administration is also worried that another launching by North Korea would encourage South Korea to move ahead with several missile projects of its own, further fueling an arms race. South Korea recently proposed building a generation of medium-range missiles that could strike much of North Korea.
The test last year, which the North Koreans insisted was for a satellite launching, set off such concern in Japan that the Government decided to make an initial investment in the United States theater missile defense program. Another launching by North Korea would almost certainly increase Japan's interest in the proposed system -- thus irritating China, which views Japanese participation in missile defense as aimed at the Chinese mainland.
In their appearance together this morning, Ms. Albright and the two Foreign Ministers tried, without being very specific, to emphasize the positive incentives for North Korea not to test.
Ms. Albright said the policy of the South Korean President, Kim Dae Jung, for engagement with North Korea, its longtime enemy, and a program to be announced by former Defense Secretary William J. Perry, President Clinton's special envoy for North Korean affairs, would give North Korea a "good chance to strengthen its economic and political ties with the world."

HEADLINE: Plaintiffs in Monmouth See Power Company Negligence and Lack of Planning in Blackouts

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
When the power went out sporadically on four blisteringly hot days after the Fourth of July weekend, George J. Tzannetakis and some of his neighbors in Fair Haven, N.J., slept on their back lawns, missed out on work assignments because they could not use their computers and worried about elderly neighbors who could not get relief from the record heat.
It was not the first time in recent memory that the power had gone out because of system malfunctions at GPU Energy, the company that supplies power to Monmouth County. 
 But this time, Mr. Tzannetakis and his neighbors are not just getting angry. A few days ago, they filed a class-action lawsuit against GPU, accusing the company of poor planning, of failing to maintain its equipment properly and of failing to anticipate the increased demands that hot weather would put on its equipment.
"They've had other power failures, and they're never even given a slap on the wrist," said Mr. Tzannetakis, who is a consultant and an economics professor at Seton Hall University. "They're supposed to give us reliable and safe service, and they have not done that."
Mr. Tzannetakis is one of 12 plaintiffs who filed the lawsuit after blackouts that affected 10 towns in Monmouth County this month. The power demands stemming from the heat wave caused the failure of two 60-ton transformers at GPU's substation in Red Bank, N.J., so the utility ordered alternating four-hour blackouts that affected 40,000 customers in northeastern Monmouth County.
The company also cut power in some locations after several small pole-top transformers failed.
A spokesman for the company, Ronald Morano, said yesterday that GPU had not been served with the suit and that he could not comment on it specifically.
But Mr. Morano said the power failures were a result of a combination of problems at the Red Bank substation and the unprecedented weather conditions, circumstances that the company has explained in a report to the state's Public Utility Board, which is investigating the matter.
"We had not seen a combination of heat and humidity of that type since 1988," Mr. Morano said.
But the lawsuit, filed in State Superior Court in Monmouth County, contends that the company should have anticipated the hot weather during the holiday weekend, when temperatures reached well into the 90's.
"Temperatures were high, but within the foreseeable range," the lawsuit states. "Defendants knew or should have known that two transformers at GPU Energy's Red Bank substation needed to be replaced."
Mayors and police chiefs in the towns have also complained that the utility gave them little notice about the "rolling blackouts," creating chaos with their ability to respond to emergencies, traffic congestion because of signal light failures and a reduced ability to deliver other city services.
Mayor Gordon Gemma of Oceanport said that in his town, a group of elderly residents at a housing complex were moved when the air-conditioning and lights went out in their homes, first to the Monmouth Park race track, which also lost power later, and then to the headquarters of the regional sewer authority, which produces its own power and so was not affected by GPU's failure.
"We played 'move the seniors' all night," said Mr. Gemma, whose town is not a plaintiff in the lawsuit.
Mr. Gemma, who is a lawyer and once worked for a utility company, said he and other members of the Two Rivers Council of Mayors, most of whose communities were affected by the blackouts, planned to ask GPU for compensation on the real costs to their towns of the power failures.
"They want to maintain that the outages were due to an act of God and of the transformers going down," he said. "I don't think that was entirely honest."
Mr. Gemma, who is also a licensed professional planner, said that the company had not accurately anticipated the growth in the demand for power in the region and that it had not invested enough in improving and maintaining its infrastructure to provide even the same amount of service.
"There's going to be a lot of mea culpas going around," Mr. Gamma said. "But that won't get at the basic issue of why was there a major screw-up in notifying us about the blackouts, and what are they doing about improving their infrastructure to keep this from happening in the future."

HEADLINE: With a New Image, Jackson Campaigns Outside 2000 Race

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 27

 BODY:
With Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley set to address the Rev. Jesse Jackson's coalition of civil rights groups and urban activists next week, Mr. Jackson says he will not endorse either candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination until he sees which seems more effective in championing causes he considers crucial.
"The issue is not who will I endorse," Mr. Jackson said in an interview here. "The issue is whether they will endorse the policies." 
 Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley will have an opportunity to do that next week at a four-day national conference of Mr. Jackson's Rainbow/ PUSH Coalition, where each candidate will give a speech. Officials with both campaigns said they considered the conference an important chance for them to address Mr. Jackson's core African-American and liberal urban audience.
"We're going to work very hard to get his support and earn his support," said Chris Lehane, a spokesman for the Vice President. "We're absolutely not going to take anything for granted."
Mr. Jackson, who sought the Democratic nomination for President in 1984 and 1988 and is often mentioned as a potential candidate, decided this spring not to run in 2000. He wants to use his platform and political stature to influence the election from the outside and "set the climate for policy," he said on Monday, sitting at a plain round table at the South Side headquarters of the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition, the organization he founded more than 25 years ago.
Mr. Jackson says he wants to make sure the candidates -- and not necessarily just the Democrats -- feel compelled to focus on issues like health insurance for the poor, workers' rights, affirmative action and more money for urban schools.
Undoubtedly, one reason that Mr. Jackson, 57, decided not to seek office was that it seemed clear he could not win, but political analysts nonetheless consider him an important figure in Democratic politics, one who is seen much less as a controversial gadfly than as someone whose influence with potential voters has increased in recent years.
David Bositis, a senior policy analyst at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, has been gauging Mr. Jackson's popularity in surveys he has conducted in each of the last four years. He said whites were increasingly seeing Mr. Jackson in a positive light.
In 1996, 30 percent of whites surveyed viewed Mr. Jackson favorably and 50 percent viewed him unfavorably, Mr. Bositis said. In a 1999 survey to be published soon, 57 percent of whites viewed Mr. Jackson favorably, and 29 percent regarded him unfavorably. Mr. Bositis also said more self-described conservatives gave Mr. Jackson favorable ratings than unfavorable ones.
Analysts say Mr. Jackson's improved image is partly due to the man himself and partly a reflection of the political climate. In the 1992 Presidential campaign, Bill Clinton, determined to show he was not a traditional liberal Democrat, seemed to make a point of distancing himself from Mr. Jackson and the black electorate by criticizing the rap performer Sister Souljah, who once suggested that blacks kill whites, at a Rainbow/PUSH Coalition convention. Now, analysts and Democratic strategists say, the party appears more well-rounded and the nation's strong economy makes Mr. Jackson's talk about helping the disadvantaged seem less threatening.
"At the national level there is no longer a sense that you're going to be opening up the public coffers to tons of welfare recipients if you say what Jesse Jackson agrees with," said Rachel Gorlin, a Democratic consultant.
In addition, Mr. Bositis said, Mr. Jackson's role as Mr. Clinton's spiritual adviser during the Monica Lewinsky scandal has given his religious persona more prominence. His campaign to encourage corporate investment in urban neighborhoods has introduced him to more business leaders. And, he continued, his role in freeing three American soldiers captured in Kosovo enhanced Mr. Jackson's public image, even if his intervention in the Yugoslavia conflict rankled the Clinton Administration.
Ms. Gorlin says Mr. Jackson has evolved "from being a figure who was able to inspire fear" to a point "where he's almost reached a statesman's status."
"He used to be a bogeyman," she added, "and that's no longer true."
Mr. Jackson said he decided not to run for President this time because campaign financing had distorted the political process, because candidates were not as free to express controversial opinions and because non-candidates had greater "moral authority."
Praising both Democratic candidates, Mr. Jackson, known for his lyrical, passionate speaking style, suggested that the less-than-galvanizing personalities of Mr. Bradley and Mr. Gore would not hinder their campaign success.
He described Mr. Bradley, who has talked a lot about racial issues, as "a very bright guy" who "has integrity" and has "sought to deal with real issues."
Eric Hauser, Mr. Bradley's spokesman, said the two men "have a lot of respect for each other."
Mr. Jackson clearly has a closer relationship with Mr. Gore. Although the two were rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988, Mr. Jackson said the campaign ultimately started a friendship that was strengthened when Mr. Jackson comforted Mr. Gore after his son, Albert 3d, almost died in an automobile accident in 1989.
"He's so smart and so well-prepared," Mr. Jackson said. "Gore has been preparing his whole life for high national service."
But he was careful not to tip his hand.
"This is exhibition season," Mr. Jackson said. "I want to see how the game is played."

HEADLINE: Russian Premier Warns U.S. Against Role as Policeman

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
Sergei V. Stepashin, the new Prime Minister of Russia, warned today that the United States should not assume the role of international policeman, a sign that relations between the two countries remain frayed by the American-led military intervention in Kosovo.
Mr. Stepashin, in Washington to meet with President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and other American leaders, rejected the notion of a "Clinton doctrine" of intervention in internal conflicts in sovereign nations. "It is very dangerous," he warned at a luncheon at the National Press Club. 
 Nevertheless, Mr. Stepashin asserted that relations between the United States and Russia had markedly improved after the severe chill brought on by the conflict in Kosovo.
The Prime Minister announced that the United States and Russia would open planned talks on a new round of nuclear arms reductions next month and would consider mutual reductions in the number of spies in each other's country as a gesture of good will after the end of the cold war.
Mr. Stepashin's visit to Washington was his first since he became Prime Minister in May. President Boris N. Yeltsin appointed him to replace Yevgeny M. Primakov, whom Mr. Yeltsin accused of moving too slowly on political and economic reforms.
His meetings with Administration and Congressional officials were intended to mend relations that were strained by the conflict in Kosovo, which Russia opposed in part because of its historic ties to Serbia. His visit was also timed to coincide with an International Monetary Fund board meeting that is expected to approve a $4.5 billion loan on Wednesday to help stabilize Russia's floundering economy.
Mr. Primakov was scheduled to visit Washington in March but turned his aircraft around over the Atlantic Ocean to return to Moscow after Mr. Gore told him that the United States was about to begin bombing Serbian targets.
Although Mr. Stepashin's sessions with Mr. Gore and Mr. Clinton were described as cordial, deep divisions remain between the two countries on Kosovo and the United States' view of its role in the world.
Mr. Stepashin criticized the Administration for plotting to remove the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, from power and for refusing to provide food and other aid to help rebuild Serbia after 78 days of heavy allied bombardment.
"The thing is," Mr. Stepashin said in response to a question after his luncheon speech, "there are 10 million people there. Summer is there, and people are getting by. However, when the winter sets in, there will be a humanitarian catastrophe in the very heart of Europe. There are no roads. Enterprises have been destroyed. There is no gas supply, no water supply in many areas of the country."
Mr. Clinton has ruled out aid for Serbia as long as Mr. Milosevic remains in power, a position repeated emphatically on Monday by his national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger.
"We will not provide one penny for reconstruction and we will not work to bring Serbia into Europe, as we will do with the rest of the region, so long as an indicted war criminal rules in Belgrade," Mr. Berger said.
In an afternoon meeting, Mr. Gore and Mr. Stepashin talked about reducing the espionage efforts each country has aimed at the other.
Neither would respond directly to a question on the matter from a reporter.
"Some questions," Mr. Gore said at a press briefing this afternoon, "are best dealt with through completely private channels."
But Mr. Gore acknowledged that "old attitudes in both countries fade away slowly," leading to overenthusiastic intelligence-gathering efforts and bloated spy agency budgets. "And then the other side has to spend the same amount," he said.
Mr. Stepashin, the former director of Russia's security and counterintelligence services, confirmed that he and Mr. Gore had discussed the matter.
"As long as states exist, there will always be special services, intelligence communities," Mr. Stepashin said in a man-of-the-world tone. But he added that such ungentlemanly pursuits should not stand in the way of "partnerlike" relations between the two countries.
On arms control, Mr. Gore and Mr. Stepashin reaffirmed a decision announced last month by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin to open negotiations on a Start III treaty, even though the Russian Parliament has let six years pass without ratifying Start II.
They also agreed to talk about the United States' desire to deploy a limited antimissile defense system that Russia says would violate the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972.
"We both understand that there are ballistic missile threats we both face that do not come from each other, but from other nations," Mr. Gore said in a statement. "That is why it is important -- in parallel with achieving our arms control objectives -- to discuss implications for the ABM treaty should the United States decide to deploy a national missile defense."
Mr. Stepashin's visit came as the policy making board of the I.M.F. was preparing to approve a new $4.5 billion loan for Russia. The fund is releasing the money -- part of a $20 billion package frozen last summer -- to reward Russia for reducing inflation (to 50 percent from 85 percent last year), reversing a budget deficit, slowing capital flight and improving tax collections.
Despite some improvements in Russia's dire fiscal situation and an easing of tensions with the West since the end of the Balkan conflict, Mr. Stepashin's future is seen as no more secure than any other Prime Minister under the mercurial Mr. Yeltsin.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Second Thoughts Caused Split in Umpires' Union

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The umpires' strategy to induce Major League Baseball to come to the bargaining table began to unravel as soon as some of the umpires returned home from the union meeting two weeks ago and began talking to their wives and lawyers.
"It's like we drank the Kool-Aid and had ether shot into the room," one umpire said yesterday, discussing the July 14 meeting in Philadelphia. "I got home that night and told my wife what we had done and she said, 'Don't you think you should have a cooling off period and talk it over with your family?' So simplistic and so true." 
 The umpire, who spoke on the condition he not be identified, said his wife's reaction had punctured the high on which he was still operating after returning home from the charged meeting, where more than 50 umpires signed letters of resignation, effective Sept. 2.
"After I came out out of the ether, I sat on the edge of the bed and said, 'What the heck have I just done?' " the umpire recounted in a telephone interview. "After giving it some thought, I was one of the first guys to rescind. Not that I fear anything, but I started looking at what happens if they accept the resignations. There's not a lot I could do to make this kind of money."
Other umpires said they had consulted their lawyers after returning home, and the lawyers reacted even more severely than the umpire's wife did, telling them they had left themselves open to the loss of their jobs. If they were going out on strike, which their labor contract prohibits them from doing, they would eventually reach a settlement with Major League Baseball and return to work. Once the umpires submitted their resignations, however, the leagues were free to accept them.
Sixteen umpires who had signed letters of resignation subsequently rescinded their action, joining eight who had never signed.
That left 42 umpires -- 9 in the American League, 33 in the National -- who yesterday withdrew their resignations after their union leader and lawyer, Richard Phillips, failed to win the first round of the union's lawsuit in United States District Court in Philadelphia.
The umpires who held to their resignations until yesterday resented those who abandoned the strategy. The refusal of those umpires to go along with the strategy was basically a repudiation of Phillips.
"It doesn't matter to me if I like Richie Phillips as a person or not," Jerry Meals, a third-year member of the N.L. staff, said in a telephone interview yesterday. "We as a union voted to retain Richie Phillips for our counsel for the next five years back in February. That is how we voted as a union and that is how the union should stand."
Randy Marsh, an 18-year N.L. umpire, said at Shea Stadium last night that he believed baseball officials would have "paid more attention to us" if the umpires had held together.
The division in the union has created hardships for the umpires.
Bruce Froemming, a member of the union's board of directors, heads a crew that has Mark Hirschbeck, the only N.L. umpire who did not resign, and Wally Bell and Jeff Nelson, the two who withdrew their resignations. "I think it's difficult for everybody," Froemming said by telephone from Atlanta. "It's a big hurt because I've treated two of these guys like my best friends and almost like my son and I feel they've turned their backs on me. Jeff just came on, but I've known Wally and Mark for a long time."
The other three, Froemming said, had told him that they thought he was making a mistake, "that I will be unemployed and they'll be working."
Secrecy has become routine in the locker room, the veteran umpire added.
"We're not an open group anymore," he said. "They have complicated it. This is about individuals thinking they can do better for themselves. They're not thinking as a group."

HEADLINE: U.S. DRAWING PLAN THAT WILL MONITOR COMPUTER SYSTEMS

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has developed a plan for an extensive computer monitoring system, overseen by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to protect the nation's crucial data networks from intruders.
The plan, an outgrowth of the Administration's anti-terrorism program, has already raised concerns from civil liberties groups. 
 A draft prepared by officials at the National Security Council last month, which was provided to The New York Times by a civil liberties group, calls for a sophisticated software system to monitor activities on nonmilitary Government networks and a separate system to track networks used in crucial industries like banking, telecommunications and transportation.
The effort, whose details are still being debated within the Administration, is intended to alert law enforcement officials to attacks that might cripple Government operations or the nation's economy.
But because of the increasing power of the nation's computers and their emerging role as a backbone of the country's commerce, politics and culture, critics of the proposed system say it could become a building block for a surveillance infrastructure with great potential for misuse.
They also argue that such a network of monitoring programs could itself be open to security breaches, giving intruders or unauthorized users a vast window into Government and corporate computer systems.
Government officials said the changing nature of military threats in the information age had altered the nature of national security concerns and created a new sense of urgency to protect the nation's information infrastructure.
"Our concern about an organized cyberattack has escalated dramatically," Jeffrey Hunker, the National Security Council's director of information protection, who is overseeing the plan, said yesterday. "We do know of a number of hostile foreign governments that are developing sophisticated and well-organized offensive cyber attack capabilities, and we have good reason to believe that terrorists may be developing similar capabilities."
As part of the plan, networks of thousands of software monitoring programs would constantly track computer activities looking for indications of computer network intrusions and other illegal acts.
The plan calls for the creation of a Federal Intrusion Detection Network, or Fidnet, and specifies that the data it collects will be gathered at the National Infrastructure Protection Center, an interagency task force housed at the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Such a system, to be put fully in place by 2003, is meant to permit Government security experts to track "patterns of patterns" of information and respond in a coordinated manner against intruders and terrorists.
The plan focuses on monitoring data flowing over Government and national computer networks. That means the systems would potentially have access to computer-to-computer communications like electronic mail and other documents, computer programs and remote log-ins.
But an increasing percentage of network traffic, like banking and financial information, is routinely encrypted and would not be visible to the monitor software. Government officials argue that they are not interested in eavesdropping, but rather are looking for patterns of behavior that suggest illegal activity.
Over the last three years, the Pentagon has begun to string together entire network surveillance systems using filters that report data to a central site, much as a burglar alarm might be reported at the local police station.
Officials said such a system might have protected against intrusions recently reported in computers at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which produces information like the consumer price index that can affect the performance of the stock market.
The draft of the plan, which has been circulated widely within the executive branch, has generated concern among some officials over its privacy implications. Several officials involved in the debate over the plan said that the situation was "fluid" and that many aspects were still not final.
The report is vague on several crucial points, including the kinds of data to be collected and the specific Federal and corporate computer networks to be monitored. The report also lacks details about the ways information collected in non-Governmental agencies would be maintained and under what conditions it would be made available to law enforcement personnel.
Government officials said that the National Security Council was conducting a legal and technical review of the plan to study whether it would violate existing privacy laws and to address concerns about Government eavesdropping on private electronic communications and that a final version is to be released in September, subject to President Clinton's approval.
The plan was created in response to a Presidential directive in May 1998 requiring the Executive Branch to review the vulnerabilities of the Federal Government's computer systems in order to become a "model of information and security."
In a cover letter to the draft Mr. Clinton writes: "A concerted attack on the computers of any one of our key economic sectors or Governmental agencies could have catastrophic effects."
But the plan strikes at the heart of a growing controversy over how to protect the nation's computer systems while also protecting civil liberties -- particularly since it would put a new and powerful tool into the hands of the F.B.I.
Increasingly, data flowing over the Internet is becoming a vital tool for law enforcement, and civil liberties experts said law enforcement agencies would be under great temptation to expand the use of the information in pursuit of suspected criminals.
The draft of the plan "clearly recognizes the civil liberties implications," said James X. Dempsey, staff counsel for the Center for Democracy and Technology, a Washington civil liberties group, "But it brushes them away."
The draft states that because Government employees, like those of many private companies, must consent to the monitoring of their computer activities, "the collection of certain data identified as anomalous activity or a suspicious event would not be considered a privacy issue."
Mr. Dempsey conceded the legal validity of the point, but said there was tremendous potential for abuse.
"My main concern is that Fidnet is an ill-defined monitoring system of potentially broad sweep," he said. "It seems to place monitoring and surveillance at the center of the Government's response to a problem that is not well suited to such measures."
The Federal Government is making a concerted effort to insure that civil liberties and privacy rights are not violated, Mr. Hunker said.
He said data gathered from non-Government computer networks will be collected separately from the F.B.I.-controlled monitoring system at a separate location within a General Services Administration building. He said that was done to keep non-Government data at arm's length from law enforcement.
The plan also has drawn concern from civil libertarians because it blends civilian and military functions in protecting the computer networks. The draft notes that there is already a Department of Defense "contingent" working at the F.B.I.'s infrastructure protection center to integrate intelligence, counterintelligence and law enforcement efforts in protecting Pentagon computers.
"The fight over this could make the fight over encryption look like nothing," said Mary Culnan, an professor at Georgetown University who served on a Presidential commission whose work led to the May 1998 directive on infrastructure protection. "The conceptual problem is that there are people running this program who don't understand how citizens feel about privacy in cyberspace."
The Government has been discussing the proposal widely with a number of industry security committees and associations in recent months.
Several industry executives said there is still reluctance on the part of industry to directly share information on computer intrusions with law enforcement.
"They want to control the decision making process," said Mark Rasch, vice president and general counsel of Global Integrity, a company in Reston, Va., coordinating computer security for the financial services industries.
One potential problem in carrying out the Government's plan is that intrusion-detection software technology is still immature, industry executives said.
"The commercial intrusion detection systems are not ready for prime time," said Peter Neumann, a computer scientist at SRI International in Menlo Park, Calif., and a pioneer in the field of intrusion detection systems.
Current systems tend to generate false alarms and thus require many skilled operators.
But a significant portion of the $1.4 billion the Clinton Administration has requested for computer security for fiscal year 2000 is intended to be spent on research, and Government officials said they were hopeful that the planned effort would be able to rely on automated detection technologies and on artificial intelligence capabilities.
For several years computer security specialists have used software variously known as packet filters, or "sniffers," as monitoring devices to track computer intruders. Like telephone wiretaps, such tools can be used to reconstruct the activities of a computer user as if a videotape were made of his computer display.
At the same time, however, the software tools are routinely misused by illicit computer network users in stealing information such as passwords or other data.
Commercial vendors are beginning to sell monitoring tools that combine packet filtering with more sophisticated and automated intrusion detection software that tries to detect abuse by looking for behavior patterns or certain sequences of commands.

HEADLINE: Will a Tax Cut Hurt the Economy?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Seeking Common Ground on Federal Tax Cut" (news article, July 25):
Now is not the time for a tax cut. The Federal Reserve Board recently raised interest rates to slow the economy down. 
 A tax cut will stimulate the economy further, prompting the Federal Reserve to compensate with a larger interest-rate increase. At some future point when the economy needs a boost a tax cut would be a useful tool. Why squander it now?
In the meantime, there's a little matter of the national debt. When do Republicans figure the debt should be paid off? When we're in a recession?
 
JAMES AFFELD
Douglas, Alaska, July 25, 1999

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 169 words

HEADLINE: Will a Tax Cut Hurt the Economy?;
Punishing the Strivers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Enhancement of the New York State earned income tax credit is justifiable (editorial, July 24). Currently, however, the program suffers from flaws.
Above a certain income level, the loss of benefits as household income rises limits the value of additional work efforts. 
 For each additional $100 of income above $12,260, households lose $21 of credits. Households will also get fewer food stamps and pay more Social Security and Federal and state income taxes, as well as child-care and commuting expenses.
Therefore, the net earnings from the extra income can be quite low. Indeed, Congress estimated that in 1997, a household headed by a female with two dependent children netted only $861 if her wages rose from $15,000 to $20,000. The solution is to make the earned-income tax credit universal so that the near-poor can gain more from their extra work efforts.
 
ROBERT CHERRY
Brooklyn, July 24, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Brooklyn College, CUNY.
