SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1275 words

HEADLINE: A $200 Million School That May Never Open

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 24

 BODY:
It looms on a lonely lot at the edge of downtown, a hulking pile of buff brick and brown stone, like some half-finished temple or pharaoh's tomb. It would be the most expensive public high school ever built in the United States, at a cost of more than $200 million, but the Belmont Learning Center may never be finished -- and if it is, no one may want to go to school there.
The school was built atop an abandoned oilfield, despite repeated warnings, and officials now say there may be no way to vent away seeping methane gas and other hazards to make it safe to occupy. This week the Los Angeles Board of Education, with four newly elected members, voted to create a commission to recommend whether to abandon the project after $125 million has already been spent on it, or spend millions more to make it work. 
 The Belmont story is a classic Los Angeles tale of sunny civic boosterism and shadowy real estate speculation and of the ever-present environmental hazards in a city that a century ago was a sparsely populated outpost dotted with oil wells and bean fields and is now a giant metropolis built astride constantly shifting earthquake faults. As the drama has dragged on, the problem that Belmont was meant to address -- severely overcrowded schools in the city's downtown neighborhoods -- remains unabated.
"It's not going to go away," said State Senator Tom Hayden of Los Angeles, one of the Belmont project's most persistent critics, noting the no-win situation. "If they abandon it, it's going to be the subject of screenplays and East Coast merriment for years. And if they open it, they're going to face endless litigation by parents who think it's going to one day be the site of a methane fire or explosion."
The effort began more than a decade ago with a plan to build a downtown high school on the site of the old Ambassador Hotel, the once-grand hostelry where Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York was assassinated in June 1968.
The school district condemned the property, but its owner, the New York developer Donald J. Trump, who wanted to build a skyscraper there, threatened a legal challenge over the price. In the real estate recession of the early 1990's, the Board of Education dropped that site in favor of one of the last remaining open parcels near downtown, a former oilfield at First Street and Beaudry Avenue.
From the beginning, the plan envisioned what school officials said would be the most expensive high school in the country, a 5,300-student complex comprising eight "academies," plus a housing and retail development to be built in a partnership with a private developer, Kajima Urban Development. But the retail and housing elements have since been dropped, in part because retail tenants were not interested in the somewhat isolated site, a gritty hillside sandwiched in an L made by the intersection of two freeways.
As early as 1993, officials of the state Division of Oil and Gas warned Los Angeles school officials about the dangers of building over an abandoned oilfield, but the school district and the developer forged ahead, taking soil samples that district officials and outside critics now say were clearly inadequate.
The Board of Education's outside legal counsel, David Cartwright of the city's leading law firm, O'Melveny & Myers, helped negotiate with the developer, Kajima, and assured the board that it was safe to go forward without a full environmental study, although it was later disclosed that his firm also represented the developer, a subsidiary of a giant Japanese construction company.
Mr. Cartwright has defended his actions as proper, but last winter the school board relieved him of duties on the Belmont project. He continues as counsel on other issues.
Construction began two years ago, with two dissenting votes on the seven-member school board. But before the groundbreaking, Assemblyman Scott Wildman, who represents the nearby communities of Glendale and Burbank and heads the Joint Legislative Audit Committee, with oversight of public entities like school districts, had begun raising questions about the contracting and safety issues for the project, and he urged the district to hold off.
Since then, Mr. Wildman has made public nine critical reports on the project, and environmental consultants hired by the district itself have shown dangerous concentrations of methane as well as hydrogen sulfide, a toxic gas that can cause neurological damage.
Some of the district's own experts have even suggested that the entire ground floor of the building be off-limits to children, to protect them from any buildup of dangerous gases. Even if a system could be devised to vent the gases, the reports have suggested, it would cost perhaps $100,000 a year to operate for the life of the school, while an earthquake fault running under the property could leave the mechanical systems subject to sudden failure.
"I think the project should be abandoned and torn down," Mr. Wildman said in a recent interview. "There shouldn't be children who go there and there shouldn't be people who work there. They made a mistake. We tried to stop them before they started, but they went ahead anyway. Frankly, they should have made the decision two years ago."
But several local officials, including Mayor Richard J. Riordan, had supported the project, and it was not until last fall, when the state Department of Toxic Substance Control concluded that the site had never been adequately assessed, that momentum grew for re-evaluation. After commissioning new tests, the district suspended most construction in February. Alternatives would be expensive, including building several smaller high schools in the area, at a cost of perhaps $75 million each.
A new, four-member majority was elected to the school board this spring on a promise to take a hard look at the Belmont project, and they had been expected to call a permanent halt. Instead, after a daylong closed session and a spirited public hearing on Tuesday, the board voted to "secure the site" by installing doors, windows and roofing to protect it from the elements, but postponed a definitive decision, opting instead to appoint a citizens' commission to make recommendations by mid-October. The board members also voted to impose a gag order on themselves and the district staff, barring any further comment on the project in the meantime.
"One of the problems with this project is there hasn't been a great deal of planning ahead," said a new board member, Caprice Young.
Despite the environmental debate, several parents testified at the hearing in support of finishing the school, saying the neighborhood badly needed it.
"Our concerns are not being heard and we are more overcrowded than ever," said Tina Hough, a 35-year resident of the neighborhood who was bused to far-flung neighborhoods to go to school. "Am I to put my children through the same thing I went through?"
Dominic Shambra, the former school official, now retired, who oversaw the Belmont project as the district's director of planning and development, also testified. He dismissed the environmental concerns as "unsubstantiated allegations," and told board members, "You are now surrounded by an environmental hysteria created by the district's own consultants."
Mr. Shambra said the problems could be remedied and that conclusions that the site is beyond repair are exaggerated.
But Mr. Wildman said it was too late to make the project work.
"It's just one thing after another," he said. "We keep finding more problems. Bureaucrats need to have permission to cut their losses and stop throwing good money after bad."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: July 31, 1999, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the Los Angeles Board of Education's debate over whether to abandon a $200 million school project because of concerns about its environmental safety misstated the views of an outside lawyer for the school district. The lawyer, David Cartwright of the law firm O'Melveny & Myers, assured the board that it was safe to build the school on land adjoining a former oilfield only after a full environmental review and an analysis of recommended safety measures had been completed. He did not say the project would be safe without such a study.
The article also incompletely described the law firm's role in representing the district and the project's developer, Kajima Urban Development. The firm represented the developer on other matters, not the school project. Both clients were aware of and agreed to this arrangement and it was disclosed before negotiations on the project, not afterward.

An article on July 28 about the Los Angeles Board of Education's debate over whether to abandon a $200 million school project because of environmental concerns misidentified the developer who is building the school. SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; House & Home/Style Desk

LENGTH: 1679 words

HEADLINE: Attic Gold A Commute Away

BYLINE: By STEVEN SCLAROFF

 BODY:
WONDERING where to go on a weekend afternoon to get out of the sweltering city and find quality antiques at competitive prices? How about the suburbs? I spent a summer Saturday shopping for antiques in suburban New York and Connecticut. As a designer (read: snob), I had had my doubts, but what I discovered was a remarkable range of stores dealing in the high-end castoffs of big-money bedroom communities.
I had set out for the huge annual flea market in Farmington, Conn., but when I pulled out the map on the road and saw I would have to drive three more hours, I changed plans. Better to shop nearer to New York, I thought, and avoid spending hours in the car (which I did anyway). My six-hour odyssey took me from Larchmont to Stamford. 
 My detour was a bit of an epiphany. I remembered the good pickings in Larchmont and Mamaroneck from visits of 10 years ago while I was still an architecture student. And I had long meant to explore the immense, windowless antiques malls right by Interstate 95 in Stamford, since other designers and dealers were always talking up their quality. Each stop yielded good stuff.
While prices are consistent with those of downtown Manhattan antiques stores, the variety and quality is higher than you find in that heavily picked market, where an uncommonly flush economy is fueling voracious buying. And though flea markets in Connecticut tend to be full of country pieces, they also have an abundance of sophisticated furniture and accessories, from Renaissance revival to Florence Knoll, which would work as well in a slick city apartment as in a Tudor house on the links.
I got off the Hutchinson River Parkway in Larchmont, where antiques stores dot Boston Post Road. I stopped at the Woolf's Den, a small store that's a tangle of furniture, accessories and art. There were dark, heavily carved Renaissance-style and Chinese stools and tables from the 1920's ($150 to $400) and midcentury Murano crystal vases ($35 to $75). I saw piles of picture frames, from Victorian gilt to 50's lacquer ($30 to $200). Some still hold artwork of varying quality, much of which might best be termed outsider art.
Half Kurt Schwitters, half Joseph Cornell -- that's the charm of the place. Even the bad things have something humorous about them. The shop was founded by David Woolf and his brother more than 35 years ago, and it's easy to believe that merchandise from the first day survives at the bottom of the heap, obscured by vintage dust.
There are other stores to investigate along this strip in Larchmont, but I like this one best. Like the town, it is closely packed and without the Disneyesque polish of some surrounding communities. It even has a bit of the Edward Gorey flavor of Larchmont's Victorian houses. From the street, the shop is distinguished by windows so crammed with old crystal that the owner can't get to the burned-out display lights to change them.
Back in the car, I followed the Post Road north to Mamaroneck, turning off on Mamaroneck Avenue, which is Main Street, U.S.A. In addition to small gift shops, a dime store and a Christian Science reading room, the street boasts four antiques stores. More proletarian than professional, Mamaroneck is great: down to earth, even a bit sloppy. And because of all the 20's Tudor houses in the area, a wealth of ornate Gothic furnishings is lurking in the shops. In fact, 20's and 30's things abound, because that's mostly when these towns rose from farmland.
The biggest store is Chatsworth Auction Gallery, at the same spot since 1937. The turnover seems brisker than at the Woolf's Den, but the merchandise is piled as high. There are four floors, mostly of furniture, some of it heinous, but I made great finds. Within the floor-to-ceiling stacks, I spotted a pair of 30's limed-oak step bookcases ($125 each), a lacy, white, king-size iron headboard in what could be termed Miami Beach baroque ($175) and a wrought-iron-and-glass fishbowl that would be at home in a Jules Verne novel ($125). There are rows of sofas and armchairs in the rough ($100 to $800), both traditional and modern.
The other stores on Mamaroneck Avenue deal in wares as diverse as carved midcentury baroque furniture and turn-of-the-century family photo albums (all exhibited in virtual darkness). Though Chatsworth is really the prize, the others are worth a look.
Along the Post Road from Mamaroneck to Stamford, I stopped on well-scrubbed Purchase Street in Rye. There I visited Twig Antiques, a small store specializing in American antiques from the late 18th and early 19th centuries. The selection is focused and nicely arranged, and all sales benefit United Hospital. I bought three large apothecary jars with reverse-painted glass labels for $25 each. They would more typically cost about $75 each. I saw a beautiful set of 12 English export-china plates in bold red and blue with little or no wear for less than $1,000 and nice Chippendale-style mirrors and mahogany tables, bureaus and chairs in excellent repair. Though decidedly preppy (like Colonial revival Rye), these familiar classics are easy to like.
From Rye, I took Route I-95 to Stamford, getting off at Exit 7, which is all glitzy glass office buildings to the west and low-lying warehouses and a scrap heap to the east. I headed east, where there are antiques malls within blocks of one another.
Having derided friends who said they had found good things in such places (which I used to think of as repositories for movie ephemera and military memorabilia), I'm embarrassed to say they are right. From the potholed, desolate streets, these mammoth, windowless bunkers don't look like much, but inside lies a huge stock of garden ornaments, highboys and everything in between. A lot of it, though not cheap, is special and in ready-to-use condition. And no trouble spotting defects under the stadium-style lighting.
The Stamford area has not always enjoyed wealth and culture, but nearby Greenwich and New Canaan certainly have. And while it's conjecture, I'll bet that a lot of the French and English antiques circulating are rejects from professionally decorated houses in those towns, because many of these stylish objects evoke the decorating trends of the 1960's and early 70's. The castoffs look pretty good today.
At Hiden Galleries, at Canal and Jefferson Streets, there were modish pairs of carved French chairs ($1,000 to $2,000), a very simple, modern-feeling Italian bombe console in patchwork veneer ($2,200) and some great lamps in crystal, woven metal and alabaster, as well as a humorous pair made from mock-classical Greek vases (as interpreted circa 1955). Like the other Stamford antique malls, this one sprawls, but it has a hidden double-height room full of overscale pieces and architectural artifacts. The room is, if nothing else, a surprise to discover.
Down Canal Street, at Debbie's Stamford Antiques Center (a former bra factory, then train shed), I found a pair of foliate Romanesque terra cotta newel posts for $2,350. Reminiscent of Karl Blossfeldt images, they would be perfect for a garden or as gateposts by a driveway, though you might have a little trouble hoisting them onto a terrace. They were in perfect condition, and the price was fair. Amazingly, there was a plywood Frank Lloyd Wright Usonian side chair ($3,950) from the Manson House in Wausau, Wis. A central corridor full of display cases holds myriad accessories, including silver serving pieces and china.
At the Antique and Artisan Center on Jefferson Street, I found a bonanza of 20th-century modern -- a 1956 George Nelson coffee table for $675, a Florence Knoll credenza for $1,250, a Paul McCobb cherry breakfront for $1,500 -- and an assortment of chic Continental furniture, including French club chairs, English drabware, a spidery tole chandelier and rare books on art and design. In the entryway are outdoor pieces in terra cotta, iron and wood. This store is more expensive than Hiden or Debbie's, and I sensed that many of the shoppers were fellow designers from their studied ensembles and large canvas bags. The booths are more styled. The staff is larger, the trend barometer more on the mark. I bought a couple of nice old design books here.
Over all, these places were uncrowded and minimally staffed, both assets. There were no competitive shoppers squeezing ahead of me and no hovering clerks monitoring my activities. When I saw things I might have use for, I clicked away with my camera and measured with a tape, and no one bothered me.
Most of these stores open at 10:30 A.M. and close promptly at 5:30 P.M. (noon to 5 on Sundays), so there is a limit to how compulsively you can shop. But if you don in-line skates in the Stamford malls and eat drive-through, it's possible to hit them all in a day. And you need leave the comfort of air-conditioning only when you dash from the parking lot.
 
Only 45 Minutes From Broadway
 
ANYONE with a car and a long weekend afternoon can make out well buying antiques in New York City's northern suburbs. Here are some spots that are worth a stop:

HEADLINE: Need Attitude? Voila, a Concierge

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

 BODY:
ITS front-line employees having completed a three-month training program to improve service for travelers, Amtrak announced in advertisements this month: "10,000 employees went back to school. 10,000 concierges graduated."
In the same way that the breakfast roll became a croissant, even with a fried egg and Canadian bacon on it, the concierge has become a concept that knows few bounds. 
 "We picked the word because 'concierge' means someone you can approach who will make it happen," said Barbara Richardson, Amtrak's executive vice president.
Though it bases its popularity on the reputations of desk clerks at four-star hotels, for whom no service request is unrealizable, today's concierge industry is untethered to performance.
"If you have the attitude of a concierge, that's a large part of it," said Holly Stiel, a former concierge, who started Holly Speaks, a consulting business in Mill Valley, Calif., whose clients include Bank of America and Compaq.
On Amtrak's No. 171 from New York to Washington on Saturday, the newly trained ex-conductors and attendants had much in common with the traditional concierge: the French war widow with the keys who runs the hotel by her own rules. One conductor was helping two extensively tattooed men not with tickets to "Wit," but with return times to New York. In the cafe car, the attendant was bullying a small boy into choosing a sandwich.
"Next stop Newark!" said Mike Sternfeld, the conductor on the intercom, who introduced himself I'm-your-server style, listing the stations like chef's specials. But the next stop was unannounced: 10 minutes in the bleached green marshes of New Jersey, as unexplained as a delay between courses.
Amtrak is hopping a business trend for personal services. Hospitals and kennels now boast concierges. "I even received a call from a prison that was interested in having me come and speak to them," said Michael Romei, chief concierge at the Waldorf Towers in New York.
Increasingly, concierges are finding themselves back where they started: on residential building staffs. Though they are not castle candle-keepers, or "comtes des cierges," as they were in the middle ages, the year-old National Concierge Association estimates that one-quarter of its 150 members are now residential concierges.
In New York, the phenomenon is not new, but it is newly popular, with a prosperous real estate market and a demand for the latest level of, and last word in, building services. A concierge has a je ne sais quoi, like a fragrance brand, that a doorman doesn't -- more personal assistant than package-toter.
"A terrific number of buildings have inaugurated concierge services in the last five years," said Stuart Saft, chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums. "Certainly, new buildings have built front desks and designated clerks as concierges. Interestingly, older buildings are doing it now."
Hal Henenson, director of on-site sales and marketing at Douglas Elliman, the commercial and residential real estate firm, agreed. "The word has a certain cachet," he said. "It's marketing as much as anything."
But if the ambiance of having a concierge is specific, the services are not.
Brian Byrne, a concierge at the Exchange, at 25 Broad Street, a two-year-old converted office building, won't pick up or return videotapes, but he will recommend them.
" 'Waking Ned Devine,' " Mr. Byrne said. "A very nice Irish movie."
Typically, a concierge is asked to coordinate pickups and deliveries, call car services, log guests in and out and expedite requests, like making arrangements for repairs. Infrequently, George Almegor, at a one-year-old apartment building at 150 East 57th Street, has reserved a restaurant table or tickets for a show. He has also fed fish. He has paid bills. He has played Cupid for single tenants.
When two women asked for male strippers, he gave them the yellow pages. "They could have been my grandmothers," he said.
At a previous job, he broke up a fight in the lobby. After knocking on a door one night, he discovered a dead body. "A guy with a football helmet. Rubbed out."
Mr. Almegor admitted to stress on the job.
"How to please everyone when you're pulled in 10 directions at once," he said. "People can be nasty, make a mountain out of a molehill. Dry cleaning -- a missing suit at 8 in the morning."
If not the patience of a saint, Mr. Almegor has technique.
"I take a step back, count to 3, to recover my professional poise," he said.
As people find themselves squeezed for time between work and play, equally stressful schedule-flexing spheres in New York, the perception of what a residential concierge can or can't do has begun to shimmer like a mirage. For tenants thirsty for services, the small desk in the lobby, palmy with pleasant, friendly faces, is the nearest oasis in the desert.
But few concierges end up working like camels. Most draw a line in the sand.
The city's newest luxury buildings are promising a caravan of services through the concierge. At the Textile Building, at 66 Leonard Street, which is now selling condominiums at $795,000 to $6.5 million, these include housekeepers, personal trainers, masseuses, acupuncturists and caterers, said Annabelle Schachner, the sales director. But even $6.5 million later, the concierge will talk the talk, not walk the walk.
"I'll tell you where the line is," Ms. Schachner said of the limits of the job. "They can't leave the desk."
In fact, the desk is the front line in the new theater of war on what the concierge is there to do. Because the concierge is not a doorman or an elevator man, he or she is perceived as a free agent, available to run errands, walk dogs, park cars and supervise repairs, deliveries and other services upstairs in tenants' apartments.
Alex Szabo, at the Alfred, a condominium building on West 61st Street, has been asked to do all of the above. Time permitting, he complies or, he said, "You bow out gracefully."
"You say, 'I'm not available,' " he said. "They ask for someone else on the staff."
Mr. Szabo, a young man with stiffly gelled blond hair and a goatee, was a doorman in the building for four years before becoming a concierge four years ago.
"It's all job titles," he said, sitting in a square enclosure in the lobby. "Basically it's the same thing."
Mr. Szabo will walk dogs on his break. Tenants' increasing time pressures also make them forget. "They forget to make arrangements for a delivery, or they forget to tell you there's someone on their way. You have to contact them at work."
Like many concierges in the city, Mr. Szabo recites the golden rule.
"If you do it once, it becomes your job," he said.
Gabriella Szathmary, a concierge at the new Trump Place condominiums at 200 Riverside Boulevard, recited her version.
"What you do today as a favor, tomorrow they're going to expect," she said, standing behind a marble desk that extends like a ship's bow into the entrance lobby. Ms. Szathmary was previously a private secretary for a woman living on Park Avenue. She will walk dogs in an emergency. "You would do it for your neighbor -- they know I'm not a dog-walker," she said. But doing errands is not in the cards. "Obviously, grocery shopping is not going to happen," she added.
Mark Caudwell, a professor of English at Fordham University and the author of "A Short History of Rudeness" (Picador USA, 1999), explained that the rise in popularity of the concierge as a new type of service staff member might be a convenient diffusion of a difficult social situation: newly affluent tenants in an expanding economy who are able to employ servants but uncertain about how to engage them.
"They rely on iconographic signs," he said. "If someone's behind a desk, or if the uniform looks more like a business suit, it legitimizes more in the way of demands. You think: 'A concierge is a competent profession. I can stop at the desk and make any demand I want to.' "
Fabian Smith, a concierge at River Tower on West 63d Street, says no as the Japanese do: by saying yes-but.
" 'I would love to do it, but I can't do it -- it's against management rules,' " he said, repeating his response to requests he can't grant. " 'It's in our union contract.' I go into details. If you say no bluntly, they think you're being rude." Mr. Smith directs his large lobby briskly, like a traffic policeman, dispatching service people, recommending a cleaning woman, answering his telephones. He makes wake-up calls. He helps tenants who can't cook with advice about oven temperatures.
A young man in a business suit approached the desk and asked Mr. Smith if he would supervise a furniture delivery, waiting in the apartment until the furniture was installed.
"I would love to," Mr. Smith explained, "but I can't. It's management policy." The tenant observed that the failure to gain Mr. Smith's cooperation "kind of defeats the purpose of a concierge building." Mr. Smith smiled commiseratively, suggesting a call to management.

LENGTH: 2401 words

HEADLINE: And the Meek Shall Inherit Nothing

BYLINE: By NEAL KARLEN

 BODY:
A YEAR after his father died in Florida, Richard Nelson, 51, can finally talk about what he calls "the war of the glockenspiel," when Mr. Nelson, an organizational consultant, and his younger brother, Larry, battled for months over the instrument their father played in the Shriner drum corps.
"We fought like Cain and Abel over that glockenspiel, because it represented the hours we both waited for him to come around the corner in Shriner parades playing 'When the Saints Go Marching In,' " Mr. Nelson said. 
 They had heated arguments over it whenever they saw each other. "And we didn't see each other very much, because we were both so mad that we'd always end up yelling about it," he added.
Last month, Mr. Nelson received the glockenspiel, after his mother brokered a deal to stop the squabbling. "Larry got visitation rights," he said, "as well as Dad's complete Spike Jones record collection and the family's home movies."
Familial fights like the Nelsons' are ripping apart many a middle-class clan. Economists have predicted that the largest intergenerational transfer of wealth in history -- approximately $12 trillion -- would take place from the mid-1990's until around 2020 as the security-minded Depression generation dies off and leaves its money and its carved mahogany bedroom suites, split-level ranch houses, family china, grandfather clocks and moldering photographs to its baby boom children, a generation weaned on irony, credit cards and broken marriages.
The bull market since 1994 may well have swelled the World War II generation's stock portfolios and retirement fund accounts even further.
"It doesn't matter if it's a lot or a little money," said Dr. Henry F. Smith, a psychoanalyst affiliated with the Harvard Medical School. "Money is a way to quantify love. And both anticipating and receiving the inheritance intensifies both the loving and hating aspects of relationships between child and parent, and sibling and sibling." That goes double when what is being inherited is valuable and tangible: the ocean-front home in the Hamptons, the collection of Art Deco furniture, even the drawer full of Bakelite jewelry or Mother's old mink coat.
The squabbling will be intensified by other problems along the way. The youngest boomer is now 35 and the oldest 53. Their parents are living ever longer. Some children could be receiving Social Security before they see a penny of inheritance.
Moreover, in the benchmark statistical study presented in 1994 by the economists Robert Avery and Michael Rendall, most of the wealth turns out to be headed for the pockets of only the few. According to the Avery-Rendall study, one-third of the money will go to 1 percent of the baby boomers, who will receive about $1.6 million apiece. Another third, representing an average bequest of $336,000, will go to the next 9 percent. The final slice, divided by the remaining 90 percent of the generation, will run about $40,000 apiece.
For those in the top bracket, "$1.6 million is worth fighting about," said Kathryn A. Johnson, chairwoman of an American Bar Association committee on trusts and estates and a lawyer in private practice in San Francisco. She added, "I think there is a big future in trust and estate litigation."
But the bulk of the population receiving $40,000, she said, would be ill-advised to go to court. She continued, "If they came in my office fighting over $40,000 I'd have to question them about why they were doing this, if they realized legal fees could eat everything up, and try and talk them into family mediation."
Besides, for most baby boomers, $40,000 is a drop in the bucket. "There's a good chance baby boomers will blow it," said Robert H. Frank, the Goldwin Smith professor of economics, ethics and public policy at Cornell University and author of "Luxury Fever: Why Money Fails to Satisfy in an Era of Excess" (Free Press, 1999; $25). "Children at the leading edge of the baby boom had their habits forged in the 1970's, when if you saved you were considered a chump. Now, a lot of baby boomer families are in deep debt, and a lot of those inheritances will be fully accounted for before they get it in the bank."
While some baby boomers are willing to do battle over a glockenspiel, a fairly large proportion lack sentimentality toward their parents' things, said Helaine Fendelman of Scarsdale, N.Y., co-host of the PBS program "Treasures in Your Attic" and one of the country's leading fine-arts appraisers.
"Baby boomers are much less interested in Eames or traditional 18th- and 19th-century furniture or antiques," she said. "They want flashy things from their own youth like Barbie dolls or baseball cards, but they want cash for their parents' most cherished items."
That lack of sentimentality is compounded when there is another generational remove, Ms. Johnson said. That is, the children will tussle over who got the Baccarat; the grandchildren just want the money. The fighting continues, however, since inheritance is like a quadratic equation being solved for the value of love.
And woe to the families left with an estate but no will. Six years ago, Pete Jakowski, 46, a San Francisco artist from a family he describes as "mediocre middle class, between the lower middle and just plain middle class," learned that his younger brother had been killed while riding in a friend's car. His brother had left no will.
"While I was literally shopping for caskets with my 76-year-old mother," Mr. Jakowski said, "my sister was cleaning out his house -- his furniture, car, stereo, keyboard and everything else of value. I was still in shock, and she and her husband were doing double time, completely emptying his place within 48 hours."
Mr. Jakowski said his sister later gave him keys to a storage locker and told him to keep anything he wanted. "All that was in there was his clothes, none of which fit me but which I held on to because it's all I have left of him," he said. "I come from a churchgoing family where you'd think this would never happen, and I'm here to tell you it does."
When telephoned about the contretemps, Mr. Jakowski's sister refused comment.
Even if there is a will, a vague phrase like "and the contents of the house will be divided equitably among the surviving children" can lead to years of arguments over who got stuck with the chipped majolica and who really wanted the Stickley breakfront. Many of the bad vibes emanate from how American society has changed since Ozzie and Harriet were considered the norm.
"When I first started practicing law 39 years ago, divorce was a rarity," Samuel Kaplan, a prominent Minneapolis business lawyer, said. "You only drew up antenuptial agreements when an 82-year-old was getting married. There might have been unhappiness when the head of the family died, but in almost every instance, those differences were worked out."
No more. "Now, divorce is common," Mr. Kaplan said, "and once the patriarch or matriarch who held the family together is gone, the amount of fighting between second husbands or wives who want their children treated appropriately can get quite brutal. The anger is astounding, especially when one sibling devoted their own life to caring for their parent at the end, while the others were gone."
And then there are the executors -- sometimes an oldest or most-trusted child (a position of honor that can lead to more family friction), otherwise a banker, lawyer or family adviser. Perhaps the shrillest battle over executors this decade concerned the estate of Joe Robbie, a Miami businessman and the owner of the Miami Dolphins who named three of his children as trustees of his estate without informing his six other children they wouldn't have direct control of their inheritance. After his death in 1990, a five-year battle was waged in court for control of the $72 million estate, with the three trustees ultimately dismissing the oldest son from the family businesses. Besides the money, childhood notions of fairness seemed to lurk behind the siblings' anger.
To avoid battles over who gets what, Morris Everett, 58, the owner of one of the largest accumulation of movie posters in the world, has chosen to get rid of his collection before he dies.
"It would be more of a burden to my family than an asset to pass it on," he said of his 200,000-piece collection, worth $8 million to $10 million and housed in Cleveland. "It represents dollar signs for my son and daughter, so it's my job to maximize the dollars."
But what about the emotional investment he made in a hobby that he started in 1961 with a lobby card for "Gunga Din" that he bought for 50 cents? "The joy of collecting is in the discovery," Mr. Everett said. "The worst thing to do is get handed a great collection. To just lay on my children this massive responsibility would be unfair."
Not every family ends up fighting over stuff. Some siblings even meet while their parents are alive and divide things up for later. "You can horse trade," said Steven Greenberg, owner of a computer company in Minneapolis called Designstein, who used this system with his two siblings. "I'd say, 'I'll trade you my next two picks for Mom's glass sugar bowl,' and the system worked."
But baby boomers -- conspicuous consumers -- may not have room left in their houses for the odd parental keepsake. And the items to be inherited have to be to their taste. The Nelsons who warred over their father's glockenspiel were not interested in his white polyester pants.
"My mother begged me to take a number of sentimental things, which I did out of respect," Mr. Nelson said. "But they never got out of the car before they went to Goodwill."
There was no squabbling over their father's 50 bowling trophies, which their mother insisted they have. "To us they symbolized all the time he didn't spend with us," he said. "After we were done grieving, Larry and I took great pleasure in throwing them into the dumpster one by one."
Sometimes, however, it's the baby boomer who wants to preserve the past. Art Simon, 40, an assistant professor of film studies at New Jersey's Montclair State University, refused to let his father sell the five-foot-tall wood-block printing press from the 1940's that once made window signs announcing sales in the family's clothing store in Minneapolis. "It's probably only worth a couple hundred dollars, if I could even find someone to buy it," Mr. Simon said. "But it was part of my family's history."
When his father died in 1996, Mr. Simon refused to put the printing press in the family's estate sale. Instead, he drove cross-country with the thing in the back of his car. "Now it's in storage," he said, "just like my dad had it."
It's a sentiment beyond dollars and cents that Ms. Fendelman, the appraiser, would applaud. "Whether you get an objet, or objet d'art, consider yourself lucky," she said. She tells clients, "The one thing no one can take from you is your memories."
 
Be Prepared
 SETTLING family treasures on family members is, like anything important, best done yesterday, worst done tomorrow and, if not done yet, should be done today.
Some tips for the children:
* If parents are still alive, gather the siblings with them to discuss what to do when they die and -- if not the specifics of their assets -- the mechanism by which those assets will be distributed.
"Sex is pretty easy to talk about these days," Dr. Henry F. Smith, a psychoanalyst in Cambridge, Mass., said. "But money is taboo." It will take effort to overcome everyone's reticence, but a candid discussion will make things easier later.
* Failing that, if a parent dies without leaving a clear indication of who gets what, hold a post-mortem draft. Gather all the siblings in one room with every item to be divided up. Any gift given by a child to a parent automatically reverts to that sibling. Then proceed down the line from oldest to youngest, with the children taking turns putting Post-it notes on items they are claiming. Prepare to horse trade.
* Even if there is little or no value to an estate, make sure parents and siblings are aware of the one item that means the most to you. "Be generous of spirit," said Mike Veeck, one of nine children of Bill Veeck, the Baseball Hall of Fame team owner and promoter, who died in 1986 leaving little money but a lifetime of good karma. Mike Veeck wanted an oil portrait showing his father sitting in a bar. So did some of the other children.
"But I'm from Chicago," he said, "so I called up mom and fixed it, like a closed election."
Some tips for the parents:
* Helaine Fendelman, a fine-arts appraiser, advises parents to learn the value of items, from abandoned G.I. Joe dolls to fireplace andirons, if they have any chance of being worth something. "A lot of parents leave messes for their children," she said. "And that's not a very nice thing to do when they're dealing with the loss of a parent."
* Take an extension course in estate planning that goes beyond mere dollars. Ann Barrash, 75, a Dubuque, Iowa, mother of six, attended a special class for women sponsored by the American Association of Retired Persons at Iowa State. "I was advised that every child would be fighting over this and that, after we were gone," she said. So she and her husband, Meyer, 76, a retired physician, made a list of every item they owned, circulated it among the kids, and made the children prioritize their choices. "It takes a long time but it really worked," she said, "because we didn't decide for them."
* If you have an estate large enough to be subject to the estate tax -- any amount above $650,000 from one person or $1.3 million from a married couple -- then before you die or become incapacitated you should hire an estate lawyer to work out what to do. An estate lawyer can show you ways to combine charitable gifts and insurance, for example, to pass on more to heirs.
* Serious collections may be sold now and money passed on to the children (next item). If the collection remains intact, leave detailed instructions on how it should be disposed of and through which experts, so the children will not have to hold a fire sale.
* Give items to children now, up to the $10,000 tax-free limit a year per parent. If a daughter needs a dining room table today, why wait?
Beyond that, make a will. And put every single thing you own in it. NEAL KARLEN

HEADLINE: Morocco's Need for Aid Could Go Unmet

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL

DATELINE: CASABLANCA, Morocco, July 27

 BODY:
In the crowded cobbled alleyways of the old souk, the young men loitering in doorways and old women selling tattered wares say they know exactly what they want from Morocco's new King.
"The problem now is jobs," said Hussein Khadoe, 28, who like many desperate young Moroccans spent years in Europe as an illegal immigrant and is back home trying to make a living any way he can. 
 At least 20 percent of Moroccans are out of work, even by the most conservative estimates. About half are illiterate, one of the highest rates in the region. And a huge debt burden has left the Government with little money to create jobs or provide a social safety net.
Little wonder, then, that with the regal pomp and the show of international support that surrounded the funeral on Sunday for King Hassan II, the new King, Mohammed VI, was already trying to convert the good will into more tangible dividends.
Prime Minister Abderrahmane Youssoufi was quoted in Moroccan newspapers as saying he had discussed with President Clinton and others "the support that Morocco expects from foreign partners, especially the United States."
Moroccan officials hope that Jordan will provide a model. The accession there in February of King Abdullah, an untested 37-year-old, has been followed by increases in Western aid and by warmer relations with neighbors, to help him fend off the discontent that might spill over into regional instability.
In Morocco, the most surprising helping hand has come from Algeria, a longtime rival with which Morocco has long had border disputes. Among the guests at King Hassan's funeral was the new President, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, the first Algerian leader to visit here in 10 years.
Mr. Bouteflika signaled that he was prepared to reopen the border, which was shut in 1994, at a cost to Morocco that economists here estimates at $2 billion a year in lost trade. In a letter to King Mohammed made public here, the Algerian said he was strongly committed to move "hand in hand with Your Majesty for the prosperity of our two people."
It is less clear, however, Western diplomats here said, that the United States and its allies are ready to welcome Prince Mohammed with new aid. For one factor, Morocco is more than 2,000 miles removed from the epicenter of Arab-Israeli struggles. Despite its important role in the past as a broker of a wider peace, it is seen in the West as a less important strategic partner than Jordan, more than half of whose population is Palestinian and which borders Israel, Syria, Saudi Arabia and Iraq.
For another factor, diplomats said, the priority that Morocco has placed on internal security over economic development may mean that real obstacles stand in the way of improving its economy. For now, the second most powerful man in Morocco, after the King, is widely said to be Driss Basri, the long-serving Interior Minister, and many people doubt that King Mohammed would be ready to move him aside.
Mr. Basri is a palace hard-liner who has been accused of widespread abuses in his 20 years in power. He is widely believed to oppose further moves toward the democratization that King Hassan began tentatively to embrace in 1986 and that is still sought by the West.
Without outside help or major internal changes, however, economists here say Morocco has little room to maneuver. Some 85 percent of Government outlays cover salaries and payments on a foreign debt of $20 billion, among the highest for any Arab country.
The rate of economic growth, which hit an impressive 6.2 percent in 1998, is expected to slow to a trickle this year because of a severe drought. And foreign investment, which hit a record $1.2 billion in 1997, shrank last year to less than half that, in large part because of investors' doubts about the Government's commitment to a further opening of the economy.
Prime Minister Youssoufi, a Socialist who was elected 18 months ago, is technically in charge of economic policy. But the King has overarching authority, with the power to dismiss ministers and even the Government. Most people here say if economic conditions are to improve, the change will have to come from the top.
In Casablanca, the commercial capital, Hassan's most visible legacy may be the enormous mosque that bears his name. The gleaming structure that towers over the old city at the edge of the Atlantic was built in 1990 from $500 million in public contributions. But the shabby back streets are just as dominant a feature of this city, like the one where Mr. Khadoe practices his trade, usually by collecting commissions from the small shops to which he tries to guide the few foreign tourists.
Mr. Youssoufi was, perhaps, referring to people like Mr. Khadoe when he said over the weekend, "We achieved positive results in favor of our people, but there are still economic and social issues to be solved."

HEADLINE: June Orders For Durables Rise Slowly

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
Orders for durable goods rose at a slower-than-expected pace in June, restrained by reduced demand for industrial machinery, Government figures showed today.
Total orders for items designed to last several years or more rose three-tenths of a percent last month after a gain of eight-tenths of a percent in May, the Commerce Department said. The June increase was less than the 1 percent rise analysts had expected. 
 "We haven't really turned the corner yet on exports, and that's the key factor holding manufacturing back," said Greg Jones, chief economist at Briefing.com in Jackson, Wyo.
The United States trade deficit in goods and services widened in May to a record $21.3 billion as exports fell for the sixth time in seven months, the Government reported last week.
Demand from consumers, however, continues to make up for slumping exports, keeping the economy's eight-year expansion on track toward a record early next year. United States companies' second-quarter profits rose a greater-than-expected 16.4 percent, the biggest gain in almost four years and well ahead of analysts' 12 percent forecast, as consumers snapped up everything from computers to pickup trucks.
The durable goods report also showed orders for nonmilitary capital goods excluding aircraft, a gauge of business investment, fell 4 percent in June after a 2.8 percent decrease in May.
Businesses overseas are not buying new equipment because of excess global production capacity and slow-growing economies, Mr. Jones said. The global economy is "clearly better than it was through much of 1998, but it's really stabilized more than it's rebounded," he said.
Industrial machinery orders, which include computers, fell 5.4 percent in June after a 4.5 percent decline a month earlier. Offsetting that weakness were orders for electrical equipment, including home appliances, and for autos, the Commerce Department said.
June sales at the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company increased, capping a record first half for the industry. North American auto makers announced earlier this month plans to increase third-quarter vehicle production 2 percent, to 4,087,700, according to Ward's Automotive Reports. That would set a record for the July-through-September period, exceeding the third quarter of 1997.
Meantime, orders for civilian aircraft fell 8.5 percent in June after a 34.3 percent increase in May, even as the Boeing Company said its June orders totaled 68 airplanes, compared with 11 orders in May. Boeing's numbers do not always track with Government reports, and analysts expect the increase in the company's orders to be reflected in coming months.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 475 words

HEADLINE: The Census as an Act of God

 BODY:
Acting as though they had just discovered that the Constitution requires a census every decade, the House Republican leadership has declared that next year's national headcount will be financed with an "emergency" appropriation of $4.5 billion. The leaders treated veterans' health care the same way, deeming it an off-budget emergency.
The process of putting together a Federal budget is always untidy, but this year the House Appropriations Committee has been turned into a wonderland. The unhappy chairman, C. W. Bill Young, had been warning for months that the spending caps imposed by the 1997 Balanced Budget Act were impossibly rigid, but no one seemed willing to listen. Both parties happily supported a $15.5 billion increase in the defense budget, to $266 billion. That used up about half of the $538 billion set aside for discretionary spending, painting Mr. Young into a corner as the pot available for other purposes grew smaller and smaller. 
 The unrealistic caps set in 1997 were a classic example of politicians' tendency to schedule all their really tough challenges for sometime in the future. President Clinton and leaders from both parties have been bragging for three years about the way they got spending under control, even as they began looking for loopholes to protect themselves from the consequences.
Last year Congress approved "emergency" expenditures outside the caps to the tune of more than $20 billion. This year the House leaders have already decided to pay for the census with an emergency appropriation, as if it were a flood or earthquake. Thanks to an accounting gimmick, additional spending on veterans' programs is supposed to be financed through the borrowing authority of the Tennessee Valley Authority. This week G.O.P. leaders were entertaining a delusion that the nation's Republican governors would help them out by giving back $6 billion in Federal funds the states received to pay for welfare reform.
The appropriations battles are part of a larger spectacle of fiscal irresponsibility, like the Republican leadership's insistence on a $792 billion tax cut that would eat up a projected surplus whose size is based, in part, on the same spending cap fictions that Mr. Young is wrestling with. Republican moderates, who wanted more modest tax reductions, settled for a compromise that was at best a meaningless fig leaf.
This is the worst kind of budgeting, a cynical exercise in which both parties try to trick the public into believing that the Government can make Draconian cuts in spending while still providing the programs people want. Responsible fiscal policy requires a clear and honest set of numbers, achievable goals and a willingness to forgo a certain amount of political gamesmanship in the name of responsible government. None of that is happening in Washington this year.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS -- Big Board at Brink of Unknown;
Questions Abound as Exchange Ponders Going Public

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
A quarter-century ago, when Richard A. Rosenblatt was first developing his skills as a trader on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, it was widely predicted that the Big Board's days were numbered.
Fixed commissions were banned in May 1975, plunging Wall Street into a frenzy of competition for customer trades. As trading fees shrank, dozens of less efficient brokerage firms closed their doors. With member firms falling away, the price of an exchange seat even dropped as low as $35,000. 
 But Mr. Rosenblatt's eyes shine when he remembers those fearsome days. "For a young entrepreneur, the opportunities just exploded," he said. With prices suddenly within his reach, he was able to borrow money and buy a seat on the exchange in 1979; it became the cornerstone of the institutional trading firm that bears his name.
Today, skeptics are once again predicting the demise of the Big Board. Its trading floor in lower Manhattan is no match, they say, for the new computer-driven systems that are attracting a growing share of the trading that traditionally has been done on the exchange and its archrival, the Nasdaq market.
And once again, Mr. Rosenblatt is optimistic. "This game is for the New York Stock Exchange to lose," he said confidently last week, on the eve of the exchange's confirmation that it hoped to transform itself into a for-profit corporation with public shareholders before the end of the year. "They've got it -- they've got a better product for the customer."
Of course, as the New York exchange and its chief executive, Richard A. Grasso, search for a survival strategy, Wall Street's central symbol faces a daunting array of challenges. The exchange must protect its franchise and find a way to blend the best aspects of its floor-based auction system with the speed and the capacity that only computers can provide. It must become more cost-efficient without becoming less careful about policing its business -- a challenge of such public importance that Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, warned Mr. Grasso earlier this week that regulatory competence will be the make-or-break issue when the commission reviews his plans.
And, as a public company, the Big Board must figure out how to make money doing all this -- enough money to placate potentially impatient shareholders.
Mr. Rosenblatt has a personal stake in how well the exchange fends off its new competitors. "I need an environment where I can make a difference to my customers," he said.
So far, the Big Board has lost only about 5 percent of its trading volume to the electronic communications networks, or E.C.N.'s, that have gobbled up nearly 30 percent of the Nasdaq market's volume.
But keeping a grip on its primary business is likely to be more of a challenge for the Big Board in the future than it has been in the past. In recent weeks, the New York exchange has liberalized its Rule 500, which prevented companies from withdrawing from the exchange without their shareholders' approval. Now, companies can withdraw merely by obtaining the approval of their independent directors.
The theory behind this change was that more companies would be willing to list on the Big Board in the first place if it was easier for them to leave. But the practical effects may simply be that it is easier to move elsewhere.
Another bellwether is the fate of Rule 390, which requires members of the exchange to trade all Big Board stocks that were listed before April 1979 only on a registered stock exchange, most likely to be the Big Board itself during the hours the exchange is open.
The rule now affects only about a third of the Big Board stocks, its supporters point out. But if this rule falls -- and the Nasdaq market has been muttering for years about challenging it -- the New York exchange could soon find that more of its trading volume has moved to other markets.
The Big Board's fabled liquidity -- a volume of trading so deep that large blocks of stock can be traded quickly without a drastic impact on prices -- is a key element of its premier brand. A migration of trading volume to competing trading systems would not only reduce its revenues, it would also undermine the value of that brand.
"This is a critical issue -- the real dollars-and-cents issue for the Big Board," said John C. Coffee Jr., a securities law professor at Columbia University and a member of the legal advisory committees for both the Nasdaq market and the Big Board. "It's a key part of their franchise, and I cannot see them liberalizing it, especially as they move to become public."
But Benn Steil, a senior fellow for foreign economic policy on the Council on Foreign Relations in New York, argues that the elimination of Rule 390 would simply increase the healthy pressure on the exchange to create a trading structure that people want, rather than one they are required to use.
In any case, the Big Board may have no choice but to live without the protections of Rule 390. "I can't imagine that it can remain in place," he said. "It is such an anomaly, with so many competitive pressures arguing against it."
There is considerable speculation that the New York exchange will be able to increase revenues by making strategic acquisitions -- perhaps buying one of the upstart E.C.N.'s, or purchasing one of the for-profit stock exchanges that are proliferating abroad, or buying a company that develops innovative software for trading services.
But for the near-term, the Big Board will most likely make its money the old-fashioned way: by charging fees for companies to list on the exchange and for investors to trade there. And in today's competitive environment, both listing fees and trading fees "are going to be under competitive pressures," Mr. Steil said.
To cope, he said, "they need to bring their costs down."
Mr. Steil believes that cost pressures in competition will force the exchange to abandon the expensive trading floor -- a trading environment that Mr. Rosenblatt insists is the symbol of the exchange and "the envy of the world" -- and replace it with an electronic trading system.
Mr. Rosenblatt disagrees. "You don't want to automate the auction," he insisted, arguing that the relationships and reputations of individual floor traders allow them to get better prices for their customers. "But you sure want to automate everything around it," he said.
Either option requires money, of course. And the need to pay for swift and significant improvements in technology will increase the pressure on the Big Board to curtail other costs.
And that raises questions about whether the exchange will be able to produce profits for its new shareholders and still adequately pay for its self-policing efforts.
It is an issue that already faces the for-profit electronic communications networks, or E.C.N.'s, that elect to compete with the Big Board and the Nasdaq market by becoming full-fledged stock exchanges.
"If you allow the E.C.N.'s to become exchanges, regulating themselves, you are inevitably going to have scandals," Professor Coffee said. Under pressure to produce profits, the for-profit exchanges may well "start to shop for the cheapest and the least, shall we say, intrusive regulator," he continued. "If that trend accelerates, you've got a race to the bottom."
Mr. Levitt, the S.E.C. head, wants to prevent that race from starting. He offered one suggestion in his first response on Monday to the idea of allowing for-profit stock trading entities: "More formally separating the self-regulatory role from the role of exchanges as trading venues."
That is exactly what the National Association of Securities Dealers is planning if it proceeds with a plan to spin off the Nasdaq market as a for-profit corporation early next year.
But that is not the plan that Mr. Grasso outlined for the exchange last week. Instead, he envisions retaining the exchange's regulatory operation within the new for-profit company.
Professor Coffee worries that in-house regulators would be vulnerable to cost-cutting pressures. His concern is shared by James J. Needham, a former S.E.C. commissioner who was the first paid chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, from August 1972 to May 1976.
With for-profit exchanges, "there is the potential for serious conflicts of interest," Mr. Needham said. "We cannot rely on self-regulation anymore."
Arthur Don, a securities lawyer in Chicago with wide experience in advising newly public companies, was less concerned about an erosion of regulatory efforts. "You just have to have sanctions sufficiently strong that noncompliance becomes uncompetitive behavior," he said.
Mr. Rosenblatt, the veteran floor trader, has heard the various arguments and said that he did not think members of the exchange cared where the regulators hung their hats. "We just care that regulation is not so cumbersome that you can't function and that regulators understand the difference between jaywalking and premeditated murder," he said.
Mr. Needham, the former New York exchange chairman, said the changes in ownership structure being contemplated by the Big Board and the Nasdaq market were so dramatic that the S.E.C. ought to hold public hearings before approving either proposal.
"The worst thing would be for the public to lose confidence because they don't understand what's happening," Mr. Needham said. "Before we take the next step, let's find out what we're really talking about."
Mr. Rosenblatt, staring down at the unstylish side-laced shoes that cushion his feet during long days on the trading floor, wondered aloud whether anyone could truly assess where the changes of today will leave the markets of tomorrow.
"For anyone to think that, five years from now, any of us will be doing business the way we do today would be dangerously naive," he said. "You show me a better way to trade, and I won't trade one more share on the N.Y.S.E. But nobody's shown me that yet."

HEADLINE: Despite Maneuvers, China Seems Cautious on Taiwan

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 28

 BODY:
A Chinese news service reported today that the navy was conducting mobilization exercises along the southern coast, across from Taiwan. But it appears to be a relatively moderate operation that hints at little real military preparation.
On Tuesday, a newspaper ran a front-page photograph of military helicopters intended to look as if they were preparing for battle. But the picture was so badly doctored, so obviously fake, that it had the opposite effect of signaling Beijing's distinctly halfhearted attitude toward potential conflict with Taiwan. 
 Nearly three weeks after President Lee Teng-hui caused an uproar by asserting that Taiwan would deal with China only on a "special state-to-state" basis, heightening tension about a possible military conflict, Chinese officials and Western diplomats say Beijing is shying away from any action.
Despite Beijing's insistence that it would use military force to block a declaration of independence by Taiwan, which it has considered a renegade province since the Chinese civil war ended in 1949, the danger of military conflict, it seems clear, is receding. Editorials in the Communist Party newspaper People's Daily continue to denounce Mr. Lee, but behind the often vociferous warnings, the overall reaction in Beijing has been restrained.
"China has to express its position strongly," a senior Chinese official involved in talks with Taiwan said. "But there doesn't seem to be any need for military action this time."
One reason behind China's relatively reserved response, the official said, is that Mr. Lee is scheduled to be replaced in elections in March. Because Beijing sees the Taiwan-born Mr. Lee as biased against China, it makes sense to wait until his successor takes office. That is especially the case because the candidate who is leading in Taiwan opinion polls, James Soong, favors more cordial ties with China.
"Seven months is not such a long time," the official said. "We can wait."
A second reason is that Beijing recognizes that its decision in the last Taiwan crisis, in 1996, to launch missiles near Taiwan only created sympathy for Mr. Lee, achieving the opposite of what it intended. China's military may have also been humiliated when the United States sent two carrier battle groups to the region to show support for Taiwan.
"They learned a lesson in '96," a Western diplomat in Beijing said as he referred to China's leaders. "This time, if they sit back and do nothing, it's Lee who's getting all the flak."
It is indeed Mr. Lee who has drawn international criticism for roiling diplomatic waters. When President Clinton spoke out last week in support for Beijing's position that the Chinese mainland and Taiwan should continue to be considered a single country, that effectively drew Washington closer to Beijing and further from Taipei.
"Lee Teng-hui is actually bringing China and the U.S. closer together," said the Chinese, who favors close ties with the United States. "We should thank him."
In Taiwan today, Mr. Lee rejected the sobriquet "troublemaker" that Beijing has tried to pin on him, saying that Taiwan should wait until China is more democratic and economically developed before it seriously considers reunification.
Talks between China and Taiwan, which have been off-again-on-again since they began in 1993, appear to be off again. Wang Daohan, a senior Chinese official scheduled to visit Taiwan in October, is virtually certain to cancel that trip.
Officially, Mr. Wang is waiting for his Taiwan counterpart, Koo Chen-fu, to take a public stance on Taiwan-China relations before a decision is made about continuing talks. But Beijing said over the weekend that with the vanishing premise of the talks -- that both sides agree on a "one China" formula -- it is highly unlikely that they will go forward.
From Beijing's view, the danger of taking no real action in response to Mr. Lee's move is that politicians in Taiwan may conclude that they can take steps to distance themselves further from China without any negative response from Beijing.
In an effort to deliver a tough-sounding, but ultimately ambiguous, message, Beijing appears to have authorized reports in China-backed news media in Hong Kong of military preparations off the Taiwan coast.
Last week, Wen Wei Po, a Communist Party-owned newspaper in Hong Kong that rarely covers sensitive political news without instruction from Beijing, reported in unusual detail about military preparations by the Nanjing Military Region, which oversees Chinese military forces in Fujian province, across the coast from Taiwan.
The paper reported that the deputy chief of staff of the Nanjing Military Region, Su Jing, had watched military drills in which sailors sang, "We will liberate Taiwan." Yet two days later, officials in the region denied the reports.
The report today by China News Service appeared to follow the same pattern, reporting military preparations that send a guarded signal to Taiwan, but allowing Beijing room for deniability.
All along, Taiwan military intelligence has told local news media that it detected no serious military activity on the mainland side of the 100-mile wide strait that separates Taiwan from the mainland.
As Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan of China reminded reporters in Singapore this week, China has never renounced the threat of using force against Taiwan, should peaceful means fail to achieve Beijing's cherished goal of reunification.
In more tough-sounding language, the New China News Agency reported today that the chief of the People's Liberation Army general staff had warned Mr. Lee to stop "separatist" activity.
"The P.L.A. has the determination and strength to defend the state's sovereignty and territorial integrity," the official, Fu Quanyou, told a visiting Malaysian military official.
Yet behind such language, there seems to be relatively little punch.
One factor often overlooked by outsiders is that military experts say any large-scale amphibious assault on Taiwan by China would face enormous military difficulties. Taiwan, operating American-supplied F-16 fighter planes, has distinct air superiority.
Even a more militarily feasible attack on one of the small islands controlled by Taiwan that are next to China's southern coast, Kinmen and Matsu, could prompt retaliation by Taiwanese guided missiles that would cause serious damage to mainland cities.
A less direct military confrontation could involve the launching of Chinese missiles into the sea near Taiwan, as in 1995 and 1996, or an attempt to blockade sea traffic around Taiwan.
There is little sign that Beijing has the political will for military action in the near future.
China's leaders left Beijing this week for the seaside resort of Beidaihe, where they are holding an annual political gathering intended to sort out pressing issues of the day. Although Taiwan may be on the agenda, leaders appear to be more concerned now with Falun Gong, the spiritual movement that Beijing has outlawed and has made the target of a major political campaign.
The other top issue at the gathering is said to be money-losing state-run industries, which the authorities have been trying to reorganize, without success.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Computer Issues Help Spark A Nasdaq Increase of 26.51

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Computer-related stocks lifted the Nasdaq market to its second straight gain yesterday, even as a majority of other issues sagged. Activity slackened as investors braced for key economic reports from Washington today.
"The stock market is waiting for some heavy-duty data," said Christine A. Callies, chief investment strategist at CS First Boston, mainly to examine them for any signs of inflation that might persuade Fed policy makers to raise short-term interest rates again. 
 Although Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, made his second Congressional appearance in two weeks yesterday, he provided no fresh clues about the central bank's intentions on interest rates, and members of Congress concentrated their questions on the wisdom of tax cuts.
Consequently, market operators are now awaiting today's Labor Department survey of employment costs and the Commerce Department's first estimate of gross domestic product, both covering the quarter ended June 30.
"The market is sort of slip-sliding around here" except for a "relief" rally in high technology, said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers. After skidding four of six sessions for a loss of 245 points, the technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index has now posted back-to-back gains for the first time since mid-month. Yesterday's bounce of 26.51 points, or just under 1 percent, was aided by a decision by the Financial Accounting Standards Board to postpone tougher rules for writing off research and development costs in acquisitions, analysts said.
But the Dow Jones industrial average could not sustain its Monday advance and finished with a loss of 6.97 points, closing at 10,972.07, after having been ahead by as many as 45.
And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, while ekeing out a gain of about two-tenths of 1 percent, showed little strength apart from technology. The index closed up 2.56 points at 1,365.40.
Interest rates were little changed yesterday as the Treasury's $15 billion auction of two-year notes went smoothly.
Stocks highly sensitive to interest rates have been prominent among those making new 52-week lows, Mr. Stovall noted, reflecting fears of narrowed margins and dampened business. New lows over all swamped new highs by 134 to 54 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, where 1,602 issues fell and 1,374 rose.
Turnover eased to 690.96 million shares from 714.6 million Tuesday.
But the general lackluster mood did not keep speculative-minded investors from chasing the latest Internet initial public offering. Drugstore.com's 5 million shares were offered at 18, began trading at 65 and changed hands at 70 before closing at 50 1/4 on volume of 8.86 million shares.
Intel was once again a market star, rising 2 3/4 to 70 5/16 after a 4 11/16-point surge on Tuesday as chip prices were reported to have firmed and S G Cowen raised its rating from "neutral" to "buy." Volume climbed to 41.7 million shares from 39 million.
Other big high-tech winners included Texas Instruments, up 5 7/16, to 148 9/16; Broadcom, up 11 3/8, to 128; Micron Technology, up 3 7/8, to 61 3/4; Microsoft, up 1 3/16, to 90; Priceline.com up 11 11/32, to 85, and Ebay and Amazon.com up 5 3/8 and 4 3/4, respectively.
Compaq Computer edged up 9/16, to 25 15/16; after the close, the company, the biggest maker of personal computers, reported a second-quarter loss that was in line with analysts' forecasts and a restructuring to cut costs that would result in the loss of 8,000 jobs.
Among the Dow blue chips, Dupont gained 11/16 to 72 13/16 after reporting earnings at the top end of expectations and I.B.M. gained 2 1/8 to 128 3/8.
Overseas, stocks were moderately higher in Tokyo, Hong Kong and Britain, slightly higher in Germany and France and down by four-tenths of 1 percent in Brazil. Mexico and Toronto jumped 1.43 percent and 1.26 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: Tab for Washington Lobbying: $1.42 Billion

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
The capital of the United States is a city with no real industry except for politics and influence, and so huge sums of money are paid to lobbyists trying to influence politicians. Last year $1.42 billion was spent in that endeavor, a research group said today.
That total was a 13 percent increase over the $1.26 billion that lobbyists were paid in 1997, said the group, the Center for Responsive Politics. If all the money had been spent on Capitol Hill, it would have worked out to $2.7 million earmarked to persuading each of the 535 lawmakers on a host of issues, the center said. 
 Of course, not all was spent on Capitol Hill; much was spent trying to persuade various regulatory agencies and other offices of the executive branch, the center's communications director, Paul Hendrie, pointed out.
The $1.42 billion was paid to lobbyists by airplane manufacturers, bankers, doctors and lawyers, drug companies, hospitals, universities, Indian tribes -- in short, by just about any person or any institution that has business before the Federal Government.
"There's certainly nothing inherently illegitimate about any of these interests' having their voices heard," Mr. Hendrie emphasized.
"We don't think so, either," said Tom McMahon, a spokesman for Cassidy & Associates, which took in $19.9 million in fees last year. Cassidy dislodged Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson & Hand as the capital's top lobbying firm by about $1 million.
Still, Mr. Hendrie said, the huge sums spent on lobbying are cause for concern. "People who don't have the money to spend are not going to speak with as loud a voice," he said. "Money does talk."
Through more and more mouths, he might have added. In mid-1997, there were 14,946 lobbyists registered in Washington, the center's report said. A year later there were 18,590, and by this June 15 there were 20,512, or about 38 lobbyists for each member of the House and the Senate.
The Center for Responsive Politics describes itself as a nonpartisan, nonprofit research organization that tracks money in politics, and money's effects on elections and public policy. Its report was based on disclosures filed with the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House under lobbying-disclosure regulations.
Mr. Hendrie said his organization was not advocating legislation to curb lobbyists. As for the money spent by interests trying to have their way with the Federal bureaucracy, he said, "It's hard to say what a reasonable figure would be."
And he agreed that the cynical-sounding term "special interest" meant different things to different people.
Take the real estate lobby, for example. It has long been a powerful one in Washington, and millions of middle-class Americans who wouldn't know a soybean future from a floating debenture are glad that the real estate lobby protects their cherished tax deductions for mortgage interest.
Businesses involved in real estate, insurance and finance, which make up one of 13 broad economic sectors defined in the report, spent $203 million on lobbying in 1998, topping the list for the second straight year. (Those businesses are also the perennial leaders in campaign contributions, the center said.)
The report notes that money is not always spent to get things done. Sometimes it is spent in the hope that things will not get done. Tobacco companies spent $67.4 million on lobbying last year, nearly double the $38.2 million they spent in 1997.
Was the $67.4 million well spent? It is impossible to make a direct connection, of course, but what ever happened to the bill that would have raised the tax on cigarettes by $1.10 a pack?
Cassidy & Associates was founded in 1975 by Gerald S. J. Cassidy, a former trial lawyer who was active in the Democratic Party and served as general counsel to a Senate select committee on nutrition.
People who know their way around Washington are good lobbyists, of course. Leon E. Panetta, a former Democratic Congressman from California and onetime chief of staff in the Clinton White House, has done consulting work for Cassidy & Associates, and Martin A. Russo, a former Democratic Congressman from Illinois, is a member of the firm.
Just as good investors diversify their portfolios, well-run lobbying firms vary their clientele to protect themselves against boom-and-bust cycles. Cassidy -- whose top client last year was Boston University, which paid the firm $760,000 -- depended on its five leading clients for only 15 percent of its revenue. Verner, Liipfert got 44 percent of its revenue from its top five, including the biggest single lobbying fee paid in Washington last year: $3.62 million, from the Philip Morris Companies.
