SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 33; Column 4; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 4574 words

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Where Steel Was King, a New Spirit Reigns

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
One fine day this summer, wreckers toppled six towering smokestacks along the Monongahela River.
Once part of a huge coke works but long idle, they were the last vestiges of Big Steel left within the Pittsburgh city limits. The mills that once employed tens of thousands of workers and made a third of the world's steel have vanished like ghosts at dawn. Iron City, a k a Steeltown U.S.A., is no more. 
 But having survived the truly grueling loss of most of its heavy industry, Pittsburgh is alive and well and getting better. It has had not one renaissance but two, and a third is under way, fueled by an intense local pride and a gritty determination to bounce back. Two new downtown stadiums (one for baseball, the other for football), a new theater designed by Michael Graves and a new convention center are on the way. Designed by Rafael Vinoly, the $231 million convention center is to have a roof in the shape of a catenary curve; water running off the building's cooling towers will make it glitter by day, and interior lights will set it aglow at night.
At the same time, Pittsburgh is hard at work, striving to forge a new economic identity as a high-tech center and a regional medical capital.
Cultural life has a fresh elan as well, sparked partly by the hip, innovative Andy Warhol Museum -- "the posthumous home of the King of Pop," as someone called it. The 53d Carnegie International, one of the world's premier surveys of contemporary art, will open in November at the Carnegie Museum of Art with works by 40 established and relatively unknown artists from 17 nations, including installation art and video as well as paintings and sculpture.
The century-old Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, under the energetic, Latvian-born Mariss Jansons, one of the most prominent of the young conductors who have emerged in recent years from the Baltic countries, will open its season this fall not with a safe selection of Beethoven or Brahms but with Schoenberg's immense, romantic, seldom-performed "Gurrelieder." Among the soloists will be two of the more sought-after singers of the day, the Canadian tenor Ben Heppner and the American mezzo-soprano Jennifer Larmore.
And of course Pittsburgh glories, as ever, in its magnificent site, first scouted by George Washington as a British major in 1753. The city lies deep within the Allegheny Mountains, where the Allegheny River meets the Monongahela to form the broad Ohio. Ernie Pyle wrote once that this was a place of "hills, mountains, cliffs, valleys and rivers, up and down, around and around, in betwixt," much better suited to goats than people.
A pair of antique funiculars, called inclines here, still slide up and down the steep face of Mount Washington, across the water from the skyscrapers packed into downtown Pittsburgh at the tip of the Golden Triangle.
Max King, the former editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, who moved to Pittsburgh this year to become the executive director of the $1.5 billion Heinz Endowments, sees a vibrancy in downtown Pittsburgh that is lacking in Philadelphia, and with industry having abandoned the riverfronts, he sees "a once-in-a-lifetime chance" to redevelop them to public benefit.
"Pittsburgh's economic troubles spared it the sprawl that is disfiguring Philadelphia," he said. "There, the hole is quickly emptying into the doughnut; all the action is in the suburbs. But Pittsburgh -- the city itself -- is still the center of this region, and it's holding."
There are, to be sure, plenty of problems. Race relations are not the best. Pockets of urban rot persist not only in the burnt-out mill towns up and down the river valleys and in the slums in the city itself, but also downtown. A tacky T-shirt store and a wig shop stand incongruously, for example, across the street from a new Lazarus department store.
The jury is still out on job creation, here as in other Rust Belt cities like Cleveland and Detroit. Pittsburgh's population is as old as those in some Sun Belt retirement cities, because too many of the area's most talented young people leave in search of economic opportunity.
 
A City of Amenities
But for those who stay or move here, the amenities are many. Leafy, close-in suburbs like Shadyside and Squirrel Hill. A low crime rate. Good schools. Moderate housing and living costs. Extensive parks. A terrific zoo. Three identical suspension bridges, all painted primrose yellow, crossing the Allegheny side by side. Three substantial universities: Carnegie Mellon, strong in science and technology; Duquesne, known for the liberal arts and law, and the University of Pittsburgh, a medical powerhouse where some of the pioneering work in liver transplants was carried out.
Pittsburgh has its own vernacular. "Redd" means clean, as in "redd off the table," and "youns" is the plural of "you." It has a certain innocence as well. Maybe, as some here complain, Pittsburgh is provincial (or, to adopt the kinder phrase, used by one local businessman, "not very cosmopolitan"). But it also lacks the edgy aggressiveness of many larger cities.
This is, after all, the hometown of Fred Rogers, the kids' sweet-natured friend Mr. Rogers, whose program is made at WQED, the nation's first public television station.
You arrive in Pittsburgh from the west, where the airport is situated, by way of the Fort Pitt Tunnel. One minute you are cruising along amid wooded hills, the next you are in the half-mile-long tube, and then you emerge onto a bridge. Dead in front of you is Pittsburgh's skyline, a sudden, dramatic, exhilarating sight, akin to spying the New York or San Francisco skyline from a steamship in the days before the dawn of jet travel.
The air is clean, the rivers are bright and clear, and if the sun is shining, John Burgee and Philip Johnson's PPG Place, the Houses of Parliament in London transmuted into a glass office building, catches your eye at once.
But of course the approach didn't always look so splendid.
 
Determined Mayors
It took a series of determined mayors to change the city's face, starting in the 1950's with David L. Lawrence, who adopted the slogan "Smoke Must Go." He and successors like Peter Flaherty and Richard Caliguiri made common cause with business leaders, notably Richard King Mellon.
Rachel Carson, who grew up not far from here, would have been proud of what they accomplished.
In its heyday as the self-described Workshop of the World, Pittsburgh was an industrial inferno. Only half a century ago, the rivers teemed with tugs and barges, and the mills poured brown and green ooze into the water and black and gray soot into the skies, so much so that street lights often had to be kept on all day. One week in 1948, 30 people were killed by smog in the grimy little borough of Donora (where, incidentally, the baseball hall-of-famer Stan Musial grew up).
"Blackest place I ever saw," said the 19th-century English traveler Anthony Trollope, and he knew grim industrial landscapes at home.
But Pittsburgh produced steel in prodigious quantities. At the end of World War II, United States Steel, the first billion-dollar corporation in history when it was formed in 1901, made twice as much steel as the entire Soviet Union. Set against that, what was a little pollution?
 
Enormous Fortunes
Pittsburgh also produced enormous fortunes for men like Andrew Carnegie, an immigrant from Scotland who built a steel empire; Henry Clay Frick, the king of coke, the baked coal essential to the steel-making process, who was first an aide and then a rival to Carnegie, and Andrew W. Mellon, the banker who financed the new magnates and grew rich in the process.
Mellon money built the National Gallery in Washington, and when Andrew Mellon's son, Paul, died this year at the age of 91, he had given it more than 1,000 pictures, including two van Goghs and 12 Winslow Homers in a final bequest, as well as $75 million in cash. Frick money built New York's finest small art museum. Carnegie money built libraries around the world.
Only small fractions of their wealth stayed in Pittsburgh, though their names grace monuments, buildings, parks, streets and museums.
To work in the mills, peasants came from all over Europe. A sign from one Carnegie plant, preserved in the excellent (if clumsily named) John Heinz Pittsburgh Regional History Center, warned of danger in English, Italian, Hungarian, Slovak and Serbo-Croatian. My great-grandfather was one of those hardy spirits, and his son, my grandfather, worked in nearby Jeanette, which was for some time the center of the American glass industry. My father was born there.
Myths grew up about industrial Bunyans like Joe Magarac, a Hungarian who could derail a locomotive with his little finger, and Steve Mestrovic, a Serb who could supposedly twist a 500-pound steel bar into a pretzel. In real life, the tough river towns where the immigrants settled produced more than their share of sports heroes, especially pro football quarterbacks, including Johnny Unitas, Joe Montana, Jim Kelly, Joe Namath and George Blanda.
Pittsburgh quickly became a battleground between labor and capital. In the notorious Homestead strike of 1892, Pinkerton detectives employed by Frick clashed with workers; 20 people were killed and 300 wounded. The Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers was crushed. Industry won the battle, but labor won the war, decades later, when Philip Murray organized the United Steel Workers Union. Now plans are afoot to bring the site of the strike and other steel-industry landmarks under the aegis of the National Park Service.
Blacks streamed into Pittsburgh as well, and soon built a thriving subculture. The Pittsburgh Courier was the nation's leading African-American newspaper, and the city produced a seemingly endless flow of jazz stars, from Billy Strayhorn to Erroll Garner to Mary Lou Williams. Before the integration of major league baseball, the Pittsburgh Crawfords and the Homestead Grays flourished on the black circuit with players like Josh Gibson and the inimitable Satchel Paige.
Sports still loom large here, as befits the city's six-pack image, though the relatively small population (350,000, with 1,335,000 in Allegheny County) makes supporting big-league teams difficult. The Pittsburgh Penguins, twice National Hockey League champions in recent years, were faced with bankruptcy until a judge approved a plan under which Mario Lemieux, the team's greatest star until he retired in 1997, took control of the team.
Legends live on, like the Pirates infielder Bill Mazeroski's improbable last-of-the-ninth home run to beat the Yankees, 10-9, in the seventh game of the 1960 World Series, and the Steeler running back Franco Harris's "immaculate reception" of Terry Bradshaw's deflected last-gasp pass to win a crucial playoff game in 1972.
 
Architectural Highlights
Pittsburgh is rediscovering its significant architectural heritage and urging visitors to do the same. Southwestern Pennsylvania has two of the very greatest American buildings, Henry Hobson Richardson's Allegheny County Courthouse and Jail, in Pittsburgh, and Frank Lloyd Wright's wonderful cantilevered country villa, Fallingwater, an hour to the southeast.
Fallingwater was built for the Pittsburgh merchant Edgar J. Kaufmann, who cooked up a number of other projects, most of them never built, with the master of Taliesen. Plans and models can be seen in a show at the Carnegie Museum through Oct. 3.
The courthouse -- a great castlelike structure of rusticated granite, with a 325-foot tower -- is connected to the jail by a Bridge of Sighs like the one that links the Doge's Palace and the jail in Venice. It is a massive, masculine ensemble; the voussoirs, or blocks, that form the main entrance, one of Richardson's trademark Romanesque arches, are eight feet long. Yet there is nothing clumsy or heavy about the structure.
If Richardson whets your appetite for more, walk down Grant Street. On the way you will see Frick's Union Trust Building (1915), with a breathtaking stack of nine balconies, crowned by a round stained-glass skylight, and a froth of terra-cotta turrets, balustrades, pinnacles and balustrades on the roof; the Koppers Building (1929), in an urbane Art Deco style, and the USX Building (1970), a bold tower in Cor-Ten steel, which oxidizes to a deep red-brown, protecting against deterioration.
The USX Building, by Harrison & Abramovitz, looks much less dated than the slightly earlier buildings from the same hands, the Metropolitan Opera House and Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center. Its exoskeleton of vertical beams is filled with water and antifreeze as a fire retardant.
In a real sense the USX Building is a continuing advertisement for the company that built it, once named United States Steel. So is the former Alcoa Building (1953), nearby on Sixth Avenue, whose skin is formed of preformed aluminum panels, and the glass-faced PPG Place (1984), on Fourth Avenue, which was built by a company formerly called Pittsburgh Plate Glass.
 
A Cultural Catalyst
No family has done more for Pittsburgh, especially for the arts in Pittsburgh, than the Heinzes, purveyors to the world of 57 Varieties -- actually, today, more like 5,700. It was H. J. Heinz 2d, known as Jack, who had the idea that cultural resources could aid in jump-starting an economic revival here. He bought four abandoned movie theaters downtown and helped turn them into the Cultural District, anchored by Heinz Hall, home to the Symphony.
Fritz Reiner, William Steinberg, Andre Previn and Lorin Maazel all helped to mold the orchestra's global reputation, but Heinz dollars balanced the organization's budget. Without them, as Gideon Toeplitz, the managing director, said several years ago, Pittsburgh would have "a small regional orchestra rather like the Wheeling Symphony just down the road."
In December, the new home of the Pittsburgh Public Theater will open across the street from Heinz Hall with a world premiere of a play by August Wilson, a Pittsburgh native. Designed by Michael Graves, with a great copper cowl giving its facade a distinctive appearance, it has a Heinz connection, too. It was partly financed by the friends of, and named for, Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, the H. J. Heinz Company's 's Irish-born chairman.
Next door will stand a fountain designed by Louise Bourgeois.
Drama is a many-layered thing in Pittsburgh. Apart from the Public Theater and the musicals that also play in the Cultural District, there are the venturesome City Theater on the South Side and Karla Boos's lively Quantum Theater, which performs in spaces either discovered or improvised.
Neither opera nor dance is big-league yet, but the city has an amazing number of dance organizations, large and small. The most prominent is the Pittsburgh Ballet Theater, whose artistic director, Terrence Orr, has steered it away from the Balanchine tradition toward that of his alma mater, American Ballet Theater.
The Phipps Botanical Gardens, an 1893 gift from Henry Phipps, one of Carnegie's sidekicks, has a 13-room Victorian conservatory, one of the finest in the country. And the Frick Art Museum, a country cousin of the New York showplace, exhibits the collection of Henry Clay Frick's daughter, Helen; its highlights are a magisterial Rubens portrait and works by the Sienese masters Duccio and Sassetta.
 
Bones and Art
But the heaviest hitters here, in addition to the Symphony, are the Carnegie and Warhol museums.
The Carnegie complex, in Oakland, east of downtown, includes a museum of natural history, renowned for its dinosaur collection, as well as the art museum, headquarters for the International, whose curator this year is Madeleine Grynsztejn. Since its beginning, the art museum has concentrated on the art of the 19th and 20th centuries -- "the Old Masters of tomorrow," as Carnegie himself put it.
Paintings, sculpture and the decorative arts are intermingled to good effect in galleries occupied by the permanent collection. Take, for instance, the room devoted to the Arts and Crafts Movement; there, furniture by C. F. A. Voysey and Harvey Ellis and copperware by W. A. S. Benson keep company with two huge, newly acquired Pre-Raphaelite canvases by Burne-Jones.
First-rate pictures by the likes of Cezanne, Kirchner and Degas (a smashing portrait of the engineer Henri Rouart) lie ahead. But most intriguing to me was a selection of pioneer American abstractionists like Burgoyne Diller, George L. K. Morris and Stanton Macdonald-Wright.
Over at the Warhol, installed in an old seven-story building renovated by the New York architect Richard Gluckman, you are greeted by a big cobalt-blue self-portrait of the artist, wide-eyed, spiky-haired. The building is filled with Warhol's collections (milk glass, shoes of famous people); Warhol's wallpaper (I liked the pink-and-yellow cow pattern); Warhol's films; Warhol's portraits of Mao, Liz and Mick; Warhol's books and Warhol's archives -- 605 identical boxes filled with everything from the master pack rat's mail to the original images on which he based his famous silk screens.
A Pittsburgh native whose parents came from the Carpathian Mountains in central Europe, Warhol once wrote: "You live in your dream America that you've custom-made from art and schmaltz and emotions just as much as you live in your real one." The museum is Andy's world, custom-recreated.
Pittsburgh has taken to it slowly; Thomas Sokolowski, the director, says, "It's a sober city, very Presbyterian." Of the 65,000 visitors to the museum last year, half came from out of state, many from Japan and Germany. But Mr. Sokolowski keeps plugging. He has started a Friday happy hour and has big plans for musical events, including a staging of the Satie-Poulenc-Ravel triple bill "Parade," as big a scandal in its day as Warhol in his.
 
Enjoying Pittsburgh
Pittsburgh is 365 miles southwest of New York City. Here is a sampling of attractions and places to stay and eat in the area, along with travel information:
 
Where to Stay
 
DOUBLETREE HOTEL, 1000 Penn Avenue, (412) 281-3700. Renovated only this year, the Doubletree is Pittsburgh's freshest hotel, with a light-filled, four-story atrium lobby. Theaters are just a couple of blocks away, and an enclosed walkway leads to the convention center. Though pretty prosaic, the rooms are a good deal roomier than the chain hotel standard. Double rooms: $189 weekdays; $119 to $189 weekends.
 
PITTSBURGH HILTON, Gateway Center, (412) 391-4600. In a city that woefully lacks a top-drawer hotel, the Hilton is blessed with those three cardinal virtues: location, location and location. Overlooking the junction of the Allegheny and Monongahela, with 711 rooms and 38 suites, it is a convention hotel par excellence, with all the pluses and minuses that go with that. The crisp, smallish, up-to-date rooms on the top floors are the best. Double rooms: $199 to $250.
 
SUNNYLEDGE, 5124 Fifth Avenue, Shadyside, (412) 683-5014. Oakland once had a pair of fine big hotels, the Schenley and Webster Hall. Both are long gone, alas, but this eight-room red-brick inn provides a classy refuge for visitors to the universities and the museums. All mod cons: minibars, cable television, Jacuzzi tubs, hair dryers and Frette linens. Double rooms: $189 and $199; suites, $275.
 
WESTIN WILLIAM PENN, 530 William Penn Place, (412) 281-7100. Henry Clay Frick built this Beaux-Arts pile to house his business friends when they came to town. After countless face lifts, the old girl is handsome enough, with enormous crystal chandeliers in the Palm Court. But the service is disheartening, with breakfast cards sometimes left dangling on doorknobs, unfilled, and desultory delivery of baggage and messages. Today's nabobs send their visitors down the street to the veddy private Duquesne Club. Double rooms: $169 to $229, weekdays; $99 to $169, weekends.
 
Where to Eat
 
CAFE ALLEGRO, 51 South 12th Street, (412) 481-7788. The cooking is a tad uneven at this relaxed spot next to the 1915 South Side Market House, just off post-industrial Carson Street; one night recently, the veal chop was tasty and sweet seared scallops were nicely mated with a tangy tangerine-juice reduction, but smoked trout was too dry and soft-shell were crabs overcooked. Still, the spirit is willing; baffled at first by a request for cheese at meal's end, the kitchen quickly improvised an appealing assortment.
 
CASBAH, 229 South Highland Avenue, Shadyside, (412) 661-5656. This is the lead restaurant of an entrepreneurial duo who call themselves Big Burrito Inc. The menu is Mediterranean: tagines from Morocco, fearlessly fiery merguez sausage from Tunisia, pasta, a dense ragout of lamb with couscous. Flavors are as emphatic as a smack in the chops. Terrific wines, especially the Rhones, and a sultry, sand-colored decor with hanging lamps reminiscent of Venice and Fortuny.
 
STEELHEAD GRILL, 112 Washington Place, (412) 394-3474. An outpost of Drew Nieporent's empire (and hence a sibling of TriBeCa Grill and Nobu), this is the city's top table, for my money. Greg Alauzen, a hometown boy, concocts a shellfish chowder that would delight any Down Easter, and serves skillfully grilled shrimp on a bed of linguine with a rich basil-lemon sauce. The wines are chosen by the savvy Daniel Johnnes of Montrachet.
 
TESSARO'S, 4601 Liberty Avenue, Bloomfield, (412) 682-6809. You're tired of beurre blanc and balsamic vinegar and waiters named Clyde. You need a joint with no attitude. In Pittsburgh, Tessaro's fills the bill perfectly: a bar in a working-class neighborhood with Sam Adams on draft, decadently juicy half-pound burgers cooked on a hardwood grill, and plenty of good cheer. No french fries, no dessert, no reservations, just sensational meat.
 
LA CUCINA FLEGREA, 2114 Murray Avenue, Squirrel Hill, (412) 521-2082. The room is plain and tiny, but the minute you walk in, you know you're in the right place. It smells Italian, not Italian-American. Anna Fevola comes from a village north of Naples, and her cooking has that superbly unadorned clarity of flavor we all long for. Order the grilled sausage, with charred edges, served underneath a blanket of bitter rapini. B.Y.O.B.
 
Attractions
 
CARNEGIE MUSEUM OF ART, 4400 Forbes Avenue, Oakland, (412) 622-3131. "Merchant Prince and Master Builder: Edgar J. Kaufmann and Frank Lloyd Wright," through Oct. 3. "Forum: Felix de la Concha," through Sept. 19. "The Other 19th Century: European Prints and Drawings," through Aug. 15. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M.; also open Mondays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., through Aug. 30. Admission: $6; $5 for the elderly; $4 for students and children 3 and older.
 
ANDY WARHOL MUSEUM, 117 Sandusky Street, (412) 237-8300. The permanent collection has more than 3,000 works of art, including drawings, prints, paintings, sculptures, film and video tapes, along with archival material. "The Architecture of Reassurance: Designing the Disney Theme Parks," through Oct. 10. Hours: Thursdays through Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Sundays and Wednesdays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $7; students, $4; the elderly, $6; children over 3, $4.
 
FRICK ART MUSEUM, 7227 Reynolds Street, (412) 371-0600. The permanent collection consists of European paintings, sculptures and decorative arts from the 12th to the 18th centuries; there is also Clayton, the turn-of-the-century Victorian residence of the industrialist Henry Clay Frick and his family. Opening today, "Shamans, Gods and Mythic Beasts: Colombian Gold and Ceramics in Antiquity." Through Oct. 3. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Admission to the Art Museum, as well as the Car and Carriage Museum, is free.
 
PITTSBURGH SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA, Heinz Hall, 600 Penn Avenue, at Sixth Avenue, (412) 392-4900. The season begins on Sept. 17 at 8 P.M. with Schoenberg's "Gurrelieder" conducted by Mariss Jansons; repeated Sept. 19 at 2:30 P.M. Tickets: $14 to $69.
 
PITTSBURGH PUBLIC THEATER, 6 Allegheny Square (two blocks from the Andy Warhol Museum), (412) 321-9800. A college production of Shakespeare's "Twelfth Night" runs through Sunday. Tickets: $12. The regular, main-stage season runs from October through June. In December, the Public will move into the O'Reilly Theater, a new 650-seat theater designed by Michael Graves across from Heinz Hall. The first production there will be the world premiere of August Wilson's new work, "King Hedley II."
 
CITY THEATER, 57 South 13th Street, (412) 431-4900. The season opens on Sept. 10 with "A Raisin in the Sun," co-produced with the Kuntu Repertory Theater and running through Oct. 10. Tickets: $19 to $28.
 
QUANTUM THEATER, a company that presents new works and adaptations of classics in site-specific spaces in Pittsburgh. The next production is Shakespeare's "Merchant of Venice," from Aug. 18 through Aug. 29 (daily except for Monday, Aug. 23), at the former Kerotest Building, a 19th-century factory at 25th Street and Liberty Avenue. Tickets: $12. Information: (412) 422-3823.
 
PITTSBURGH BALLET THEATER, Benedum Center, Seventh Avenue between Penn and Liberty Avenues, (412) 456-6666. The fall season begins on Oct. 7 with "Dracula."
 
JOHN HEINZ PITTSBURGH REGIONAL HISTORY CENTER, 1212 Smallman Street, (412) 454-6000. The main permanent exhibition is "Points in Time: Building a Life in Western Pennsylvania, 1750-Today." Also: "Eat'n Park's Anniversary: Celebrating 50 Years of Smiles," through Sept. 12; "Pittsburgh Rhythms: Music of a Changing City, 1820-1950," through Jan. 2; "Heinz: Preserved in Pittsburgh," through spring 2001. Hours: Daily except holidays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; library closed Sundays and Mondays. Admission: $6; $4.50 for the elderly and children 3 to 18; free for children under 3.
 
PHIPPS CONSERVATORY AND BOTANICAL GARDENS, 1 Schenley Park, (412) 622-6914. A 13-room Victorian glass house features desert plants, palms, orchids, seasonal butterflies and traditional flower shows. The Butterfly Forest, with 26 species of butterfly, is open through Oct. 15. Visitors can see butterflies hatching and flying freely around the glass pavilion. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $5; $3.50 for the elderly and students; $2 for children 2 to 12; free for children under 2.
 
Getting There
 
BY AIR: U.S. Airways (800 428-4322) has nine nonstop flights daily to Pittsburgh from La Guardia and eight from Newark. Last-minute fares are approximately $307 each way from La Guardia and $322 each way from Newark. There is a special $306 round-trip last-minute fare from Newark with departure on a Saturday or Sunday and a return on a Saturday or Sunday. The 14-day advance fare from Newark is $316 round trip; not available from La Guardia. The least expensive fare, $248 round trip from Newark, requires a Saturday stayover, is based on availability and requires 21 days' notice. Continental (800 525-0280) has six nonstop flights daily from Newark. Last-minute fares range from $324 to $425 each way. The 14-day advance fare from Newark ranges from $293 to $476 round trip, with a Saturday stayover. The least expensive fare, which requires 21 days' notice and a Saturday stayover, ranges from $252 to $425. R. W. APPLE Jr.

LENGTH: 700 words

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The March of Folly

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
"A phenomenon noticeable throughout history regardless of place or period is the pursuit by governments of policies contrary to their own interests.
"Why do holders of high office so often act contrary to the way reason points and enlightened self-interest suggests? 
 "Why, to begin at the beginning, did Trojan rulers drag that suspicious-looking wooden horse inside their walls despite every reason to suspect a Greek trick?"
The questions open a book by the late American historian Barbara Tuchman. Its title shames Western democracy even more than when it was published 15 years ago -- "The March of Folly."
For most of this century we have been staring at the horses of totalitarian governments and not only opening the gate but stuffing them with feed. We garlanded them with money and weaponry -- until the soldiers leapt out, German soldiers, Japanese, Iraqis, soldiers who have been not only a danger to us but the instrument of oppression for their own people, the engine of destruction of the freedoms we hold so dear for ourselves.
But never have democracies accepted with such sweaty eagerness the influence of totalitarian society, so allowed themselves to be influenced by foreign tyranny against their own interests, turned a more cold and cowardly shoulder to the victims of foreign dictatorship than in the case of Communist China. About China America is no worse than its allies.
Right now, the issue is the right of a small nation to mention in the mildest terms a most obvious truth. Taiwan, self-made and free, does not demand independence but believes it should deal with China as state to state. That sent the ever-terrified Beijing Politburo into froth-mouthed fury and the U.S. Government into an orgy of appeasement.
This slavering endorsement of China's vendetta against Taiwan is simply one example of the peonage of American policy to China, and of the knowing hypocrisy of "engagement" and "partnership" with China.
Recognition of Communist China as reality was overdue when Nixon-Kissinger "reopened" China. But Americans believed that reopening would include the Chinese people, and engagement would include open debate about the relative merits of Communism and freedom.
Instead the engagement has become between the Washington and Beijing bureaucracies. China's people? Beijing gave them orders to continue keeping mouths closed. As the price of doing business with China, Beijing ordered American businessmen to do the same. Our two most recent Presidents passed on the orders to their subordinates.
So America's Government apparatus zippered mouths about the real extent and duration of Chinese espionage, about forced labor as an official part of the Chinese economy, about the enslavement of Tibet, the arrests of Christians who refuse to worship only in the place and manner ordered by the Communist Party, and about the continuing hysterical roundup of Chinese whose tradition-based spiritual movement attracts millions.
For China to become far more influential in America requires more than Presidents. Other parts of American society had to go along and have -- the majority of Congress, press commentators, academics, American clergy who tell us not to rock the boat, and particularly business.
American business executives convinced themselves and their beneficiaries in politics that somehow the Chinese economy, still tottering under a Government frenzied with fear of its own people, is a future U.S. gold mine. Meanwhile, Americans passively absorb the $50 billion trade deficit the wait costs.
American believers in human rights, secular and religious, do not talk war. Only Beijing, not the Chinese or U.S. people, encourages hostility with threats and aggressive insults. Human rights advocacy asks only that we not strengthen despotism so that we become part of its oppression machinery.
Why do powerful free nations like America keep acting against their interests by building up despotisms until they feel strong enough to threaten us?
One reason is self-deception stemming from stupidity -- the refusal to learn from experience. In a person that is a danger; in a free nation it is closer to a deliberate sin.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 928 words

HEADLINE: Daimler's Profit Trails Forecasts And theShares Fall Sharply

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 29

 BODY:
Shares of DaimlerChrysler A.G. took a pounding on two continents today after it turned in flat second-quarter earnings, hurt mostly by weaker-than-expected profits from Chrysler models.
The company, formed in November when Daimler-Benz A.G. bought the Chrysler Corporation, said its second-quarter adjusted net income fell three-tenths of 1 percent, to 1.48 billion euros, or $1.53 billion, compared with the 1.49 billion euros, or $1.534 billion, that the two companies together earned in the quarter a year earlier. 
 Revenue rose roughly 10 percent, to 37.33 billion euros, or $38.48 billion, from 33.87 billion euros, or $34.92 billion.
Analysts had expected more. Their consensus was that DaimlerChrysler would earn $2 a share in the second quarter, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks earnings. But the company earned 1.47 euros, or $1.52, a diluted share, down from the 1.52 euros, or $1.64, a share in the period a year earlier.
In Frankfurt, shares of DaimlerChrysler dropped 5.45 euros, or 6.8 percent, to 74.25 euros. They fared even worse in the United States, falling $7.4375, or 8.75 percent, to $77.5625.
"Expectations were not met," said Scott F. Merlis, a managing director and head of the automotive practice at Wasserstein Perella Securities Inc. "It is a paradox that the earnings were so disappointing because the company continues to set sales records."
He said profits suffered because rebates were higher than expected in North America and Europe and because of heavy losses from the Smart car in Europe.
Executives defended the financial results. "These are quite good numbers," said Jurgen E. Schrempp, the co-chairman.
"We kept our eyes on the ball and continued to grow the business profitably," Mr. Schrempp said. "We expect this trend of profitable growth to continue in the second half of the year."
David B. Healy, an auto analyst with Burnham Securities, said DaimlerChrysler's earnings in the second quarter suffered from three problems: heavy losses in the Asian and Latin American operations of the former Chrysler, continued losses on Daimler's Smart car in Europe and the weakness of the euro, which made European profits worth less when converted into dollars.
Because the reporting of quarterly earnings remains fairly new for DaimlerChrysler, the company might have made conservative accounting choices that will result in better profits later this year, particularly as economies from the merger begin to be realized, Mr. Healy said. But he added that the steep fall in DaimlerChrysler's shares today suggested that many investors did not believe this.
Despite the hottest American sales market ever, profits were lower than expected from the mass-market brands sold under Chrysler marques because higher rebates and other incentives were required to keep people buying in the United States and because unit sales outside North America fell 20.1 percent in the quarter.
Second-quarter operating profits for Chrysler, Plymouth, Dodge and Jeep brands rose just 1.4 percent, to $1.36 billion compared with $1.34 billion in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue for those lines rose 9.6 percent, to $16.77 billion, from $15.3 billion.
Robert J. Eaton, the other co-chairman, said sales continued their sizzling pace this month and that sales of Chrysler minivans, which had seemed to be flagging, were picking up. "We're going to have a very strong July, headed by minivans," he said.
The luxury Mercedes-Benz line fared better. Operating profits for Mercedes and Smart jumped 17.8 percent, to $635 million, from $539 million in the second quarter of last year. The tiny Smart car remains unprofitable, but the gains came from rising Mercedes sales, particularly high-profit sales of the Mercedes M-class sport utility vehicle, built in Alabama.
Operating profits from sales of DaimlerChrysler's commercial vehicles dropped 1.2 percent, to $329 million from $333 million in the second quarter of last year. Profits were hurt by the economic crisis in Brazil.
Earnings from DaimlerChrysler's aerospace unit jumped 21.1 percent, to $195 million. The company plans to merge its aerospace unit, known as Dasa, with the Spanish state aerospace company, called Casa.
Mr. Eaton said that the company had found many synergies since the $36 billion deal combining the two auto makers and that DaimlerChrysler was on track to meet its goal of finding $1.4 billion in savings this year. Of the 1,200 separate projects undertaken this year to combine the companies, 31 percent are complete and 80 percent will be finished this year, he said.
Although executives expect further consolidation in the auto industry, DaimlerChrysler is concentrating on making its own deal work rather than shopping for other auto companies to buy. "We are not looking for any further acquisitions, except if something would pop in front of us," Mr. Schrempp said.
Judging from the performance of DaimlerChrysler's stock since the merger, there is still some work to be done. In Europe, DaimlerChrysler's stock has risen 4.3 percent since the deal was completed. In the United States, the company's shares, which are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, have fallen 7.5 percent in value.
Mr. Schrempp continued today to campaign for DaimlerChrysler's inclusion in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, a step that would increase demand for its shares by index mutual funds. He explained the stock's poor performance this way: "Most analysts so far have us on buy, but not sufficient people have bought us yet."

HEADLINE: Patients' Rights, Done Wrong

BYLINE: By Tom A. Coburn; Tom A. Coburn is a Republican Congressman representing Oklahoma.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Even though I am a Republican Congressman, I am also a doctor, and I have continued to treat patients and deliver babies in Muskogee, Okla.
I have experienced first hand the frustrations that have pushed managed care reform to the forefront of the Congressional agenda. Indeed, after treating patients, I usually return to Washington with a new horror story about a health insurance bureaucrat who has arbitrarily denied care to one of my patients. 
 While I believe the vast majority of health maintenance organizations are doing a good job and provide quality care at an affordable price, the frequency of abuse across the nation justifies prompt Congressional action. Unfortunately, the managed care bill recently passed in the Senate does little to solve the problems.
A credible bill should restore the doctor-patient relationship, which is being increasingly severed by insurance companies whose primary motivation is profit. Doctors no longer charge patients, patients no longer pay doctors, and neither determines what is medically necessary. Only by restoring the intimate bond between doctor and patient can Congress return free-market principles to an industry that in many ways resembles an arbitrary and inefficient Soviet-style economy.
The Senate bill, however, is so narrow that it completely ignores most insurance plans and the needs of the vast majority of Americans. And even for the minority of Americans the bill does cover, the 48 million people in self-financed health plans usually offered by large employers that do not fall under state regulation, the Senate's approach has three major flaws.
First, the Senate bill gives insurance companies rather than doctors the authority to decide what care is medically necessary. This bill would permit plans to deny coverage to patients, even if they are contradicting medical advice. Any bill that tries to protect patients is worthless if it doesn't have a proper standard of medical necessity. Indeed, the ability of insurance plans to adopt arbitrary definitions of medical necessity is at the root of many of the problems in managed care.
Second, the Senate bill falls short of establishing an independent external appeals process for patients who have been denied coverage. Under the Senate's plan, the appeals process is stacked in favor of insurance companies. The appeals panel would not be truly independent and objective. Reviewers would be allowed to have a financial relationship with the insurer, and the company could choose which cases would be appealed. If an insurance plan's decision caused injury or death, a patient would have no legal recourse. No other industry or individual in America enjoys this special exemption.
Congress can create an external appeals process with teeth, without resorting to lawsuits. Two Republican colleagues, Charlie Norwood of Georgia and John Shadegg of Arizona, and I have drafted a bill that would impose daily fines on health plans that are guilty of denying coverage. These fines would be so horrendous that companies would wish lawsuits were an option.
Finally, under the Senate bill, most people enrolled in an H.M.O. would still be unable to choose their own doctors.
I certainly don't believe that excessive government involvement in health care will lead to long-term solutions. But Congress can write legislation that allows the market to control our health care system while also protecting patients. Indeed, modest protections won't harm the industry any more than child labor laws slowed the Industrial Revolution.

HEADLINE: Rebuilding the Balkans

 BODY:
President Clinton's meeting with more than 30 other national leaders in Sarajevo today offers a chance to get the postwar reconstruction of Southeastern Europe off to a sound start. Billions of dollars have already been pledged to help rebuild Kosovo and several neighboring countries. But a lot of this could be wasted unless Washington, the European Union and the United Nations show they have learned from their only partly successful efforts in Bosnia. This time, more must be done to build new locally based economic and political institutions so that international relief can give way to long-term recovery.
The Sarajevo meeting launches the Balkan Stability Pact, an international relief and recovery plan intended to help the Balkan region overcome its history of conflict and ethnic strife and speed its integration into democratic Europe. The main beneficiaries will be Kosovo, Albania, Macedonia and Montenegro, which like Kosovo is formally part of Yugoslavia. Help will also be available for Romania and Bulgaria. 
 So long as Slobodan Milosevic remains in power, most international reconstruction aid will rightly bypass Serbia. The point is not to punish the Serbs but to hasten Mr. Milosevic's downfall. Once he is gone, building a more democratic and prosperous Serbia will help cement regional stability.
Bosnia shows that it is best to avoid building big, overlapping international bureaucracies that attract corruption and crowd out local political and economic initiatives. Western intervention brought desperately needed peace to Bosnia. But unemployment remains devastatingly high, foreign investment minuscule and politics dominated by ethnic nationalist parties.
In Kosovo, international administrators need to make sure moderates and independents get a fair chance to compete politically with the activists of the Kosovo Liberation Army. The K.L.A. has begun forcibly taking over political institutions and businesses while the U.N. administration is still getting organized. Once U.N. officials take charge, they should set a reasonable target date for local elections to begin the process of establishing self-government. A degree of economic self-sufficiency can be attained relatively quickly by assisting local farmers in getting back on their feet. They need modern equipment and lower trade barriers for their exports.
President Clinton helped to free Kosovo from brutal Serbian rule and enable its refugees to return home. Now he must help consolidate a wider Balkan peace.

HEADLINE: Senate G.O.P. Moves Ahead On Tax Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 29

 BODY:
Republicans moved closer today to Senate passage of a $792 billion tax cut over the opposition of President Clinton and Congressional Democrats, but they still face the difficult task of uniting the party on what form the cuts should take.
The Senate took up dozens of amendments to the tax bill today, rejecting the broadest of them and heading toward a vote on final passage on Friday. 
 The Senate bill was all but certain to pass with its major provisions intact, including a reduction in the lowest personal income tax rate.
Seeking to make political points, Democrats offered a series of amendments, including one that would have postponed the tax cuts and another that would have carved out money to provide a prescription drug benefit as part of Medicare. All were defeated, largely on party-line votes.
Senators debated but did not vote on a compromise plan offered by a bipartisan group of centrists. That plan would have cut taxes by $500 billion over 10 years, an effort to find a middle ground between the Republican plan and Mr. Clinton's insistence that any tax cut be limited to $300 billion.
The Senate voted down an effort by conservative Republicans to rework the $792 billion tax bill to include a reduction in all income tax rates and in capital gains tax rates, provisions that are in the House version of the bill.
It was also considering numerous special-interest amendments. Senators Mitch McConnell and Jim Bunning of Kentucky, both Republicans, sought a change that would benefit horse owners by reducing to one year from two years the time they would need to own a horse before being able to sell it at a favorable capital gains rate.
The House passed its version of the $792 billion Republican tax-cut plan last week. Once the Senate has finished work on its legislation, appointees from both chambers will meet to hash out the many variations in their bills. Some reflect fundamental differences in approach to tax cuts and others reflect the priorities of interest groups with a political or economic stake in the outcome.
Given that Republicans have no higher priority this year than passing a tax cut -- even though they know that Mr. Clinton will veto it -- they will almost certainly reach a compromise among themselves in the next week on what the tax package should look like.
"The debates will be of high energy and great commitment, but I think it gets done," said Representative Michael N. Castle of Delaware, one of a handful of House Republicans who believes that the $792 billion tax cut is too big. "Those committed to getting this bill done are more committed to getting it done at $792 billion than to any particular provision."
But getting there may not be easy. And even after the House and Senate negotiators reach agreement, they could face a tricky task in selling the deal to their members, especially in the House, where a group of moderate Republicans is watching closely to make certain that their concerns are addressed in the final package.
"There are significant differences both in approach and in structure in the House and Senate bills," said Trent Duffy, a spokesman for Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. "Conferencing them will be challenging."
The House bill is generally more appealing to conservatives in both chambers than the Senate bill, which was written to draw some support from Democrats.
The House bill, written by Mr. Archer, is built around a gradual reduction in all income tax rates, a provision that Republicans say would benefit those people who pay the most in taxes but that Democrats say disproportionately rewards the wealthy.
The Senate version, which was written by Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, the chairman of the Finance Committee, provides a smaller income tax cut and directs a greater proportion of it to middle-income households than the House bill.
It would reduce only the lowest income tax rate, bringing the current 15 percent bracket down to 14 percent and expanding it to include more taxpayers at higher income levels.
But the Senate version goes farther than the House version in addressing the so-called marriage penalty, a primary goal of social conservatives, one of the most influential of Republican constituencies. The Senate plan would almost eliminate the penalty -- which leaves many two-income couples paying more in taxes than if they were single -- by eventually allowing married couples to file as if they were single.
The House plan would limit its marriage penalty provisions to people who use the standard deduction, meaning that it would do little for higher-income couples, who almost invariably itemize their deductions. The House bill also contains a reduction in the top rate on capital gains to 15 percent from 20 percent, while the Senate version has no provision for capital gains.
The House and Senate negotiators will have to maintain a delicate political balance, retaining the appeal of the package both to the conservative wing of the party and the moderate wing.
Keeping that balance will be especially challenging in the House, where Republicans have a razor-thin majority.
A group of Republican moderates in the House objected to the size and composition of the original bill last week, forcing concessions from party leaders intended to assure that the tax cuts would not lead to renewed budget deficits.
Today, a group of those same moderates circulated a letter demanding that the party retain a feature of the House bill that is certain to bring intense objections from the Senate. The House bill contains a "trigger" that would allow the income tax reductions to take place only if the interest cost on the national debt does not rise.
Seventeen of the Republican moderates had signed the letter by tonight, suggesting that the leadership could have trouble passing the final version of the bill if it does not include the trigger.
"A lot of us have told the leadership that without a hard trigger we will have difficulty supporting the bill," said Representative Fred Upton, Republican of Michigan.
The Senate bill has a procedural wrinkle that also could give the negotiators headaches. It would require that the tax cuts be rescinded after 10 years, a provision that would be unappealing to conservatives in the House.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senators John D. Rockefeller 4th, left, Tom Daschle and John Kerry watched Edward M. Kennedy argue for tax-cut plan changes yesterday. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Tax-Cutting Proposals in Congress"
Congress is considering two Republican tax-cutting bills. The House approved legislation last week cutting taxes by $792 billion over the next 10 years. The Senate is debating a proposal that would cut taxes by the same amount over that period. President Clinton has promised to veto either version.
Although they are similar in scale, the two bills take very different approaches to reducing taxes for individuals and companies. The following is a description of some of their main provisions.
 
Personal Income Taxes
 
HOUSE
Would reduce all personal income tax rates by 10 percent, each gradually over 10 years.
COST -- $373.5 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would reduce the 15 percent income tax rate -- the lowest of the five brackets -- to 14 percent, starting in 2001. Would also expand the 14 percent bracket so that fewer taxpayers must pay the next-highest rate of 28 percent.
COST -- $297.5 billion over 10 years.
 
Married Couples
 
HOUSE
Would reduce the so-called marriage penalty, the quirk in the tax code that leaves many couples paying more in combined taxes than they would individually if single. The main provision would gradually increase the standard deduction for a couple filing jointly to twice the level of the standard deduction for a single filer (this year the deduction for married couples is $7,200 while the deduction for single people is $4,300).
COST -- $47.5 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would almost eliminate the marriage penalty. Married couples filing joint returns would have the option of filing single returns on a combined tax form, enabling them to take the standard deduction for single people rather than the standard deduction for joint filers, which is less than twice as big. But they would both have to take the standard deduction or itemize, and the change would not take effect until 2005.
COST -- $117.7 billion over 10 years.
 
Minimum Tax
 
HOUSE
Would gradually repeal the individual minimum tax, which was created to insure that wealthy people paid a fair share of income tax even if they were able to take advantage of deductions and other breaks, but which has increasingly applied to middle income taxpayers.
COST -- $63.7 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would limit the effects of the alternative minimum tax by allowing personal exemptions to be included in determining tax liability.
COST -- $96.1 billion over 10 years.
 
Savings and Investment
HOUSE
Would reduce the top rate on long-term capital gains from the sale of stocks, bonds and other assets. The rate would fall to 15 percent from 20 percent, and to 7.5 percent from 10 percent for people in the current 15 percent income tax bracket. It would apply retroactively to transactions after June 30 of this year.
COST -- $51.6 billion over 10 years.
 
Would also exclude some interest and dividend income from taxation, with the amount increasing to a maximum of $400 for joint filers and $200 for singles in 2003.
COST -- $19.6 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would make a variety of changes intended to stimulate more retirement savings. Among the changes would be increasing the contribution limit for individual retirement accounts to $5,000 from $2,000, increasing the income limits that determine eligibility for tax-deductible IRA's, and gradually increasing the maximum annual contribution to 401(k) programs to $15,000 from $10,000.
COST -- $69.5 billion over 10 years.
 
Inheritance Tax
 
HOUSE
Would phase out the estate and gift tax, which is currently levied on estates and gifts valued at $650,000 or more.
COST -- $65.4 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would reduce the estate and gift tax. Would reduce the top rate to 50 percent. Would change the unified credit that excludes most estates from taxation to an exemption. Would increase the exemption to $1.5 million from $1 million starting in 2007.
COST -- $58.6 billion over 10 years.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
SharePrices Tumble After Report Shows Gains in Wages

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stock prices tumbled sharply and broadly yesterday after the Government reported that employers paid unexpectedly large wage and benefit increases during the spring quarter, making it more likely -- but by no means certain -- that the Federal Reserve will again increase interest rates to avert inflation.
As traders reacted to a 1.1 percent jump in the Labor Department's employment cost index, the main gauges remained in negative territory throughout the session. The Dow Jones industrial average finished down 180.78 points, or 1.65 percent, at 10,791.29, but that was somewhat above its low. 
 For a while the Dow's slide was the biggest since May 27, but the late firming made it less severe than a 191.55-point selloff early last week.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index skidded 24.37 points, or 1.78 percent, closing at 1,341.03, while the recently-battered Nasdaq market took the biggest hit, dropping 65.83 points, or 2.43 percent, to 2,640.01.
"The numbers, chiefly the labor costs, were worse than expected," said Jeffrey M. Applegate, chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers. "This makes another Federal Reserve tightening more likely than not."
A separate Labor Department report showed a sharp cut in first-time claims for unemployment insurance last week, suggesting that the labor market remained tight into summer. Market operators took little comfort from a Commerce Department estimate that the economy's growth rate was slower than had been expected during the spring.
Trading volume quickened a bit, but analysts said much of the weakness reflected program trades by professionals and there was little evidence of indiscriminate selling.
"This is just a correction, not the beginning of anything we should be concerned about," said Jeffrey Rubin, research director at Birinyi Associates. "It's not your grandmother going and throwing the baby out with the bathwater."
Others were less sanguine. For example, Richard T. McCabe, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch, said, "It looks like a resumption of the downswing that started last week" when investors who had bet correctly on strong second-quarter profits decided to cash in. And the next upward push is unlikely to occur before the Fed's Aug. 24 policy meeting, he said, with the interim clouded by fears that the central bank will find much to fret about, especially next Friday's report on the labor market in July.
Paul Rich, a trader at BT Brokerage, largely agreed. "We're seeing some serious selling" because of interest-rate jitters, he said, expressing disappointment that good corporate earnings, the best since the first quarter of 1997, have been rewarded with such heavy profit-taking.
Bond prices also slumped yesterday on rate fears, putting pressure on financial stocks, with J. P. Morgan falling 3 3/8 to 130 5/8, leading the decline of the blue-chip Dow average.
Only four of the 30 Dow stocks gained. The only sizable gains were from Procter & Gamble, up 2 a share, to 88 1/8, and Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing, up 1 11/16, to 90 13/16. Both reported profits that beat expectations.
Gold stocks, one of the most depressed groups, were higher, with Newmont Mining rising 1 1/8, to 19 3/8.
Waste Management was a major casualty, skidding 5 1/2 a share, to 25 15/16, after warning again of lagging profits. The shares, which traded at 60 in early May, hit a new low of 24.
In a prominent initial public offering, Net2Phone's shares surged as high as 29 1/2 from 15 before closing at 26 9/16. A total of 18.7 million shares changed hands, meaning that each of the 5.4 million shares issued averaged more than three different owners.
Declining issues swamped advancing ones on the New York Stock Exchange, 2,242 to 809; there were 166 new lows compared with 31 new highs.
Major European stock markets, which were open long enough to digest the American economic news, closed with even bigger losses, ranging from 2.8 percent in Paris to 3.4 percent in Frankfurt. Mexico's Bolsa dropped nearly 4 percent while earlier, stock prices climbed 1.6 percent in Tokyo.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Fall
 By Bloomberg News
Bond prices fell yesterday after a bigger-than-expected rise in second-quarter job costs fanned speculation the Federal Reserve might increase interest rates soon.
The report heightened concern that rising labor costs would push up prices on goods and services, and now "there's a genuine concern that the Fed will take action" when it meets on Aug. 24, said Margo Cook, who helps invest the bond portfolio at Bank of New York, which manages $50 billion.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 25/32, to 88 27/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.07 percent from 6.00 percent on Wednesday.
With today's declines, investors who bought 30-year bonds at the start of the year are now sitting on paper losses of 10.1 percent.
"The bond market is not taking this well," said Charles Parkhurst, co-head of Government bond trading at Salomon Smith Barney. "There's more concern that the Fed will raise rates."
Also raising bond traders' fears of inflation, crude oil traded at more than $21 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange for the first time since November 1997.

HEADLINE: Multiplex Is Planned Above Bus Terminal

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Continuing its efforts to transfer pieces of its vast real estate empire to private hands, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that it had selected a developer to build a multiplex movie theater on top of its George Washington Bridge bus station in upper Manhattan.
Under the plan, approved by the Port Authority board yesterday, McCann Real Equities, a developer in Armonk, N.Y., will conduct a six-month engineering study for erecting the multiplex over the roof of the three-story station, which straddles the congested traffic lanes of the Cross Bronx Expressway leading to the George Washington Bridge in Washington Heights. 
 If the project proves feasible, the developer will build a 12-screen, 2,800-seat multiplex and sign a 40-year lease for its use. The deal calls for McCann to pay $20 million in lease payments to the Port Authority, increasing from $350,000 to $809,000 a year over the term of the lease. The plan was first reported yesterday in the New York Post.
Martin Berger, the managing partner of McCann, said yesterday that engineering studies had already been conducted on the bus station site and that he was "very encouraged" that the project could proceed.
Executives of the Port Authority said the project provided the latest example of how a private, money-making venture would provide a financial return on its real estate and benefit the public. Other recent ventures by the agency have included the transfer of two terminals at Kennedy International Airport to private operations and the sale of land it had owned in Yonkers. The agency also plans to sell development rights for a hotel or other private development over the Port Authority bus depot at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.
"This project will be a powerful economic tool for economic revitalization in Washington Heights," Charles A. Gargano, vice chairman of the Port Authority and the chief development adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki, said of the multiplex plan.
McCann has built several large projects in the New York area, including a multiplex theater in Huntington, N.Y., and a nursing home in Jackson Heights, Queens. Mr. Berger said the Washington Heights project was appealing because the neighborhood had been bypassed by the recent wave of movie theater construction elsewhere in the city.
"It is pretty close to a free zone," he said, adding that McCann hoped to start building by the end of the year and complete its project by the end of 2000. He said McCann was negotiating with several large movie theater chains, which he declined to name, to select an operator of the Washington Heights multiplex.
The main construction difficulty, Mr. Berger said, stems from the bus station's location directly above local streets and highway lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge, which would require crews to work mainly at night and on weekends.
The plan calls for the multiplex to be built on pillars rising above the roof of bus station, which is now used for public parking. By leaving the roof in place, Mr. Berger said, it could be used by the multiplex operators for customer parking, providing 150 spaces.
But despite its location at a major interchange of car traffic, he said that no more parking spaces were planned than those already set aside on the bus station roof, and that most patrons would be expected to use public transportation to get to the multiplex.

HEADLINE: Hillary Clinton Shifts Her Focus to Taxes

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: ELMIRA, N.Y., July 29

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton came to this Republican patch of upstate New York today intent on embracing what Democrats see as a major issue in next year's Congressional elections: the Republican drive to put through the largest Federal tax cut since 1982. But she also found herself again discussing the question of whether someone who does not live in New York could represent it in the Senate.
The First Lady, on her third week of touring the state since she officially began exploring a Senate race, sought to frame her latest "listening forum" around the Republican tax bill being debated in Washington, which President Clinton has said he would veto. 
 "There is a debate going on in the Senate about a nearly $1 trillion Republican tax cut that I believe would damage most New Yorkers," Mrs. Clinton said. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is likely to seek the Republican nomination for the Senate seat, declined today to say if he supports the proposal being advanced by fellow Republicans in Washington, though he has said he supports using some of the Federal surplus for a tax cut.
Even as Mrs. Clinton sought to turn the topic to Republican fiscal policy with what were her most partisan remarks since she began this tour, she twice found herself answering questions from Elmira residents about her interest in representing a state where she has never lived.
Both of the residents were cordial, and afterward, both said they were impressed by her answers. Nonetheless, their questions, coming after the First Lady has spent a fair amount of time in the state -- and in a week in which Mr. Giuliani traveled to Little Rock, Ark., where Mrs. Clinton used to live, to draw attention to the issue -- suggest the task that Mrs. Clinton faces.
"If you become Senator from New York State," asked David Caton, a factory worker at the Hillard Corporation plant here, "would you work at getting a bill through that you have to be a resident for 'X' amount of time before you can run for office?"
"No, that would be a state decision," Mrs. Clinton responded instantly. "That's in the State Constitution and it's state law. So the people of New York would have to make whatever changes they would make through their State Legislature."
As Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Caton exchanged smiles and handshakes, she then called out with a grin: "But I like it the way it is."
The question came up again at the end of the forum, when Jim Davis, a registered Republican who is an executive with a natural gas company here, told Mrs. Clinton that he admired her work in Washington. "But why did you choose New York, and how are you going to overcome the carpetbagger question?" he asked.
"It's a very fair question," Mrs. Clinton said. She said that she and her husband had decided to live in New York before anyone raised the idea of her running for Senate. And then, when some New Yorkers began pushing her to consider running for the seat being vacated by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, she found, she said, that many of the concerns that they raised, like health care, mirrored her own interests.
"Ultimately, it will be up to the people of New York," she said.
The re-emergence of the residency issue today had to be somewhat frustrating to Mrs. Clinton. Her decision to discuss the Republican tax cut plan so pointedly today marked a strategic departure at these sessions. By all appearances, she was trying to engage Mr. Giuliani on an issue that her advisers believe will be a vital one in the months ahead.
In describing her opposition to the Republican tax plan, Mrs. Clinton reprised many of the arguments being made by Democrats in Washington, including the President.
"It does not do enough for Social Security," she said. "It does not provide one additional dollar for Medicare. And it certainly doesn't provide a prescription drug benefit for seniors who need it. It would undermine the kind of education aid that New York needs for its schools and colleges. And it very well might undermine the economic progress we have made for the past eight years."
Mr. Giuliani, speaking in Alabama during a fund-raising trip on Wednesday, said that he supported using some of the surplus for a tax cut but that he did not have a position on the Republican plan.
"Oh, I'd really have to analyze those proposals," he said. "I would support reducing taxes. Exactly which proposals, I would have to go over."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Big Gain in Labor Costs Raises Fear of Higher Rates
The Labor Department reported that the so-called employment cost index rose 1.1 percent from the first to the second quarter of the year, its biggest increase in eight years. The unexpected gain overshadowed a separate Government report that showed the robust American economy took a breather in the spring. 
 Stock and bond prices plunged as investors appeared worried that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who closely monitors the employment gauge, might be more likely to favor raising interest rates to keep inflation in check. Page A1.
 
Stock and Bond Prices Tumble
Stock and bond prices fell on inflation fears. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 180.78 points, or 1.65 percent, to 10,791.29. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index skidded 24.37 points, or 1.78 percent, to 1,341.03, and the Nasdaq composite index decreased 65.83 points, or 2.43 percent, to 2,640.01. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond increased to 6.07 percent from 6 percent on Wednesday. C8.
 
The National Association of Securities Dealers board authorized its staff to step up preparations for converting the Nasdaq stock market into a publicly traded company. C7.
 
Trash Hauler Issues Profit Warning
Waste Management warned for the second time this month that its second-quarter earnings would be tepid at best. Though the company announced several steps, including the resignations of Gregory T. Sangalis, its general counsel, and Earl E. DeFrates, its chief financial officer, to improve its forecasting ability and shore up its bottom line, Wall Street was not appeased. Investors sent the shares down $5.50, to $25.9375, less than half the $60 the stock peaked at May 4. C2.
 
Rejection of Airline Deal Expected
The Department of Transportation is expected to reject the three-year effort by American Airlines and British Airways to win approval to share revenue and to coordinate schedules and fares. But the two carriers said they would broaden their cooperation in other ways. C2.
 
Japan Punishes Credit Suisse
Japanese authorities imposed severe sanctions on the Credit Suisse Group, closing a six-month investigation into the firm's sale of derivative securities intended to help Japanese banks and companies hide huge losses. C6.
 
Procter & Gamble Tops Forecasts
Procter & Gamble, aided by successful new products and recovering foreign markets, reported robust quarterly earnings that beat Wall Street expectations. C7.
 
Martha Stewart to Issue Stock
Martha Stewart, the doyenne of domestic details, plans to sell $100 million in stock in her company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Investors will be able to buy stock in a company dominated by the monthly magazine Martha Stewart Living, but whose television, merchandising and Internet businesses are growing robustly. C4.
 
Strong Earnings for AT&T and MCI
The nation's two largest long-distance telephone carriers, AT&T and MCI Worldcom, posted strong quarterly earnings. MCI met forecasts and AT&T was a bit higher. C4.
 
2 Weeks Given to Resolve Dispute
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission have been given two weeks to resolve a dispute over whether the firm must produce all the information the Federal Government agency has subpoenaed in a sex discrimination case, people briefed on court proceedings said. C7.

HEADLINE: Jump in Labor Cost Prompts Fear of Rising Interest Rates

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
An unexpected spike in an important inflation warning signal that tracks labor costs spooked financial markets yesterday, overshadowing a separate Government report that showed the robust American economy took a breather in the spring.
Despite the reassuring signs that the economy was not overheating, both the stock and bond markets fell sharply after the Labor Department reported that the employment cost index rose 1.1 percent from the first to the second quarter of the year, its biggest gain in eight years. The measure tracks changes in total compensation -- wages and salaries, of course, but also fringe benefits like health insurance and pension contributions. Both benefits and pay leapt, with the biggest increases coming in the highest-and lowest-paying industries. 
 Investors appeared worried that the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who closely monitors the gauge, might now be more likely to favor raising interest rates in the near future as a preventive measure against rising prices.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 180.78 points, or 1.65 percent, to close at 10,791.29. The broader market fell even more, with the Standard & Poor's 500 index down 1.78 percent and the Nasdaq composite index dropping 2.43 percent.
The Treasury market, ever sensitive to inflation fears, took a direct hit. The price of the benchmark 30-year bond was down about three-quarters of a point as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.07 percent from 6 percent on Wednesday.
The Fed already nudged short-term rates up by a quarter of a point at the end of June, and in the past several days Mr. Greenspan has warned that he would act "promptly and forcefully" at the first hint that inflation was accelerating.
But several analysts cautioned that the financial markets may have overreacted to the threat of inflation and that any upswing in prices was likely to be muted.
"The best days of inflation news may be behind us," said Nicholas Perna, chief economist at the Fleet Bank in Hartford. Still, he added, "nothing untoward is necessarily down the road."
And Bill Cheney, chief economist at John Hancock, the insurance and investment company in Boston, said that the big rise in compensation costs last quarter needed to be balanced against the previous two quarters, when the gain was unusually small. "The wage inflation picture is still benign," he said.
Meanwhile, even though economic growth moderated significantly in the April-June quarter, there were plenty of signs of continued strength in the latest figures.
The gross domestic product -- the nation's total output of goods and services -- expanded at a modest 2.3 percent annual pace, not much more than half the rate of last winter, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.
The slowdown in growth was much more abrupt than forecasters had been expecting.
American consumers, who had lately been doing so much of the world's buying, pulled back from their torrid 6.7 percent spending pace earlier in the year. But spending still advanced at a robust annual rate of 4 percent, with Americans digging deeper into debt by shopping more avidly than their gains in take-home pay could support.
The trade deficit continued to serve as a drag on the economy, but it was a less severe brake than in recent periods. Spending on housing slowed considerably and so did the accumulation of inventories by American businesses.
By contrast, business investment in equipment and buildings grew at a strong annual rate of 9.1 percent and computer purchases by businesses advanced at a blazing 41.5 percent annual rate.
After two years of growth well in excess of the 2.5 to 3 percent rate the Fed deems sustainable over the long haul, the signs of moderation would normally have been cause for celebration on Wall Street.
But instead it was the surprisingly large 1.1 percent jump in the Labor Department's employment cost index that created a commotion.
Financial firms sharply raised bonuses while retailers, coping with labor shortages in many parts of the country, increased both pay and benefits. The second-quarter increase was the biggest spurt since the spring of 1991 and nearly three times the first quarter's tiny increase of four-tenths of 1 percent.
Wages and salaries grew faster than fringe benefits, but benefit costs rose by nearly a percentage point in the spring. Costs for employer-provided health insurance had been remarkably tame in recent years, thanks to the pressure on most workers to shift to health maintenance organizations. But economists have been warning for some time that once the one-time savings have been achieved, health care costs will start rising faster. They now appear to be doing so.
Investors have been worried that the Fed was preparing to initiate a series of rate increases to rein in the exuberant economy. The outsize spurt in labor costs seemed to confirm their anxieties.
The economic picture, however, does not look as alarmingly different as the headline numbers on yesterday's reports made it seem.
Take the labor cost data first. For one thing, the spurt in labor costs followed a puzzling slowdown last winter when the index barely rose even as unemployment dropped to its lowest level in three decades. For another, compensation costs for private industry are up just 3.3 percent from a year ago, less than the 3.5 percent rise the previous year.
As of now, it is still possible that labor costs are simply catching up, and that the second quarter does not signal a new trend. "Nobody will know for another few quarters whether the second quarter increase was an aberration," Mr. Perna said.
Further, there was no evidence in yesterday's G.D.P. report that actual inflation was accelerating or that American corporations were finding it any easier to pass cost increases on to consumers. While import prices moved up sharply, the so-called G.D.P. deflator, which measures the prices of all domestically produced goods and services, rose at a tame 1.6 percent annual rate in the spring.
By the same token, the economy still appears to have plenty of momentum. After the big blowout on cars and other big-ticket items, which was accompanied by a surge in borrowing, a slowdown was not only inevitable, but reassuring.
Over all, the evidence seemed to point to a slight cooling off of the economy. "Slower growth in consumption, housing and inventories," said Dean Baker, an economist at the Preamble Center, a liberal advocacy group in Washington, "should eliminate any immediate concerns that the economy is growing at an unsustainable rate."
But given the mixed picture, investors and analysts will focus on next Friday's release of July employment data.
"The economy is moderating but the Fed is still on hair-trigger alert," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch in New York. "Stay tuned."
