HEADLINE: Detroit, Still Blighted, Puts Hopes in Casinos

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 29

 BODY:
With glittering lights and the roll of dice, a casino opened here today, the first of a number of promised attractions that Detroit is counting on to bring long-lost prosperity back to its blighted streets.
The MGM Grand Detroit is the first of three casinos due to open before the end of the year, making Detroit the largest city in the United States with casinos. Two new sports stadiums will follow close on their heels, and the momentum has helped persuade the Compuware Corporation, maker of software, to announce plans to move its headquarters and 6,000 workers downtown from the suburbs. 
 The three casinos are expected to add 7,000 to 8,000 jobs in Detroit, where the unemployment rate, 7 percent, is more than double the suburban rate.
"The casino represents a piece of the puzzle that will be of enormous help that will enhance the city's economy and image," Mayor Dennis W. Archer said. "People will want to come to Detroit."
Ever since Henry Ford invented the assembly line, Detroit has been a gritty city; only the fleeting glamour of the Motown era interrupted its dirt-under-the-nails image. But just as Las Vegas used a string of casinos to transform itself from a lonely stretch of desert to a neon mecca, Detroit is hoping that opening casinos and building ball parks will make it a tourist destination as well.
The prospect of adding tens of millions of dollars to annual tax revenue persuaded a once-skeptical electorate to vote last spring to allow three casinos here. The three will eventually be situated on the city's waterfront, right across the Detroit River from a pair of competitors: government-run casinos in Windsor, Ontario.
Until those permanent Detroit casinos can be built, the city will make do with three temporary, less expensive versions, including the $220 million MGM Grand, which sits next to a highway downtown. They will stay open 24 hours a day, every day of the year.
At the MGM Grand, owned by the Las Vegas casino giant of the same name, bright lights beckon visitors to slot machines, some of which cost just a nickel to play. There are 80 table games -- blackjack or baccarat, pai gow or poker -- along with three restaurants, where gamblers can have something as simple as macaroni and cheese or as steady as a steak.
Except for all the card tables and slot machines, the place looks like a strip club. Most of the decorationsare of the two-legged variety, well-built young women wearing white-and-gold outfits cut low in front and high behind. These are the Grandettes, the waitresses and hostesses who serve up drinks and smiles to the customers.
By winter, the two other casinos are expected to open. And then thoughts will turn to the two new stadiums.
The Detroit Tigers will play their last home game at historic Tiger Stadium on Sept. 27 and will start up next April at Comerica Park, which construction crews have been working on all year. The new stadium, made of light brown brick, will replace one of the two oldest major league ball parks; Tiger Stadium opened on the same day in 1912 as Fenway Park in Boston.
The Ford family, which owns the Detroit Lions, has promised to build a $225 million football stadium next to the baseball park and, says Thomas J. Lewand, the Lions' vice president, could break ground for it by the end of the year.
Having pro football games downtown will itself benefit Detroit, which long ago lost the Lions to suburban Pontiac. But developers say the double-stadium complex is planned specifically not only to draw suburbanites into the city but to keep them there for a few extra hours.
Michael Ilitch, owner of the Tigers and the Detroit Red Wings hockey team, said that he planned a number of retail stores and restaurants and even a children's carousel in the stadium complex and that an Embassy Suites hotel would sprout just beyond right field. (The last new hotel here was built two decades ago.)
In fact, Mr. Ilitch believes that while the casinos will provide thousands of jobs, their impact on the city as a whole could be overstated.
"I think the people, when they go into the casinos, are not going to leave them," he said. "There's some spinoff from the casinos, but I don't think they're going to be the saviors by any means."
Still, he said, a momentum has been created in Detroit, and "the city will turn around."
To be sure, it has a long way to go. Race riots in 1967 caused the flight of tens of thousands of white residents, which in turn left this the nation's poorest big city. Detroit hit bottom in the 1980's, when a recession caused widespread layoffs in the auto industry just as crack hit the streets of the inner city. Even now, boarded-up buildings mar the downtown skyline, and on hot days people with nowhere better to be can be found whiling away the hours under trees in vacant lots, trying to stay cool.
The Mayor hopes to help some of those people, too, with taxes collected from the casinos. The city and the state will divide 18 percent of the gross profits from the gaming houses -- 55 percent of the tax share goes to Detroit and 45 percent to Michigan, which plans to spend the money on educational grants statewide. The city expects $250 million in casino taxes in the next four years.
Laying down their share will be people like Leona Monit, 49, a waitress from nearby Garden City, Mich. Ms. Monit, who was so eager to wager at the MGM Grand today that she lined up two hours before it opened at 4 P.M., said the casino would bring both good and bad to the city.
"The good is a lot of jobs, the bad is a lot of people are going to gamble who can't afford to," said Ms. Monit, who by 7:30 reported that she was even for the night, playing slots.
Among some of the gamblers, there was a buy-at-home sentiment. Gloria Wheeler, 58, who works on a pickup truck assembly line in Pontiac and was playing the slots tonight, said that she had been driving to the casinos in Windsor but that "it is better to turn over the money in the city."

HEADLINE: A Pillar of Opposition Who Keeps Belgrade Guessing

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, July 29

 BODY:
Dragoslav Avramovic is sorely tempted to heed the call, but he's nearly 80 and has serious kidney troubles, and he's not really sure the moment is ripe.
Mr. Avramovic, a frail, unlikely looking technocrat, is the most popular opposition figure in Yugoslavia, revered for beating back hyperinflation in 1994. And the Clinton Administration and the foundering Alliance for Change here are pushing him to become the Prime Minister of Serbia, the overwhelming power base in Yugoslavia, and there take a leading role in the effort to oust Slobodan Milosevic from the presidency of the Yugoslav federation. 
 But Mr. Avramovic, who speaks modestly but enjoys the spotlight, really is not convinced, he said in an interview on Wednesday, just before leaving today for Sarajevo, to attend a Balkan summit conference as the representative of the Serbian political opposition.
"I'm conscious of the pressure, and every morning I have a serious self-examination about whether to get in deeper and deeper," he said.
The country badly wants change, but not revolution, he said, and the opposition "has to have a theory about how it's going to work out."
"You just can't move from day to day without some idea of how it's going to work," he said.
The Alliance for Change, to which Mr. Avramovic belongs, and its rival, the Serbian Renewal Movement, which is led by Vuk Draskovic, both suggest the naming of a transitional government that they hope Mr. Milosevic will be forced to accept by popular pressure. That government is supposed to bring Yugoslavia back to the world's good graces and organize new elections, while Mr. Milosevic is supposed to resign.
A key member of the alliance, Vuk Obradovic, a former general, has openly pushed Mr. Avramovic to accept the leadership, as has the alliance coordinator, Vladan Batic. Mr. Avramovic, who will be 80 in October, is the least controversial possibility, with the broadest appeal.
But asked if he would agree to serve, Mr. Avramovic sighed.
"First, will there be a transitional government?" he said. "How will it take place?" He continued, "There's a theory that it will end up with a general strike, with all these people in the streets, but that's not clear."
Second, he said, "I'm not a young man, my health is not the best, and while I'll do what I can, I naturally have some reluctance to take on something with such demands."
And then there's his wife, Marija, "who thinks whatever I do is wrong," he said. "My wife says her whole life has been centered around me and public affairs," he continued, "and it's high time to have some family life."
The country demands and needs a change of leadership, he says. "The pressure comes from the feeling that there is no prospect for improvement now, for citizens or for their children," he said. "The prevailing uneasiness and demonstrations reflect this lack of perspective, and people in the streets reflect this pessimism and need for change."
After all, he said, Mr. Milosevic has been in power 10 years, "and there is an internal fatigue of a sort and a lack of imagination." While Mr. Milosevic "must feel it's not all his fault and the world illegitimately pushed him into a corner over Kosovo," Mr. Avramovic said, "the Government should not have gotten into a situation where the whole world is our enemy."
Mr. Avramovic, a socialist and lawyer who spent more than 20 years working with the World Bank, is disarming but shrewd. He says he wants to do no harm to the opposition, which he thinks is improving in its ability to work together. But he also has a healthy regard for the tactical strength of Mr. Milosevic and his ability to keep a tightly constrained economy afloat.
Mr. Avramovic served Mr. Milosevic from 1993 to 1996, mostly as governor of the central bank, probably saving the regime by ending hyperinflation.
His actions made him wildly popular. By ordering the exchange of 12 million old dinars for one new dinar equal to the German mark, he stabilized prices and wages and pensions, expanded the economy and gave the poor, old and working class not only hope, but sustenance.
He was dismissed in May 1996 after calling for the Government to resign after a dispute over monetary and fiscal policy, when he urged curbs on renewed inflation and refused to hand out loans indiscriminately. His popularity increased, and he is known as Deda Avram, or Grandpa Avram.
He agreed to lead the list of opposition candidates in the 1996 federal and local elections, and the list of the coalition Zajedno itself bore his name, as the list of the ruling coalition bore the name of Mr. Milosevic.
But shortly before the elections, Mr. Avramovic pulled out and insisted on taking his name off even the collective list. Many of the opposition were hurt and furious; Mr. Avramovic said simply that his health was too poor, but there were rumors, which he denies, that he was somehow blackmailed.
This week he talked about the decision, as he has rarely done. His health was indeed poor, he said; while he is off dialysis now, he was then having it three times a week, and his blood pressure was too high. But he also said he felt there were too many divisions within Zajedno, and that he "was pushed into deciding who would get what post, which was not my job." "I'm not a politician by training or by instinct," he said.
And last, "the coalition was moving too much to the right for my taste," both economically and politically, with too much of a nationalist tinge, he said.
Nationalism continues to disturb him, especially as the world wants "a non-domineering nation in Yugoslavia." He thinks Kosovo was a disaster and could have been kept within Yugoslavia had Mr. Milosevic agreed to make it a federal republic, instead of removing all its autonomy.
The Milosevic Government is not yet printing money, he said, and while there is a deep recession, basic commodities and food are probably adequate for the winter and at relatively stable prices.
But electricity is another matter. Many Yugoslavs heat with electricity, and the distribution system and the refineries were badly damaged by NATO bombs. Some Government ministers say they think that supplies will be one-third less than last year.
"If we can import electricity, will we have the hard currency for it, and if we get it, can we transmit it?" Mr. Avramovic said. "Really, this is the main threat to the regime."

HEADLINE: Waiters, a Newly Rare Ingredient;
Suddenly in Demand, They Have Become Demanding

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
A press of eager diners followed the boomlet of favorable reviews about Tabla and Eleven Madison Park, the new dining establishments owned by the empire-building Manhattan restaurateur Danny Meyer. So what could be bad?
Well, for starters, it was eight long weeks after the debut before he could open Eleven Madison Park for the lucrative lunch trade. Worse, it took eight full months for Tabla to be able to offer that perennial profit maker, Sunday-night dinner. 
 The reason? Mr. Meyer just couldn't find enough waiters.
With new upscale restaurants seemingly opening as fast as the most tyrannical maitre d'hotel could hope to turn a table, New York is in the throes of what people in the business describe as an escalating skilled-labor crisis.
It's "the worst shortage I've seen in 30 years," said Michael (Buzzy) O'Keefe, owner of the River Cafe and the Water Club. "It's across the board -- for waiters, sous-chefs, line cooks and front-of-house people."
The shortage is changing the nature of restaurants' employer-employee dynamic and transforming the culture of the dining trade, even affording waiters a measure of respectability they have rarely achieved outside Europe.
The dearth has led not only to headhunting but also to outright poaching. Luring waiters to work in new luxury eating places, managers are resorting to sweeteners ranging from fully paid health benefits and paid vacations to 401(k) retirement plans and free vouchers for meals in other top restaurants. And owners are increasingly relying on training to jump-start waiters from naifs to sophisticates.
The shortage has even fostered an ad hoc sort of unemployment insurance. When Cena, the highly regarded new three-star restaurant on East 22d Street, closed its doors this month, 50 stunned waiters, busboys and kitchen workers found themselves unemployed during the dog days of summer. Traditionally that's a nightmarish time to look for a job.
But 10 of Cena's unemployed were immediately snapped up to work at Sono, a new restaurant opening next month on East 57th Street. Others were hired at Gramercy Tavern, Zoe and Gotham Bar and Grill. Most of the former employees have landed permanent or temporary jobs.
While the need for waiters is cited most often, kitchen workers are also being stalked. "Every week I get calls from at least two or three new restaurants opening up," said Jennifer Roesch, student placement director for the 700 graduates of the French Culinary Institute. "Chefs are crying about how difficult it is to find qualified people."
"These days, the hard part is to choose which restaurant you want to work in," said Juan Pablo Vicente, a 35-year-old veteran of Patria and Osteria del Circo who is currently a waiter at Judson Grill.
Bernard Grenier, 39, a Judson Grill colleague who has waited tables at Zoe, Becco, Sign of the Dove and Tavern on the Green, agreed. "Now the whole job-interview process has changed," he said. "You used to be happy just to have a chance at a job. Now you feel free to question, to ask how much you can make -- and what the benefits are."
Waiters who work in hotel restaurants like Lespinasse and Le Cirque 2000 get pensions and health benefits through Local 6 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union. But most of the waiters at the city's top restaurants are nonunion.
Now, "increasingly we're seeing health benefits, paid vacations and even restaurants that pay for wine or cooking classes," said Eric Weiss, a Manhattan service and wine consultant. He added, "Such benefits were unheard-of only a few years ago."
Waiters are hardly celebrated for being treated well, and indeed in some New York restaurants they are still getting no respect -- or worse. Some cite horror stories about bullying owners, autocratic chefs and even managers who skim the waiters' pooled tips.
But as demand for skilled workers grows at premium restaurants, bargaining power is growing. For start-up restaurants, "It's even harder to attract staff, because experienced servers don't want to wait until the business builds," said Patrick O'Sullivan, a training consultant who is opening a 130-seat restaurant, Jack's Fifth, at 8 West 58th Street in September. To attract workers he is offering paid health insurance "and a 401(k) plan to all staff down to the dishwashers," he said.
Veterans of the dining wars have seen "a steady increase in benefits," said Carmine Cozzolino, a 40-year-old waiter at Le Cirque 2000. At Mr. Meyer's restaurants, employees get full dental coverage after three months. At Bayard's, owner Peter Poulakakos pays 100 percent of waiters' health insurance after three months and offers two weeks' paid vacation.
And now many fledgling eating places are easing the shortage by ambitiously educating their new servers. For example, there is a training session every evening for the wait staff of Pop, a buzzy new high-end restaurant at 127 Fourth Avenue near 12th Street in Manhattan.
"So, let's review," said Rudy Santos, the 37-year-old general manager, 20 minutes before the 6:30 arrival of the hungry horde on a recent evening. "When do we serve bread?" he asked the 16 young servers arrayed before him in the 130-seat restaurant's 1950's-Modern dining room.
There was a thoughtful pause. "Remember," Mr. Santos prompted, "the service of bread comes after cocktails, ideally after people have put in their order. It is the visual cue to our guests, signalling that the games have begun."
Even since its April opening, Pop has already suffered the theft of several waiters.
These days "the demand for qualified restaurant employees is the highest it's ever been," said E. Charles Hunt, executive vice president of the city chapter of the New York State Restaurant Association, a trade group with 2,500 member restaurants in the city.
The reason is that establishments that indulge New Yorkers' eating and drinking habits were one of the fastest-growing segments of the city's economy last year, up 5,000 jobs to a total of 145,400, according to the New York State Department of Labor. Such jobs have increased 24 percent since 1992. There are some 50,000 waiters in the five boroughs, Mr. Hunt of the Restaurant Association estimated. The city has issued 20,000 permits for restaurants, which collectively generated about $7.2 billion in revenues last year.
But the dearth is especially acute at Manhattan's 3,000 "tablecloth restaurants," primarily at high-end places that offer attentive service to a demanding clientele.
The shortage "has been growing since last summer," said Malcolm M. Knapp, a restaurant analyst who heads a consulting concern in Manhattan that bears his name. "The service expectations are so high now that the employment pool is much thinner."
And so these days, servers at the city's four-star ornaments are being relentlessly headhunted. Jose Faria, 38, a waiter at Jean Georges, recently turned down offers from Aquavit and Gigino's.
Kit Wong, a 33-year-old waiter at Jean Georges who has previously worked at Aureole and Les Celebrites, says that although "Jean Georges is the best restaurant I have ever worked for," he is jumping ship for a de luxe new dining place in the Paris Hotel in Las Vegas, opening in September.
Some chefs and managers "turn their dinner visits to other restaurants into recruiting trips," said Patrick F. Graham, a 30-year-old waiter at Balthazar who has worked at Aquavit and Verbena. "They come in, they have dinner, they say, 'I'm the chef, we're doing really well, please come work for us,' and they leave a card."
Like combat survivors in a foxhole, some restaurant owners try not to get too close to their peers because poaching is now so much a part of the game. "At gatherings, I've done my best to avoid meeting owners of large restaurant operations socially," said Mr. O'Keefe, the owner of the River Cafe and the Water Club. "Because if I knew them it wouldn't be polite for me to approach any of their employees."
Mr. Meyer took recruitment to a new level last year in his newsletter mailed to loyal customers, inviting them to recruit waiters at other restaurants. It not only raised high dudgeon among his competitors but also engendered an item in The New Yorker.
In the early 1990's, some seasoned waiters decided to exit the trade after the dawn of taxation, when the ubiquity of credit-card gratuities prompted the Internal Revenue Service to force restaurants to keep stricter financial records. Now Manhattan's leading restaurants contend that most waiters' tips are fully declared.
The taxable transition hit the profession like a mango bombe. "It was like starting all over again and going into a new business," said Mr. Cozzolino at Le Cirque.
These days, the holy grail of the Manhattan waiter is to make $200 a day, or $1,000 a week, many of them say. But at Manhattan's four-star establishments waiters can earn as much as $75,000 or $80,000 a year before taxes if they're willing to work five "doubles": lunch and dinner shifts five days a week.
Other waiters have found even more lucrative niches. "I know room-service waiters at the Carlyle who make $90,000 or $100,000 a year for pushing a cart," Mr. Wong said. "I could never do that."
Furthermore, many waiters agree, the elite banquet waiters at the city's luxury hotels earn $150,000 a year and more because hefty gratuities are prepaid components of the banquet contracts.
Mr. Knapp, the restaurant analyst, said that the help-wanted crisis in New York restaurants will endure until the next downturn in the economy. Meanwhile, the current shortage makes it plain that "the city's restaurants should create a place to train waiters," said Harry Poulakakos, owner of Harry's at Hanover Square. "It should be more of a respected profession, as it is in Europe."
Furthermore, "I think perhaps customers should be taught how to deal with waiters," said Sirio Maccioni, owner of Le Cirque 2000. "Waiters do a difficult job, and they should be treated with more respect."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Factory-Built Units Are Planned for Rental Development in Central Harlem

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
The new owner of two vacant lots on separate blocks in central Harlem plans to put up rental buildings totaling 28 one- and two-bedroom market-rate apartments. But instead of being built with traditional techniques, they will be manufactured in a factory and assembled on the sites.
The owner, DW Development of Middle Village, Queens, plans to develop a five-story building on each of the sites, which have been vacant for more than 10 years. One, with 10 two-bedroom units, will be built at 111 West 113th Street between Lenox Avenue and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard; the other, with 18 one-bedroom apartments, will be at 2101 Eighth Avenue, between 113th and 114th Streets. Site work is to start in October and on-site assembly is to begin two months later. 
 Monthly rents will be $750 to $950 for the smaller units, with 600 square feet, and $950 to $1,200 for the larger ones, with 850 square feet, said Andrew Heiberger, president of Citi Habitats, a Manhattan rental brokerage that is the project's leasing agent.
The $1.5 million two-building project, to be completed by January, is the latest investment in a neighborhood that is experiencing a wave of residential development. While most of the housing is being developed with public financing, the two rental buildings will be built using private money.
"This reflects a growing trend," said Richard T. Roberts, the city's Commissioner of of Housing Preservation and Development. "Because of a significant amount of public investment and the strength of the market, there is increasing interest on the part of private investors to look for opportunities in northern Manhattan."
Along with other city and state agencies, the department is a sponsor of a number of programs that have helped spur the development of 11,000 new and renovated housing units since 1994 in central and East Harlem. They comprise mostly rental apartments as well as condominium and cooperative units and two- and three-family homes, mainly for families with low and moderate incomes. An additional 3,700 residences are planned, according to the department.
"There is intense potential in Harlem and we're building for the future," said Anthony DiRusso, president of DW Development. This project, the company's first in the neighborhood, "is an effort to create market-rate housing in an area where in the next few years such housing will be at a premium," said Mr. DiRusso, who owns rental and commercial properties in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan and has been involved as a contractor in the development of rental projects in Queens.
The company bought the lots for $150,000 at a bankruptcy auction in May and is in the process of securing bank financing, but, if necessary, will use its own money to start the project, Mr. DiRusso said.
Both lots, he noted, are just a few blocks from Renaissance Plaza, an 11-story, $60 million mixed-use building under way at the northeast corner of West 116th Street and Lenox Avenue. Financed mostly with public funds, it will contain 241 one- to three-bedroom limited-equity cooperative apartments, 60,000 square feet of ground-floor retail space and more than 200 parking spaces.
DW is developing its two sites with factory-built houses "because it's a way for us to produce a higher-quality apartment at a more economic rate," Mr. DiRusso said. Since the factory-built homes are produced under closer supervision than is the case with "stick built" housing, "the quality is there," he said, adding that because of greater operating efficiencies, the project's timetable will be reduced to three months from a year and its overall cost has been lowered by about 15 percent.
Mr. DiRusso said he would sign a contract next month with one of three manufacturers to produce the buildings, which will require no special permits because they will be built to meet state and city building codes for multistory housing.
Last year, 2,600 factory-built homes, also known as modulars, were assembled in New York State, about 10 percent of which were put up in New York City, said Fred Hallahan, a Baltimore-based consultant who works with the modular industry. That represents about 6.5 percent of the state's overall housing production, he said.
Though the early cracker-box design of assembly-line houses proved unappealing, Mr. Hallahan said, "modular manufacturers have taken great strides" in providing designs that are both functional and esthetic.
The central Harlem buildings will be faced with red brick and will have front stoops to blend with other neighborhood buildings. They will also have small rear yards and video-intercom security systems. Inside, all the apartments will have features like nearly 10-foot ceilings, hardwood floors and dishwashers as well as Internet and cable access.
Mr. Heiberger, the broker, said that although the rents were about 5 percent higher than those for existing apartments in the area, he expected the buildings to attract young middle-income singles and couples who would be willing to pay a little more for the amenities and a brand new unit. In addition, he said, the rents are still much lower than those for similar size units in comparable new buildings elsewhere in Manhattan, where monthly rents average $2,400 for one-bedroom apartments and $3,200 for two-bedroom units.
"The bottom line," he said, "is that the neighborhood is changing, and where else can you find new rentals in this price range?" Leasing is expected to begin in October.

HEADLINE: Police Recruiting Drive Lags Despite $10 Million Budget

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
With the New York City Police Department in the midst of its largest recruitment drive ever and one month left to apply, the number of people who have signed up so far is not on a pace to set any records.
As the Aug. 27 deadline looms, 5,657 people have applied since April to take the written exam on Oct. 2, which is the first step toward becoming a police officer, city officials said. Although the number of applicants to join the force has slipped in recent years, past tests have routinely drawn more than 20,000 people. 
 But police officials said yesterday that they were not concerned about the numbers and that most people do not file to take the test until they are right up against the deadline.
"Historically, the last two weeks of our recruiting efforts is when we get half or more of our candidates applying," Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday, before unfurling a 12-story-high recruiting banner over the side of Police Headquarters. "We're doing O.K."
The department announced the $10 million recruiting drive to attract more city residents to the force after the killing of Amadou Diallo, an unarmed African immigrant, by four white police officers. The shooting in February has prompted criticism that the police force is not representative of the city's population.
It is not the first time the department has had trouble attracting applicants. A test administered last fall drew only 14,202 applicants, down from 21,567 the previous winter, said Robert Giacopetti, a spokesman for the Department of Citywide Administrative Services. The test before that, in 1996, drew 31,986 applicants, he said.
Experts gave a variety of reasons for the recent low turnouts.
Chuck Wexler, the executive director of the Police Executive Research Forum, a nonprofit group in Washington, said that urban police departments around the nation have had trouble recruiting because of the strong economy, which has led people to other careers. He also said that Federal financing has already led to the hiring of 100,000 police officers nationwide in the last six years, depleting the number of potential candidates for police work.
"New York is not alone in this respect," he said.
Others note that the New York Police Department, despite its success in driving the crime rate to historic lows, has had to deal with a number of highly charged cases that have frayed relations between the force and the public it serves, from the choking death of Anthony Baez to the torture of Abner Louima to the Diallo case.
Michael Meyers, the executive director of the New York Civil Rights Coalition, said he believed that the department was simply a hard sell right now. "You could not have a worse time for marketing and recruitment," he said. "Morale could not be lower, race relations are the worst level one can think of -- it's going to be a heck of a time recruiting minorities -- and the job does not pay well."
The entry-level salary is $34,970 a year.
Thomas Scotto, the president of the Detectives' Endowment Association, said that the campaign may be suffering because police officers, who are often the best recruiters, are feeling underappreciated.
"It is my belief that the primary source of recruiting are the police officers themselves," he said. "They encourage neighbors, their children, family members and friends to join, who convince them that the Police Department is a great place to work. But with the morale of the Police Department so low, the police themselves that would normally tell people to sign up for the exam are now telling them just the opposite."
In the next month, the department plans to hold five recruiting parties in city parks in conjunction with the radio station Hot 97 (WQHT FM).

HEADLINE: Snacking Today: Any Time and Anywhere

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 29

 BODY:
On a Sunday morning at a Roman Catholic church here, Mary Hallan Fiorito glanced at a nearby pew to see a woman drinking a can of Coke at Mass.
At a musical in a Broadway theater, Alex Wang turned to the row behind him to discover people eating corn on the cob. 
In schools that once forbade chewing gum, students now bring doughnuts and candy to class -- along with chewing gum.
Americans seem to be eating all the time, and wherever they please.
"Consumers now see eating as something to be done while you do something else," said Bobby Calder, a marketing professor at Northwestern University. "Everybody wants to save time by multi-tasking. So you don't just sit down and eat. You eat while you work, while you're watching TV, while you drive."
The automobile, among the favorite places for people to snack, is well on its way to becoming a rolling dining room. A car is scarcely considered worth driving now without cup holders in the front and back. Some cars now have refrigerated glove-boxes. And within the next six months, the Samsung Corporation plans to market the first microwave for cars and mini-vans. The microwave will plug into the cigarette lighter.
Only 24 percent of Americans eat breakfast, lunch and dinner and nothing else, according to a 1996 survey by Roper Starch Worldwide, a marketing research concern in Manhattan, down from 33 percent in 1985.
Polls indicate that a majority of families still eat dinner together, or at least say they do. But a walk through any convenience store or grocery store shows that "portable foods" have been taking up a lot more room on the shelves.
"I get nervous if I don't have something to munch on," said Paul Johnson, a 34-year-old computer programmer in Chicago, as he left a convenience store with a bag of fat-free chips and a very large cup of a frosty drink. "I guess some people are like that with smoking."
Health experts say the increased snacking is partly to blame for the rising rates of obese and overweight people. Fifty-two percent of Americans are now overweight, the highest rate ever, according to the National Institute for Health.
"Eating has become a recreational activity," said Linda Van Horn, a nutritionist in Chicago. "And it's one of the biggest reasons for the epidemic of obsesity in this country."
Ms. Van Horn said people were clearly snacking for reasons that went beyond hunger.
"It's a comfort thing," she said, "like having your baby blanket with you."
To be sure, Americans did not just recently pick up the habit of eating outside the home. As far back as a generation ago, the New Yorker cartoonist Saul Steinberg was skewering the growing tendency of people to dine on the dash.
In the last few years, people in the food business say, snacks have become a main course. And stores like 7-Eleven are increasing the number of products that can be eaten with one hand, like sealed tacos and stuffed breadsticks.
Todd Hultquist, a spokesman for the Food Marketing Institute, a trade group in Washington, said the two-income family and busy lives of children had changed eating habits for good.
"We're simply not going back to the days of spending two hours in the kitchen every night preparing a meal," Mr. Hultquist said.
Fast-food restaurants, which report that 50 percent of their sales are now at the drive-by window. McDonalds is testing in some markets the McSalad Shaker, which comes in a plastic container that fits in a car cup-holder. It is designed so that the customer can pour in the dressing, fasten the top and shake it up, then eat it with a long fork.
In the view of Michael Batterberry, the editor of Food Arts magazine, the flowering of the eat-where-we-may style, was nourished by mineral water.
"This whole thing reached a kind of virus with the carrying of water bottles by the yuppies in the 80's," Mr. Batterberry said.
When people started walking around offices with their water bottles, he said, a line had been crossed. And there seems to be no turning back.
In some offices, desks and cubicles look almost like food pantries -- chips, nuts, rice cakes, fruit -- all placed within easy reach of the telephone and the computer keyboard. Food has become requisite at almost any staff meeting. This practice of all-day grazing, meanwhile, has largely replaced the old-fashioned business lunch, for which workers actually leave the office.
Libraries, which once stood at the vanguard of etiquette, shooshing talkers and scowling at nibblers, have in many places given up the fight. They have taken a page from the big booksellers and started selling coffee near the stacks.
Some movie theaters now sell turkey breast sandwiches, even smoked salmon, along with popcorn.
The success of the big chain bookstores, Borders and Barnes & Noble, where designer coffee and snacks was seen as a big boost to their businesses, has not gone unnoticed in other types of business. The furniture store Ikea has a cafeteria, and Crate and Barrel sells coffee.
It has become rare for a group of people to gather, even for a short time, without some snacking. At almost every youth soccer or baseball game, one player's parents are assigned to bring treats for the team, generally candy, chips and soda. Some teams wait until after the game for the treats, but others have half-time treats, too. As if that is not enough, some parents send their children to the games equipped with soda and chips.
To Ms. Hallen Fiorito, who spotted the Coke-drinking woman at church, the constant eating is a sign that people cannot deny themselves, even for a short time. "You'd think you could get through 45 minutes, wouldn't you?" she said.
Ms. Fiorito, the vice chancellor for the Archdiocese of Chicago, said it had also become common for people to take little bags of cereal to church for their youngsters. And then they leave the bags in the pews.
"When you're trying to reach a state of spiritual contemplation," she said, "there is nothing like sitting on a bag of Cheerios to throw you off."
Ms. Van Horn, the nutritionist who is also the mother of a soccer player, was alarmed by what she considered an excess of treats for young ball players. She said that children who are obese in the second and third grade have a difficult time ever slimming down.
"The only thing playing children need is fluid replacement," Ms. Van Horn said. "That's water."
At her suggestion, the treats for her child's soccer games were changed to fruits from candy and chips.
Not all of the players were happy.
"I'm sure at first they're thinking, 'Oh, no, here comes the nutritionist,' " Ms. Van Horn said. "They thought I was raining on their parade."

HEADLINE: Evolving Answers to the Why of Suicide;
Is It a Medical Problem? A Moral or Social Failure? An Assertion of Freedom?

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
"There is but one truly serious philosophical problem," Albert Camus said, "and that is suicide. Judging whether life is or is not worth living amounts to answering the fundamental question of philosophy."
Suicide has become more than a philosophical question, however. This week, Dr. David Satcher, the United States Surgeon General, declared it a serious public health threat, with the number of reported suicides among children doubling over the last 20 years. In Japan, meanwhile, statistics show a record increase in suicide as that country copes with economic recession. 
 But some social scientists believe that the apparent rise, at least in the United States, is a result of increased reporting as the stigma of suicide diminishes. "We now have an increase because we see depression and suicide as the result of a chemical imbalance," said Howard I. Kushner, a professor at San Diego State University, the author of "Self Destruction in the Promised Land," (Rutgers University Press, 1989), a history of suicide in America. "It's legitimized because it's biological."
Social attitudes determine how suicide is reported, Mr. Kushner said, adding, "One reason we hear about it in Japan is that it is sanctioned." He was referring to the tradition of hara kiri, for instance, or honorable suicide when a person is shamed or has failed in his responsibility to others. Social attitudes can also decide what is considered suicide, he said: "Risking your life jumping into a pond can be seen as suicide or as an act of courage."
Whether there is an actual increase in suicide or better reporting of it, views of suicide are a reflection of moral belief, medical theory and cultural forces, and they are constantly evolving.
Suicide remains to some extent taboo, Mr. Kushner said, as a violation of natural law and a mark of shame for the families of those who take their own lives. "When people die of suicide, our reaction is to feel anger, grief, responsibility," said Mr. Kushner. "Suicides are seen as judgments on the people left behind."
Such attitudes stand in the way of treating serious depression, said Kay Redfield Jamison, a professor of psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine and author of the forthcoming "Night Falls Fast: Understanding Suicide." "In the United States, we regard it as a highly individual act. We tend not to see it as a cause of mortality, as we do cancer or heart disease. We see it less as an illness than as a consequence of social and relationship issues."
In his "History of Suicide," the French scholar Georges Minois traces the way attitudes toward suicide have evolved from the classical period into the modern era. Suicide seems deeply threatening at least partly because it is an assertion of individual freedom against the power of the state, Mr. Minois writes: "It is an affront to all political and religious systems."
"Anyone who chooses death and its unknowns displays a total lack of confidence in the theories, ideologies, beliefs, plans and promises of all leaders," he continues. As a consequence, "Whatever its nature, power seeks to prevent and conceal suicide."
There has always been a double standard in perceptions of suicide, Mr. Minois says. In ancient Rome, there was the cult of "the noble suicide," embodied in the deaths of Brutus, Cato, Antony and Cleopatra. But suicide was outlawed for slaves and foot soldiers, "because a slave belongs to the owner and he doesn't own his life," Mr. Minois, 53, explained in a telephone interview from his home in Brittany. Slaves in ancient Greece were also prohibited from killing themselves because they were essential for agriculture and for the maintenance of the society, Mr. Minois said.
The early Christians strengthened strictures against suicide. There was the notion that "God gave us life," Mr. Minois said, and "man hasn't got any right to take his own life." But the Old Testament never specifically prohibits suicide, Mr. Minois noted, only murder. In fact, the Old Testament is littered with the dead bodies of heroes who took their own lives -- Samson, for one, who brought the palace of the Philistines down on his head as well as theirs.
It was St. Augustine who once and for all solidified the Church's prohibition against suicide. The estates of those who killed themselves were confiscated, and a stake was driven through their bodies to keep them from rising up and haunting others with their unquiet spirits. Their bodies were buried at crossroads under rocks.
Mr. Minois said religion was not the only reason for the prohibition. The Roman Empire was expanding into a totalitarian system, and outlying regions were being colonized. The Christian church's own land holdings had also increased. "An acute shortage of manpower dictated the requisitioning of all human lives for the service of the economy and the defense of the empire," he writes.
Although disapproval of suicide was generally harsh during the medieval period, suicide for "noble" purposes was sometimes glorified, for example, in the case of knights who died in battle rather than surrender, or of the Christian martyrs.
With the Renaissance came a shift in attitudes. "It was a time of great changes in values with the wars of religion," Mr. Minois explained, "the discovery of the New World, changes in economics, capitalism." At the same time, he said, "the medieval types of family solidarity were becoming looser and looser, leaving the individual more and more alone."
The question of suicide was widely discussed in the public realm. At the turn of the 17th century, Hamlet asked what was essentially the first modern question: "To be or not to be?" Self-destruction occurs no less than 52 times in Shakespeare, Mr. Minois says.
It is significant, he observes, that the word "suicide" does not appear in English until the 1650's. The creation of a new word marked the final separation of suicide from homicide, he says.
The Reformation and the Enlightenment brought another shift. Religion itself was being re-examined. For the Deists, God was not a vengeful figure, and Deism reduced the fear of hell, making death seem less fearsome.
The British historian and philosopher David Hume even wrote a pamphlet defending the right to suicide, but at the last moment decided not to publish it. Still, for the Puritans, suicide was the work of Satan.
In the 1700's, suicide came to be known as "The English Malady," after a popular 1733 treatise by George Cheyne. England was thought to have a particularly large number of cases because of the bad climate and rich food. But Mr. Minois argues that the perception of an increase was probably a result of the expansion of the popular press and the frequent mention of the topic.
The death of the poet Thomas Chatterton in 1770 made suicide fashionable. And with the success of Goethe's "Sorrows of Young Werther," in 1774, the story of a young man who kills himself because of his unrequited love for a married woman, the notion of Romantic suicide was born. "The figure of Werther arrived on the scene just as the question of the legitimacy of voluntary death reached an emotional high point,' Mr. Minois writes.
Increasingly, in Europe, suicide was attributed to insanity, resulting in fewer draconian punishments for those who attempt it or for the families of those who succeed. The leaders of the French Revolution condemned suicide because they saw the individual's body as the property of the state. Nonetheless, sanctions against suicide disappeared from the penal code after the Revolution in 1791. In other European countries, however, criminalization of suicide continued into the mid-1950's.
In 1897, Emile Durkheim tried to find sociological causes for suicide. People are more inclined to commit suicide when they are not part of a strong social fabric, Durkheim wrote. At the same time, Freud put forward a psychoanalytic explanation of aggression turned inward.
In his book on suicide in America, Howard Kushner describes the way it was transformed from a moral problem into a medical one. This coincided with the rise of medicine as a profession, he writes, and the substitution of the notion of mental illness for immoral behavior. Mr. Kushner argued that doctors, in an effort to increase their power and influence, claimed suicide as a medical problem and had an investment in saying it was treatable.
But Dr. Arthur Kleinman, a professor of psychiatry and medical anthropology at the Harvard Medical School, believes that seeing depression -- and suicide -- as a medical problem alone strips suffering of its moral and emotional importance. He cites as an example the depression suffered by terminally ill people. In the past, that depression was accorded a moral and religious purpose, as the terminally ill looked back on their lives, sometimes with regret and apology to their loved ones for their shortcomings and failures. It is an end-of-life "conversation," Dr. Kleinman said, that has a healing effect and brings closure. But today, said Dr. Kleinman, "somehow they are ill with clinical depression."
"I think we should be careful before we label them depressed," he continued. With the medicalization of suffering, said Dr. Kleinman, it is all too often simply "easier to give anti-depressants and walk away." " Often the most important thing," he said, "is not the anti-depressants, but that people can participate in the moral and religious conversations of suffering at the end of life."

HEADLINE: June's Rise in Personal Income Beat Rise in Personal Outgo

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 30

 BODY:
Personal income galloped ahead in June, outpacing the rise in spending for the first time since January, the Government said today. In a separate report, it said that new home sales, meanwhile, rose 3.1 percent as buyers rushed to beat slowly rising mortgage rates.
Both reports, economists said, were outgrowths of a healthy economy, a low unemployment rate, a strong stock market and benign inflation. 
 Neither report was expected to raise eyebrows at the Federal Reserve Board, which nudged up interest rates on June 30 in a pre-emptive strike against inflation.
The Commerce Department said personal income, which includes wages, interest and government benefits, rose seven-tenths of a percent, faster than expected. It was the biggest income gain since a nine-tenths of a percent rise in November.
The income growth in June reflected gains in wages and salary as well as from interest and dividends. A surge in farm income, stemming from Federal subsidy payments to farmers, increased overall income growth. Still, excluding these payments, income would have gone up half a percent, economists said.
At the same time, Americans tempered their spending somewhat. Spending went up just three-tenths of a percent in June, a little less than many analysts had expected. That too was the smallest increase since November, when spending rose one-tenth of a percent.
By contrast, in May, income rose three-tenths of a percent, while spending went up six-tenths of a percent.
"Consumers are still in a buying mood but not as aggressive," said Gary Thayer, chief economist with A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc.
Economists attributed the moderation in spending to a number of factors, including a recent rise in interest rates and a decline in mortgage refinancing. People who refinance homes end up with extra money, which leads to higher spending, they said.
Because consumer spending has outpaced incomes repeatedly, the savings rate -- saving as a percentage of after-tax income -- has set a string of record lows this year.
In June, the savings rate was minus 1 percent, better than the record low of negative 1.4 percent set in May.
In its housing report, the Commerce Department said sales of new single-family homes rose in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 929,000 units, better than forecast. In May, new-home sales fell 4.1 percent, to 901,000 units, not so bad as previously estimated.
"Despite rising interest rates, home sales have remained strong because home buyers are rushing to lock in current interest rates in the fear that rates might climb higher," said Karen Dexter, a Merrill Lynch economist.
The average interest rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage this week was 7.70 percent, up from 7.52 percent last week.
The increase in sales pushed prices up, too. The median price for a new home in June -- meaning that half of all homes sold for less and half for more -- rose 4.7 percent, to $157,000, up from a median price of $149,900 in May but still below the record median of $159,900 set in February.
Spending on nondurable products, like food and fuel, increased four-tenths of a percent in June, less than the increase of half a percent in May.
But spending on durable goods, which are big-ticket manufactured items expected to last at least three years, like washing machines and cars, was flat in June, after a sharp gain of 2.2 percent in May.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled By Jeanne Moore 

 BODY:

MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: U.S. ROLE CHARGED IN UNREST -- Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, blamed the "hidden hands" of the United States for pro-democracy protests this month, saying Washington had tried to repeat the 1953 coup that restored the monarchy. Speaking before worshipers at Friday Prayers, he also dismissed talk of serious differences in the leadership, which is widely seen as divided into conservatives who surround him and reformers grouped around President Mohammad Khatami. (Reuters)
 
IRAQ: MORE BOMBING DEATHS REPORTED -- Nine Iraqis were killed and 23 injured in air raids by American and British warplanes in northern and southern Iraq, an Iraqi military spokesman said. United States military officials said American planes patrolling the northern no-flight zone bombed antiaircraft installations after coming under fire. (Reuters) 

THE AMERICAS
 
ARGENTINA: FAILED BID FOR NATO -- Argentina has formally requested to become the first Latin American nation to become a member of the NATO military alliance. But Secretary General Javier Solana rejected the request in a letter to President Carlos Saul Menem, saying the current expansion was intended only to integrate former members of the Warsaw Pact in the Western alliance. Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
PANAMA: U.S. ARMY OFFICE MOVES OUT -- The United States Army withdrew its regional headquarters from Panama, leaving only a few hundred American soldiers until the Panama Canal is handed over at year's end. The United States Southern Command, the administrative head for all branches of the American military in the region, left Panama in 1997. The Army headquarters moves now to Puerto Rico. (AP)
 
CHILE: RISK SEEN TO PINOCHET -- Two doctors reported that Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former dictator, who is under house arrest in London, is suffering from stress that is so severe it is worsening his diabetes and slowing his recovery from back surgery. The examination by the Chilean and British doctors was commissioned by the Chilean Government, which hopes to stop a extradition request by a Spanish judge to try the retired General on charges of crimes against humanity. Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
EUROPE
 
IRELAND: GUN-RUNNING PLOT SUSPECTED -- The police said a Roman Catholic guerrilla group, possibly the Irish Republican Army, was involved in an effort to smuggle 32 handguns into Northern Ireland from the United States. Two of three people detained by the Irish police this week remain in custody, including an American. Meanwhile, three people have been charged in Florida with attempting to bring firearms to Ireland. James F. Clarity (NYT)
 
SWITZERLAND: GUIDES INVESTIGATED -- Prosecutors have begun an inquiry into whether four guides who survived this week's "canyoning" disaster, in which at least 19 people died in a river near Interlaken, were guilty of criminal negligence. Two of the dead were guides. Another two people are still missing and feared dead. (Reuters)
 
AFRICA
 
IVORY COAST: PRESIDENTIAL CONTENDER -- Alassane Ouattara, a deputy managing director at the International Monetary Fund, arrived on Thursday from Washington to pursue a bid for the presidency in next year's elections. Since he had announced his plans to resign from the I.M.F., the return of Mr. Ouattara, a former prime minister here, had long been anticipated by the Government, which is contesting his eligibility to run as a presidential candidate. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)
 
ALGERIA: FRANCE TO REOPEN CONSULATES -- In a sign of renewed dialogue, the Presidents of France and Algeria, a former colony, exchanged invitations for talks, and France said it would reopen cultural centers and two consulates that were closed in 1994 for security reasons. A meeting of the two leaders would mean a fresh start for relations between the two countries, which have languished since the start of an Islamic insurgency here in 1992. (AP)
 
SOUTH AFRICA: STRIKE ENDS, FOR NOW -- Public sector workers ended a huge two-day walkout, vowing to mount a bigger and broader strike against President Thabo Mbeki's new Government if their demand for a 10 percent pay increase is not met. Reacting to the first major public sector strike since apartheid, the Government warned that essential service staff who strike will face disciplinary action. (Reuters)
 
ASIA
 
INDONESIA: MASSACRE CHARGE -- Human rights groups said the bodies of 51 villagers in the province of Aceh had been found in two mass graves and they blamed the military for what they said was a massacre of civilians. A military spokesman denied the accusation and said the only deaths were 31 rebels killed in a raid one week ago. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
MONGOLIA: A NEW PRIME MINISTER -- Parliament overwhelmingly approved the appointment of Renchinnyamiin Amarjargal, 38, a Moscow-educated economist, as the new Prime Minister. The vote followed last week's resignation of Janlaviin Narantsatsaralt and his Government, which lost a parliamentary vote of confidence, the third Government to collapse in 15 months. (AP)
 
CAMBODIA: REQUEST FOR U.S. AID -- Prince Noro dom Ranariddh, president of the National Assembly, asked the United States to resume direct aid to the Government because "the democratic process has positively developed in the country." International aid was slashed two years ago when Prince Ranariddh, left, was ousted in a coup by his co-Prime Minister, Hun Sen. The Prince then disputed the results of an election last year in which he was defeated as a candidate for Prime Minister by Mr. Hun Sen. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
INDONESIA: THE SKIES DARKEN -- Forest fires are burning again on Sumatra and Kalimantan and the smoke is again drifting across Singapore and Malaysia. The pungent haze dims the sun but has not reached the choking levels that caused disruptions and deaths in 1997. Seth Mydans (NYT)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Blue Chips and Leading Indexes Hurt by Economic Data

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks and bonds slid yesterday and the dollar remained depressed, as more evidence of inflation pressures convinced investors the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates soon.
Falling stock and bond prices helped push the dollar down against both the Japanese yen and Europe's single currency, the euro. The dollar recovered from session lows to finish slightly higher against the euro after Thursday's selloff, but ended the week about 2 percent lower against both currencies. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average ended down 136.14 points, or 1.26 percent, at 10,655.15, after losing 180.78 points Thursday. For the week, the blue-chip index was down 255.81 points after sliding nearly 300 points in the previous week.
In the broader market, advancing issues led declines 1,533 to 1,356 on moderate volume of 736.8 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 1.52 points, to 2,638.49.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 12.31 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 1,328.72.
Evidence of potential inflation showed up when the Chicago Purchasing Management Index, also known as the Chicagoland Business Barometer, showed manufacturing activity and prices paid by manufacturers rose at a higher-than-expected rate in July.
The regional report followed Thursday's news that United States wage costs had jumped at the fastest pace since 1991 in the second quarter, which increased worries that the Fed might be ready to raise interest rates again to fight inflation.
The Chicago Purchasing Management Index rose to 60.5 in July from 60.0 in June, beating expectations for an overall reading of 58.8. The closely watched Prices Paid Index rose to 59.8 in July from 57.2 in June.
"It's troubling -- more troubling inflation news we didn't need," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.
"That report will not quiet any fears about inflation that were started with the remarks from Greenspan and the Employment Cost Index report," he said, referring to Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.
The focus on Monday will be on the National Association of Purchasing Management's survey for July, which will show whether the rise in manufacturing prices in the Chicago data was a nationwide problem.
Bank and brokerage stocks were particularly hurt by the news. Among Dow components, American Express fell 6 13/16, to 131 3/4; J. P. Morgan lost 2 3/4, to 127 7/8, and Citigroup was down 1 3/16, to 44 9/16.
However, Procter & Gamble continued a rally from Thursday's session, climbing 2 7/16, to 90 9/16, after its earnings beat Wall Street's expectations.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Fall Again, Pressed by Economic Reports

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday, rounding out the sixth consecutive losing month for Treasuries.
The decline was spurred by reports on housing, manufacturing and personal income that added to concern the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates soon. 
 "It's more fuel to the fire," said Graham Allen, who handles $50 billion as chief fixed-income officer at Wells Capital Management in Los Angeles. Mr. Allen, who's been buying corporate bonds for their bigger yields, sees 30-year yields as high as 6.40 percent in the weeks ahead.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 13/32, to 88 14/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.10 percent from 6.07 percent on Thursday.
Bonds fell after a report by the National Association of Purchasing Management's Chicago branch showed manufacturing activity in the Chicago area accelerated at a faster-than-expected pace in July. Separate reports for June showed new home sales rose more than expected while personal income, one of the economy's driving forces, rose at the fastest pace in seven months.
Taken together, they point to resilience in the economy, now in its ninth year of expansion, that might prompt the Fed to take action. That could also result in further losses in the already battered bond market, investors said.
"Bond yields have more room to rise," said Don Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, who predicts 30-year yields will reach 6.25 percent in the months ahead. "The economy is showing scant signs of slowing. Inflation is clearly moving up. The Fed's going to have to react to that."
Bonds slumped Thursday after a bigger-than-expected increase in second-quarter employment costs fanned speculation that the Fed may increase interest rates as soon as Aug. 24, when policy makers next meet, to keep growth from spurring inflation. The central bank already raised its target for overnight lending between banks by a quarter point to 5 percent on June 30.

HEADLINE: Gore Proposes Tax Breaks For Aiding the Middle Class

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, July 30

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore today proposed a long list of tax breaks to address specific goals like making health care and education more affordable.
The proposals, which Mr. Gore said would be a central part of his campaign for the Presidency, are much more modest than the large tax reductions favored by most Republicans and philosophically at odds with the tax policies of Bill Bradley, his rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination. 
 "You'd better believe America's middle class deserves a tax break," Mr. Gore said in a speech at the Minnesota Community Technical College.
Mr. Gore said Republican tax plans like the one approved by the Senate today and the one passed by the House last week offered "too much for too few at the expense of too many."
Mr. Gore's list -- "carefully targeted," he said, "to the hard-working middle class" -- would allow new tax deductions or credits for education and retirement savings, medical expenses, nursing-home costs, corporate research and development, child care, low-income housing, energy conservation, school construction and investments in poor neighborhoods.
Mr. Bradley, the former Senator from New Jersey, did not respond to the Gore speech. His staff said he was not running a campaign geared to reacting to the Vice President. And Mr. Bradley has not delivered a campaign address detailing his own tax policies.
But Mr. Bradley's philosophy is well known. He was a central figure in putting together the Tax Reform Act of 1986, the most comprehensive tax law in the last half of the 20th century. He is adamantly opposed to narrow tax breaks like those offered by Mr. Gore, arguing instead that most, if not all, tax credits and deductions should be abolished and that the money saved should be used to make tax rates as low as possible.
Then, Mr. Bradley holds, if the Government wants to promote a particular social goal like education, it should spend the money directly. Doing it through the tax code, he believes, is wasteful.
Many tax breaks on Mr. Gore's list, like those for school construction and child care, have been part of the Clinton Administration's budget and have generated little interest in the Republican-controlled Congress.
But Mr. Gore offered two new proposals today that are not part of the Clinton package. One would be tax-free savings accounts to allow workers to put aside money for education. The other would be an increase in the standard deduction for married couples who do not itemize deductions, so the couple's deduction would be the same as if the two were single and filed separate tax returns, eliminating the so-called marriage penalty in the current law.
Students, parents and grandparents could have up to $2,500 withheld from their pay and placed in the accounts. Employers would be allowed to match the contributions. And taxpayers with incomes below $40,000 would get an additional tax credit offsetting half the money they placed in their accounts. The money could be withdrawn tax-free to meet education expenses.
Mr. Gore's speech today was the latest of several in which he has set forth detailed positions on issues, including education, crime, cancer research and aid to religious institutions to help combat social problems.
On taxes, Mr. Gore has a fundamental philosophical difference with Republicans that echoes through the running budget conflict between the Clinton Administration and Congress.
The Republicans want to keep taxes low with the explicit goal of reducing the size of the Government. The Administration favors using much of the budget surplus to maintain and even expand programs. Mr. Gore described the difference this way:
"Proponents of the Republican tax scheme will tell us: 'It's your money, and you should have it back. It is our money. But it is also our Social Security. It is our Medicare. It is our good jobs and our stable economy."
Mr. Gore's philosophical difference with Mr. Bradley is more sophisticated.
The Vice President, his staff says, believes that the Government will never provide the money directly to reach important social policy goals and that the way to accomplish them is through targeted tax breaks.
Mr. Bradley views that as an inefficient approach. People and companies would adjust their finances to achieve tax savings, and much of the cost to the Government would go to taxpayers who are not necessarily the ones the Government is trying to help.
Almost all politicians, whatever their party or ideology, agree with the Gore approach, though they disagree over what the specific tax breaks should be. Almost all academic experts on tax policy agree with the Bradley approach of the fewest possible deductions and exemptions and the lowest possible tax rates.

HEADLINE: World Leaders Join in Pledging Effort to Rebuild Balkans

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, July 30

 BODY:
Next to a graveyard of Bosnia's war dead, 39 world leaders, including President Clinton, met here today to inaugurate an effort to rebuild southeastern Europe and its economy from the ravages of a decade of war.
The sole leader to pledge specific aid today, Mr. Clinton announced a package of $700 million in aid, trade programs and business incentives to generate investment in the Balkans. 
 That package is in addition to $500 million in relief assistance earmarked specifically for Kosovo that the United States pledged on Wednesday in Brussels.
The aid to the region is intended to address long- and short-term problems. In the short term, the $500 million pledged by the United States, as well as funds from other countries, will go to rebuild Kosovo and repair the bombing damage, and compensate neighboring countries that housed refugees or suffered economic harm.
More broadly, the leaders gathered here are seeking to avert future conflicts in the Balkans through longer-term economic reconstruction.
The eventual scope of the international effort, which began with the American contribution of $700 million, is not clear.
"It is not enough to end a war," Mr. Clinton told students at a school in Sarajevo. "We must build the peace."
Having chosen this re-emerging but still shell-pocked city as a hopeful symbol, Mr. Clinton and other leaders agreed to a "stability pact" to rebuild and develop the region at a one-day summit meeting of heads of state from the Balkans and industrialized countries.
The horrors visited upon this city and the region have to be "consigned to history," Martti Ahtisaari, the President of Finland, said as he opened the conference. Finland also holds the rotating presidency of the European Union.
"It is high time for the region to make up for lost time," said Mr. Ahtisaari, who helped negotiate the peace in Kosovo. "The stability pact envisions a Europe at long last undivided, prosperous and free, a Europe where war becomes unthinkable."
The main goal of the meeting was for the nations to promote peace and economic help for the region.
But they also pointedly wanted to try to isolate President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, who was not invited, as they met in the shiny copper-roofed Olympic stadium, which was rebuilt after Serbs had shelled it in the Bosnia war. The leaders said that as long as Mr. Milosevic remained in power, they would not contribute to rebuild Serbia.
"I do not believe," Mr. Clinton said, "that we should give reconstruction aid to Serbia as long as it rejects democracy and as long as Mr. Milosevic is in power. We have had enough of 'ethnic cleansing.' "
Prime Minister Sergei V. Stepashin of Russia repeated objections that he had raised this week over the decision by Mr. Clinton and European leaders to deny aid to the Serbian people because of Mr. Milosevic. Mr. Stepashin reminded the conference that a failure to provide aid could lead to "very complicated and unpredictable" consequences for the 10 million people in Yugoslavia as winter approaches. He predicted a human catastrophe if the Serbs did not receive aid.
Despite his criticisms, he signed the pact because he did not want to ruin the conference, Russian officials said.
"We do not have any serious apprehensions about this pact," Mr. Stepashin said.
The $500 million in Kosovo aid pledged by the United States was in part offered to head off such criticism.
"We do not want to see the Serb people freeze or suffer during the coming winter," said Barry Toiv, a spokesman for President Clinton. But Mr. Toiv said the United States and its allies would "work through" the distinction between relief aid and reconstruction assistance, saying they would provide the relief aid but not the reconstruction help.
Still, the United States pledged $10 million to "promote democracy" in Serbia. The money will go to the democratic opposition to Mr. Milosevic and to encircle Serbia with a ring of transmitters for the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe to counter Mr. Milosevic's state-run propaganda machine.
There was no price tag on the total amount that the 39 countries and several international institutions like the World Bank would spend on rebuilding southeastern Europe. The United States has estimated that its cost for the bombing ran from $3 billion to $6 billion.
The costs to the surrounding countries have been considerable, as trade was disrupted and as they absorbed thousands of refugees. The International Monetary Fund estimated this summer that helping Montenegro and Kosovo, both part of Yugoslavia, and Albania, Macedonia, Romania and Bulgaria could reach $1.25 billion to $2.25 billion a year for several years.
In a meeting on Wednesday in Brussels, the European Commission and the World Bank said that pledges of up to $2 billion had been made toward rebuilding Kosovo. Some commission members questioned the figure, saying some of the money had already been collected and disbursed.
Estimates of the rebuilding cost have varied widely, but have been somewhat reduced by the lessening of assessments of damage there.
Among the aid items in Brussels were $200 million for immediate needs identified by the United Nations, $45 million to cover Kosovo's budget deficit and $318 million for reconstruction, based on initial estimates by the European Union.
Among Mr. Clinton's pledges announced today are business and trade initiatives, including a plan to have the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a United States agency, establish a $150 million investment fund for the Balkans and provide an additional $200 million in credit for American companies that seek to establish operations in the region.
To promote trade, Mr. Clinton announced a program that would grant duty-free status to some exports to the United States. The United States also plans to contribute up to $50 million to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to encourage business ventures, provided that the bank focuses an additional $80 million on the region.
He also said he would ask Congress to reduce the tariffs for exports like shoes to American markets. The cost of the lower revenue over five years is estimated from $50 million to $80 million.
Congress has already approved the $500 million in relief aid to Kosovo, and its approval is needed only for the duty-free part of the package.
Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, told reporters that America had a direct interest in the reconstruction.
"Helping the region is strongly in our national interest," he said, "by reducing the risk that our troops will have to fight another, far costlier European conflict down the road and helping to make the whole of Europe a stronger partner for advancing our security, our prosperity and our values."
Mr. Clinton and other leaders, like Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany, did not address the main meeting, leaving the limelight to the nations of the region to underscore the idea that reconstruction is something the Balkan leaders seek, not something imposed by richer countries.
But in remarks afterward, Mr. Clinton acknowledged problems with the reconstruction in Sarajevo. "The Dayton agreement in 1995 did not rid Bosnia of all anger and fear or frustrating problems like high unemployment, corruption and crime," he said. "But Dayton did offer all the people of Bosnia peaceful means to resolve their differences and move forward."
Now, he said, Sarajevo can boast "fair elections, a free press, reformed courts, a new single currency, the beginning of economic growth, better ties with your neighbors, war criminals out of power."
He said that refugees were still returning and that he found at the meeting today that the three leaders of Bosnia were speaking "with one single, united voice."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Senate Votes to Cut Taxes By $792 Billion in 10 Years
The Senate voted to cut taxes by $792 billion over the next 10 years, moving the Republican-controlled Congress toward a showdown with President Clinton over how the nation can best use trillions of dollars in projected Federal budget surpluses. The vote was 57 to 43. Four Democrats joined 53 Republicans in support of the bill, while 2 Republicans and 41 Democrats voted against it.
The bill would cut personal income taxes by reducing the lowest tax rate starting in 2001. It would give a tax break to many married couples, expand the Individual Retirement Account program, create a deduction for some health insurance costs and reduce the inheritance tax on large estates. Page A1. 

Dow Jones Average Falls 136 Points
Stocks declined as more evidence of inflation pressures convinced investors the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates soon. The Dow Jones industrial average ended down 136.14 points, or 1.26 percent, to 10,655.15, after sliding 180.78 points Thursday. For the week, the blue-chip index was down 255.81 points. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 1.52 points, to 2,638.49, and the Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks declined 12.31 points, to 1,328.72. C3.
 
Treasury bond prices dropped, rounding out the sixth consecutive losing month for Treasuries. The decline was spurred by reports on housing, manufacturing and personal income that added to concern the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates soon. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.10 percent from 6.07 percent on Thursday. C3.
 
 
Personal Income Increased in June
Personal income, which includes wages, interest and government benefits, rose seven-tenths of a percent, faster than expected, in June. It marked the first time since January that personal income outpaced the rise in spending. In a separate report, the Government said that new home sales jumped 3.1 percent as buyers rushed to beat rising mortgage rates. Sales of new single-family homes rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 929,000 units, better than forecast. C2.
 
Philadelphia Exchange Reappoints
The Philadelphia Stock Exchange reappointed Meyer Frucher, its chairman, for two years, despite some opposition from the exchange's largest seatholder. C3.
 
Argentina and Brazil End Dispute
Argentina has retreated from a threat to impose punitive tariffs on Brazilian exports, easing a dispute between the two countries that had threatened the cohesion of the $1.1 trillion Mercosur trade bloc. C2.
 
A Merger of British Newspapers
Trinity, Britain's largest regional newspaper company, plans to buy the Mirror Group for 1.24 billion, or about $2 billion. The deal would create the largest newspaper publisher in Britain, combining local newspapers like The Liverpool Echo with The Mirror. Trinity's chief executive, Philip Graf, will head the new group. C2.
 
Head of China Everbright Resigns
The chairman of China Everbright Group, one of that nation's largest financial conglomerates, resigned and was replaced by a deputy governor of the People's Bank of China. C2.
 
Brazil Truckers Halt Strike
The Brazilian Government reached a deal to end a strike that had paralyzed road transport. Federal authorities agreed to suspend an increase in diesel prices, freeze tolls on some highways and send Congress a proposal that would penalize truckers less than other motorists for traffic violations. C2.
 
Chicago Title Is in Merger Talks
Chicago Title is in talks to be acquired by Fidelity National Financial. Both companies provide title insurance, credit reporting, property valuation and technology services. C3.
