HEADLINE: SENATE APPROVES BIG CUT IN TAXES, COURTING A VETO

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 30

 BODY:
The Senate voted today to cut taxes by $792 billion over the next 10 years, moving the Republican-controlled Congress toward a politically charged showdown with President Clinton over how the nation can best use trillions of dollars in projected Federal budget surpluses.
The vote was 57 to 43. Four Democrats joined 53 Republicans in support of the bill, while 2 Republicans and 41 Democrats voted against it. 
 The bill would cut personal income taxes by reducing the lowest tax rate to 14 percent from 15 percent starting in 2001. It would give a tax break to many married couples, expand the Individual Retirement Account program, create a deduction for some health insurance costs and reduce the inheritance tax on large estates.
Most of the bill's provisions, which also include breaks for business and special-interest groups, would be phased in gradually as the expected surpluses grow, and some would not be fully effective until 2009. Of the total of $792 billion in tax reductions over 10 years, only $4.1 billion would take effect next year.
Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who was the main author of the measure, said the Senate had taken "a giant step forward to give the American people a tax break."
The House passed a tax cut last week that is the same size as the Senate's but has different provisions. Leaders of the Republican majority from both houses met today even before the Senate bill had been passed to begin reconciling the two versions, and hope to complete their work next week before Congress leaves for its summer vacation.
The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said the momentum within the party was toward adopting the centerpiece of the House bill, a 10 percent reduction in all income tax rates. Such a move would further harden objections to the tax bill among Democrats, who say the House approach favors the wealthy even more disproportionately than the Senate version.
Mr. Clinton has promised to veto the Republican tax bill in whichever form it emerges from Congress. Along with most Democrats in Congress and Vice President Al Gore, who laid out his own tax proposal today, Mr. Clinton is pushing for a 10-year tax cut no bigger than $300 billion.
Mr. Clinton said the Republican approach would risk a return of big budget deficits, squander an opportunity for further reductions in the national debt and leave too little of the projected surplus to deal with Medicare, education, health, the military and other programs.
"By pushing through a tax plan that is too big and too bloated, the majority party has pushed aside our vital national priorities," Mr. Clinton said in a statement issued by the White House as he returned to Washington from Bosnia. "I will not sign a tax plan that shortchanges our seniors and our young people. I will not sign a plan that signs away our future."
Taken together, the House and Senate bills amount to the opening move by Republicans in what is likely to be a high-stakes negotiation between the White House and the Congressional leadership this fall over taxes, spending, Social Security and Medicare.
To a considerable degree, any negotiations will be driven by complex calculations within both parties about how a deal will affect the elections next year. With both the Presidency and control of the House up for grabs, some members of both parties would prefer drawing lines in the sand and fighting out their differences on the campaign trail. Others see a compromise as the best way of showing that their party can be trusted to govern.
But the fight will also reflect fundamentally different ideological approaches to government and taxation.
Even with a large tax cut, Republicans said again today, there is enough money to deal with pressing problems like the cash shortage that threatens to confront Medicare. And they said returning as much of the Government's excess revenue to the taxpayers as possible was the best way of insuring the economy's long-term health, and the best defense against further growth in the size and influence of the Federal Government.
"When you put a surplus on the table in this town, it gets spent," Speaker J. Dennis Hastert said.
Democrats said it would be imprudent to lock in a big tax cut now when there is no assurance the anticipated surpluses will materialize. They noted that the last big tax cut, in 1981, had helped send the nation into a spiral of rising deficits and debt from which it had only just emerged.
"This is another riverboat gamble with the American economy," said Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota.
If the surpluses do materialize, Democrats said, they should be divided among a variety of purposes, including modest tax cuts for low- and middle-income families, additional spending on vital programs, reducing the national debt and shoring up the Medicare system.
There is one point on which the two parties generally agree: that the portion of the projected surplus generated by Social Security payroll taxes -- about $1.9 trillion over the next 10 years, of a total surplus of $2.9 trillion in that period -- should go only to shoring up Social Security's financial condition or revamping the program.
As a result, the two sides are fighting only over the remaining $1 trillion or so. Once technical calculations about the tax cut's effect on interest payments on the national debt are taken into account, the $792 billion Republican plan would use up nearly all of this surplus.
In the final hours of debate today, the Senate either rejected or did not take up scores of amendments intended to score political points or secure a change that would benefit an interest group. But it adopted a number of amendments.
Among them was an expansion of the provisions intended to eliminate the so-called marriage penalty, which leaves many two-income couples paying more in taxes than they would if single. The amendment, sponsored by Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, would add to the tax package an increase in the standard deduction for couples filing jointly.
The Senate also accepted an amendment offered by Senators Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, and Paul D. Coverdell, Republican of Georgia, to reduce capital gains taxes. The measure would allow taxpayers to exempt their first $1,000 in capital gains each year, starting in 2006.
Mr. Roth, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and his counterpart in the House, Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, are to meet on Sunday to begin negotiating in earnest over how to mesh their bills.
In addition to reconciling different approaches to income tax rates, the marriage-penalty solution, reductions in the inheritance tax and other elements affecting individual taxpayers, they will have to pick and choose among a variety of much smaller provisions that are important to politically influential constituencies.
The Democrats who voted for the Senate tax cut today were Mr. Torricelli, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, and John B. Breaux and Mary L. Landrieu, both of Louisiana.
The Republicans who voted against it were Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and George V. Voinovich of Ohio.

HEADLINE: Vendor of News From Afar Yields to Technology

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
It has survived almost everything New York could throw at it: wars, blackouts, the Depression, the decline of Times Square and even its revival. But now Hotalings News Agency, the purveyor of newspapers and magazines from around the globe that has become a New York City institution, is disappearing from the street.
Yesterday, the Hotaling family closed the store it has run in Times Square since 1926, and retrenched to a kiosk inside the tourist information center on Broadway just north of 46th Street. 
 The main culprit, according to the family, is the Internet. Newspapers across the country have put their news -- and worse, their help-wanted and real-estate ads -- on the World Wide Web. Foreign papers and magazines are also available on line. So many homesick immigrants from Damascus and heartsick New Yorkers dreaming of a job in Des Moines no longer need to go to Hotalings to buy a newspaper.
"We never had any competition; now the Internet is our competition," said Susan A. Carey, 53, who owns the business with her brother, Arthur G. Hotaling, 49. Their grandfather founded the business in 1905.
The city's booming economy has only made things worse for the store, Mr. Hotaling said. A lot of his customers used to be "people who were looking to leave the city," he explained. "With the economy as strong as it is and New York City being the place to live, they aren't leaving the city in droves the way they were."
The problem began four or five years ago, said Marvin Cohn, who has worked at the store since 1985 (and first visited Hotalings as a customer in 1950). The San Jose Mercury News had always been popular with certain customers who Mr. Cohn speculates were looking for jobs in Silicon Valley. When the newspaper put up its Web site, these customers disappeared. That, he said, "was the beginning of the end."
Today, the trade publication Editor & Publisher tracks 3,744 newspapers with Web sites, including almost 1,500 overseas papers. In the United States and Canada, the number of daily and weekly newspapers available on line has more than doubled in the last two years, to 2,224, according to the company's 1999 yearbook.
Hotalings tried to find ways to compete. It spruced up the store, which is on the south side of 42d street between Sixth Avenue and Broadway (it is now so attractive that CNN sometimes uses it as a set), and it expanded its selection of American magazines. But business did not pick up.
Earlier this year, the store stopped staying open until 9 P.M. and started closing at 6. And it cut its staff from 22 employees to a dozen or so.
Finally, Mr. Hotaling said, he decided to cut back the store's retail operation to the kiosk, which he had opened a year ago. The company's business of delivering out-of-town newspapers will move from the back of the store to a warehouse far west on 52d Street.
"Everyone sounds like this is such a sad thing," he said. "I'm pretty -- depressed is not the word, but I was so stressed about what to do, and now that I've made the decision I'm very encouraged."
To prepare, he began cutting back on the number of publications he carries -- though he still has daily and weekly papers from 225 cities around the United States, and about 1,000 overseas publications, from the staid Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung to the racy Russian tabloid Speed, whose name is the only English word in its pages.
The new newsstand will contain most of the overseas papers, Mr. Hotaling hopes. But the display space is limited, and browsing will be more difficult for impulse buyers drawn by headlines like "Gangsters drink human blood with champagne" (from the July 25 Sunday Herald of Jamaica).
The customers are likely to be different, too. At the kiosk, the customers tend to be foreign tourists who buy European titles, said Gabriel Toussaint, who tends the counter. While American tourists come into the information center, they do not buy newspapers or magazines, he said. At the store, three-quarters of the customers were repeat visitors, Mr. Hotaling said.
Which is not to say they were not a diverse group; Anderson Celius, who has worked at the store for a decade, has learned phrases in a half-dozen languages, most recently Russian.
He worries about leaving 42d Street, "the heart of the world," as he called it, and said he finds the situation unfair. "When 42d Street was unclean, dirty, we were trying to keep it alive," Mr. Celius said. "Now that it's better, we're moving."
There were some foreign tourists at the store yesterday, including one man from Monte Carlo complaining that he was stuck in the land of baseball when the European soccer season was about to begin. A little boy was looking for foreign publications for a school project, and a young woman was buying a stack of out-of-town newspapers for her boss.
But most were immigrants in search of a taste of home, like Ismail Deakete, from the Ivory Coast, who imports African art and speaks little English. He said Hotalings was the only place he had been able to find the magazine Jeune Afrique, so "toujours I come in here."
Then there are the real old-timers, like Joey Sasso, who has been coming to Hotalings since the store was located on 43d Street in the old New York Times building. (That store closed in 1983.)
Mr. Sasso, who will be 78 next month, buys Editor & Publisher every Friday to keep up with the media business, and out-of-town newspapers to find fodder for his freelance gossip column, which he pounds out on a typewriter. But even he is thinking of abandoning paper for computer bits and bytes, he said, adding, "I've got to get on the Internet, honey, that's the thing."

HEADLINE: Under Arid Skies, Crops and Livelihoods Wilt

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., July 30

 BODY:
Every morning, Magdaleno Fuentes waits by the shoulder of Route 59, hoping to find a job mowing lawns, trimming bushes or planting bushes. Eager to impress, he wears his best button-down shirt and clutches a plastic bag hiding a sleeveless gray T-shirt, specked with the toil and soil from previous jobs. Usually, he waits for a few minutes, a couple of hours at most, before the right job comes along.
But these days, Mr. Fuentes, 39, a native of Puebla, Mexico, is waiting a lot more. It has been two weeks, in fact, since he last found work, and it may be another week or more, he worries, before he and other day laborers in Rockland County are able to find steady work. The reason, he says, is simple: 
 "No rain, no work."
For all the complaints and misery swirling around the effects of the dry weather and subsequent water restrictions on verdant lawns, the quieter reality is that the restrictions are also having a ripple effect on anyone who depends on rain to eke out a living.
For farmers, no rain means that the life has been sucked out of cornfields and fruit trees. For landscapers, no rain means mandatory water limits that have almost forced them to cease operating -- and stop hiring day laborers like Mr. Fuentes. Unless there is a change in the weather soon, no rain also means that life promises to become more dire for more people.
"It's a trickle-down effect, because if these people don't make money, they affect our local economy," said Mayor Allan Thompson of Spring Valley. "It's hurting everybody."
Already, many farmers are calling this summer the hottest and driest in recent memory. In the entire eastern United States, rainfall in June and July has been the lowest in more than a decade, according to the National Weather Service. And the impact is being felt across the region.
"We're seeing the effects on everything from fields to orchards to nurseries," said Sharon M. Douglas, a plant pathologist at the Connecticut Agricultural Station, a state agency in New Haven. "People are trying to get as much water on their crops as possible, but some growers have pumped their ponds dry."
Nancy Wood, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Agriculture Department, said the arid weather was having a devastating impact on corn, alfalfa and soybean crops and that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was preparing to ask the Federal Government to declare the state's farmland a disaster area, making farmers eligible for low-interest loans. In addition, the state is expected to impose voluntary limits on water use next week.
Already mandatory restrictions are in place in all of Rockland County and in many municipalities in Orange County. On July 13, Rockland County, which draws all its water from within its geographic boundaries, imposed Stage 1 water emergency restrictions, curbing the watering of lawns to every other day. But when officials discovered that people simply watered nonstop on the designated day, causing use to actually inch up, the county imposed a Stage 2 emergency on July 21, forbidding the use of lawn sprinklers.
Violators are first warned, and informed of the maximum penalty of $1,000 a day, said Tom Micelli, the county's Acting Health Commissioner. And so far, at least, the message has filtered through: daily water use has dropped to an average of 32 million gallons from 42 million gallons, said Terri Guess, a spokeswoman for United Water, which provides water to most of Rockland County.
But still, there has been hardly any rain in the region, and little prospect for relief in the coming days, according to the Weather Service. Even when there has been rain, it has usually been of the cloudburst variety. On Thursday night, a brief shower dumped up to three inches in some parts of Orange County. But that was of little use, because the soil did not have time to soak it up.
What is more desirable, said Maire Ullrich, vegetable crops agent for the Cornell Cooperative Extension of Orange and Ulster Counties, is Seattlelike weather for a week: a good, but not overwhelming, soaking of a couple of inches a day, for four to seven straight days.
Like any other meteorological calamity, there's not much to blame here but fate. But in Rockland County, officials and the public have found a target for at least some of their anger: New Jersey. United Water, the utility that serves Rockland and parts of New Jersey, is entitled to channel more water from a Rockland reservoir to New Jersey if water levels there fall too low. Even though that hasn't happened, some people in Rockland, where water use is restricted, are unhappy that United is pumping any water to New Jersey, where there are no restrictions.
"It's like you're standing on this side of Rockland County, and the grass looks like weed, and in New Jersey," said C. Scott Vanderhoef, the Rockland County Executive, with a hint of outrage in his voice, "the grass looks plush."
It is still too early to quantify the impact the dry weather has had on local landscaping -- a $250 million-a-year business -- or on local farmers, officials say. But there have been plenty of anecdotes about the ruinous and near-ruinous repercussions.
In Orange County, onion farmers have been staring at dusty, desertlike soil and poor yields. "The farmers are in trouble," said Matthias Schliefer, the Assistant Commissioner for Environmental Health of Orange County. "Our onion-growing country is just about a total disaster."
Corn fields have been devastated, too, with some farmers reporting damage to 50, 60 or even 80 percent of their crops. At the Fort Hill Farm in the Orange County community of Goshen, Claudia and Phil Johnson have watched helplessly as about 400 acres of corn have withered in the oppressive heat. That corn was supposed to be used as feed for their 300-head dairy farm; now, instead, the Johnsons, sixth-generation farmers, will have to buy feed.
In New City, in Rockland County, Jim Cropsey, whose family has owned Cropsey Farms since 1893, has watched his 40 acres of corn wilt, turning what should have been a lush, green plain of 10-foot-high stalks into a yellow, even singed-looking field of half-sized corn. On Thursday, for instance, his workers picked 23 bags of corn; during a normal summer with rain, that figure is up to 125 bags a day.
The pumpkin fields are so dry and dusty, Mr. Cropsey said, that his workers may have to wear masks when they work the fields. His snap peas do not snap; they look limp. And some of his peaches have been useless, puny things that resemble golf balls. "I can't remember as dry a summer as this," said Mr. Cropsey, a robust 70-year-old.
So far, Mr. Cropsey and other farmers have been forced to lay off, or at least not hire, day laborers to work their fields. There are easily hundreds of day laborers in Rockland County, mainly from Latin America, who look for work, have families to support and generally live in substandard conditions anyway, said Patricia Feeley, executive director of Catholic Community Services of Rockland.
And it will be particularly trying in the next few days, she said, as the rent comes due on the first of the month and food becomes scarce. "We're going to see tremendous suffering," she said.
At Lucrezia's Nursery in Spring Valley, home to lush weeping Norway spruces, thundercloud purple leaf plums, and Japanese weeping cherries, hardly anyone stops by anymore because no one wants to buy something they will not be able to water, said Rosa Lucrezia, who with her husband owns the nursery.
Thursday morning, for instance, one person visited the nursery. It turned out to be an advertising salesman for a local newspaper. And usually, Mrs. Lucrezia takes out a monthly ad. But this time, she said, it would be of no use -- not until it rains again, anyway.

HEADLINE: A Law Opening Research Data Sets Off Debate

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS 

 BODY:
The proposition is simple enough: Public dollars pay for a lot of scientific research, so data from that research should be available to the public.
At the request of Senator Richard C. Shelby, Republican of Alabama, a measure saying just that passed quietly one evening last October, without hearings or debate, as a one-sentence amendment to the 4,000-plus-page appropriations bill. Under the amendment, anyone can write a request to the Government under the Freedom of Information Act and get "all data produced" by a published study paid for with any public dollars, and potentially receive everything from a summary of findings to a scientist's notebooks or E-mail or, in some cases, information about patients. 
 "Experience has shown that transparency in government is a principle that has improved decision-making and increased the public's trust in government," Mr. Shelby stated in explaining the law's premise.
For too long, he said, Americans "have been unable to access federally funded research data despite the significant impact of this data in the policy-making process."
The law has the United States Chamber of Commerce delighted. "In the regulatory reform arena there may never be a more important issue," its Web site reads. It says that companies would be better able to scrutinize the data that policy makers use when they issue regulations, and it adds, "This would be the first time the business community has ever been provided with the basis for the bureaucracy imposing $700 billion in annual regulatory costs on us."
The conclusion: "If implemented properly, this rule will do more for regulatory reform than all the legislation passed in the last 10 years!"
But scientists and university administrators, who took some time to notice the law, are alarmed. They fear that corporate or political interests will use the law to hamper research on controversial subjects, tie up scientists in red tape, circumvent confidentiality agreements and thwart Government regulations. While they agree with the general notion of giving the public access to research data, they assert that data from any study, no matter how rigorous, can be made to appear questionable if examined by hostile experts and publicists.
"We have now concluded that the legislation constitutes a broad political attack on both science and on the Federal regulatory apparatus," Nils Hasselmo, president of the Association of American Universities, said in a letter to Vice President Al Gore on Wednesday. He added that "we are very concerned that such an effort could involve actions designed to discredit scientists and discourage researchers from addressing controversial topics."
At a hearing about the law before a House subcommittee on government management and technology earlier this month, scientists recalled previous clashes between science and industry and said they feared that the law would increase such cases.
In one example, Dr. Paul Fisher at the Medical College of Georgia published a study in 1991 of what small children know about tobacco brands. He found that Joe Camel was a figure known just as well as Mickey Mouse by 6-year-olds, and that they knew the brands of cigarettes in some detail.
The cigarette maker R.J. Reynolds decided it wanted to see Dr. Fisher's data and do its own analysis. The company wanted not only all the raw data, but also the names and addresses of the children who were interviewed so the company could go back to "re-interview" them. Dr. Fisher fought the case in court, but ultimately the college's own president agreed that the company should have access to the data. Dr. Fisher resigned from the college, and Reynolds got most of the data it wanted, although it did not contact the children. The litigation dragged on for years and made Dr. Fisher decide not to do research on tobacco issues ever again.
Supporters of the law dismiss the possibility of harassment. But critics point out that Senator Shelby started work on the amendment after Harvard researchers, citing confidential patient information, declined to give Congress their raw data in a two-decade-long pollution study. The study, sponsored by the Environmental Protection Agency, was instrumental in creating a 1997 Federal regulation that required stronger controls on sources of small particle emissions, including cars and power plants. Among the companies that opposed the regulation was the Alabama Power and Light Company.
Ultimately, Harvard compromised by giving the data to a bipartisan group, funded by both the E.P.A. and the auto industry, which is auditing the data and conclusions.
After that episode, Senator Shelby recommended that businesses be able to get the raw data themselves for analysis and re-interpretation.
"I strongly believe that federally funded research data that is used to drive public policy should be available to the taxpayers who paid for it," he said in a statement today.
But Kevin Casey, who as senior director of Federal and state relations at Harvard University was involved in the dispute over the pollution study, called the Shelby amendment a backdoor attack on regulations like the emissions rule.
"This is not about getting the public information," he said. "It is about attacking regulations on pollution and other areas."
Through the new rule, Mr. Casey asserts, Republicans are able to attack environmental laws under the guise of sunshine laws and not lose public support, as they have for their more open challenges in recent years.
"The Shelby amendment is a backdoor way to achieve the same goal," Mr. Casey said. "It allows company lawyers to harass scientists collecting data on the most sensitive and controversial issues -- such as environmental health and pollution -- to slow down the research used to make policy."
The real impact of the amendment will not be known until it goes into effect later this year; it is now being formulated into regulations by the Office of Management and Budget. Among the questions facing the office is how to define "data" -- does it mean blood samples and archeological finds as well as written work?
Under a draft of the regulations, those who want data must ask for it under the Freedom of Information Act, by submitting a request to the agency that gave the grant to the scientist. The scientist then would turn over all data -- including names and addresses of patients and other private and commercially secret information -- to the agency. Then, the F.O.I.A. office of that funding agency would determine what must be given to the requester and what must be withheld. The information act carries protections against giving out some kinds of information, including commercial trade secrets or financial data, and private information such as medical records.
Administrators at the National Institutes of Health, the agency that finances the largest percentage of biomedical research, said they were concerned about the cost of collecting and storing all the raw data. As it is, in the fiscal year 1998, the institutes' F.O.I.A. office had 20 full-time employees answering 1,200 requests at a cost of $500,000. And despite the legal protections, administrators say they worry, too, about the confidentiality of patient records.
"Even if they redact the name and address, there are other ways to identify the patients -- if it was a female patient at a certain hospital with a particular diagnosis, that might be enough to identify them," said Wendy Baldwin, the institutes' deputy director for extramural affairs.
Members of Mr. Shelby's staff said that while they understood the scientists' worries, they believed that the F.O.I.A. rules would prevent disclosure of private or trade secret information. And, if problems do occur, "we can address those. We will be alert to those."
In most areas of science, the way to test the mettle of a study is not to examine data, but to do another study, said Carol Scheman, vice president for governmental affairs at the University of Pennsylvania, but for some kinds of studies, she said, "Senator Shelby is right. There are real issues of how to share data."
For example, in the pollution studies by Harvard's School of Public health, thousands of subjects were followed for more than two decades. That kind of work is unlikely to be copied. So some other method must be used to review the data behind the scientists' final conclusions, she said.
Industry is not uniformly in favor of the new rule. Pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies, for example, fear that the rule will jeopardize university-industry agreements. If a scientist's data can be fetched through F.O.I.A., so can information they have shared with the scientist. This means, potentially, that competitors could learn much about the progress of their commercial work through the new rule.
The Washington watchdog group OMB Watch also points out that the rule is aimed at nonprofit groups while leaving the corporations who work with government funds untouched. The amendment applies to hospitals and other nonprofit groups that get grants from the government, but excludes other groups that get contracts from the Government. "Thus, it applies to a Y.M.C.A. that receives a Federal grant, but not to Boeing that is doing a range of research through contracts," Gary D. Bass, a spokesman for the group, said in a July 15 statement.
But other business and advocacy groups are enthusiastic. Those on the record in favor of the Shelby amendment include Gun Owners of America, which has complained about research that shows guns in the home are several times more likely to kill family members by accident than intruders on purpose. In Washington, several dedicated anti-regulatory groups have lined up in favor of the Shelby rule, including the Competitive Enterprise Institute and Citizens for a Sound Economy.
In its Web site, the Chamber of Commerce, notes that huge masses of data can be fetched from scientists -- data to challenge E.P.A. regulations on clean air and water, data supporting the global warming agreement called the Kyoto Protocol. "This list is virtually limitless and can be extended into areas other than health and safety," it says.

SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 773 words

HEADLINE: Which Do We Need More, Bigger Cars or Better Schools?

BYLINE: By Robert H. Frank; Robert H. Frank, a Cornell University economist, is the author of "Luxury Fever" and co-author of "The Winner-Take-All Society."

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y.

 BODY:
Tax-cutters claim the moral high ground. "It's a matter of principle," says Bill Archer, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, "to return excess tax money in Washington to the families and workers who sent it here."
In pushing the current tax-cut measures through Congress, Mr. Archer and other proponents have built their case on the proposition that money spent in the private sector is almost always used more responsibly than money spent by bureaucrats. 
 At first glance, this appears unassailable. The Pentagon's $7,600 coffee maker may have been an aberration, but private fire companies routinely deliver comparable protection at half the cost of their municipal counterparts.
Adding to the appeal of tax cuts is that, despite our robust economy, millions of taxpayers feel strapped for cash. As a nation, we're currently spending 1.2 percent more than we earn, and more than 1 family in 70 filed for bankruptcy last year.
Yet the gains promised by tax-cutters are illusory. A cut would worsen an already serious imbalance in the overall mix of things we buy.
A disproportionate share of the tax relief now being considered -- 45 percent under the House plan and 30 percent under the plan the Senate passed yesterday -- would go to the wealthiest 1 percent of households, which earn more than $300,000 a year. These households have captured most of the growth in earned income during the last 25 years, and their spending on luxury goods is already growing at record rates.
With more cash in their pockets, top earners would demand still bigger houses and cars. A sport-utility vehicle just one inch wider than Ford's new Excursion -- which weighs three times as much as a Honda Civic -- would require special "wide load" running lights. And increased spending at the top always spawns additional spending by others.
Ardent tax-cut proponents will respond: "So what? If top earners want to spend the wealth they have generated on bigger houses and cars, why should Congress second-guess them? And if middle-class families can't afford to keep up, why can't they just summon the will to live within their means?"
But the problem confronting a family is like the one confronting a participant in a military arms race. It can choose how much of its own money to spend, but it cannot choose how much others spend. A middle-income family that buys a smaller-than-average house typically must send its children to below-average schools. Buying a smaller-than-average vehicle means greater risk of dying in an accident. Spending less -- on bombs or on personal consumption -- frees up money for other pressing uses, but only if everyone does it.
The persistent budget deficits of the past three decades have gutted many public services once considered essential. At a time when we are wealthier than ever, does it really make sense to be closing our public libraries on Sundays or cutting Federal inspections of meat-processing plants? Does it make sense not to have replaced antiquated water supply systems that deliver potentially dangerous levels of toxic metals, pesticides, and parasites to some 45 million of us?
Paradoxically, a tax cut could actually leave Americans with less to spend on themselves. Money spent on a tax cut instead of repairing a road means not only having to spend two to five times as much to fix that same road in the near future, but also having to pay an average of $120 per car to repair the damage that bad roads inflict each year.
Proponents of smaller government argue that if we let the government spend more money, more will be wasted.
This is true, of course, but only in the trivial sense that there would be more of everything the government does -- good and bad -- if public spending were higher. The solution favored by many opponents of government waste, epitomized in the Proposition 13 movement in California, is to starve the government.
But, as Californians have belatedly recognized, this remedy is like trying to starve a tapeworm by not eating. Residents of the Golden State, who once proudly sent their children to the nation's best schools, are now sending them to some of its worst.
The question, then, isn't whether bureaucrats know best how to spend our money. Rather, it's, "How much of our money do we want to spend on public services?"
The current budget surplus could be used to help restore public services that deliver good value for our money. Or it could be used to pay for tax cuts that would help fuel an already intense consumption spiral. Tired slogans about government waste won't help us make this decision more intelligently.

LENGTH: 1088 words

HEADLINE: Thoughts for Your Penny, Suddenly Scarce

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
The long-maligned penny, kicked about the sidewalks of New York, disparaged by the "take a penny" cups at cash registers and mocked by the "no pennies" signs on bridge and tunnel tollgates, is finally enjoying its revenge.
New York is enduring the great penny shortage of 1999. 
 Some city merchants are literally penniless, losing money by rounding off customers' purchases. A Manhattan McDonald's is awarding free Big Macs to customers who bring in $10 worth of pennies. And the Chase Manhattan Bank is offering a 5-cent premium for every 50-cent roll that customers deliver to the teller's window.
"I've asked all my employees to break their piggy banks and bring in their pennies," said John Pourakis, manager of the Food Emporium at 10th Avenue and 43d Street. "We're going after pennies any way we can."
Around town these days, New Yorkers can aspire only to pennies from heaven instead of from the United States Mint. According to Peter Bakstansky, a spokesman for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which distributes pennies manufactured by the Mint, "We are not able to fill all commercial banks' orders for pennies, and the Mint doesn't have any more to send us at this time."
The shortage, which is being felt in the five boroughs, is a month old, but has worsened in the last two weeks, said Duane Fingall, manager of the penny-hungry McDonald's at 51st Street and Broadway, where those free Big Macs are being offered. "Every day at least one person comes in to take the offer," he said. "I even brought in a jar full of $40 worth of pennies myself."
The penny's sudden sheen is, at least in part, a direct result of its slide into ill repute.
The penny shortage "is actually a penny imbalance," contended Mr. Bakstansky of the Fed. "There are plenty of pennies out there, but people are putting them into bottles. They're just not in circulation."
"People hoard them," said Loretta Hoehler, a manager at Sunshine Cards at 536 Metropolitan Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. "I have to beg for pennies."
Indeed, according to a recent study by Coinstar, the nation's largest manufacturer of self-service coin-counting machines, two-thirds of Americans do not regularly circulate their pennies, instead letting coins accumulate on bedroom dressers and in jars or piggy banks. Some $7.7 billion worth of change is out of circulation for this reason, Coinstar contends, with the typical American consumer stashing about $30 worth of change.
Sultan Stower, a 23-year-old senior at the School of Visual Arts who was shopping yesterday at the Associated Supermarkets branch at 278 Park Avenue South, said he dumps his pennies in an office-sized plastic water-cooler bottle in his dorm room. "Now it's just a habit to dump change in there," he said, adding that the bottle is now half full.
Penny-ante, short-lived penny shortages have recently been reported in Albany, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Chicago, St. Louis and Cleveland, coin experts say. Now it's New York's turn.
But why now? "We're not at all sure why," said Mr. Bakstansky of the Fed. "There could be some seasonality to it, leading up to the vacation period."
One coin expert, Ray Canales of the Brigandi Coin Company on West 44th Street, said that "the Mint has been working at making quarters and other coins, and haven't made as many pennies."
Philip N. Diehl, director of the Mint, denied that. "We are working six days a week to make more pennies," he said.
He added: "This is a temporary shortage, and one that we are working very closely with the Federal Reserve to address. Production is beginning to eat into the deficit and we are getting closer to having our heads above water."
Mr. Diehl said that the Mint would produce 13 billion pennies this year, and that projected coin demand was running 21 percent above the all-time high of 19 billion coins in 1994.
More than 426 pennies for each man, woman and child in the nation are currently in circulation, according to the Mint, which has produced more than 312 billion pennies during the last 30 years, 114 billion of which are now in circulation.
Several factors have contributed to the national pattern of temporary shortages, experts say. The booming economy has raised the number of cash transactions, "and that's creating a demand for more change," said Dave Herrick, a spokesman for Coinstar, of Bellevue, Wash.
Furthermore, "Banks have determined that it's much too costly when customers come into the bank and deal with the teller," said Mr. Diehl of the Mint. Banks have been encouraging ATM's, telephone and Internet banking, he said, "and many banks won't accept coinage at all, especially pennies."
Mr. Herrick of Coinstar made some additional points. "Americans are increasingly time-starved," he said. "Many don't want to sit at the dining-room table anymore to count and wrap their coins and put them in paper tubes, then stand in line at the bank to cash them in."
As a result, coin-processing machines have proliferated around the country, exhorting consumers to be penny-wise by dumping the contents of their piggy banks into counting engines that sort coins at the rate of 600 a minute. Studies have shown that 75 percent of Americans accumulate all forms of coins at home, while only 21 percent of the population puts coins in wrappers and takes them to the bank. It takes 167 pennies to make a pound of coins.
Coinstar has established its machines in 5,900 supermarkets in 38 states. The self-service machines count coins and reimburse consumers for dumping coins in the hopper, after subtracting an 8.9 percent fee for the service. For the first time last May, Americans put more coins back in circulation using coin-processing machines than the United States Mint produced, according to Coinstar.
Mr. Pourakis, the Food Emporium manager, pointed to his store's large green-and-purple Coinstar change-counting machine. "We're practically tackling customers before they can use the machine, and asking them if we can buy their pennies," he said with a laugh. "Every penny counts."
Downtown, at the Associated store, a sign has been posted asking for pennies. Quite a few customers have obliged, said Thomas Santos, the assistant manager, including one woman who arrived with 10 pounds of coins in a plastic kitchen bag.
Because of the shortage, "I try to keep change with me at all times," said Jonathan Shulman, a 36-year old theater-building manager who was shopping at Food Emporium. "But I guess this is a shortage that we'll survive."

HEADLINE: The Right Way To Engage China

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Wang Dan's and Wang Juntao's conclusion (Op-Ed, July 27) that the United States strategy of engagement with China has failed is unwarranted. In fact, the Chinese Government crackdown on the seemingly harmless Falun Gong spiritual sect is, if anything, a sign that our policies are working. 
 Clearly, the despots in Beijing are nervous that they are losing control. No wonder, since China's growing market economy is slowly but steadily eroding the power of the state. So to cut commercial ties with China now would be to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory.
Moreover, we should never sacrifice our liberty to achieve a foreign-policy objective. Thus, the question of whether to trade with or invest in Chinese businesses should continue to be answered by individual Americans, not dictated from Washington.
 
AARON LUKAS
Washington, July 28, 1999
 
The writer is an analyst at the Cato Institute's Center for Trade Policy Studies
